fields.headline: England wary of ridicule factor
fields.standfirst: Bangladesh are first up today as Hussain's men look to build on summer success
fields.trailText: England play Bangladesh today as Nasser Hussain's men look to build on their summer success and avoid an embarrassing start to their winter programme.
fields.body:
A match against Bangladesh is a no-win situation for England. Everyone expects a victory; defeat would be the cue for ridicule. So, if England are to build on their success of recent months under Nasser Hussain, they need to pilot a smooth passage through their opening encounter in the ICC Knockout Trophy today.

In truth, Bangladesh should be dispatched with ease. Although granted full Test status in June, their only one-day international victory against Test opponents remains the 62-run win over Pakistan in last year's World Cup, a match that has since been the subject of match-fixing allegations.

They have a couple of decent batsmen in Akram Khan and the former captain Aminul Islam but the first two matches, in which India beat Kenya and Sri Lanka thrashed West Indies, have been played on surfaces with decent pace and Bangladesh are unlikely to withstand England's greater firepower.

Alec Stewart compared England's potential for embarrassment to a first-class county facing a minor county in the NatWest Trophy. England must be arrogant, he said, but not complacent. If England perform to anything like their capabilities, the result should take care of itself.

After beating Zimbabwe and West Indies in Test series last summer, as well as collecting the NatWest Series tri-nation one-day tournament, the England team looks healthier than for several years. They are anxious not to disperse too many of the good vibes with poor showings in Kenya, Pakistan and Sri Lanka this winter.

Stewart, England's most experienced player with a record 132 one-day international appearances, says nobody should undervalue the importance of this tournament. "When England play well in any sport, the public gets behind us," he said. "That certainly was the case during the summer.

"Some people seem to be belittling the ICC Knockout but, as far as we're concerned, it's a mini-World Cup with many of the game's best players here. If we perform well, we can take great pride."

England's preparation has gone well, with several arduous sessions and the tied practice match against Australia on Tuesday. The management is convinced the players have benefited from missing the final two rounds of county championship matches.

Ashley Giles, the Warwickshire left-arm spinner who strained his left calf on Tuesday, is struggling to be fit for the quarter-final match England will face against South Africa next Tuesday if they beat Bangladesh. England must choose between Mark Alleyne and Vikram Solanki to fill Giles's place.

 Nottinghamshire have signed the Australian Test all-rounder Greg Blewett as their overseas player for next season. Blewett had an unsuccessful season for Yorkshire in 1999 but may yet figure in Australia's Ashes tour party for next summer, in which case Nottinghamshire would have to think again.

Another Australian, the former Test pace bowler Carl Rackemann, has been appointed as Zimbabwe's coach in succession to Dave Houghton.

webTitle: Frank Keating on Wembley's last hurrah

fields.headline: They think it's all over. It is now
fields.standfirst:
Last hurrah for the crumbling towers of fable. Amen to that
More about England v Germany

RIP Wembley quiz
fields.trailText: Around Saturday teatime the most heartfelt and realistic applause will surely be for the first bulldozer moving in to put Wembley out of its misery.
fields.body:
"Field of Dreams" all right - and this week will be full of old men vying to relive its most precious moments. But when the football teams of England and Germany finish their business at Wembley around Saturday teatime the most heartfelt and realistic applause will surely be for the first bulldozer moving in to put out of its misery a location which has long become, quite frankly, a nightmare.

England's long-presumed (in fact, commercially owned) "national stadium" has dreamily retained its garlanded and romantic resonance around the country and the whole world despite, in practical terms, the most glaring, even humbling, evidence to the contrary. It has long been a crumbling, depressing dump, an unkempt ancient monument gone to seed. Its dingy corridors and dreadful, cul-de-sac staircases are as soul-destroying as its primitive and overflowing urinals; the interrupted sightlines from many of its exorbitantly priced seats are as wonkily infuriating as the traffic infrastructure all around and to and from it.

In fairness, especially in most recent times, its owners have tried their darnedest with heavy spending to invest some life and logic into the decaying corpse, but as the author-architect Simon Inglis says in his classic Football Grounds of Great Britain, "like a patched-up old jalopy which struggles to pass its annual MoT, Wembley has reached the point at which any further expenditure would be money poured down its drains".

And so, mercifully, it has come to pass. The demolition men move in, and the trademark twin towers are due to be dismantled and transported (at £3m cost) to the proposed new Museum of Rugby League alongside the Runcorn Bridge at Widnes.

And quite right, too. Because the indisputable truth is that Wembley is, and always shall remain, a venerable shrine, the backpages' veritable Colosseum, its Parthenon, one of all sports' wonders of the world.

So it is, with next week's explosive demolition fuse already well on fire and fizzing, that all this final week are veterans of the public prints - like this one - and croaking, greybeard broadcasters being wheeled out and asked for their favourite recollections of best matches and moments, of goals and tries joyously scored, or agilely saved, of breathless races run and won and lost ... and indelibly cemented in the lore and legend. And shall be so for ever and ever, amen ...

So rich and long has been the litany of men and moments since some 200,000 and a single white horse attended Wembley's first football Cup final 77 years ago, that such lists have to be broken up into at least three sections - those witnessed in real life, those seen or heard secondhand through live broadcasting, and those immoveably glued into the lore by fathers, uncles, grandfathers or the permanent legend of history.

For instance, off the top of my head, I would say the top 10 best goals I actually witnessed were those scored by, Bobby Charlton for England v Portugal (1966), Geoff Hurst for England, his World Cup final third against Germany (1966), Rodney Marsh, for QPR against West Bromwich (1967), George Best, for Manchester United v Benfica (1968), Charlie George (Arsenal v Liverpool, 1971), Ricky Villa for Tottenham (1981), Norman Whiteside for Manchester United (1985), Keith Houchen for Coventry (1987), Paul Gascoigne for England (1996), and Stuart Pearce's atoning penalty for England, also in 1996.

But not one of those actually witnessed, I am well aware can remotely match a handful I did not see. For instance, vividly I can remember still my puny spine being riddled with the sheer and utter palpitating excitement of it, my ear bent to our bakelite wireless set far away in the west, when Raymond Glendenning, he of the soupstrainer moustache and the brown-windsor tones, shrieked "Stamps has scored! Stamps has scored!" in the first post-second world war Cup final and the first one ever to enter my consciousness. That was for Derby County - and the following springtime it was for Charlton Athletic and, if anything even more dramatically, "Duffy has scored! Duffy has scored!" (True-great old Raymond always trusted his script's original folio).

Six years later, and by now fuzzy grey blobs on a monochrome 12-inch screen, and it was Glendenning again - and I can still recite his crescendo of a 1953 curtain-call - "Taylor to Matthews on the right ... Matthews beats one man, beats two ... moves in ... he centres ... it's Perry ... Perry has scored! Perry has scored!" And only this year in Blackpool, I asked old Bill Perry about it: "I remember like it was yesterday. Stan slipped slightly as he centred it, so Morty overran it, and it was left to me, loitering, to bang it through the scrum of Bolton players." Just like that.

That remains, for me anyway, Wembley's most resonant domestic goal. Best foreign one - and again not actually witnessed but just seeped in the aspic of legend - was probably the third of Hungary's six that same 1953, scored by Ferenc Puskas, bamboozling England's captain Billy Wright by dragging the ball back with the sole of his left boot before, with a pirouette and the same famous left foot, smashing it into the roof of the net. It made Wright's frenziedly charging thin-air tackle, wrote Geoffrey Green in the Times, "resemble a fire engine rushing to the wrong fire".

But Wembley is not only football, not by any means. It staged the Olympic Games in 1948 when the flying Dutchwoman Fanny Blankers-Koen, 30 years old, housewife and mother of two, ran away with four golds on the track. Belle Vue, Manchester, may have brought greyhound racing to Britain for the first time in 1926. But Wembley made it famous at once when it let loose at the hare the legendary Mick the Miller. Some nights in the 1920s and early '30s, up to 60,000 would turn up to see the brindle Mick and Co run. Speedway as well will be reliving its legendary moments when the walls of Wembley begin crashing down next week. Be careful, for the chunks of old concrete will be falling on dreams.

Rugby league, too. Don Fox's muffed sitter - "Ee, poor lad": Eddie Waring - will never get buried in the rubble. Nor will the grandeur of Jonathan Davies's long curving score; nor the "Watersplash" final, nor the 1985 Wigan v Hull challenge final, choreographed magically by Brett Kenny and Peter Sterling, which remains the finest game of rugby, of either code, I have ever been privileged to see.

So much more ... at rugby union, Scott Gibbs of Wales making last-minute monkeys of the haughty English a couple of years back ... tales of Scotland's "Wembley Wizards" of 1928, or Jimmy Cowan's goalkeeping in 1949 ... I saw Jim Baxter standing on the ball and taunting England in 1967 ... and Norman Hunter's missed tackle, plus Jan Tomaszewski's saves ... not to mention Alex Stepney's against Eusebio . . . and Jim Montgomery's save . . .

Dammit, Britain first met Muhammad Ali at Wembley - when the then young Cassius got dumped on his butt by our Henry before recovering to rip Cooper's eyebrow to shreds. That was two years before my first actual working visit. I had a new job as a tyro producer with ITV. It was October 1965 and, pre-World Cup, England disastrously lost 2-3 to Hungary.

To sign off, I cued good Gerry Loftus our commentator, in vision, to wrap up the home tale of woe for England's new manager with something pithy and scathing about the hapless team. So Gerry looked the nation in the eye and plonkingly pronounced - "Alf Ramsey must certainly get out his chopper tonight." Fade to black and titles - and, with the country on a roar of mirth, I reckon both Gerry and I were lucky ever to work again at Wembley. Bless its tattered and threadbare old cotton socks.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Sona Fariq
fields.standfirst:
Rocket, Leeds
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Rocket, Leeds
Rating: ***
fields.body:
A few hours earlier, up-and-coming Sona Fariq were scheduled to support horrible metal shouters Pitchshifter when fate dealt them a cruel blow. Pitchshifter's singer lost his voice (I can't imagine why) and the show was cancelled. Many artists would have welcomed a night off in the pub. Not Sona Fariq. They phoned round, pulled in fellow support the Workhorse Movement and put on their own gig.

Two Asian skinheads (drummer Wasif Hussein and bassist Abrar Hafiz), an Anglo-French guitarist (Dom Bouffard) and shaven-headed Moroccan singing sensation Michael Frankl, Sona Fariq deliver life in the modern UK with almost unrivalled spirit. Two songs in, Frankl wades into the crowd to deliver a song, jumping up and down within the m lée. Wild-eyed, he appears to take the sight of somebody unimpressed as a personal insult.

Bewilderingly lumped in with Nu Metal, which obviously irritates the singer (he talks of "minds numbed by testosterone"), Sona Fariq are metal-ish but multi-faceted. Their global palette mixes punk, glam, hip-hop and reggae and, while nowhere near fully developed, could emerge as a fusion of, say, the Stooges and Audioweb.

Frankl's stirring, vulnerable vocals are close to those of the late, great Malcolm Owen of the Ruts (he should hear their LP The Crack for lessons in how to use his voice.) Still, the Nu Metal kids seem happy. "Destroy!" shouts someone in a dog collar.

Frankl ends by asking half the audience on stage; then he sings the final number while getting a piggy back from somebody on the dance floor. He then instructs everyone off the stage (they obey) and stands, still singing, as people queue to shake his hand.

fields.headline: Impromptu game of Footsie
fields.trailText: The prospect of an early reshuffle of the benchmark FTSE 100 index had brokers across the Square Mile indulging in a spot of crystal ball gazing yesterday.
fields.body:
The prospect of an early reshuffle of the benchmark FTSE 100 index had brokers across the Square Mile indulging in a spot of crystal ball gazing yesterday.

The game was to try to predict which blue chip company will be facing the indignity of life in FTSE 250 index later in the month.

Normally traders get to play this game only when index compiler FTSE International carries out its quarterly review. Last month's review saw five companies including Granada Media, down 4p to 452p, join the blue chip index. The next review is due early in December.

But the demerger of BG Group (due October 23) means an early change to the constituents of the UK's most widely watched index. BG, off 0.75p to 429.75p yesterday, is to spilt into two entities: BG Group, which will house its international exploration and production business; and Lattice, which will be home to its gas transmission business, currently known as Transco.

When BG becomes two, the FTSE 100 would become the FTSE 101 if the smallest company was not required to leave. Given the current size of BG Group it is unlikely to be either Lattice or the new BG Group.

Based on Tuesday's closing prices magazine publishing group Emap - market cap £2.2bn - would be heading for the exit. But internet service provider Freeserve is also in the firing line. On Tuesday night it had a market cap of £2.4bn. Freeserve shares closed down 14.75p at 228.25p, while Emap shed 12p to 874p yesterday.

The picture will be further complicated by the demerger of P&O - also scheduled for October 23. Analysts expect its demerged cruise business, P&O Princess, to be valued at around £2.6bn. As things stand this would secure it a FTSE 100 berth at the expense of Emap, but as City traders know only too well this could change.

The rest of the market enjoyed a mixed day as investors moved out of "new economy" into "old economy" stocks. The trigger for the switch was Nasdaq's weak performance on Tuesday.

The FTSE 100 closed down 10.1 points at 6,334.9 - at one time it was off 60 points - while the FTSE 250 eased 32.8 to 6,660.9 and the Techmark fell 104.5 to 3,741.56.

Abbey National, whose chief executive has been the subject of a nasty whispering campaign designed to undermine his position, advanced 38p to 931p after an upgrade from Deutsche Bank. The broker lifted its rating on Abbey to an outright "buy". It reckons the recent acquisition of Scottish Provident will create real value for Abbey shareholders.

Deutsche Bank was also behind the upward move in Cadbury Schweppes, up 17.75p to 417.25p. Deutsche, which now rates the stock a "buy", reckons the drinks and confectionery giant is trading well.

ICI, up 13p to 388p, was lifted by the performance of its US peers on Tuesday night which had moved sharply in the wake of positive comments from Goldman Sachs. The broker told clients that the sector had bottomed out and the risk-reward profile had turned positive again.

But mining group Billiton topped the blue chip performance chart with a gain of 11.5p to 265p. Dealers attributed the move to the strong showing of basic material stocks in New York on Tuesday.

On the downside, technology and telecoms stocks were out of favour. Software groups Logica, down 135p to £22.25, Sage, off 30p to 513p, and CMG, 77p lower at £14.08p, were the worst hit.

In the telecoms sector, Spirent fell 45p to 695p, while Energis dropped 24.5p to 460.25p and BT shed 22p to 695p.

Lower down the market, Snackhouse, formerly know as Bensons Crisps, plunged 12.5p to 32p after issuing a shock profit warning.

Newcomer Music Choice Europe ended at 181p, up 19p from its issue price.

Lower down the market, Snackhouse, formerly know as Bensons Crisps, plunged 12.5p to 32p after issuing a shock profit warning. Newcomer Music Choice Europe ended at 181p, up 19p from its issue price.

webTitle: UK cashed in on euro intervention

fields.headline: UK cashed in on euro intervention
fields.standfirst:
Traders believe Treasury profited as G7 drove up single currency

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The Treasury cashed in on Britain's involvement in the concerted G7 intervention to support the euro last month by selling the single currency for an instant profit after it rose on the foreign exchanges, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
The Treasury cashed in on Britain's involvement in the concerted G7 intervention to support the euro last month by selling the single currency for an instant profit after it rose on the foreign exchanges, it emerged yesterday.

Official figures detailing Britain's stock of gold and foreign currency reserves reveal that the government bought €85m (about £50m) on September 22 as its part of an agreed rescue bid for the ailing euro, but offloaded large quantities of the single currency later the same day.

The net fall in the reserves in September amounted to the equivalent of only £28m last month, prompting currency traders to assume yesterday that the Treasury had sold euros as the value rose from 87 US cents to 90 cents during the three separate bouts of intervention.

The Treasury was last night making no official comment about whether the government had made a profit out of the G7 move. However, sources said that while Britain's part in the attack on currency speculators had been a public signal of the G7's intent, there was no reason why the government wanted to increase its exposure to the euro.

Nick Parsons, currency analyst at Commerzbank, said that Britain's ejection from the exchange rate mechanism eight years ago had made the authorities wary of large-scale action in the currency markets. "This was token intervention by the UK," he said. "The ghost of Black Wednesday is still stalking Threadneedle Street".

In all, City analysts believe that the the G7 spent about $6bn-7bn propping up the euro two weeks ago, with Britain's share put at about 1.5% of the total. But analysts said the impact was greater than the amount spent, as it provided a show of support for the joint intervention.

"The point of intervention is to try to change the psychology, rather than necessarily to move the market on the basis of flows," said Dick Howard, director of economic research at Julius Baer Investments.

With the markets taken unawares by the G7 move, the euro's value rose sharply against the dollar to about 90 cents on the day but has since drifted back down to about 87 cents again.

Analysts believe that the European Central Bank put up about half of the $6bn-7bn, with the US buying $1bn worth of euros and Japan purchasing $1.5bn worth.

Last night dealers were weighing up the chances of the ECB raising interest rates today as a way of underlining its determination to underpin the euro and prevent its weakness leading to higher inflation.

fields.headline: Angie Stone
fields.standfirst:
Hammersmith Apollo, London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Hammersmith Apollo, London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
The American chanteuse's repeated requests that the house lights be turned up so that she can see her audience go ignored. So she simply halts the music and sits down, waiting to be obeyed. And lo! There is light! But it would be wrong to label Stone an R&B prima donna. She simply inspires respect, crooning mellifluously and sashaying barefoot in shimmering boudoir robes, exerting a sensitive command over her musicians, raising a hand aloft for wah- wah guitars or a percussion solo.

Stone's ascent to fame, via early hip hop outfits and backing vocals, is arguably long overdue, and she's no wide-eyed, over-styled ingénue. She performs tracks from her much-acclaimed album Black Diamond along with earnestly executed vintage soul standards. (She cites her heroes as Marvin Gaye, the Isley Brothers and Al Green.)

These are works of experience, both positive and painful. However, she also revels in highlighting the talents of her backing outfit, which features impressive prodigies, including a teenage keyboardist and drummer. The gospel solos from her trio of female backing singers are truly stunning, prompting yells of delight and standing ovations. Her three-year-old son from her relationship with soul star D'Angelo even makes an appearance to rap along to a cover of Sade's Sweetest Taboo. The concert concludes, as it began, with an excellent a cappella number.

The only irritation is that the venue's sound seems muffled; while Stone's voice is awesomely luscious and powerful, it becomes frustratingly difficult to make out some of the lyrics. That's a real shame, as numbers like Coulda Been You are imbued with bitter-sweet passion, reflecting Stone's warm, rich, accommodating kind of soul.

fields.headline: The Crucible
fields.standfirst:
Mercury, Colchester
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Mercury, Colchester
Rating: ***
fields.body:
When Arthur Miller's play about the 17th-century Salem witchhunts in which neighbour betrayed neighbour and friend accused friend, was first performed in the early 1950s, its point of reference was the hearings of the Un-American Activities Committee. In the past 50 years the play has tended to pop up regularly in countries where dictatorship is just around the corner. But what does the play now mean, if you live in a democracy?

Gregory Floy's simple, very measured production, played with a quiet understated power, presents the story as that of a small, isolated rural community that implodes upon itself under a welter of confessional frenzy and false accusations.

Of course it makes the play less universal, less politically relevant, and smaller, but it also has the interesting effect of somehow making it more personal.

The production does something else interesting too: it gives the characters strong East Anglian accents which not only makes the play instantly relevant to the local community to whom it is being performed but also makes the historical link to the roots of the Salem community, which was in the hard, unforgiving Puritanism of Norfolk and the surrounding region. There religion was not a joy but a stick with which to beat any who stepped outside of the accepted norm.

Tim Meacock's plain wooden set has a wimple-like purity and added depth from the wood behind which, with its gnarled, tangled branches has both a nightmarish fairytale quality and is also a symbol of the unconscious.

The production would benefit from a little more pace and a notch or two more tension, but it is another major achievement for the Mercury. It boasts some excellent performances, most notably from Kelly Williams as Abigail, and Ignatious Anthony and Emma Gregory as John and Elizabeth Proctor, whose body language speaks volumes about the state of their marriage.

Until October 21. Box office: 01206 573948.

fields.headline: Romeo and Juliet
fields.standfirst:
Olivier Theatre, London
Rating: **
fields.trailText:
Olivier Theatre, London
Rating: **
fields.body:
Lightning rarely strikes twice in the same place. Eighteen months ago the National Theatre launched an ensemble of black and white actors with a Shakespearean study of doomed love. But where Troilus and Cressida was a triumph, this Romeo and Juliet, which introduces another new company, is a muddled, mediocre affair characterised by poor verse-speaking.

The first thing this play requires is a sense of place; the two best productions I've seen (Zeffirelli's and Michael Attenborough's) were set respectively in Renaissance Verona and contemporary Sicily. But Tim Supple's modern-dress version seems, literally, all over the place. We have black Montagues and white Capulets, which is fair enough. But then we also have dark-suited mafiosi, machine-gun-toting soldiers, Latin American music and an Irish whisky-priest in Friar Laurence. I assumed we were in a composite Graham Greeneland but, although you find the odd echo of Haiti or Cuba, nothing fits politically. Robert Innes Hopkins' designs - two curved, mobile walls - do nothing to anchor the play.

If I add that the verse-speaking is often dismal, people will assume I am making a racist point; and, in a sense, I am. Why is it that the white actors speak the verse so poorly? Charlotte Randle is a good actor who has impressed in the past; but as Juliet she not only mistakes running exits and entrances for youthful impetuosity but chops the verse up into tiny, over-emphasised fragments. At one point she tells a surprised Friar Laurence, "O bid me LEAP rather than marry Paris." Was she announcing she was for the high jump? What Juliet means, of course, is that she'd rather leap from the battlements of any tower. And she is not the sole offender: even an experienced actor like Ronald Pickup as Capulet mumbles semi- coherently into his beard.

What this play needs above all is heat, passion and a death-marked eroticism; but, although the text is drenched in sun imagery, in Supple's production no one sweats. The one actor with the requisite fire is Chiwetel Ejiofor, whose fine Romeo progresses from moping courtly lover to someone spurred by untrammelled sexual desire. He is almost alone in speaking the verse with intelligent feeling but he operates in a vacuum since his Juliet is a foot-stamping Violet Elizabeth Bott and Patrick O'Kane's Mercutio is a Celtic babbler.

Pace is achieved at the expense of clarity. But the giveaway sign is the way Adrian Lee's ubiquitous music is used to signal emotion in much the same way as a Morricone score in a spaghetti Western.

The production is not a disaster, just a disappointment. But the question it urgently raises is when will Trevor Nunn, whose own productions largely sustain the National, surround himself with a directorial team capable of working to his level.

 In rep. Box office: 020-7452 3000.

webTitle: Conflicting figures point to no change in interest rates

fields.headline: Conflicting figures point to no change in interest rates
fields.standfirst:
Money Unlimited
The issue explained: setting Britain's interest rates
fields.trailText: The Bank of England is expected to leave interest rates on hold today amid conflicting figures on the strength of the economy.
fields.body:
The Bank of England is expected to leave interest rates on hold today amid conflicting figures on the strength of the economy.

Halifax, Britain's biggest mortgage lender, said house prices rose 1.6% in September, the biggest increase since January. At the same time there were signs of inflationary pressures in the service sector.

But the Confederation of British Industry's monthly snapshot of retail trends revealed that sales volumes grew at the slowest annual rate for 17 months in September.

While conceding that this was probably a blip due to the disruption caused by the fuel crisis, the CBI said there was no evidence that inflation was accelerating.

"There is nothing in this survey that points to a need for a rise in interest rates," said Alastair Eperon, chairman of the CBI's distributive trades panel.

City analysts said the figures pointed to another close vote on the nine-member monetary policy com mittee. But most continued to predict interest rates would be left at 6% for the eighth month in a row.

According to the Halifax the increase in house prices took the value of the average home to £86,304. Martin Ellis, group economist at Halifax, said: "We would be surprised if this was followed up by further sharp rises in the coming months." Halifax is predicting that the rate of house price rises - running at 9.2% on an annualised basis - will ease during the remaining part of the year.

Yesterday's figures gave ammunition to both sides of the interest rate debate. The Chartered Institute of Purchasing and Supply reported the sharpest increase in price pressures in the services sector for four years.

Figures published by the Engineering Employers Federation showed a bounce back in orders and output from the low reached in the second quarter but with intense downward pressure on prices and margins due to the weakness of the euro and competitive pressures.

fields.headline: Gerald Finley
fields.standfirst:
Wigmore Hall, London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Wigmore Hall, London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
In the premiere of Mark-Anthony Turnage's The Silver Tassie at ENO in February, the baritone Gerald Finley sang the main role of Harry Heegan, the footballer who goes off to the first world war and returns in a wheelchair. During rehearsals for the show Finley asked Turnage if he would consider writing something for a recital programme that he was building around Ravel's Histoires Naturelles; the result was the Three Songs that formed the centrepiece of Finley's Radio 3 Lunchtime Concert with pianist Julius Drake at the Wigmore Hall. These were followed by the Histoires Naturelles themselves.

The Ravel songs are vivid portraits of animals; Turnage has taken up that theme in his miniature cycle, setting two poems about cats, Stevie Smith's The Singing Cat and Thomas Hardy's Mourning, and following them with Last Words, a section of Walt Whitman's Leaves of Grass in which the poet imagines that he could "turn and live with animals". They are beautifully judged pieces - the Smith spun out over piano tracery in a way that recalls some of Britten's late songs; the Hardy a sombre elegy; the Whitman an eloquent declaration tinged with blue notes, to which the piano adds spare yet telling punctuation.

Finley delivered them exquisitely, as totally absorbed in Turnage's world as he had been in the opera. The rest of his recital was equally compelling. Whether in Loewe's version of The Erl-King, or the four numbers from Wolf's Morike Lieder, his presentation was absolutely attuned to the text and the implicit drama, while the way in which he gently, affectionately brought Ravel's little vignettes to life was masterly. Nothing was overstated or contrived, and Drake added equally tactful support.

fields.headline: Shivaree
fields.standfirst:
Borderline, London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Borderline, London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
Although Shivaree is nominally a band, all interest is inevitably going to focus on vocalist Ambrosia Parsley (her real name, should you feel inclined to believe her record company). She lounges at the microphone like a supermodel on Mandrax, thumbs hooked into trousers sliding down her hips to reveal a perfectly-formed navel. She fixes the audience with a quizzical gaze from beneath semi-lowered eyelids, while her lyrics float languidly over whatever the band can think of to throw at her - mambos, bossa novas, elevator schmaltz or primitive skating-rink pop. It's like the 1950s, the 1960s and the 23rd century all rolled into one.

It might all seem like little more than an ingenious gimmick were it not for the fact that the band can muster a display of hard-boiled expertise in any number of styles, while Ambrosia's erotic, exotic ghost of a voice is far tougher and more subtle than it appears. In Goodnight Moon, Shivaree's new single, Ambrosia's voice is like a gun hidden under a mink coat.

It's part of Shivaree's surreal appeal that the musicians resemble long-serving veterans from any number of forgotten campaigns. On keyboards and synths, Danny McGough bears a passing resemblance to actor Lloyd Bridges as he gyrates around his battery of devices. Beefy blond guitarist Duke McVinnie (another name straight out of Dashiell Hammett) looks like the Beach Boy that time forgot as he hunches over his Fender. And when Ambrosia sings the blues, it's like subsiding into a Radox bath with a bottle of whisky.

fields.headline: Steady as she goes
fields.trailText: The Bank of England's widely expected decision to keep interest rates at 6 per cent for the eighth month running will be welcomed by homeowners.
fields.body:
The Bank of England's widely expected decision to keep interest rates at 6 per cent for the eighth month running will be welcomed by homeowners. The move means mortgage lenders are unlikely to raise their rates and homeowners - many of whom are already mortgaged to the limit as a result of the past year's house price boom - can breath easy.

It's also good news for anyone with an overdraft or anyone planning to take out a personal loan. The decision means the Bank will continue to lend to commercial banks at 6 per cent, making it difficult to justify any increase in the cost of their loans and overdrafts.

In contrast, savers will be less enthusiastic as banks and building societies are unlikely to offer them a better rate.

Evidence has been coming in that some of the country's more popular stocks are seeing a rise in share price in the wake of the decision.

Exporters who are competing against European rivals will also welcome the move. The pound's strength against the euro makes British products more expensive.

The Bank gave no reason for its decision, but it probably reflects the widely held view that inflation is under control. The current inflation rate is 1.9 per cent, significantly below the government's target of 2.5 per cent. The impact of the fuel crisis and a slowdown in the housing market are also thought to have influenced the monetary policy committee - the group of nine economists who decide the rate.

Rates were increased four times between September 1999 and February as an attempt to slow economic growth and keep inflation under control.

Meanwhile, the European Central Bank shocked the city by announcing an interest rate rise from 4.5 per cent to 4.75 per cent.

fields.headline: He Stumbled
fields.standfirst:
Everyman, Liverpool
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Everyman, Liverpool
Rating: ****
fields.body:
Howard Barker is the great anatomist of the British theatre. He does not dissect the state of the nation but the state of our heart and souls. Often it hurts. The company dedicated to staging his work is not called The Wrestling School for nothing. His latest play, his first full-length new play to be staged in Britain for three years, is as knotty as anything he has written.

The guts of it are this: Doja, an anatomist whose reputation for embalming dead monarchs is second to none, is summoned by an obscure kingdom where the king is on his death bed. But no sooner has Doja put the first incision into the body than he is besieged by the queen, the young prince and others in the kingdom who all want to seduce him. He senses that he is in extreme danger but is powerless to escape and avoid his doom. He is forced to collude in his own assassination.

The play takes the form of an intricate intellectual thriller that only unravels for the audience as the net tightens around Doja. Like many of Barker's plays, He Stumbled is about the slippery relationship between truth and lies and our taste for deception. Even the thriller-like form of the play plays on and panders to the audience' s love of a secret, the thought that we might be discovering something unknown, even unknowable. With its corrugated iron set in which shutters snap open and close, we are like voyeurs at a pornographic peepshow.

But there is so much more here too: a debate about superstition and rationality, the morbidity of our desires, the sweet rotting smell of our evasions and lies and the desolation of intimacy. This is classic Barker territory and he approaches it here with customary wit and poetic intensity.

The acting is crystal, almost frighteningly so. You have to be prepared to work damn hard for the rewards, but ultimately He Stumbled delivers, laying bare the secrets beneath its cool skeletal exterior.

 Ends Saturday. Box office: 0151-709 4776. Then touring to the Lowry, Salford, Warwick Arts Centre and Riverside Studios, London.

fields.headline: Standoffish
fields.standfirst:
City Arts Centre, Dublin
Rating: *
fields.trailText:
City Arts Centre, Dublin
Rating: *
fields.body:
The Pan Pan company and its director Gavin Quinn have always made an absurdist, dysfunctional kind of theatre, but you wonder at the Ozzie critics who sent this show home from the Adelaide festival this year with an award.

The audience are welcomed into a bright white space by three actors who beam idiotically at us for a while. Bored with each other, they focus their confessional, often lewd, attentions on us, even climbing among the seats to hug people.

Then the lights go down, and the kids knuckle down to daft, disjointed, knockabout routines. The actors, Kevin Hely, Emma McIvor and James Hosty, speak as "themselves".

There are things you may never have seen before in a theatre, such as a man pulling out his penis and pissing into a bucket, stopping, starting again, stopping and starting. Hosty, a dancer-actor, displays wonderful muscle control here - I'm sure I would have dried, as they say.

Grotesquely pulled faces, ridiculous songs and eye-poke routines degenerate into wrestling that is more bum-sniffingly sexual than aggressive. McIvor blow-jobs a microphone, and Hely complains how his obsessive hygiene has left him with a hand smelling of "cunt and Domestos".

It's like some silly party game, and the only adrenalising factor is Brian Mooney's music and howling feedback loops. Mooney also provides the goofed-out guitar behind the final jilted love song - perhaps the key to Quinn's opus.

The piece seems hypnotised by theory and the psychodrama of the rehearsal studio. At 80 minutes it is way overlength, and by the time it shrieks to a halt, it has disappeared up its own behind.

 Until October 10. Box office: 00 353 1 677 0643 .

webTitle: Inter sack Lippi after opening defeat

fields.headline: Inter sack Lippi after opening defeat
fields.trailText: Marcello Lippi was yesterday sacked as Internazionale's manager. And Gianluca Vialli's name has cropped up as a possible successor.
fields.body:
Robbie Keane will have to get used to a new manager barely two months after moving to Internazionale following the Italian club's sacking of Marcello Lippi yesterday.

Lippi's departure came after one match of a Serie A season delayed to accommodate the Olympics, immediately sparking speculation about the identity of his successor.

The name of Gianluca Vialli, one of the game's most high-profile unemployed Italians, has cropped up, as has that of Italy's Olympic team manager Marco Tardelli. But the smart money is on the former Inter and Argentina defender Daniel Passarella, currently earning a crust as manager of Uruguay.

In Sunday's match at lowly Reggina, which Keane started in the absence of the injured Christian Vieri and Ronaldo, Inter threw away an early lead and lost 2-1. After the match Lippi said he was ashamed of his team, whom he referred to as "spoilt children".

"Today, if I was the chairman, I would dismiss the coach and line the players up against a wall and give them all a kick up the backside," Lippi added.

The Inter chairman evidently took him at his word although it is not known if Massimo Moratti has yet applied his boot to the players.

Inter's vice-chairman Peppino Prisco said: "I'm sorry for Lippi," but added: "It was on the cards because of the lack of results and the team's lack of any system of play. And if you don't win and you don't give the team a system of play ... "

Lippi's first year at Inter had failed to reproduce his success at Juventus, where he won three league titles and the European Cup with a team led by Vialli. The Milan club crashed out of this season's Champions League at the qualifying stage to Helsingborgs of Sweden despite spending over £40m on players in the summer.

Yesterday training was taken by the assistant coach Narciso Pezzotti but the club said Lippi's permanent replacement would be named "in the next few days".

Vialli's Chelsea career has not gone unnoticed in Italy. His lack of a coaching badge is an issue but not insuperable; like his friend David Platt at Sampdoria, he could be given some sort of "team manager" title.

However, for all his cup triumphs at Chelsea, Vialli has yet to achieve the league success Italians really respect.

Meanwhile, at Barcelona, who have lost four out of five games, the coach Llorenc Serra Ferrer is no doubt eyeing Lippi's downfall nervously after his chairman Joan Gaspart yesterday gave him a vote of confidence. "I have absolute faith in him," said Gaspart.

webTitle: ICC Knockout Trophy: : Kenya v India

fields.headline: Ganguly glitters as Kenya fall at the first
fields.trailText: Sourav Ganguly hit 66 to gatecrash the biggest party Kenya has ever staged as India won the opening ICC Knockout Trophy match by eight wickets.
fields.body:
Sourav Ganguly is already finding Nairobi's Gymkhana Club infinitely more tranquil than the claustrophobic confines of Old Trafford. The Indian captain, whose failure to score a first-class hundred this summer made him an unpopular figure among Lancashire fans and team-mates alike, hit 66 yesterday as India gatecrashed the biggest party Kenya has ever staged.

From the moment they were drawn to play the first match of the ICC Knockout Trophy, the hosts were never expected to last more than a day. But given Bangladesh's promotion to Test status, on the back of their curious World Cup win over Pakistan, the Kenyans - who beat West Indies in equally spectacular but less suspicious circumstances three years earlier - are entitled to dream.

Their captain Maurice Odumbe, the hero of that Windies wipeout, was again a leading light yesterday, putting on 81 with the opener Ravindu Shah as Kenya made a creditable 208 for nine.

It could have been more but for a miserly Anil Kumble and three wickets from the 21-year-old debutant Zaheer Khan, whose name suggests a Pakistan batting all-rounder of impeccable pedigree rather than that somewhat rarer species of an Indian left-arm fast bowler.

Rahul Dravid was unbeaten on 68 and Vinod Kambli marked his return to favour by crashing 39 from 33 balls as India strolled into Saturday's quarter-final against Australia with seven overs to spare.

 South Africa's King Commission will not resume hearings until next month as investigators await new information from Indian police.

fields.headline: Giles injury blow for England
fields.trailText: Ashley Giles suffered a strained calf as England drew with Australia in their only warm-up match before the ICC Trophy.
fields.body:
England's only warm-up match before they begin their assault on the ICC Knockout Trophy ended in a tie against Australia here yesterday, but the sense of drama and excitement was lost on Ashley Giles. He felt only pain in his leg and a terrible sinking feeling in his stomach.

Giles, the Warwickshire left-arm spinner, managed just five deliveries before leaving the field with a strained left calf. He experienced a couple of twinges at the start of his over and then, as he walked towards his team-mates to celebrate holding a return catch to dismiss Michael Bevan, the pain became extreme.

The England physiotherapist Dean Conway immediately applied ice and Giles was dispatched to the team hotel with his leg heavily strapped. He can count himself a seriously unlucky man and must wonder whether he will ever play more than the occasional match for his country.

Giles has been selected for 34 England one-day international squads, but has made the starting line-up only five times. He is unlikely to play in England's first game against Bangladesh tomorrow and is considered doubtful for the entire two-week tournament.

If the injury turns out to be serious, Giles would be replaced by Robert Croft, the official spin-bowling cover who publicly and angrily contemplated never playing for England again after missing selection for this winter's tours.

Despite their problems, the coach Duncan Fletcher says he cannot remember a squad more prepared to work hard - England have been undertaking regular 5-hour sessions. But they needed a competitive outing and that, even in a practice game, was exactly what they got against the world one-day champions. England bowled well and, until a late stutter, batted consistently, although Glenn McGrath was rested and Shane Warne was missing with injury.

Damien Martyn made 70 and Mark Waugh a half-century from 39 balls before he retired. Andrew Caddick and Craig White each collected a couple of wickets and England's out-cricket was generally impressive on a rough outfield.

Each of the 14 squad members was allowed to play some part and the main batsmen all made starts. Alec Stewart's 38 was the highest but Nasser Hussain's 21, which hinted at a return to form, was the most gratifying.

England needed five from the final over but Mark Alleyne was adjudged leg-before and Caddick, attempting the winning hit, was spectacularly caught at square-leg by Brett Lee. "I think most of the players benefited from missing the last couple of championship matches," Fletcher said afterwards. "It means they are fresh."

Australia 236-9 (DR Martyn 70, SR Waugh 50; Caddick 2-19).

England 236 (AJ Stewart 38; Symonds 3-16, Lee 3-51).

Match tied.

webTitle: MPs urged to review funding of good causes

fields.headline: Lottery behind the lottery
fields.standfirst: MPs urged to review funding of good causes
fields.trailText: While argument over who should run the National Lottery threatens to head back to the courts, risking a hiatus in distribution of "good cause" funds, MPs are being urged to review how such funds are distributed in the first place.
fields.body:
While argument over who should run the National Lottery threatens to head back to the courts, risking a hiatus in distribution of "good cause" funds, MPs are being urged to review how such funds are distributed in the first place.

In a submission today to the Commons culture select committee, the National Council for Voluntary Organisations (NCVO) says the distribution system should stand alone and distinct from government. The Labour administration's directions to the new opportunites fund represent "meddling" and "a potentially dangerous erosion of the principle of additionality".

Under this principle, lottery cash is supposed only to fund projects additional to those underwritten by normal public spending. Critics claim this rule has been breached in the way ministers have directed the fund to spend £2.3bn on specific causes within the broad themes of health, education and the environment.

In its support, the NCVO is citing findings of an ICM opinion survey it commissioned. These suggest that only 12% of people think the government should have a say in deciding where lottery money is spent, as against 72% who feel there should be a role for an independent, publicly appointed body.

Asked to choose just one body to determine lottery spending, only 10% of people opt for government, 62% for an independent body, 16% for local councils, 9% for the lottery operator and 3% have no view.

Stuart Etherington, NCVO chief executive, says he wants "cast iron assurances" that the government remains committed to additionality and is prepared to review decision-making processes in respect of the new opportunities fund.

The NCVO will also press for reassurance that there will be no hiatus in distribution of good cause money.

webTitle: The sacked rat-catcher who took on his old bosses

fields.headline: The pied piper of Thorne
fields.standfirst: The sacked rat-catcher who took on his old bosses
fields.trailText: The sacked rat-catcher who took on his old bosses
fields.body:
Six years ago, Martin Williams was a rat-catcher with Doncaster council. He lived in an average semi-detached house in the small town of Thorne on the outskirts of Doncaster and, to his neighbours and his workmates, was a pretty normal bloke living a pretty unremarkable life.

Then he was sacked for taking time off work without permission, something he vehemently denied. His world collapsed around him. He had spent 10 very content years driving his van round the leafy South Yorkshire lanes of Thorne, catching rats and destroying wasps' nests, passing the time of day with the locals and loving every minute of it. Suddenly, it was all taken from him. Over the next few years, Doncaster council was to rue the day it sent Williams packing.

Last month, a high court judge was asked to stop Doncaster council going ahead with the closure of two residential homes for elderly people. While it is not uncommon these days for local authorities to face such legal action, what was unusual about this legal move was that it was instigated - and paid for - by a councillor from the local authority itself. That councillor was Williams.

In the six years since he lost his job, the one-time local rat man has become a thorn in the side of Doncaster council. When he heard that residents' relatives were opposed to the homes' closure, he immediately instructed his barristers to ask the high court for permission for the case to go to judicial review. In the end, the application was refused. It cost Williams a few thousand pounds, but he was quite prepared to spend the £40,000 he estimates it would have cost if the case had gone ahead and he had lost.

He can easily afford it. When he appeared before an industrial tribunal in 1995 in an unsuccessful bid to claim unfair dismissal, it was revealed that this humble rat man was a rich rat man indeed. He was part-heir to a family fortune worth more than £11m and had been brought up in historic Brodsworth Hall, now a jewel in the crown of English Heritage. He was dubbed the millionaire rat catcher.

It ought to have been obvious to his bosses and his workmates that something was different about Williams. He refused to wear the standard boiler suit the council had provided for him. Instead, he had a pair of overalls made-to-measure with his name sewn in gold thread on the breast pocket. On his head, he wore a top-quality deerstalker.

Unluckily for certain Doncaster councillors, at the same time that the authority sacked Williams they also gave notice to an environmental health officer, Peter Gumsley, and the two men became friends with a common bond - to get their own back. Gumsley claimed he had been dismissed on trumped-up allegations of time off without permission because he had refused to go along with what he felt were corrupt practices in his department.

Williams seized on this and soon the district auditor had a pile of papers on his desk, containing serious allegations against councillors and officers by the former environmental health officer. Williams and Gumsley firmly believe that this was the birth of "Donnygate", the ongoing scandal of corruption at Doncaster council that has seen 13 councillors found guilty of fraud - five of whom have been jailed - with, perhaps, more to come.

Still seething, Williams then set up his own pest control business and began to take customers off the local authority. Two years ago, not satisfied that the council was by then under the national spotlight and becoming a byword for corruption, he decided he would help fill the void left in the council chamber as a succession of Labour councillors resigned in disgrace. Standing for election in Thorne, he won. Last year, his wife, Carol, joined him. And the two of them have been causing havoc since.

As well as the residential homes issue, a row is raging over the council's attempts to close sixth forms in some schools - one of which is in Thorne. Residents are mobilising for a long fight and, predictably, the Williamses are in the forefront of the battle.

Locals cannot remember when there has been so much dissatisfaction with their local authority and are demanding change. Some have turned their anger on Thorne-Moorends town council, which they claim simply pays lip service to big brother Doncaster. They are demanding what is known as a "parish poll" - a referendum on whether the town council should be abolished. Williams has declared his readiness to dip into his pocket again if legal action is required to force such a vote.

It need never have been like this. "I was very happy to be a rat man," says Williams, 49. "I did it for 10 years and loved it. Then I got sacked for something I didn't do and my world collapsed. I have a debt of gratitude to pay to the people of my area who have given me back my self-respect. To the electorate in Thorne, I will always be eternally grateful."
fields.bodyText: Six years ago, Martin Williams was a rat-catcher with Doncaster council. He lived in an average semi-detached house in the small town of Thorne on the outskirts of Doncaster and, to his neighbours and his workmates, was a pretty normal bloke living a pretty unremarkable life. Then he was sacked for taking time off work without permission, something he vehemently denied. His world collapsed around him. He had spent 10 very content years driving his van round the leafy South Yorkshire lanes of Thorne, catching rats and destroying wasps' nests, passing the time of day with the locals and loving every minute of it. Suddenly, it was all taken from him. Over the next few years, Doncaster council was to rue the day it sent Williams packing. Last month, a high court judge was asked to stop Doncaster council going ahead with the closure of two residential homes for elderly people. While it is not uncommon these days for local authorities to face such legal action, what was unusual about this legal move was that it was instigated - and paid for - by a councillor from the local authority itself. That councillor was Williams. In the six years since he lost his job, the one-time local rat man has become a thorn in the side of Doncaster council. When he heard that residents' relatives were opposed to the homes' closure, he immediately instructed his barristers to ask the high court for permission for the case to go to judicial review. In the end, the application was refused. It cost Williams a few thousand pounds, but he was quite prepared to spend the £40,000 he estimates it would have cost if the case had gone ahead and he had lost. He can easily afford it. When he appeared before an industrial tribunal in 1995 in an unsuccessful bid to claim unfair dismissal, it was revealed that this humble rat man was a rich rat man indeed. He was part-heir to a family fortune worth more than £11m and had been brought up in historic Brodsworth Hall, now a jewel in the crown of English Heritage. He was dubbed the millionaire rat catcher. It ought to have been obvious to his bosses and his workmates that something was different about Williams. He refused to wear the standard boiler suit the council had provided for him. Instead, he had a pair of overalls made-to-measure with his name sewn in gold thread on the breast pocket. On his head, he wore a top-quality deerstalker. Unluckily for certain Doncaster councillors, at the same time that the authority sacked Williams they also gave notice to an environmental health officer, Peter Gumsley, and the two men became friends with a common bond - to get their own back. Gumsley claimed he had been dismissed on trumped-up allegations of time off without permission because he had refused to go along with what he felt were corrupt practices in his department. Williams seized on this and soon the district auditor had a pile of papers on his desk, containing serious allegations against councillors and officers by the former environmental health officer. Williams and Gumsley firmly believe that this was the birth of "Donnygate", the ongoing scandal of corruption at Doncaster council that has seen 13 councillors found guilty of fraud - five of whom have been jailed - with, perhaps, more to come. Still seething, Williams then set up his own pest control business and began to take customers off the local authority. Two years ago, not satisfied that the council was by then under the national spotlight and becoming a byword for corruption, he decided he would help fill the void left in the council chamber as a succession of Labour councillors resigned in disgrace. Standing for election in Thorne, he won. Last year, his wife, Carol, joined him. And the two of them have been causing havoc since. As well as the residential homes issue, a row is raging over the council's attempts to close sixth forms in some schools - one of which is in Thorne. Residents are mobilising for a long fight and, predictably, the Williamses are in the forefront of the battle. Locals cannot remember when there has been so much dissatisfaction with their local authority and are demanding change. Some have turned their anger on Thorne-Moorends town council, which they claim simply pays lip service to big brother Doncaster. They are demanding what is known as a "parish poll" - a referendum on whether the town council should be abolished. Williams has declared his readiness to dip into his pocket again if legal action is required to force such a vote. It need never have been like this. "I was very happy to be a rat man," says Williams, 49. "I did it for 10 years and loved it. Then I got sacked for something I didn't do and my world collapsed. I have a debt of gratitude to pay to the people of my area who have given me back my self-respect. To the electorate in Thorne, I will always be eternally grateful."

fields.headline: Trimble urged to give ultimatum
fields.trailText: David Trimble, Northern Ireland's first minister, was last night under pressure from some Ulster Unionist allies to reunite the party at its conference on Saturday with a motion to quit the power-sharing executive within three months if the IRA fails to begin destroying its weapons. He is said to be resisting the plan.
fields.body:
David Trimble, Northern Ireland's first minister, was last night under pressure from some Ulster Unionist allies to reunite the party at its conference on Saturday with a motion to quit the power-sharing executive within three months if the IRA fails to begin destroying its weapons. He is said to be resisting the plan.

As Mr Trimble warned that the Good Friday agreement was in dire trouble because of the IRA's failure to begin decommissioning, the deputy leader, John Taylor, said that its days were numbered. Jeffrey Donaldson, seen as a likely future leader, said at a fringe meeting at the Conservative Party conference in Bournemouth that only IRA weapons destruction could save the executive now.

Mr Trimble also faces a Democratic Unionist Party motion of no confidence as first minister in the assembly on Tuesday. It cannot be passed without nationalist backing, but even if he fails to achieve a majority of unionist backing, he would be seriously undermined.

Unionists taking his party whip total 27, and he can count on the support of the two Progressive Unionists. But the DUP and other anti-agreement unionists also number 29.

Although Mr Trimble is expected to survive Saturday's annual conference, the test is likely later in the month. His critics are expected to push for yet another meeting of the Ulster Unionist council, the party's ruling body, to force a withdrawal from the executive, which would signal Mr Trimble's demise.

But Gerry Adams, the Sinn Fein president, accused Ulster Unionists of creating a false crisis to detract attention from policing reform. Mr Trimble wants changes to the RUC to be halted until the IRA decommissions, but Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, will resist any such demand.

Mr Adams appeared to suggest that the IRA would allow the weapons inspectors, Martti Ahtisaari and Cyril Ramaphosa, back to re-inspect the dumps they saw in the Irish Republic. But with Ulster Unionists in crisis after the catastrophic byelection defeat at south Antrim last month, that may well be insufficient.

Mr Adams said: "The IRA ... have said there will be regular inspections and they would re-engage with the independent international commission on decommissioning and it's my view they will do that. I think the attempt to create a crisis around when the IRA bring back the inspectors is bogus.

"I have no doubt there is a crisis within unionism and I think part of that crisis is created by the fact there is no one out there actively promoting the Good Friday agreement, giving a positive, constructive, consistent and strategic lead to unionists who voted for the agreement."

Mr Donaldson said at a Save the Union meeting: "There is no reason why the leadership cannot give a lead and the Ulster Unionist ministers should withdraw from the executive as soon as possible."

He ridiculed arms inspections, and predicted Ulster Unionists would no longer accept that step.

The DUP deputy leader, Peter Robinson, said of Mr Trimble: "I have no confidence in him and the electorate has no confidence in him. It's not the inspection of a few wonky rifles we want, it's the complete destruction of all paramilitary weaponry."

fields.headline: Trimble is vital
fields.standfirst: His absence could risk more bloodshed
fields.trailText: Even colleagues who have little time for Peter Mandelson must feel for him now. The Ulster Unionists' loss of South Antrim to the Democratic Unionist Party has triggered events which now threaten a second suspension of the province's devolved institutions and even the possible loss of the whole peace process.
fields.body:
Even colleagues who have little time for Peter Mandelson must feel for him now. The Ulster Unionists' loss of South Antrim to the Democratic Unionist Party has triggered events which now threaten a second suspension of the province's devolved institutions and even the possible loss of the whole peace process. The DUP was not alone in finding South Antrim gratifying. It also brought hope to that sizeable force of Ulster Unionists who want to remove Mr Trimble in the hope that the Good Friday Agreement could then be renegotiated or, more practically, ditched.

Other developments too have stacked up the odds against Mr Trimble as he prepares to face his party conference on Saturday. Mr Mandelson has said that convicted IRA terrorists on the run in other countries will not be further pursued; also that further reductions in the security forces are planned. And on Monday the Daily Telegraph, eager as ever to undermine the agreement, reported, on the basis of evidence from "senior security sources", that leading Provisionals have been touring the province assuring their supporters that there will be no further movement on decommissioning until a united Ireland is certain.

All of which leaves Mr Trimble dangerously vulnerable, with the very real prospect that a month or so from now the Ulster Unionist council will once more be asked to choose between backing and sacking him. In an article for yesterday's Telegraph, he implicitly appealed to Mr Mandelson to throw him what he sees as the only feasible lifeline: the rescinding of the government's commitment to implement the Patten report on the future of the RUC. To save the agreement, he says, the government must agree to a moratorium on Patten until decommissioning has occurred, and to a "complete reopening" of the argument over its name.

If the fate of the agreement is to hang on complete decommissioning, rather than just further progress (Mr Trimble here is ambiguous) then the agreement is finished, with all the consequences that means for the province. But there may be some leeway here if, as is also suggested, the two special investigators, Martii Ahtisaari and Cyril Ramaphosa, are swiftly invited back for a second tour. That certainly ought to happen. But it is not, on any calculation, something within the power of the Northern Ireland secretary to deliver. Patten is different. Here, it is well within Mr Mandelson's powers to assent to what Mr Trimble is asking.

Yet to do that would merely swap one intractable problem for another, no less intractable. Sinn Fein, which has listed London's failure to move faster on Patten as one of the reasons why dissident republican groups are flourishing, would not be alone in condemning it. The SDLP would find it a surrender too far: so would Dublin. Nor, crucially, would it serve the long-term interests of Northern Ireland. It must be as clear to politicians in London as to those in Dublin that the province cannot move to consensual policing if the RUC is sustained in anything like its present form.

The terms in which Mr Trimble has made his bid have as much to do with his party audience as they have with the Northern Ireland secretary's agenda. He has to be heard talking tough. Because Mr Trimble is virtually irreplaceable, Mr Mandelson needs to explore all possible ways of helping him; but not where, as here, they would amount to a sell-out. And unhappy as they are, unionists at all levels ought to consider this. No Trimble is likely to mean no agreement. And what no agreement is likely to mean is already written in blood across Northern Ireland.

webTitle: Conservatives in Bournemouth: Hard line against soft drug users

fields.headline: Conservatives in Bournemouth: Hard line against soft drug users
fields.trailText: October 4 2000: Fixed penalties for cannabis possession
fields.body:
Ann Widdecombe will today unveil new hardline Conservative policies against the recreational use of soft drugs when she announces a £100 automatic fixed penalty for possession of cannabis .

The Tory leadership remains as hostile as Labour to calls for cannabis to be decriminalised and today's creation of the equivalent of a parking ticket - paid without a court appearance - is not intended to signal a softer line.

Some 90,000 people a year are fined for possession of cannabis and many more are cautioned in those police authorities where a less severe view is taken. Under Tory plans the caution option would be closed.

In her speech to the party conference in Bournemouth the shadow home secretary - currently darling of the Tory activists - will underline the traditional view by urging substantially higher penalties for anyone caught in possession of larger amounts that may be used for dealing purposes.

Under a Hague government the police would also gain further powers to raid crack houses. Only last week Tony Blair told his conference that he wants the police to be able to "do more damage" to the illegal drugs industry than it does to society at large.

Miss Widdecombe will also back calls for a new penalty of driving under the influence of drugs, closing an anomaly which allows drunken drivers to be heavily penalised but drug-users to escape. She has already called for "cops in shops" this week, a scheme requiring policemen and women to write up their reports in public places.

Miss Widdecombe's zero tolerance policy on drugs follows the decision by Michael Howard when he was Conservative home secretary to increase fines for cannabis possession by 200%. A recent Police Foundation report recommended that cannabis possession should no longer result in a prison sentence.

Miss Widdecombe also wishes to introduce a scheme allowing 16-year-olds to become part-time police cadets used on duty by adult police. She believes this would encourage full recruitment at 18 and might discourage anti-police attitudes.

Speaking at a fringe meeting held by the Police Federation Miss Widdecombe said the idea of police cadets will also have the unseen benefit of changing young people's attitude to the police. She would not pledge to recruit more police officers than the extra 9,000 recruits already promised by Jack Straw.

But she wanted to remove some functions currently carried out by police. Among those which could be taken over by private security companies would be running police custody suites.

Miss Widdecombe added that a police officer could spend up to four hours doing the paper work to book in a simple shoplifter. By handing over this function to a private company it would free the police to spend more time on the beat.

She also thought the police should no longer have to escort "wide loads" along motorways. She suggested this was another function where the private sector could be involved.

Fred Broughton, chairman of the Police Federation said he was sympathetic to the idea of the police cadet but he also wanted to see ex-army personnel and others which "life experience" joining police ranks.

fields.headline: The last Mini
fields.standfirst: All you need to know about the demise of the lovable car, and its second coming
fields.trailText: All you need to know about the demise of the lovable car, and its second coming
fields.body:
1. So, farewell then, mighty Mini. You always had a lot of friends. But not enough to keep you running. I had a Riley Elf once, as it happens.

2. The very last proper Mini staggers off the production line today at Longbridge. It's number 5,387,862.

3. So there's a lot of them still about, all over the world.

4. The first Mini, designed by Alec Issigonis, emerged blinking into the sunlight in 1959. It cost less than £500.

5. Issigonis was also responsible for the Morris Minor. It too hung around well beyond its sell-by date.

6. The Mini quickly acquired the killer tag, 'design icon'.

7. The Mini cult reached its frenzied height after the release of the movie The Italian Job.

8. The little car's fate was sealed when BMW, the former parent of Rover, designed a trendy new version. It will be produced at Cowley.

9. The crisis-wracked Rover group, remnant of the once-proud British car making industry, is now seeking a tie-up with Malaysian upstart Proton.

10. It is, as Keith's mum would say, the end of an era.
