fields.headline: Go forth and multiply
fields.standfirst: He may not remember a thing from his A-levels about inverse hyperbolic functions or Angrand diagrams. But yesterday's call for an end to compulsory maths at secondary school left Ian Katz aghast
fields.trailText: He may not remember a thing from his A-levels about inverse hyperbolic functions or Angrand diagrams. But yesterday's call for an end to compulsory maths at secondary school left Ian Katz aghast
fields.body:
The pages had yellowed and the dense, controlled writing bore precious little resemblance to the scrappy, barely legible scrawl that careers across my notebooks these days. Slowly, I read aloud the brief sentence at the top of one page: "To within isomorphisms, there are two groups of order: the cyclic group C4 and Klein's 4-group." Nothing. No bell rang, however distant. The strings of words and characters might have been lifted straight from the Dead Sea scrolls for all they meant to me.

I knew without having to check the cover that the dog-eared exercise book that emerged from the bottom of a packing crate during a recent house move was filled with my A-level maths notes. I remember how I had decided at the time that compressing my handwriting to the verge of requiring a magnifying glass would somehow help to impose clarity on my disordered mind, make it more mathematical. But nothing else seemed familiar. I flicked through pages devoted to Lagrange's Theorem and inverse hyperbolic functions and Argand diagrams but nothing came. Years of high-quality education seemed to have passed through my cortex as smoothly as a pint of lager slips through the digestive tract on a hot summer's day.

I was reminded of this mildly depressing episode when a new study yesterday called for an end to compulsory maths education in secondary schools. Steve Bramall, a London University lecturer in the philosphy of education, argued that the subject is "a restricted and limited means of describing and communicating about the world". He suggested that studying sociolology - "a subject expressly committed to developing in pupils an awareness and appreciation of the contexts of moral and political action" - might be more useful. "Higher mathematical knowledge and competence is not needed by the majority of the populace to ensure the economic success of modern industrialised society," chimed his co-author, Paul Ernest, himself a professor of mathematical education, no less.

My first reaction, like that of anyone else who has spent precious teenage hours poring over the Newton Raphson Iteration, was mild outrage. What about all those studies showing Britain to be embarrassingly innumerate? What about the demands of a world increasingly dominated by science? What about Carol Vorderman?

The trouble, of course, is that without being able to summon a single meaningful scrap from two years of maths education (strangely the O-level syllabus seems to have stuck) it is quite hard to marshal a defence for Gauss's Queen of Sciences. I wracked my brains for examples of how my maths had come in useful in later life. There had been a vague glimmer of recognition when Charles Murray and Richard Herrnstein published their ugly pseudo-scientific tract, The Bell Curve - I had once spent hours producing similar graphs, though usually plotting the thickness of washers produced by a screw factory rather than the IQs of ethnic groups. Then there was the night a heated argument with my wife about a principle of sailing (we were both beginners) ended with me furiously scribbling vector diagrams on a paper napkin to prove my point. I will save her writing in by admitting now that I ended my demonstration with the declaration: "I've got two maths A-levels and a physics S-level so I can't believe you're still arguing with me about this." On our next sortie I insisted on proving my point and was promptly catapulted into the water.

On the face of it this seems a pretty poor return on years of hard work. I still know enough maths to calculate that I must have spent more than 1,000 hours studying the subject at A-level alone, at least half as much again if you include my whole time at secondary school. It's hard not to wonder whether that time might have been more usefully employed reading Shakespeare, or learning Farsi or just doing unpleasant teenage things that I might conceivably have been able to remember 20 years later.

But the truth is that my memories of grappling with the Wilcoxin test and Kendall's co-efficient - though I could not now tell you a single thing about them - are by far the fondest of my school career. I can still feel the thrilling sensation of stumbling into some secret and distant country as our gnomic teacher Dr Solomon (I don't think he had a first name) introduced us to numbers that did not exist or multi-dimensional space. The inaccessibility of much of the subject matter only added to its appeal; I could always read a novel or learn a language in later life, I reasoned, but friends studying English and French would never know the delights of an inverse hyperbolic function.

Until sex came along there wasn't much to rival the satisfaction to be got from producing a crisp proof. I couldn't have made head or tale of a line of it but when Princeton mathematician Andrew Wiles later told me about the "feeling of naturalness and elegance" of his historic proof of Fermat's Last Theorem, I understood exactly what he was talking about. Wiles compared the process of edging towards a proof to making your way through a large house in darkness. "You work your way around the room and you begin to feel objects here and there and suddenly the light goes on and you can see everything clearly." For a moment I wished I had pressed a little further into his house of numbers.

As it was, I never got past Dr Solomon's introductory tour and it wasn't long before I found myself wondering whether all those hours of labouring over equations were well spent. At 3am on the day I was supposed to deliver my first university essay I found myself staring at a blank sheet of paper in a state of blind panic: I didn't have the faintest idea how to write an essay; in two years of studying maths and physics I hadn't been required to produce one.

The stock defence of maths, like Latin, is that it teaches structured and disciplined ways of thinking, but I'm not convinced. At least at school level, maths is all about hard, clean answers, the certainty that a solution is out there to be found. By and large, though, the world isn't like that; it is about arguments and choices and complex, messy decisions. Even the most exciting areas of science in the past 20 years have been in the relatively "messy" fields of biology and quantum physics. These areas may rely as heavily on high-level maths as any other but a high school grasp on the subject won't help much to get your head around them - philosophy might be more useful.

Meanwhile, I'm glad to report that my efforts to recall a single useful fact from my mathematical education did throw up one tantalising nugget: if you take a deep breath while reading this there is a better than 99 per cent chance that you will inhale a molecule of air which was exhaled by Julius Caesar in his dying breath. Don't ask me to prove it - I wouldn't know where to start - but I'm sure you'll agree it shows all those years weren't completely wasted.
fields.bodyText: The pages had yellowed and the dense, controlled writing bore precious little resemblance to the scrappy, barely legible scrawl that careers across my notebooks these days. Slowly, I read aloud the brief sentence at the top of one page: "To within isomorphisms, there are two groups of order: the cyclic group C4 and Klein's 4-group." Nothing. No bell rang, however distant. The strings of words and characters might have been lifted straight from the Dead Sea scrolls for all they meant to me. I knew without having to check the cover that the dog-eared exercise book that emerged from the bottom of a packing crate during a recent house move was filled with my A-level maths notes. I remember how I had decided at the time that compressing my handwriting to the verge of requiring a magnifying glass would somehow help to impose clarity on my disordered mind, make it more mathematical. But nothing else seemed familiar. I flicked through pages devoted to Lagrange's Theorem and inverse hyperbolic functions and Argand diagrams but nothing came. Years of high-quality education seemed to have passed through my cortex as smoothly as a pint of lager slips through the digestive tract on a hot summer's day. I was reminded of this mildly depressing episode when a new study yesterday called for an end to compulsory maths education in secondary schools. Steve Bramall, a London University lecturer in the philosphy of education, argued that the subject is "a restricted and limited means of describing and communicating about the world". He suggested that studying sociolology - "a subject expressly committed to developing in pupils an awareness and appreciation of the contexts of moral and political action" - might be more useful. "Higher mathematical knowledge and competence is not needed by the majority of the populace to ensure the economic success of modern industrialised society," chimed his co-author, Paul Ernest, himself a professor of mathematical education, no less. My first reaction, like that of anyone else who has spent precious teenage hours poring over the Newton Raphson Iteration, was mild outrage. What about all those studies showing Britain to be embarrassingly innumerate? What about the demands of a world increasingly dominated by science? What about Carol Vorderman? The trouble, of course, is that without being able to summon a single meaningful scrap from two years of maths education (strangely the O-level syllabus seems to have stuck) it is quite hard to marshal a defence for Gauss's Queen of Sciences. I wracked my brains for examples of how my maths had come in useful in later life. There had been a vague glimmer of recognition when Charles Murray and Richard Herrnstein published their ugly pseudo-scientific tract, The Bell Curve - I had once spent hours producing similar graphs, though usually plotting the thickness of washers produced by a screw factory rather than the IQs of ethnic groups. Then there was the night a heated argument with my wife about a principle of sailing (we were both beginners) ended with me furiously scribbling vector diagrams on a paper napkin to prove my point. I will save her writing in by admitting now that I ended my demonstration with the declaration: "I've got two maths A-levels and a physics S-level so I can't believe you're still arguing with me about this." On our next sortie I insisted on proving my point and was promptly catapulted into the water. On the face of it this seems a pretty poor return on years of hard work. I still know enough maths to calculate that I must have spent more than 1,000 hours studying the subject at A-level alone, at least half as much again if you include my whole time at secondary school. It's hard not to wonder whether that time might have been more usefully employed reading Shakespeare, or learning Farsi or just doing unpleasant teenage things that I might conceivably have been able to remember 20 years later. But the truth is that my memories of grappling with the Wilcoxin test and Kendall's co-efficient - though I could not now tell you a single thing about them - are by far the fondest of my school career. I can still feel the thrilling sensation of stumbling into some secret and distant country as our gnomic teacher Dr Solomon (I don't think he had a first name) introduced us to numbers that did not exist or multi-dimensional space. The inaccessibility of much of the subject matter only added to its appeal; I could always read a novel or learn a language in later life, I reasoned, but friends studying English and French would never know the delights of an inverse hyperbolic function. Until sex came along there wasn't much to rival the satisfaction to be got from producing a crisp proof. I couldn't have made head or tale of a line of it but when Princeton mathematician Andrew Wiles later told me about the "feeling of naturalness and elegance" of his historic proof of Fermat's Last Theorem, I understood exactly what he was talking about. Wiles compared the process of edging towards a proof to making your way through a large house in darkness. "You work your way around the room and you begin to feel objects here and there and suddenly the light goes on and you can see everything clearly." For a moment I wished I had pressed a little further into his house of numbers. As it was, I never got past Dr Solomon's introductory tour and it wasn't long before I found myself wondering whether all those hours of labouring over equations were well spent. At 3am on the day I was supposed to deliver my first university essay I found myself staring at a blank sheet of paper in a state of blind panic: I didn't have the faintest idea how to write an essay; in two years of studying maths and physics I hadn't been required to produce one. The stock defence of maths, like Latin, is that it teaches structured and disciplined ways of thinking, but I'm not convinced. At least at school level, maths is all about hard, clean answers, the certainty that a solution is out there to be found. By and large, though, the world isn't like that; it is about arguments and choices and complex, messy decisions. Even the most exciting areas of science in the past 20 years have been in the relatively "messy" fields of biology and quantum physics. These areas may rely as heavily on high-level maths as any other but a high school grasp on the subject won't help much to get your head around them - philosophy might be more useful. Meanwhile, I'm glad to report that my efforts to recall a single useful fact from my mathematical education did throw up one tantalising nugget: if you take a deep breath while reading this there is a better than 99 per cent chance that you will inhale a molecule of air which was exhaled by Julius Caesar in his dying breath. Don't ask me to prove it - I wouldn't know where to start - but I'm sure you'll agree it shows all those years weren't completely wasted.

fields.headline: Arafat and Barak 'enter direct talks'
fields.trailText: The Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, and the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, were meeting face to face today, according to unconfirmed reports.
fields.body:
The Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, and the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, were meeting face to face today, according to unconfirmed reports.

Earlier, as fresh violence erupted in the West Bank and Gaza, Mr Barak had warned that peace negotiations would not resume until the fighting stops.

The US secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, had urged Mr Barak and Mr Arafat, to return to "the psychology of peacemaking".

Ms Albright was reported to have begun brokering direct talks between the Middle East leaders late this afternoon.

Earlier, Mr Arafat said that he would see Mr Barak only if there was a guarantee that his people would be protected and an inquiry was launched into the fighting.

Ms Albright held separate meetings earlier today with the two leaders in Paris. She hoped to convene the three-way meeting earlier today but both leaders initially rejected the move.

Sixty people, mostly Palestinians, have died during six days of fighting between Israeli soldiers and police. But Mr Barak said he held the Palestinians responsible for the violence.

In her two-hour session with Mr Barak, at the residence of the US ambassador, Felix Rohatyn, the Israeli prime minister told Ms Albright that the Palestinians were violating agreements with Israel. The Palestinians were acquiring illegal arms and shooting at soldiers, Mr Barak's office said.

Afterwards, Ms Albright met with Mr Arafat for 90 minutes.

A senior Palestinian official has said an international inquiry into Israel's actions would be a condition of reviving the peace talks. But Mr Barak's office has said he "totally rejected the call for an international investigation."

Fighting broke out last week after an Israeli hardliner, the Likud party leader, Ariel Sharon, visited one of Jerusalem's most hotly-contested holy sites, a spot revered by both Jews and Muslims. The dispute over who will control the site is the main obstacle to a peace agreement.

Mr Chirac has blamed the violence on an "irresponsible provocation". Many have interpreted this is a clear reference to Sharon's visit to the holy site.

Mr Sharon, notorious among Palestinians for launching the bloody war against Mr Arafat's forces in Lebanon in 1982, denied responsibility and blamed Mr Arafat.

The Egyptian president, Hosni Mubarak, is planning a leadership summit tomorrow. Mr Barak and Mr Arafat have both agreed to come, Mr Mubarak claimed.

Meanwhile, the Iraqi president, Saddam Hussein, said that Iraq has the potential to quickly restrain Israel if its Arab neighbours give it territory from which to mount operations against the Jewish state, despite the sanctions imposed on his country.

fields.headline: Knowledge Unlimited
fields.standfirst: Send your questions to the.boss@guardian.co.uk and we'll do our best to answer them
fields.trailText: SOCIALIST FOOTBALLERS
fields.body:
SOCIALIST FOOTBALLERS

"Two members of Tottenham's great FA Cup and Uefa winning side of the early Eighties were confirmed socialists, contributing articles to Living Marxism and other journals," writes one Knowledge Unlimited reader whose correspondence we have sadly mislaid. "Said players were Republic of Ireland internationals Tony Galvin and Chris Houghton. Galvin, a Russian language graduate, backed the TGWU's 'Campaign for a Living Wage' during the more extreme years of Thatcherism, appearing on a Union poster. I also know that Cloughie was a leftie, but what other players have backed the revolutionary struggle?"

A number of socialists have come out of Scottish football. Brian McClair was once asked in a Match questionnaire: "What scares you the most?" to which he answered: "A Thatcher government." While Billy Shankly famously said: "The socialism I believe in is everybody working together for the collective good. That's how I see life. That's how I see football." Another socialist of sorts is Alex Ferguson, who was a hard-left shop steward in Govan before transforming into a card-carrying Blairite.

Elsewhere, there are several Argentinian players: Diego Maradona, Jorge Valdano and Fernando Redondo, to name just three, are all confirmed socialists. And Barcelona's Pep Guardiola is passionate supporter of Catalanism and decentralised government - which is why he's never got on with Ferdando Hierro, who is a devout supporter of a strong Madrid (even though he's from Malaga). If you know of any more footballing lefties - or conservatives/fascists, come to think of it - then let us know, and we will print them next week.

CLUBS ON CELLULOID

"In This is Spinal Tap, the bassist Derek Smalls can be seen to be wearing an early 80s Shrewsbury Town shirt. Have there been other incidences of silver screen glory for the lower league clubs?" asks James McKie.

"I spotted King Arthur in a Coventry shirt in the 1998 film Arthurs Quest," says an excited Sean Boland. While Philip Hassell points out that, "in Trainspotting, Renton and Spud are rabid Hibs fans - chanting 'Oh to, oh to be, oh to be a ... Hibee'."

CLUBS WITH NUMBERS

"Why have Schalke got the 04 by their name?" asks William Smith. "And are there any others with numbers in their names?"

"I emailed the club and got an incredibly efficient Teutonic reply - ten minutes later - from Klaus Horstmann who is Internet Services Manager for Schalke 04. They were formed on May 4th 1904. Obvious really," says James McKie.

And while we are on Schalke 04, Hauke Richters remembers that during the 1970s "the first female football presenter on the German equivalent of Match of the Day called them Schalke 05 rather than Schalke 04. Thousands of people apparently called the TV station, giving their comments about women and football - and the unfortunate young lady never appeared on the show again." Meanwhile, as Martin Tobutt, David Hopkins and Carsten Bogdahn point out there are several other German teams, including: Bayer 04 Laverkusen, SSV Ulm 1846, FSV Mainz 05, Hannover 96 who all have their year of formation in their name.

And for those particularly interested in German football team names (and judging by the mail we get there are lots of you out there) it's worth bearing in mind - as Martin Tobutt points out - "how many clubs are called Borussia - the Britannia-esque figure of Prussia (e.g. Ballsport Verein Borussia 1909 Dortmund); and how many football clubs are keen to show that they were the first FC in that town (e.g. 1FC Kaiserslautern, 1FC Cologne)."

THE FIRST CLUB TO PLAY UNDER FLOODLIGHTS

Last week, we claimed that the first British club to play under floodlights were Arsenal, who played a friendly against Hapoel Tel Aviv at Highbury under lights in September 1951.

However, Steven Randell points out that on Oxford United's official website it says: "Only a handful of Football League clubs had installed floodlights when Headington proudly opened theirs in December 1950 with a friendly against local side Banbury Spencer."

"As you are no doubt aware, Headington was the former name of Oxford United," Steven adds.

TOUGH-TACKLING TOFFS

"Does anyone know of any footballers that went to public school? I know Frank Lampard Jnr was one (he went to Brentwood). But are there any others?" wonders Joel Davison.

"Ex-Arsenal, West Ham and Coventry midfielder Stewart Robson was also a former pupil of Brentwood public school, along with Mike Smith and Noel Edmonds!" says Simon Jarvis.

Meanwhile, two of our readers remember playing against Quinton Fortune when he was at Forest School private school in London. "I know this because I once marked him out of the game (although he did score a hat-trick)," remembers Matthew Pike. Paul Giles has a very similar story, claiming that he gave young Quinton, "a torrid time, shortly after which I think he left Tottenham's books and returned to the easy life in South Africa."

Glad to see that Quinton suffered no lasting effects, eh?

CAN YOU HELP?

"Was Bob Paisley ever considered for the England manager's job?" asks Killian Morgan. "And if not, why not?"

"After watching a couple of Arsenal games this season myself and my flatmates have noticed that several of the players appear to have a patch of slime on the chest of their shirts. Does anyone have any idea what this is?" ask Paul Bird and Will Morrison.

fields.headline: Serbian police acquiesce to protesters
fields.standfirst: Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: Police loyal to Serbian president Slobodan Milosevic backed off today when confronted by huge crowds at a coal mine
fields.body:
Police poured into a major coal mine in Yugoslavia today to break up the largest of the nationwide strikes aimed at ousting the president, Slobodan Milosevic, but authorities backed off when huge crowds responded to the workers' cries for aid.

Thousands of miners and supporters streamed into the Kolubara mine complex after security forces withdrew from their barricades and were mingling with strikers inside the compound.

Meanwhile, caravans of supporters swarmed in vehicles and on foot to the mine from every direction. One bus pushed aside a police car blocking its way, witnesses said.

Police in riot gear watched passively as the crowd swelled.

"Take off your uniforms and join the people," said Dragan Kovacevic, an opposition leader. "The battle for Serbia was won here."

The startling turnaround was hailed by foes of Mr Milosevic as another key victory in their civil disobedience campaign to force him to accept election defeat.

At first, however, it looked as if Mr Milosevic was turning to brute force to crush dissent. Truckloads of police and soldiers swarmed into the mine complex, which employs 7,000 workers, after the government said the five-day strike threatened electricity supplies.

However, there were no clashes or arrests, according to striker Ranko Radasinovic.

He said about 100 policemen had taken over the head office and the main crusher plant at the strip mine near this town about 25 miles south of Belgrade.

Workers called for help as authorities set up cordons at the entrance. But they failed to hold back crowds flocking to the open pit mine in support of the strikers.

The confrontation came one day after the Milosevic government threatened "special measures against leaders of strikes and road blockades", which were launched this week to force the Yugoslav president to concede defeat to challenger Vojislav Kostunica in last month's elections. Police loyal to the embattled Serbian president also arrested several truck drivers today as they attempted to clear blockades by protesters on key roads.

Near Pozarevac, Mr Milosevic's home town, 30 miles south of Belgrade, tensions grew after the arrest of the truckers whose vehicles were blocking the road. Dozens of people subsequently sat down on the pavement, strengthening the blockade.

In Belgrade, where the civil disobedience campaign has been less noticeable than in smaller cities, there were signs that more people were joining the opposition campaign.

Hundreds of stores were closed and city bus drivers and rubbish collectors stayed away from work, leaving overflowing bins scattered in the streets.

The postal service announced a warning strike for later in the day, and by noon, the city centre was effectively put off limits to cars and other vehicles by thousands of pedestrians roaming the streets and blocking traffic.

Fears are mounting that Mr Milosevic may resort to force to hold on to power, despite rising calls at home and abroad for him to step down in favour of Mr Kostunica.

In an interview published in Moscow's Komersant daily, Mr Kostunica said he believed Mr Milosevic was preparing to resort to force.

"He experiences no moral dilemma or torments of the soul about that," Mr Kostunica said. "However it is clear that he does not have enough force at present."

webTitle: Last days of the tower,  Additional power, and  Fit me a shower

fields.headline: Last days of the tower,  Additional power, and  Fit me a shower
fields.trailText: TOWER POWER
fields.body:
TOWER POWER

You may or may not be aware that this Saturday sees the final ever ever event to be held at the grand old twin towers of the national stadium of the home of football before it's knocked down to give birth to a spanking new Wembley stadium. The event is, of course, the titanic clash between the Teutonic titans of Germany and some bumblers with more money than hair. But today, the Fiver wants to put the spotlight on the stadium, not the football, because she deserves it. And also because her Chief Executive has gone around shouting his mouth off as if the Millennium Dome never happened.

"We will create a Wembley experience which will start from the moment someone buys a ticket and will last until they get home after the event," said Bob Stubbs of the new stadium that is yet to receive enough financial backing to guarantee that it will be built. "I have been involved in this project for four years and firmly believe it will surpass anything which has been done before," he said of the projected 90,000 capacity stadium which will have more toilets than any ground in the world.

Not content with praising something that may never get built, Bob also took the opportunity to have a pop at the world's major stadiums while he was at it. "I have been to them all," he said. "You can't buy anything to eat and drink at the Stade de France and Cardiff is not particularly impressive either." So there you have it. All the more reason to cheer the death of the old Wembers this weekend. As the Koogmeister himself put it: "Because it's Germany, because it's the last game at Wembley, this one's just got a bit more cream on it."

MUSCLING IN

If, in three years time, Barnet are Premiership champions and their players are walking around with Schwarzenegger-sized biceps and an undersized throbbing python of love to match, the club's new £250,000 sponsorship deal with dietary supplement company Maximuscle might well be to blame. "But aren't they the chaps who were blamed when Mark Richardson, Doug Walker and Gary Cadogan all tested positive for the banned steroid nandrolone?" you ask. Well, yes they are. But our lawyers are watching so we won't be entertaining any wild accusations - especially when Maximuscle can point to a University of Aberdeen study that proves that all their products are clean. And, even if we had fears that the whole Barnet squad could be risking a ban if something goes strangely wrong - a la Richardson and co - they were thankfully assuaged at the press conference today. "I look forward to meeting them to take their advice on all matters relating to fitness," said Barnet's general manager John Still about the deal. And then he continued, in a manner that was just a bit too laissez faire for the Fiver's liking: "Anything that improves players' performance will suit me fine."

"Anything?" thought the Fiver. But before we could get Still to elaborate, up stepped Maximuscle's managing director Zef Eisenberg to announce that there really was nothing to worry about. "All the controversies in the past were linked to just a few elite athletes and there may be reasons for that," he said confusingly. "But the rest of the people who use our products have not complained. It makes sense for us to help advise Barnet." And, realising that Barnet are in no way elite athletes, the Fiver went away reassured.

QUOTES OF THE DAY

"I am travelling to London to meet with Sir Alex Ferguson and we will discuss a potential bid for Clarence [Acuna, Chilean international midfielder]. Sir Alex and I are friends and in professional terms, I scout players for him, especially in Argentina, Brazil and Chile" - Agent Ronen Katzav, as quoted yesterday on the Planet Football website.

"I am not currently in London. If I wanted to arrange a meeting with Sir Alex Ferguson, I would not do it through the media. I never said anything about Manchester United being interested in Acuna. I'm not sure how this got out" - Agent Ronen Katzav, as quoted today on the Planet Football website. The Fiver pledges to wholeheartedly join Ronen in his wondering.

COOKING WITH CARLTON

The Fiver is always on the lookout for ways of making an extra few bob. One idea we had was to set up a company called Fiver Building Services and offer construction solutions to Premiership footballers - if David Beckham wanted some crazy paving laying down, for example, we'd be round with trowel at the ready before he could say "water feature". But after finding out what happened when Carlton Palmer wanted a new kitchen, we've decided not to bother.

You see, poor Carlton gave builder Wayne Haslam £12,000 to construct the cooking area of his dreams. Sadly, work on the new kitchen never began, forcing the former England international to demand his money back. But when the cheque refunding Carlton's cash bounced higher than one of his clearances, things started getting out of hand. "I was furious," Palmer seethed, as he gave evidence in Sheffield Crown Court against Haslam, who was on trial for six charges of deception. "I said I would burn his premises down and I wouldn't care if he was in there."

Luckily for everybody concerned, Carlton - who was playing for Southampton at the time - didn't actually mean it. Instead, Haslam told the court Palmer arranged to meet him in a golf club car park, bringing Chris Eubank's former minder along for the ride. As all the chums sat chatting in Palmer's Merc, the "nervous" builder agreed to a repayment plan. Predictably, the terms of this particular scheme were never met, which may go some way to explaining Carlton's successful appearance in the box (surely a first).

As a result of all this, Haslam was sent down for a six-month stretch on Friday. The presiding judge also explained how "disturbed" he was by Palmer's workshop-torching threat, and called for an investigation. However, it is understood that the South Yorkshire Police will not be making any enquiries. We're still getting rid of our tool box though, it's not worth the bother.

THE RUMOUR MILL

Christian Panucci wants a move back to Internazionale now that Marcello Lippi has been sacked. The defender, who is struggling to settle on loan at Chelsea, has issued a come-and-get-me plea to whoever takes over at the San Siro, according to Planet Football.

Bobby Robson has told Manchester City he won't sell them defender Laurent Charvet. "It's no secret that we were ready to let Laurent Charvet go in the summer," said Robson. "But the situation has changed now and we want to keep him, especially after the way he has been playing lately."

Bradford have been linked with a £1.5m bid for Everton's Republic of Ireland international defender Richard Dunne.

NEWS IN BRIEF

A former girlfriend of sacked Brazil coach Wanderley Luxemburgo has claimed he was a drug addict who smuggled cocaine around the world inside footballs. Renata Alves, who was also Luxemburgo's former secretary, told a public prosecutor: "Before international trips, Wanderley used to lock himself in the bathroom with three or four footballs and a 007-style suitcase. Then he started to inhale something that he had spread over the basin. He filled the balls with some substance that I think must have been cocaine. Nobody checked his luggage because he was famous. He had free circulation in the airports."

Celtic have confirmed that midfielder Morten Wieghorst has been taken to hospital with a mystery brain illness. The 29-year-old Danish international has been suffering from a virus which affects the brain nerve endings and has been complaining of dizzy spells and flu-like symptoms.

Republic of Ireland manager Mick McCarthy has named an unchanged team for Saturday's World Cup qualifier against Portugal in Lisbon. "I saw no reason to change the team," he said. "Portugal play in a similar style to the Dutch side and that will suit us just fine." The team: Kelly, Carr, Breen, Dunne, Harte, McAteer, Roy Keane, Kinsella, Kilbane, Quinn, Robbie Keane.

Plymouth manager Kevin Hodges and his assistant Steve McCall have been sacked.

Sky Sports 1: The Last Word (6.30pm) Jimmy Hill sits down and has a one-to-one with a sporting celebrity.

Futbol Mondial (9.30pm) It's like Brian Moore's Monday night show, only it's on earlier - which means it's harder to fall asleep during it.

You're on Sky Sports! (10pm) But look on the bright side: if you drift off you've got 13 hours of dreamy bliss ahead.

British Eurosport: Football (7.15pm) Which means you would miss this.

Live Football: France v Cameroon (7.45pm) And this. But that's not so bad, is it?

Are you mates with top pop tot Craig David? Or do you hang out with any of the blokes from the Artful Dodger, fellow Southampton-based garage stars? If so, could you please tell them that, if they get a chance, they should make a speech at tonight's MOBO awards criticising the club's decision to name their new ground 'The Friends Provident Stadium'? fields.bodyText: TOWER POWER You may or may not be aware that this Saturday sees the final ever ever event to be held at the grand old twin towers of the national stadium of the home of football before it's knocked down to give birth to a spanking new Wembley stadium. The event is, of course, the titanic clash between the Teutonic titans of Germany and some bumblers with more money than hair. But today, the Fiver wants to put the spotlight on the stadium, not the football, because she deserves it. And also because her Chief Executive has gone around shouting his mouth off as if the Millennium Dome never happened. fields.headline: Pride editor quits blaming lack of support
fields.standfirst: Pride editor resigns
fields.trailText: 1pm: Joy Francis, who has resigned as editor of black women's title Pride, has blamed the magazine's unwillingness to support home-grown black talent as a key reason for her departure. By Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Joy Francis, who has resigned as editor of black women's glossy magazine Pride, said the magazine's unwillingness to support home-grown black talent was a key reason for her departure.

Ms Francis, who leaves Pride after only three issues, said: "I was unhappy with the way the goalposts were being moved in terms of the magazine's editorial strategy." She said this had been exacerbated by "unrealistic expectations in terms of staffing and financial support".

The former editor claimed that despite boosting the magazine's profile with an interview with Snatch director Guy Ritchie and a series of high-profile sponsorship deals, the editorial staff of five had received insufficient support from Pride's publisher, Werbayne Macintyre, or the publishing company, Pride Magazine Ltd.

Mr Macintyre confirmed that Ms Francis had resigned, but would not comment further.

fields.headline: BBC1 scheduling changes throw ITV into confusion
fields.standfirst:
David Teather on BBC news move
Sissons hails 'bold move'
fields.trailText: 11.30am: BBC2 stalwart Have I Got News for You? looks set to move to BBC1 as part of the channel's new 10pm news line-up starting on October 16, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
BBC2 stalwart Have I Got News for You? looks set to move to BBC1 as part of the channel's new 10pm news line-up starting on Monday October 16.

The BBC's plan has thrown ITV into a scheduling crisis. The network has taken the unusual step of delaying publishing its final schedule for that week until 6pm tonight. The deadline for submitting final schedules to listings editors was 4pm today.

The transfer of Have I Got News For You? to BBC1 - at its usual time of 9pm from Friday October 20 - was revealed in a revised version of the initial schedule published this morning.

The long-running BBC2 show and a Vicar of Dibley repeat will replace Parkinson, which had originally been pencilled in for 9pm that night.

BBC and ITV schedulers often try to wrong-foot each other with last-minute changes and further revisions could yet be made to the BBC1 line-up before the final listings deadline at 4pm today.

Earlier today BBC1 revealed it was putting its faith in pensioner Victor Meldrew and Men in Black to push viewers to the new Ten O'Clock News in its first week.

The last ever series of sitcom One Foot in the Grave will occupy the first vacated 9pm BBC1 slot when the channel's hastily rejigged late-evening schedule relaunches on October 16.

Victor Meldrew's last hurrah will be followed at 9.30pm on BBC1 by another comedy, the returning Royle Family, which will lead in to the first Ten O'Clock News. The following night the channel will give Will Smith and Tommy Lee Jones' blockbuster, Men in Black, its UK terrestrial premiere at 8.30pm.

On Wednesday October 18, the Scarlet Pimpernel will return for a 90-minute romp from 8.30pm; while on Thursday, BBC1 has juggled its line-up to bring forward Lenny Henry drama Hope & Glory to 9.05pm.

BBC1 will end the week with a new sitcom premiering after the news at 10.35pm. Too Much Sun stars the Fully Monty's Mark Addy as a Brit-in-Hollywood.

Panorama moves the week before the news. Its first Sunday night airing will be on the October 15 at 10.15pm, following a 15-minute news bulletin.

Ms Wright, who has been with LWT for three years since joining from the BBC, is expected to take up her new post at the end of the year.

John Chapman, who has been overseeing TalkBack's drama slate, is said to be staying on at the indie as a senior producer.

fields.headline: Genetic parenting - 'designer babies'
fields.standfirst:
The first "designer baby", whose birth in America made international headlines today, has rekindled furious debate about the ethical issues of using genetics to select the attributes of babies. Genetic screening was used so that the test-tube baby Adam Nash could become a donor for his six-year-old sister Molly, who has a rare and fatal genetic disease. But whilst the case has inspired sympathy, it has also increased fears of babies becoming "commodities" where intelligence and athletic prowess are bought. The genetic Pandora's box is open. Mark Oliver guides you through the ethical minefield.
Special report: the ethics of genetics
fields.trailText:
What is a "designer baby"?
Adam Nash is the world's first known designer baby. Using a revolutionary new technique, called a "pre-implantation process", scientists genetically selected his embryo so that he would have the right cells to save the life of his dying sister. His parents, Lisa and Jack, were able to conceive normally but their sperm and eggs were manipulated in a laboratory to create 15 embryos. One was selected which did not have Fanconi's anaemia, which their daughter Molly suffers from. Normally, there would be a very high chance any baby they had would also have the disease. After Adam's birth last month, he became a donor to his sister and there was a blood transfusion which has more than doubled her survival chances.
fields.body:
What is a "designer baby"?
Adam Nash is the world's first known designer baby. Using a revolutionary new technique, called a "pre-implantation process", scientists genetically selected his embryo so that he would have the right cells to save the life of his dying sister. His parents, Lisa and Jack, were able to conceive normally but their sperm and eggs were manipulated in a laboratory to create 15 embryos. One was selected which did not have Fanconi's anaemia, which their daughter Molly suffers from. Normally, there would be a very high chance any baby they had would also have the disease. After Adam's birth last month, he became a donor to his sister and there was a blood transfusion which has more than doubled her survival chances.

If he saves his sister's life, why the concern?
For many the specifics of the Nash case lie outside the main ethical issues. However, despite sympathy for the parents' dilemma, there are those who believe it is intrinsically wrong to bring a human being into the world for any purpose other than living their own life. But, in the main, fears revolve around the precedent this birth sets and that the technique could be extended to allow parents to "design" children with a variety of genetic traits.

What would be available to parents deciding to have a "designer baby"?
Eye colour, athletic ability, beauty, intelligence, height, stopping a propensity towards obesity, guaranteeing freedom from certain mental and physical illnesses, all of these could in the future be determined by genetic science. Even characteristics such as sexuality could be selected. The problem for many is that the frontiers of what is now genetically possible are being pushed back far quicker than the ethical debate can keep up with. In Britain, the Human Fertilisation and Embryology Authority has not even finished its public consultation about the pros and cons of pre-implantation genetic screening, and the debate has already rushed on.

Who are the people worried about genetics?
Some scientists have voiced concerns although many echo the views of Dr John Wagner, of the University of Minnesota, who carried out the Nash operation. He said he was not an ethicist and was just trying to save the girl's life. The anti-abortion charity Life said selecting top quality embryos was more akin to the farmyard and that one child should not be used to save the life of another. The Catholic Church have condemned any tampering with genetics, even in cases such as the Nash's. Groups worried about social injustices, and the gap between rich and poor, are also concerned at a future where the wealthy can purchase a perfect offspring. Last year, related controversy was created when a US entrepreneur started a website offering the embryos of models.

How will the debate pan out?
As the knowledge of what each gene does grows then it will become possible to predict most, if not all, diseases and details of other characteristics, before birth. A key issue for genetic commentators is how parents respond to the increasing possibilities that will be offered to them. In specific health cases, if you compare it to the case of the conjoined twins Jodie and Mary, their future has rested in the hands of judges. However, if parents are given the choice of having further children to help existing ones, many will take those. They will argue, as the Nash's have done, that they wanted more children anyway and no harm has come to the genetically screened baby.

webTitle: Middle East leaders set out their bloody stalls

fields.headline: Middle East leaders set out their bloody stalls
fields.standfirst: Derek Brown on the tactics ahead for the main players in the crisis
fields.trailText: Derek Brown on the tactics ahead for the main players in the crisis.
fields.body:
There is little apparent urgency about the trilateral talks in Paris which are aimed at ending the carnage in the Holy Land. US Secretary of State Madeleine Albright has held separate meetings with Israeli prime minister Ehud Barak and Palestinian president Yasser Arafat. All three are supposed to move on to substantive discussions of the situation, and of the wider peace process. But Barak says he will not meet the Palestinian leader until the violence stops, and Arafat for his part is saying his people must be "protected" before he will sit at the same table as Barak.

These are dangerous times and dangerous tactics. Barak, an ex-army chief, is parroting the conventional Israeli military wisdom that Palestinian leaders can turn the violence off and on like a tap. That is, and always has been, manifest nonsense, especially at a time of white-hot anger on the streets.

Arafat too is playing with fire if he imagines he can extract concessions from the Israelis when they are under fire. He may not control the riots, but his best chance of making Barak budge is to get the Americans on his side. And to do that he needs to be willing to talk, all night if necessary, instead of dithering in the ante room.

As the death toll mounts - it is now over 60 and climbing - the greatest danger is that neither Barak nor Arafat can regain control of their own streets. The anger of the Palestinians is manifest, but there is growing unease in Israel too about the threat to isolated Jewish settlements in the Gaza Strip and on the West Bank.

There is also widespread alarm about the unprecedented surge of violence involving Israel's 1m Arab citizens, most of whom identify with the Palestinian cause, if not with Arafat's embryonic statelet. For the Americans, the ultimate nightmare is that the unrest will spill out of Israel and the territories and infect the wider Middle East region.

Already Jordan - diplomatically closely allied to the USA and Israel - is seething with anger about the conflict on its doorstep, and has opened its borders to wounded Palestinians needing treatment. In Syria too anger has erupted on the streets, with a mob attack on the US embassy in Damascus. Police dispersed the rioters, mostly students, but not before they had pelted the embassy with rocks and rubbish.

There is as yet, though, little sign of a concerted Arab diplomatic initiative. Nor, for that matter, is the EU doing much more than issuing earnest appeals for calm. As usual, it is the Americans who are in the driving seat, and there is every chance that the hard decisions that are needed will be made not in Paris, Israel or Palestine, but in Washington.

There is also widespread alarm about the unprecedented surge of violence involving Israel's 1m Arab citizens, most of whom identify with the Palestinian cause, if not with Arafat's embryonic statelet. For the Americans, the ultimate nightmare is that the unrest will spill out of Israel and the territories and infect the wider Middle East region. Already Jordan - diplomatically closely allied to the USA and Israel - is seething with anger about the conflict on its doorstep, and has opened its borders to wounded Palestinians needing treatment. In Syria too anger has erupted on the streets, with a mob attack on the US embassy in Damascus. Police dispersed the rioters, mostly students, but not before they had pelted the embassy with rocks and rubbish. There is as yet, though, little sign of a concerted Arab diplomatic initiative. Nor, for that matter, is the EU doing much more than issuing earnest appeals for calm. As usual, it is the Americans who are in the driving seat, and there is every chance that the hard decisions that are needed will be made not in Paris, Israel or Palestine, but in Washington. webTitle: Why the BBC is gambling with news at 10

fields.headline: Why the BBC is gambling with news at 10
fields.standfirst:
Insiders fear governors may have signed their professional death warrants with move of the main nightly bulletin within two weeks
Sissons hails 'bold move'
fields.trailText: Insiders fear governors may have signed their professional death warrants with move of the main nightly bulletin within two weeks, writes David Teather.
fields.body:
If the cost cutting and job losses had not already made it plain to employees of the BBC that its new director general hailed from a commercial background, then the move of its main nightly news bulletin to 10pm certainly did.

The manner of the announcement to steal ITV's thunder and reschedule the news within two weeks smacked of someone whose tactics had been battle hardened in the trenches of commercial television. The trouble is that if the director general, Greg Dyke, wants to play by commercial rules, he may find commercial rules foisted back upon him.

Little more than a week ago the culture secretary, Chris Smith, had urged the BBC to think again about moving its main nightly news to 10pm. Going head-to-head with ITV made no sense, he argued, and threatened to create a "democratic deficit" of viewers.

Yesterday's announcement that the BBC planned to do just that provoked a furious reaction from Mr Smith who again expressed severe misgivings. While admitting he has no power over the schedule, he in effect put the BBC governors on notice to watch for any slip in quality or viewer numbers. The nightly Nine O'Clock News attracts around 5.2m viewers.

The immediate reaction from insiders yesterday was that the governors who rule what the BBC can and cannot do may have just signed their professional death warrants. The BBC's freedom to shift its news output without consultation could not be more different to the situation at ITV, which has battled with regulators for the past two years before being forced to reinstate News at Ten.

With the communications white paper being put together at present, some may have counselled the governors to resist raising the hackles of the culture secretary.

One of the options for the paper is to abolish the board of governors or at least to limit their powers and bring the BBC under the same regulatory regime as everyone else. If that is the case, the corporation's new found nimbleness may not last.

To prove it is fulfilling its public service remit by shifting the news, the BBC has to engage in a difficult balancing act.

The corporation argues that a 10pm slot for the main nightly news makes powerful sense editorially. "It allows the BBC to provide better coverage of parliamentary votes and the business markets as well as breaking stories in America which, with a US general election coming, will be vital to our international coverage," said BBC chairman Sir Christopher Bland.

He maintained that the viewing figures for the main news programme would rise by moving it to 10pm.

At the same time, Mr Dyke presented the move as being in line with the BBC's ambition of creating a portfolio of channels for the digital age, including the introduction of the new BBC's 3 and 4.

The aim is to make BBC1 a broad based entertainment channel and shunting the main bulletin to a later time slot will clear space.

The BBC hopes to fill the 9pm slot with new drama, comedy and factual programming which will be funded by an extra £95m investment to improve the quality of the corporation's main two channels.

That too will not be easy. The BBC's inability to release its first schedule yesterday was taken as a clue that programme makers are not ready for the shift in the news - down to the practical problem of most dramas being 50 minutes long.

ITV found it difficult to produce a strong slate of programming for the post 10pm slot left vacant by its own news programme.

Critics seized on yesterday's move as evidence that the BBC is dumbing down by marginalising its news coverage. Panorama, the corporation's flagship current affairs programme, is at least staying put on BBC1, although the move to Sunday night will attract adverse comment.

Last month's fudged agreement between ITV and its regulator, the Independent Television Commission, played into the BBC's hands however and its insistence that it remains committed to serious news coverage.

Sir Christopher was quick to make capital of the compromise which means the ITV nightly news will appear at 10pm for only three nights a week.

The BBC's main evening news will run six nights a week at 10pm including a new truncated Sunday programme. "Serious news must have scheduling certainty," Sir Christopher said.

His dismissal of Mr Smith's comments yesterday, though, may come back to haunt him. He said: "Chris Smith is a licence fee payer and therefore entitled to his view.

"But it is not in the jurisdiction of the secretary of state to schedule the BBC's news service." It could be soon.

Mix One-third international coverage

Frequency Six nights a week

webTitle: Peter Sissons hails BBC news move

fields.headline: Sissons hails 10pm news as 'bold move'
fields.standfirst:
BBC1 scheduling changes
Full reports on 10pm News
fields.trailText: 1.15pm: Peter Sissons, one half of the team that will present the BBC's Ten O'Clock News, said yesterday that the presenting team was "raring to go", writes David Teather.
fields.body:
Peter Sissons, one half of the team that will present the BBC's Ten O'Clock News, said yesterday that the presenting team was "raring to go".

Mr Sissons described the corporation's decision to move the main nightly news bulletin to 10pm in less than two weeks' time as a "bold move".

"This is a terrific vote of confidence in the Nine O'Clock News team. Everyone is buoyant and raring to go. This is what we were all waiting to hear," he said.

"Anyone who has ever worked on a 10pm news programme will tell you that this is a better time. For those who think they are losing a national institution I would say watch the 10pm programme. There is a hunger for news at that time and people will get a better programme."

The presenter also shrugged off any concerns about going head-to-head with ITV's nightly news bulletin, which is likely to be fronted by Trevor McDonald. "We are going head-to-head with a pale imitation of News at Ten," he said.

Mr Sissons' sentiments though have not been echoed by staff at Panorama, who have expressed private concerns about the shift of the BBC's flagship current affairs programme to Sunday evenings. Critics have seized on the decision combined with the move of the main nightly news bulletin as evidence that the BBC is marginalising its news coverage.

fields.headline: Daddy's home to stay
fields.standfirst: Labour MP Alistair Darling has hinted that he may step down to spend more time with his children. But will they benefit?  Richard McClure  reports
fields.trailText: Labour MP Alistair Darling has hinted that he may step down to spend more time with his children. But will they benefit? Richard McClure reports
fields.body:
When social security secretary Alistair Darling admitted last week that he was considering his cabinet position due to the "wrench" of leaving his children in Edinburgh to work every week in Whitehall, history was made in the House. This, surely, was this the first time a politician was planning to "spend more time with my family" without using the phrase as a euphemism for scandal or sacking.

"It's an increasing problem," moaned Darling, in a surprisingly candid interview for the New Statesman. "The only solution is for me to stop what I'm doing."

This week it is the turn of Sir Trevor McDonald to stake a claim to new dad-hood. Apparently, the ITN anchorman is now so enjoying spending time with his 11-year-old son Jamie that he is reluctant to give up the "precious" evenings freed up since he started hosting the 6.30 evening news slot. It will take some wooing by TV executives, apparently, to lure Sir Trevor back to the News at Ten when the bulletin is relaunched next year.

But the cabinet minister's announcement raised interest for another reason: the advanced ages of the Darling bairns. At 12 and nine respectively, Calum and Anna are hardly babes in arms, and by his own admission there is doubt as to whether they would actually welcome their 46-year-old dad's sudden desire to be a man about the house. Darling wants to spend more time with his kids - but do they want to spend more time with him? At a time when a child's image of its father can switch from superhero to source of embarrassment, his increased presence might simply drive them deeper into their bedrooms.

Besides, according to many child development experts, it would seem that Darling has missed the boat. Parental contact, we're told, is at its most vital during a child's early years. The need diminishes with the growing acquisition of confidence and independence. In the latest book on the topic, Love, Laughter and Parenting, Steve Biddulph has teamed up with wife Shaaron to harmonise on the traditional theme that the most important time in a child's life is from birth to six. "We call these the 'precious years' because the foundations of trust and confidence are being laid down that will affect all the years to come," the couple writes. "Your child will never need you as much as during these tender and dependent times."

But is this necessarily the case? Steve Carr, a screenwriter who sold his casting agency business to work from home and raise his two daughters, believes not. "It wasn't until my eldest had started school that I decided to change my working patterns," he says. "Selfishly, I felt I was missing out - her character was really taking shape - but I also realised the pre-teenage years would be critical for Nancy."

When Nancy, now eight, was recently upset by changing schools, her father was there to offer sympathy and support. "Instead of hearing about her worries second-hand from my wife, I was around at home to help her settle in," says Carr. "Kids need fathers at this age as much as at any other. My own father was never around. I want my daughters to know their father, for good or ill."

His instincts have been borne out by a forthcoming research paper collated at Lancaster University. Detailing the academic evidence for why fathers matter, the paper discovers real benefits for older children who have close contact with their dads. According to this research, the greater a father's involvement between the ages of seven and 11, the better the child's educational qualifications at 16 and the smaller the chance of a criminal record at 21.

"Adolescence is when any problems of early child-rearing come home to roost," says Jack O'Sullivan, co-founder of Fathers Direct, the national information service for fathers, which commissioned the paper. "It is vital before children reach that age that the father is really involved, otherwise, come adolescence, he can expect to have little positive impact."

For fathers themselves, these pre-teen years are often the most rewarding. Many men of Darling's generation share his view that their early absence from child-rearing doesn't matter because "when they are babies they don't actually notice". For others, feelings of uselessness or jealousy - common during the first few years - can disappear with the onset of conversation and shared activities. Full-time father Paul Doherty, who gave up his job as a magazine designer after the birth of his daughter Jasmine, now nine, admits that he gains more enjoyment from her company as she grows older.

"I disagree that dads can afford to skip the baby years, but at this age, there's a lot of pleasure to be had just by talking to Jasmine and helping out with her projects," he says. "She's currently trying for her cookery badge with the Brownies so we spent yesterday buying ingredients to make fruit salad. This week, she's getting her meningitis jab, so I'll be there to reassure her.

"Obviously, these days she has plenty of friends and can be left to her own devices but, in a different way, she needs me as much now as when she was a baby."

Why, then, are these years so disregarded by child psychologists? Blame Freud, says Mary MacLeod, chief executive of the National Family and Parenting Institute.

"The years from nine to 11 are are actually a period of great curiosity and independence - especially with the move to secondary school and the fact that adolescence is starting earlier," she explains. "But less attention is paid to this age group, partly because in psychoanalytic terms these are the 'latency' years, when nothing very interesting is supposed to happen. Certainly in terms of policy provision, these in-between years are more neglected than the early and teenage years."

A case in point is last year's adoption of the European directive which grants 13 weeks of unpaid leave per parent during the first five years of a child's life, a policy measure which ignores the significance of ensuing years altogether. Similarly, the Government's recent paternity-leave proposals appear to imply that a father is only really needed in the first two weeks following birth.

"Ideally, we'd like to see reasonable leave provision throughout the pre-teen years in case parents need to deal with emergency issues such as bullying or truancy," says MacLeod, who hopes parental leave will one day be extended until a child's 16th birthday. "The work-life balance must be flexible enough to allow fathers to be with their children at times of most need."

With our culture of working long hours and a value system that places a premium on career above family life, there is little chance of that yet. Nor, with just 15% of men enjoying flexible working patterns, is it likely that Alistair Darling's mooted downshifting will set a compelling precedent. Worst of all, according to Professor Charlie Lewis, even if more men were to "do a Darling", there would be still no guarantee that society would notice the benefit.

"Sure, there'll be positive effects from someone like Alistair Darling spending more time with his kids," says Lewis, one of the UK's leading experts on fatherhood. "But, in fact, most children brought up in a single-mother or lesbian family are indistinguishable from those from two-parent households - a child's development may actually be more influenced by its peers. Fathers are not indispensable and if Darling thinks his new influence will be a magic ingredient, there may be trouble ahead."

fields.headline: Go on, have a biscuit
fields.standfirst: Are we over-obsessed with making sure our children eat healthily? There's nothing wrong with a little bit of chocolate, says  Anne Karpf
fields.trailText: Are we over-obsessed with making sure our children eat healthily? There's nothing wrong with a little bit of chocolate, says Anne Karpf
fields.body:
I am a lapsed food purist, an ex-paragon, and last week's article by Joanna Blythman on parents and sugar induced in me such a rage that only a new dark chocolate Mars bar could assuage it.

Blythman exhorted parents to banish biscuits, honey and even fruit juices from their children's diets. There's nothing she can urge that I haven't done. Neither of my two children ever tasted a molecule of non-homemade baby food. Visitors marvelled at the way my first child downed a plate of spinach. For her second birthday, I baked a sugar-free cake (carob, naturally) so weighted with healthy nutrients that it could have caused serious injury, if hurled. A friend said it wasn't a cake but a statement.

Nine years later and I chuckle at the Waitrose checkout, that place where shoppers furtively scrutinise each other's trollies for signs of wealth, greed and loneliness. Mine overflows with as much organic greenery as I can afford - and equal quantities of chocolate. (Why do they call large packs "family" size, as if no single individual could ever consume so much? And why do they carry such laughably distant use-by dates, as though anyone could actually keep those mini-sized packets of Maltesers for a year?)

My metamorphosis was clinched by two events: my first child starting school, and the birth of my second. School marked the end of the grated-carrot stage of our lives. Never mind that she mainly had packed lunches, food is a social experience: surrounded by children who would only eat fish fingers and pasta without sauce, her own tastes began to migrate towards theirs. Kids want to be like their peers.

When her sibling arrived, I also found myself short of that most essential commodity: time. At first, I tried to make interesting meals while also puréeing baby food, but as my creations were increasingly rejected with an apologetic "Sorry, but I don't like it", we soon found ourselves going the pasta route.

As a sociologist as well as a mother, I began to admit personally that which I had always known theoretically - food choice in the real world is a complex issue. What people eat is influenced by more than just nutrition, and is integrally connected with class, history and culture.

Money is also critical, since fresh fruit and vegetables are expensive, and not always easily available to car-less parents reliant on local shops. Blythman has been a pioneer in helping us understand how food production has been industrialised, with health being a low priority, so it was curious that this article placed the onus of children eating healthily almost entirely on individual parents. You need to be a well-informed, demon label-reader with infinite energy to live up to that responsibility.

We ignore at our peril the psychological dimensions of food. Those parents who placate their complaining children with cakes are often feeding their deprived-child selves. Tolerating their children's fillings is easier for some than tolerating their children's unhappiness or frustration.

Dividing foods into good or bad, and struggling to ensure that the latter doesn't contaminate the former, is symptomatic of what psychoanalysts call "splitting". Like 50s cold-warriors, we see the risk of invasion from aliens all around. Only now we fear Mars bars instead of martians. Sugar is the new communism.

Of course, I'm not a total revisionist. No turkey dinosaur has ever waddled into my home. I'm aspartame-wise, anti-GM and thrilled that my children hate fizzy drinks. This summer - spontaneously (well, almost) - they discovered green salad, and my 11-year-old now makes a mean vinaigrette.

But I've also recognised that children want some control over their own food, and my interventions near-as-damn-it made mealtimes into a battleground. So now I give them chocolate-chip cookies when they come home from school.

When we first have children, most of us are terrified that every single experience will have a major impact on their life. As they grow older, we realise that this isn't the case. So it is with food. If most of their eating is reasonably healthy, a few Jammy Dodgers aren't going to pollute them. Besides, I don't want to have to hide my own chocolate wrappers.

And why do they carry such laughably distant use-by dates, as though anyone could actually keep those mini-sized packets of Maltesers for a year?) My metamorphosis was clinched by two events: my first child starting school, and the birth of my second. School marked the end of the grated-carrot stage of our lives. Never mind that she mainly had packed lunches, food is a social experience: surrounded by children who would only eat fish fingers and pasta without sauce, her own tastes began to migrate towards theirs. Kids want to be like their peers. When her sibling arrived, I also found myself short of that most essential commodity: time. At first, I tried to make interesting meals while also puréeing baby food, but as my creations were increasingly rejected with an apologetic "Sorry, but I don't like it", we soon found ourselves going the pasta route. As a sociologist as well as a mother, I began to admit personally that which I had always known theoretically - food choice in the real world is a complex issue. What people eat is influenced by more than just nutrition, and is integrally connected with class, history and culture. Money is also critical, since fresh fruit and vegetables are expensive, and not always easily available to car-less parents reliant on local shops. Blythman has been a pioneer in helping us understand how food production has been industrialised, with health being a low priority, so it was curious that this article placed the onus of children eating healthily almost entirely on individual parents. You need to be a well-informed, demon label-reader with infinite energy to live up to that responsibility. We ignore at our peril the psychological dimensions of food. Those parents who placate their complaining children with cakes are often feeding their deprived-child selves. Tolerating their children's fillings is easier for some than tolerating their children's unhappiness or frustration. Dividing foods into good or bad, and struggling to ensure that the latter doesn't contaminate the former, is symptomatic of what psychoanalysts call "splitting". Like 50s cold-warriors, we see the risk of invasion from aliens all around. Only now we fear Mars bars instead of martians. Sugar is the new communism. Of course, I'm not a total revisionist. No turkey dinosaur has ever waddled into my home. I'm aspartame-wise, anti-GM and thrilled that my children hate fizzy drinks. This summer - spontaneously (well, almost) - they discovered green salad, and my 11-year-old now makes a mean vinaigrette. But I've also recognised that children want some control over their own food, and my interventions near-as-damn-it made mealtimes into a battleground. So now I give them chocolate-chip cookies when they come home from school. When we first have children, most of us are terrified that every single experience will have a major impact on their life. As they grow older, we realise that this isn't the case. So it is with food. If most of their eating is reasonably healthy, a few Jammy Dodgers aren't going to pollute them. Besides, I don't want to have to hide my own chocolate wrappers.

fields.headline: The panel
fields.standfirst: The Question: Prince Charles says he's 'always chipping in' to help Prince William pay his bills. Are you ever too old to expect financial help from your parents?
fields.trailText: The Question: Prince Charles says he's 'always chipping in' to help Prince William pay his bills. Are you ever too old to expect financial help from your parents?
fields.body:
Dirk Flower Psychologist

Becoming financially independent is a developmental milestone in the progression of life. In our society, it's expected that our offspring will reach financial independence when they leave full-time education. What's important is that you're not depending on your parents at a time when most of your contemporaries are independent themselves - that's not good from a self-esteem point of view. In the broader context, emotional independence - ie, being able to make decisions yourself without relying on your parents - is the more crucial and significant issue.

Verdict: Yes

Dr Mark Hamilton Agony uncle for Radio 1 and BBC Essentials website

Weaning yourself off your parents' financial support has got to be a gradual thing. Most young people will need help from their parents at least until they're out of full-time education, and probably for a while beyond. It's important that you have experience of managing a budget, even if it's just pocket money, by the age of 16. If your parents are always bailing you out, you don't learn how to look after your money. I think it's OK even for 40-year-olds to go on being helped out - as a parent, you've got to think it's your own future as well as theirs.

Verdict: No

Owain James President of the National Union of Students

In an ideal world, I'd like to see young people becoming financially independent of their parents at 18 and recognised as such. There's no point being given legal independence if you aren't on your own feet financially. At the moment parents are expected to be responsible for young people in full-time education until they are 22 or 23, and some either can't or won't shell out. What's more, there's no safety net because students aren't eligible for benefits. That means some students have to drop out because they can't get the financial help they're dependent on from their parents.

Verdict: Yes

Michele Elliott Director of Kidscape, author of 501 Ways to be a Good Parent

In an emergency you're never too old to expect your parents' help. I think it would be very hard-hearted parents who wouldn't chip in if they saw their offspring facing some genuine need they hadn't anticipated, provided they were in a position to help. But I do mean emergency - I don't mean being sponged off for holidays, CDs and pizzas. It's the same when they're older. It's difficult when they're in their late teens and studying when they phone you up to borrow money. It's hard to do, but I say, "No, but you can come over for a meal if you're starving."

Verdict: Yes

Daphne Metland Mother of 20-year-old Sam and 16-year-old Caitlin

The vital element here is need: does your child really need financial help, and is it for something valuable and worth paying for? Sam is at university, so he has a loan and works in the holidays, but he still ends up with an overdraft. We pitch in because we don't want him to be up to his neck in debt by the time he graduates. I'd expect him to go on needing our help over the next three to four years, but then perhaps there will be a pause when he's self-sufficient for a while. Then I expect we'll need to provide financial support again when he has a family of his own.

Verdict: No
