fields.headline: Never say never
fields.standfirst: New evidence indicates that older women may be jeopardising the health of their children by leaving motherhood late. Nonsense, says  Maureen Freely
fields.trailText: New evidence indicates that older women may be jeopardising the health of their children by leaving motherhood late. Nonsense, says Maureen Freely
fields.body:
What's the most important thing to bear in mind when you're planning a family? Outside in the real world of uncertain marriages, unforgiving bank managers and inflexible employers, most people would say money, a stable relationship or emotional maturity. But when it comes to the comedians leading the debate about the "proper" way to become a parent, the single most important factor seems to be timing. Don't be too early or too late is the popular refrain. It may seem terribly old-fashioned and simplistic, but thanks to the world of science there is a growing mountain of studies that would seem to support it.

No one gets too upset about new research pointing to the dangers of teenage pregnancy, but it is a different story when it comes to studies casting doubts on late motherhood. Although the conception rate for women between 35 and 39 has gone up by 82% since 1976, it remains a controversial choice. This may explain why the tiniest cloud wafting out of the remotest of research labs gets tabloid headlines.

Early last summer, for example, there was great interest expressed in a study published in the British Medical Journal by Professor Melbye of the Danish Epidemiology Science Centre in Copenhagen. His research showed that the chances of a woman carrying a wanted child to term decreases radically as she gets older. While the risk of a miscarriage is only 8% for women aged 22, it rises to 20% for women aged 35, 50% for women aged 42, and 84% for women aged 48.

In August, the same journal brought news of a study conducted in Oxford revealing that women who delayed starting their families were more likely to have children who develop diabetes. The authors suggested that older motherhood might explain the dramatic rise in childhood diabetes across the developed world. The newspapers were quick to give this hypothesis saturation coverage.

And so it was last week, when Nature magazine published a study by two doctors at the University of Missouri showing that mice who had their first litters as young adults had the healthiest offspring. Male pups born to early adolescent and middle-aged mothers were smaller at birth, entered puberty later, and had smaller reproductive organs. Although their female pups did better, they were more likely to produce low-birthweight babies than were females born of young adult mothers. According to Dr Frederick vom Saal and Dr Ming-Hseng Wang, this was because of differences in hormone levels in females in their early and late reproductive years.

"The Nature paper simply puts this on the radar screen as a factor to be considered," comments vom Saal. "Obviously, women late in their fertile lives who desire a child should not panic based on our data."

Nevertheless, the Daily Mail seized upon the research. "How Older Mothers Put Baby at Risk" proclaimed its headline. The article itself was so quick to link celebrity older mums such as Cherie Blair, Madonna, actress Patricia Hodge and former Bond girl Jane Seymour, with the dangerous new baby-harming trend that I had to read it twice before it dawned on me that we were dealing with an animal study.

As an older mother who has been reading veiled warnings about deferred motherhood for nearly two decades, I can't say this worried me. It's like static: annoying, but easy to block out. The study itself I find more alarming.

For one thing, it gives credence to one of the favourite notions of early 20th-century eugenics. This was that the weak, the puny and the degenerate affected the health and mental hygiene of not just their children, but also the generations that followed. It was this perceived link that led Hitler to the view that "undesirables" should be weeded out of the gene pool. If eugenics research went into decline after the war, it was because no one wanted to be branded a neo-Nazi. But eugenics is what the new reproductive technologies are all about. Scientists are quick to point out the difference between "positive eugenics" (helping to ensure that the babies we bring into the world are as healthy as possible) and "negative eugenics" (killing or sterilising the defective). However - as ethically-responsible scientists are only too aware - even the most people-friendly positive eugenics is still politically slippery. It all depends on who defines the meaning of the word "healthy".

The definition of health that emerges from this new study is narrow. Based on a population of mice living in laboratory conditions, it has limited relevance to humans who do not. Had it compared several groups of mice, living in a variety of conditions and following difference diets, the final picture would have been much harder to read.

It would probably have confirmed what other, less headline-grabbing research has shown time and again, that the main causes of low birth- weight are poor maternal health, malnutrition and poverty. To present research on maternal age outside this context might be fine for a community of scientists who are already aware of this established body of knowledge, but to do so when writing for a larger audience is misleading.

What bothers me the most about the new maternal age debate is its time frame. It focuses on gestation and the moment of birth, as though anything which happens after that is immaterial. Everyone knows that there is more to being a parent than that. But the media have not gone out of their way to highlight research showing that older motherhood may have benefits as well as risks.

According to Dr Julia Berryman, of the Leicester University Parenthood Research Group, older mothers tend to tire more easily, but there is no evidence that they are poorer parents. In fact, there is research that suggests their children have higher IQs than those of younger women. This may be explained by the fact that they invest more in their children: because they are older, they are likely to be wiser, more affluent and more settled than they might have been as young adults.

That said, she is keen to point out that for middle-aged women it is harder to conceive, there is a greater chance of miscarriage, and they're more likely to have complications during pregnancy. "But it's very much a swings and roundabouts situation," concludes Berryman. If a woman has got to her late 30s and is thinking of having children, and it makes sense psychologically and financially, then why not? "The bottom line has to be whether you're motivated, whether you want to have the child."

fields.headline: Network problem was temporary, says NTL
fields.trailText: 10am: NTL says it has sorted out a problem with its interactive TV services after customers were unable to receive email and internet services over the weekend, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
NTL says it has sorted out a problem with its interactive television services after between 200 and 300 customers were unable to receive email and internet services over the weekend.

But reports claim that the NTL helpdesk told callers the network had a "serious" problem.

A spokeswoman confirmed that the provider had a "temporary" problem with some switches, but said it had been sorted out.

The problem will represent a setback for NTL, which delayed the rollout of its interactive television service for over six months due to technological problems.

webTitle: BBC seeks public nod for £153m digital TV plan

fields.headline: BBC seeks public nod for £153m digital TV plan
fields.trailText: The BBC yesterday sought approval to spend an annual £153m of licence-fee payers' money on its range of new digital television channels and radio stations.
fields.body:
The BBC yesterday sought approval to spend an annual £153m of licence-fee payers' money on its range of new digital television channels and radio stations.

The corporation published a public consultation document on the issue - something it must do to gain approval to launch the services by culture secretary Chris Smith.

The plans, which were announced by BBC director-general Greg Dyke in August, include the launch of TV channels BBC3 and BBC4 and two services for children.

BBC3 will be born out of the existing digital service, BBC Choice, and will provide entertainment, comedy and drama aimed at the youth market. BBC4, a remodelled BBC Knowledge, will feature programming focused on the arts and culture.

The children's services, one for pre-school and the second for older children, will run on BBC3 and BBC4 during the day.

The corporation plans to spend £100m on digital TV channels in 2001 and £140m a year from 2002. A further £13m will be spent on radio.

"This is an exciting day for the BBC," said the chairman, Sir Christopher Bland. "It is not every day, indeed not every year, that we get to announce four new TV channels and five new radio stations."

Sir Christopher reiterated that the services would represent the limit to the BBC's ambitions in multi-channel TV and radio. "The BBC is very clear about its future and will continue to offer a distinctive, valuable alternative to commercial services."

He said the BBC services would help drive the take-up of digital TV beyond the estimated 70% of people who will eventually have pay-TV.

The new radio services outlined last week include a black music station, an Asian station and a service offering music and interviews for what the BBC terms "the post-Beatles" generation. There will also be a speech-based service featuring drama, comedy and readings and an enhanced 5Live for sports fans.

Sir Christopher dismissed criticisms that the corporation would be treading on the commercial sector's toes with some of the new services.

He said 80% of programming on the children's services, for instance, would be made in Britain - compared with 9% on the commercial pay-TV channels.

fields.headline: Dismissed Sun columnist to appeal
fields.trailText: Former Sun columnist Marina Hyde is understood to be appealing against her dismissal from the newspaper, writes Janine Gibson.
fields.body:
Former Sun columnist Marina Hyde is understood to be appealing against her dismissal from the newspaper.

Ms Hyde, who was dismissed for sending a large volume of emails to Mirror editor Piers Morgan, has engaged the legal firm of Mishcon de Reya to argue her case.

Friends of the ex-UK Confidential columnist said that Hyde had an excellent case for appeal and would not hesitate to take legal action for unfair dismissal.

She has not taken another job since being escorted from the Sun's offices in Wapping three weeks' ago.

webTitle: When caring ends in breaking down

fields.headline: No good goodbye
fields.standfirst: A lack of support when caring for her dying husband at home took  Catherine Venn to breaking point
fields.trailText: A lack of support when caring for her dying husband at home took Catherine Venn to breaking point
fields.body:
Last year was the most shocking and traumatic of my life. Out of the blue, my husband, Nick, father to my five-year-old daughter, Bethany, failed to come home one evening. He was eventually found collapsed in his van, and was later diagnosed with a secondary brain tumour.

Nick endured brain surgery and radiotherapy, but never had a moment's let-up before the next crisis hit. They found the primary cancer in his colon and operated again, but a few short weeks later they confirmed the tumours were back in his brain. By the end of the year, we were utterly exhausted and knew he had only a short time left to live. But the worst was yet to come - and some of the shocks were not just of natural causes, but concerned the care services available to us at home.

In December, it became clear that Nick needed somebody to be with him all night. He was very weak, and getting increasingly confused. He needed somebody to empty his colostomy bag (or he, the bed and the bedroom became the most indescribable mess) and give him his painkillers.

The first weekend we struggled through with the help of some really kind friends. Come Monday morning, in my naivety I was expecting the various statutory and voluntary agencies to come up with a package of help to provide regular night cover - an expectation which turned out to be unrealistic.

I was keeping a daily journal at this time, which was a lifeline. Here is an extract for that day: "Got a phone call at 2.30pm to say there's no night cover tonight, and very little available all week. Felt very abandoned and had a major cry. I had to tell poor Bethany to go away and leave me alone while I tried to sort some things out, and she wandered off to bed with her whole body drooping and sagging and her head hanging down ... I just do not know what on earth I'm supposed to do, and I can't believe that I'm just left."

We had been very impressed with the amount of support available to us up to this point, with people visiting to talk things over and a wonderfully helpful GP. But this was the crunch. All the services together could only provide cover for three - possibly four - nights a week, and nobody had any solution as to what was supposed to happen the other nights. I was even asked if I could not stay up with Nick at night, but I was already absolutely on my knees by the end of each day and nobody was available to sit with him during the next day to let me snatch some sleep. Neither could friends and relatives come and stay up all night if they had work the next day, or young children to look after.

Eventually, we survived because one of Nick's nieces happened to be made redundant and came down from her home town to stay with us for several nights at a time. It totally disrupted her young life (and not many young women of her age would have dealt with all the mess), and she had to tread very carefully to avoid losing her benefits.

In the new year, though, things got worse again. Nick's niece got a new job and had to leave us. Nick was much weaker, and constantly in danger of falling, while being very confused at times (he would regularly get up in the night looking for his bowl of breakfast cornflakes). And then he had a major epileptic fit. It was no longer safe to leave him alone at any time during the day or night. How was I supposed to manage now, with my young daughter to get to school (the car being the only means of getting her there, and no other pupils living anywhere near us)?

Again, it was a major shock. There was no scheduled daytime care available, even to cover my absence for half an hour at a time. So every day turned into a nightmare of tenuous, last-minute arrangements, relying on nervous elderly people, anybody I could possibly find to hand, who could come and sit with Nick and call an ambulance if needed. They certainly would not have been able to help him physically if he fell or got stuck anywhere - he was still a big and heavy man.

Social services insisted it was a matter for the NHS, while the health authority said it could not provide the regular input of help we needed. Here is another extract from my journal: "I just cried and cried with exhaustion and despair. Absolutely feeling that I am at the end of me, and wanting to crawl into a hole and stay there. And worried too that forcing myself to carry on all the time may in itself give me a breakdown. Wishing I could have a physical illness to just let me lie down and give up, so somebody else would have to take over. I simply can't carry on ... terrible struggle to make lunch ... just about managed to get through the evening. Bethany getting up and complaining of horrible pictures in her head and the walls of the room closing in on her."

Three weeks later, the day after social services finally got a package of help organised for us, Nick went to the hospice. I simply couldn't carry on. He died there a few days later. They found the primary cancer in his colon and operated again, but a few short weeks later they confirmed the tumours were back in his brain. webTitle: Court delays are ruining the Children Act's effectiveness

fields.headline: Slow pace of change
fields.standfirst: Court delays are ruining the Children Act's effectiveness
fields.trailText: Court delays are ruining the Children Act's effectiveness
fields.body:
Looking back at reports at the time - not only in the press, but in social work and legal journals - it is clear that the Children Act 1989 was seen as a sea change in the way we work with children, the start of a new era.

Childcare professionals who go back that far will remember the staff reorientation courses. We were going to have to work in a new way. We were going to have to stop looking to the courts to impose solutions. Parents, relatives and professionals were going to have to work together. Creative alternatives were going to have to be found.

And if cases did have to go to court, the court process was going to be quicker. Delay is harmful to children (it says so in the act) and the legal process was going to be speeded up to take account of children's developmental timescale (six months for a five-year-old is 10% of their life). "After the welfare principle, the need to avoid delay is one of the most important policies underlying the bill," as Lord Mackay of Clashfern, the then lord chancellor, put it.

Children should no longer be subjected to long, emotionally damaging waits in the uncertain limbo of temporary care, while courts ponderously deliberated their fate. A time scale of 12 weeks was generally agreed to be the target.

Sadly court delays have turned out to be one of the biggest problems of the post-Children Act era. Figures show that, by the end of 1996, children in England and Wales were on average waiting more than seven months for court decisions in care proceedings - more than twice the average wait immediately prior to the act. The problem was considerably worse in some areas of the country, just as it was in the higher courts which hear a significant minority of care cases (50 weeks on average in the county courts; 64 in the high court).

There seem to be several reasons for this. These include inadequate court time, poor case management by judges and a heavy use of "expert witnesses", with resulting long delays while reports are written and additional hearings fitted into packed diaries.

Another cause of delay is that more parties can be joined to proceedings, and many more issues can be argued about, under the act than under previous legislation. These issues include the precise details of the care plan.

This is fertile ground for participants who want to use delay as a tactical weapon - and perhaps also for those who would like to put off the agonising decision to separate a child from their parents. But it is not necessarily good news for children who have to wait months in temporary care without knowing where their future home will be.

Nor is it good news for social work agencies, who have to sink more money into the considerable costs of lengthy litigation, and consequently have less left over for the supportive and preventative services that the act was supposed to promote. A local authority's legal costs for a single case can easily run into tens of thousands of pounds.

Another likely cause of delay is the sheer volume of proceedings. It was hoped that the act would reduce them, but the number of care applications has risen. The annual total of care proceedings brought to court in England and Wales more than doubled between 1992 and 1998, while there has been a corresponding decline in the use of other orders that were supposed to provide alternatives to care. Care applications were about 40% of all public law applications under the act in 1998, as against less than 20% in 1992.

Whatever the intentions of the act, it has ushered in an era in which care proceedings have become more frequent, longer and more likely than before to result in an order that compulsorily removes children from parents. What one makes of that depends, of course, on what one thought of the original objective of deflecting practice away from compulsion and use of the courts. It has been argued that more care proceedings are a good thing because more children are being protected from mistreatment as a result - and even that long proceedings do not matter because cases get a thorough hearing. But while these are legitimate points of view, it cannot be denied that the current situation is not at all what the act intended.

Perhaps it is time for a re-think. Was it ever realistic to believe that we could have - and adequately resource - both a far more costly and elaborate court framework and a more community-based and preventative approach?

 Chris Beckett is a lecturer in social work at Anglia Polytechnic University, Cambridge, and a former social work team manager

Burton Mail 14.9.00 (SA Brookfield, Newton Solney)

Balanced diet A 20-stone trucker from Selby, North Yorkshire, carries a sack of potatoes in the passenger seat of his Robin Reliant three-wheeler to stop the car from tipping over.
News North West, 8.9.00 (Ian Fletcher, Manchester)

Money to burn A woman who hid £340 in a toaster at her home in Walmer, Kent, lost it all when her grandson came to stay and decided to make beans on toast.
Sunday Independent, 17.9.00 (Hetty Fletcher, Budleigh Salterton)

Twin target Council officers have ordered the demolition of a five foot-high playhouse, built for seven-year-old twins in the back garden of their home in Belsize Park, north-west London, because planning permission had not been sought.
Hampstead & Highgate Express, 15.9.00 (J Mackrell, London NW3)

Timely reminder A clockmaker from Halesowen, West Midlands, has bought a car registration plate that has the date of his wedding anniversary on it.
Halesowen News, 14.9.00 (St John Howell, Halesowen)

webTitle: Why companies are giving more to charities

fields.headline: A bit of give and take
fields.standfirst: Companies are giving more to charities but it's not just an act of generosity.  Alison Benjamin,   investigates
fields.trailText: Companies are giving more to charities but it's not just an act of generosity. Alison Benjamin investigates
fields.body:
Britain's largest companies are channelling more funds to voluntary and community organisations than ever before. Last year, some £310m was handed out by the 100 or so highest corporate donors, as against £275m the year before. However, the nature of their giving has changed strikingly, with a big shift from cash gifts to investment in cash and kind.

Take BT. Its £15m a year programme makes it one of the most consistent big givers. Yet charitable donations now account for less than 10% of its community budget, despite little change in the way the company distributes its money among education and employment projects, arts, environment and voluntary sector partnerships. Although the latter receives some £4m a year, the majority of that cash is not a donation.

Peter Thompson, BT's community operations manager, says: "The company has changed the way it accounts for its community spend and only money that supports staff giving, or time, through matched give-as-you-earn and staff awards is now classified as charitable donations." In other words the company expects a return on its "investment" in charity.

Scottish Power, the utility group which includes Manweb and Southern Water, contributed £6.1m to the community last year, of which just £600,000 was awarded to charities. Even its PowerPartners initiative, designed to raise £2m for six charities, including the Royal National Institute for the Blind, the Royal National Institute for Deaf People and Disability Scotland and Wales, is part community investment because it also engages the charities in helping improve the utility's services for special needs customers.

According to Paul Pagliari, Scottish Power human resources director, nobody is suggesting that the company should award these funds purely for altruistic reasons. "It is also a win-win situation for us as a business and reflects the strong links which we seek to establish with the communities in which we operate," he says.

The figures for company giving come from the annual survey by Corporate Citizen magazine. The totals include donations to charity, gifts of old equipment or furniture and a value attributed to the work time which employees spend volunteering or fundraising. Money or goods donated to non-charitable local causes, such as schools or economic development bodies, are also included.

Two of last year's top corporate donors, Lloyds TSB and Northern Rock, give for neither altruistic nor business reasons, however. Under terms dating back to when the Trustee Savings Bank became a plc, and updated when it merged with Lloyds, the four Lloyds TSB foundations are shareholders in the company and receive 1% of the group's pre-tax profits, averaged over three years, instead of a dividend on their shareholding. Last year, this amounted to a "donation" of £26.5m.

Similarly, when Northern Rock converted from a mutual to a bank in 1997, a foundation was established to receive 5% of the company's pre-tax profits - close on £10m in 1999. It is arguable whether both privatisations could have gone ahead without such arrangements.

The upward trend in corporate giving is in many ways a reflection of better calculation, rather than a sudden attack of generosity. Scottish Power is one of a number of companies using more sophisticated methods to measure community investment. Five years ago, the only way corporate citizen could gauge the sector's community support was to add together the charitable donations in companies' annual reports. Now, more than 50 top givers put a figure on their much larger community contributions.

The headline increase also masks a decrease by some of the leaders in the field. British Airways has cut its community budget following a nose-dive in profits. Yet despite the reduction, its £5.7m worldwide community budget outstripped the airline's pre-tax profits for 1999-2000. The reason for this anomaly is that the community budget was set the previous year when profits were far healthier.

Luc Vandevelde, chairman of Marks & Spencer, told a packed shareholders' meeting in July that the flagging company was reducing the £14.1m it contributes to good causes. Last year its donations fell by a quarter. For 2000, the company has a £7.3m budget - a 48% drop. "We can't maintain current spend if profits are much less, but what is important is that we are committed to investing more than 1% of pre-tax profits in the community," says Leris Harefield, M&S community involvement spokeswoman.

It is not just falling profits that jeopardise fragile community budgets. NatWest's £15.4m community spend is up in the air following its takeover by the Royal Bank of Scotland. And United Biscuits (UB), now owned by Final Realm, has halved its contributions to £750,000 and slashed charitable donations by more than 80% to just £125,000.

For the record, UB denies that the buyout or the departure of its chief executive, Eric Nicoli, have any thing to do with its decision to ditch a commitment to contribute 1% of pre-tax profits to the community. But the fact that Nicoli, now at EMI, continues to chair the PerCent Club - a 200 strong group of companies promoting this 1% benchmark - would suggest otherwise.

According to Alan Coutes, UB's director of community affairs, the company has pared down those areas where it sees no direct business benefit from its spend. Its new focus, like a number of companies, puts the onus on employees to donate to charity. In business speak, this approach "empowers" staff to raise money, or volunteer, for the cause they support and in turn feel motivated about the company they work for.

Given such volatility of company giving, charities should not lose a proper perspective on its relative importance. In 1999, according to the National Council for Voluntary Organisations, the corporate sector provided just 4.5% of voluntary sector income.

 Alison Benjamin is editor of Corporate Citizen magazine, published by the Directory of Social Change. For subscriptions phone 020-7209 5151

webTitle: Do medical press editors need someone to watch over them?

fields.headline: Guarded words
fields.standfirst: Do medical press editors need someone to watch over them?  Alison Tonks calls for recruits to a BMJ ethics committe
fields.trailText: Do medical press editors need someone to watch over them? Alison Tonks calls for recruits to a BMJ ethics committe
fields.body:
Day after day, manuscripts reporting medical research pour into the offices of medical journals. The British Medical Journal (BMJ) alone processes more than 6,000 a year. Most submissions are eventually published in one journal or another, and their findings join the body of medical evidence that doctors and patients use to make critical decisions about health.

It is an editor's job to pick the best and reject the rest, but what happens when one of "the rest" outlines a dangerous experiment that should never have been done, or a case that looks like medical negligence, or a piece of research so unsound that the results will be no use to anyone?

The decision not to publish is straightforward enough, but there is a growing consensus that an editor's responsibility does not end there. Patients have wasted their time or, worse, may been harmed. Public funds may have been squandered and an opportunity to do more worthwhile research has been lost.

Exactly what editors should do when they suspect wrongdoing, poor judgment, bad medicine or bad science is still an open question. To help them answer it, my colleagues and I at the BMJ have decided to appoint an ethics committee - the first of its kind. This independent group will include people who conduct research, treat patients and interpret the law. In addition, there should be some professional ethicists, with openings for lay members.

The committee will be looking critically at everything the journal does, reviewing our existing policies and developing new ones. We still have no formal policy for dealing with whistleblowers, for example, despite being an obvious point of contact for doctors and others with grievances. Perhaps we should.

Editors of medical journals live in a morally complex world where vested interests can subvert almost every stage of a study's journey from a researcher's brain to a printed, visible paper. Politicians, researchers, the drugs industry and the journals themselves have competing agendas, and it can be difficult to hear the patient's voice above the noise.

A culture of "publish or perish" is one well-known example. Publication is a numbers game that doctors in training, as well as established academics, must play. It is one of the most powerful forces shaping medical literature. There are few things more impressive to an appointments committee than a lengthy list of publications, regardless of quality or content.

Misdemeanours that result from this pressure include splitting a research paper into its "least publishable units" and sending each one to a different journal; publishing the same paper twice by manipulating the data to look different; and including in a paper's list of authors people whose only contribution was to buy the real authors a pint and promise to return the favour next time they write something up.

Suspect manuscripts are only half the problem. Peer review, a legacy system of unpaid experts passing judgment on each other's work, is also vulnerable to human weaknesses such as arrogance, envy and naked ambition. For many journals, it is the reviewers who decide what is published - and not all journals insist on full disclosure of competing interests. The BMJ requires reviewers to be open about their financial affairs and affiliations, but how should the editors deal with reviewers who insist that their portfolio of shares in leading drug companies does not affect their judgment on related research? It would be easy to use other reviewers instead, but should the shareholder and his subconscious biases be left at large for other journals to worry about?

Mike Farthing, editor of Gut, the leading gastroenterology journal, and chairman of the committee on publication ethics, thinks all this matters very much indeed. He has declared that distortions in medical literature are as damaging to public health as unclean water or a badly regulated food industry.

Duplicate and redundant publications gum up the works, making an already chaotic literature even harder to navigate and therefore less useful.

Imagine trying to find out which drug works best in psychoses, such as schizophrenia, when the data from a handful of clinical trials testing a new drug appear in various disguises, in several journals, none of which is cross-referenced.

Reviewers or editors who fail to own up to competing interests, or think they are above all that, add yet more bias to a research effort already knocked out of shape.

An ethics committee will help us think harder about the public health impact of what we do - and you may be able to help. If you think you could serve as a lay member of the BMJ's ethics committee, please get in touch before next Monday.

 Alison Tonks is an assistant editor of the BMJ. She can be contacted at atonks@bmj.com or on 020-7387 4499

fields.headline: Eco soundings
fields.trailText: The aftermath of anti-globalisation protests in Prague
fields.body:
Collared in Prague

Around 1,000 people are now believed to have been arrested as a result of S26, last Tuesday's anti-globalisation demonstration in Prague which coincided with the IMF/World Bank annual meeting. Only six have been charged according to police and independent reports, including two Czechs, two Austrians and two Spanish. Legal observers say over half the arrestees were Czechs, despite prime minister Milos Zeman's claim that "most are foreigners who came to enjoy the beer".

Many of the foreigners arrested were taken to detention centres outside Prague to await deportation. Around 200 are believed to have been released so far - 34 of them British - and sent over the border into Germany. Inpeg, the Initiative Against Economic Globalisation, says it has received various reports of "abhorrent conditions and mass human rights violations". Of 44 people surveyed on their release, almost all said they were not read their rights, 38% say they were beaten, a third strip-searched, and three-quarters were denied food and sleep. The Czech police say they are unable to investigate until official complaints are made, but a spokeswoman angrily dismissed the allegations. "We are not the Ukraine," she said. Meanwhile a political row has broken out after Miroslav Macek, the deputy head of the Civic Democratic opposition party, chided the police for "not responding with their guns".

Cool under fire

Very un-pc, but how did the massed groups of European NGOs, ecologists, anarchists, unions and others conduct themselves in Prague? Eco soundings convened a group of international protest watchers to compile the first Euro-protest league table. The judges took into account dress, comportment on marches, ability to get up before 11am, entry and exit into Prague, tactics, number of arrests, quality of slogans and graffiti, originality of tactics, theatricality, political commitment, intellectual content, coolness under water cannon fire, comportment in prison, use of irony and ability to work with other countries.

fields.headline: Lots of promise, but little remedy
fields.standfirst: Bob Holman, community worker and author, on the future of community groups
fields.trailText: Bob Holman, community worker and author, on the future of community groups
fields.body:
In his July spending review, Gordon Brown announced he was putting aside £450m for preventative work, of which £70m over three years would be for a children's fund. Based on 50 networks in deprived areas, the fund would aim to improve the living standards of families, involve hard-to-reach groups and widen the experiences of poor children.

So far so good. But now the Treasury has released a letter which explains how the networks will be administered. My fear is that its approach will lessen the fund's impact. The 50 networks will each be run by a voluntary organisation "with strong experience in grant-giving in that region". Locally-controlled community projects do not possess this experience.

Allocation of the fund's grants looks likely to be placed with national or regional voluntary societies which do valuable work, but which are usually managed outside the deprived neighbourhoods. The danger is that, in making grants, they will favour bodies like themselves. The losers will be community projects with committees, staff and children who most understand local needs.

The explanatory letter states that "the aim of the local network is to empower communities, families and children". Yet, if the networks are dominated by large organisations, or the usual quango figures, then no empowerment will occur. Of course the networks will allocate some money to local projects, but this merely perpetuates the charity system of the privileged deciding what the deprived can do.

Whoever gets the money, the scale of the children's fund is too small. At its height, each network will have £800,000. The Treasury points out that "most grants are likely to be small, in the hundreds and low thousands of pounds".

This miserly approach perpetuates the myth that community projects require a few quid for a second-hand photocopier. In fact, they most need grants for salaries. Their staff are adept at running food co-ops which help families improve living standards; they are skilled at preventing youngsters from going into care. The Cedarwood Trust, in North Shields, Tyne and Wear, successfully helps low-income families. Its annual expenditure is about £140,000, mostly for salaries. It does not need a photocopier.

My proposal is that the 50 networks be under the control of representatives of the deprived areas. Equipped with the whole £450m, they should allocate money to projects which are genuinely controlled by residents. Such community projects are responsive to what low-income families and children want - the right children's fund.

fields.headline: Jewish roots in rock
fields.standfirst: Chris Arnot on how a social sciences professor turned his passion for music into a historical study
fields.trailText: Chris Arnot on how a social sciences professor turned his passion for music into a historical study
fields.body:
Back in 1960, Michael Billig was 13, living in Wandsworth, London, and doing what many British youngsters were doing after dark. He was trying to tune his new-fangled transistor radio to Radio Luxembourg which was transmitting exciting sounds from a more distant, infinitely bigger land across the Atlantic. On a clear night, between hisses and crackles, young Billig might be rewarded with a minute or so of pure, unadulterated Elvis.

By the time Radio One hit the airwaves seven years later, British rock bands dominated the charts. The Beatles and the Rolling Stones acknowledged their debt to early influences from black America. Indeed, the whole history of rock'n'roll has been portrayed as white artists "ripping off" black music. Only now has the major Jewish contribution been acknowledged.

For that we can thank Billig, who grew up to become professor of social sciences at Loughborough University. He would write books on Freud and fascism. He would become an expert on far-right ideology. Then he would write Rock 'n' Roll Jews, a labour of love which came about by chance.

He was compiling a tape of rock music for his daughter's bat mitzvah and, in keeping with the occasion, he concentrated on songs with Jewish composers. "To my surprise, song after well-known pop song, revealed itself to be 'Jewish music'," he writes, "from Presley to the softer sounds of the Drifters and Phil Spector. So much of the rebellious music which I had loved in my youth and which seemed to be a window into a foreign, dangerous world, turned out to be a product of familiar surroundings. Surprise was mingled with delight."

When those emotions had cooled, his analytical instincts took over. He began to investigate. Inevitably, his book concentrates on American society and the complex relationship between black and Jewish people which shaped popular entertainment in the 20th century. But there are resonances for society in Britain. After all, our two cultures were intertwined by the output of Hollywood and Tin Pan Alley even before Irving Berlin's White Christmas hit the shops.

It would become the biggest selling record of all time - a secular celebration of a Christian festival written by a man whose real name was Israel Baline. With the exception of Cole Porter, almost every writer of musicals in the pre-rock era was Jewish, even if their names sometimes suggested otherwise. Three decades later, Robert Zimmerman would change his name to Bob Dylan before fleeing to New York from a small town where Jews were still barred from the local country club.

"Anti-Semitism led to a fear of appearing too Jewish in public," says Billig. Only in the last two or three decades, it would seem, have those fears subsided. Back in 1964 Paul Simon and Art Garfunkel had to be persuaded by a black producer at Columbia Records not to change their names to something more gentile.

Jewish and black people were unwelcome on Wall Street for many years. So they looked to areas where there were fewer barriers. The so-called "race" labels, which played black rhythm and blues, proved profitable. "Unlike mainstream white businessmen, whose lack of imagination or fastidious prejudices kept them from doing business with black producers and customers, these Jews dealt successfully in this corner of the market," Billig says.

Jewish and black people had much in common. They were victims of prejudice and they lived close to one another. The young Jerry Leiber, one half of the successful Jewish songwriting team Leiber and Stoller, used to deliver coal to black families in his poor neighbourhood of Baltimore. It was the music emanating from their radios that inspired him. He and Mike Stoller were still in their teens when they wrote Hound Dog for a black blues singer called Willie Mae Thornton. It became rather better known when it was taken up by Elvis Presley.

The British public remained, for the most part, unaware of the complex racial divisions which made the US market so unpredictable. In 1966, for instance, Ike and Tina Turner's River Deep, Mountain High became a big hit in Britain. Yet in America it flopped, much to the astonishment of its Jewish producer, Phil Spector. Ike offered an intriguing explanation. The rhythm and blues stations in the US wouldn't play it, he claimed, because it sounded too white. To the white stations, though, Tina's voice sounded "too R and B". Too black, in other words.

Racial divisions were hardening again in the US, after a brief period when Spector's productions for groups including the Ronnettes, and Leiber and Stoller's songs for the Drifters and Coasters, found airtime on white as well as black stations. "There was a missed opportunity in the mid-60s," Billig says, "when Leiber and Stoller and Jerry Wexler [the Jewish producer who played a big part in creating soul music] set up their own record labels without taking any black people into economic partnership. As the 60s moved on, it became a matter of pride for black American youngsters to buy music by black artists." Motown fitted the bill by providing black artists, black writers and a black owner.

Today, the music market in Britain is fragmenting into niche markets as never before. But at least the stations are divided by taste - not race.

Early influences

British Jews in the early days of rock'n'roll tended to confine themselves to management. An exception was the singer Frankie Vaughan, (real name Abelson) who made hit records but belonged to the glitzier end of showbusiness - "uncool and delightfully dated in the age of rock", as Billig puts it in his book.

Certainly, Vaughan appealed more to the mature female fan than Billy Fury and Marty Wilde and other stars from the stable run by the Jewish Larry Parnes. All would become terminally uncool when the Beatles arrived, guided by their Jewish manager, Brian Epstein, and changed everything.

Some people of a certain age can trace their conversion to Beatlemania back to John Lennon's version of Twist and Shout, rasped out on a long-forgotten programme called Thank Your Lucky Stars during the bleak winter of 1963.

Few knew, or cared, that the song had previously been recorded by the black Isley Brothers. Fewer knew that it was written by one Bert Berns. Jewish, needless to say.

 Rock 'n' Roll Jews is published by Five Leaves at £7.99.

webTitle: Pheasants - the latest battle over hunting

fields.headline: Feathers are flying
fields.standfirst: Residents of a mid-Wales valley are fighting against the annual slaughter of pheasants, but shooters refuse to give ground.  Paul Evans  on the latest battle over hunting
fields.trailText: Residents of a mid-Wales valley are fighting against the annual slaughter of pheasants, but shooters refuse to give ground. Paul Evans on the latest battle over hunting
fields.body:
Pheasants: hundreds, perhaps thousands of them, tottering around the hillside, clucking their clockwork alarm call and flapping off in a pathetic attempt at wild pheasanthood. The pheasant shooting season began on October 1 and a hail of lead awaits these birds. But another storm surrounds them: pheasants have friends and resistance to the annual slaughter is under way.

Cwm mountain is a beautiful and enigmatic cluster of the Y Wenallt, Maes y castell and Gallt y Goedhwch hilltops rising 200 metres above the valley of Cwm Nant-y-meichiaid in mid-Wales. The young pheasants here have been intensively reared in a game farm, held in cages like free-range chickens then released on to the hill.

With its wooden lower slopes and open sheep-grazed tops, Cwm mountain is like many other hills nearby, but it has strange fenced patches of brassicas - kale, rape and turnip - some covering a couple of acres; feeding hoppers are dotted around; the woods conceal huge fenced enclosures and a new road for 4x4s is blazed across its face. The pheasant business has a profound impact on this ancient landscape, creating an eerie paranoia, broken only by barrages of gunfire when the shoot is on.

Although the odd bit of shooting has been practised here for years and there was a pre-war estate shoot on Cwm mountain, these pheasants are part of a new phenomenon. The social make-up of the countryside has changed dramatically over the last few decades and the acceptance of traditional field sports is being challenged.

The farmers who own the mountain and have sold or leased the shooting rights see it as a way of supplementing their income during troubled times. The majority of people who live around the mountain are against it. They, apart from a dry-stone waller, do not work on the land. They are teachers, artists, engineers and business people; quite a few are retired.

"It took 36 years in the Royal Navy to get this," says Kit Davidson, secretary of the Cwm Mountain Residents, standing outside his restored farmhouse where he and his wife have lived for the past two years. "When I started my objection to the pheasant shoot I was a Nimby," he admits, "but after a lot of research and exposure to the protest here I now object to sport shooting on welfare and environmental grounds everywhere. Now I'm an environmentalist".

The position of the protesters is tenuous. Some have lived here all their lives, some are recent incomers; they all want good relations with their neighbours but they all share a passion for this place, threatened by what they see as a cruel sport which they fear also puts them, their families and wildlife at risk. "Townie. Get back to the city where you came from. You English are all the same," yell a van load of beaters at an impromptu protest against a recent shoot.

This irony is not lost on the Cwm Mountain Residents who are protesting against the shooters coming out from English cities. A protester, Kath Morell, was warned off land she has walked on for many years by a gamekeeper. "He effed and blinded at me and said I should go back where I came from," Morell said, "but I've been a teacher in a local school for 30 years".

"We are saturated with pheasants and partridge, there are three times as many of them this year and the shooting goes on around the houses," says Tom Hughes, a Welsh-speaking retired headmaster and local historian. "I can't see the point, killing birds that have been artificially reared like this, it's disgusting."

So what is the point? The man behind the Cwm mountain shoot, and 30 others in the vicinity, is Christopher Williams. I ask Williams if I can accompany him on a shoot to find out what it is like but he refuses; because of adverse publicity the shooting syndicate he represents does not want a journalist around. He will not say who the members of the syndicate are, how many birds have been bred and released, or what kind of financial investments have been made.

Williams is not about to give away any commercial information and is worried that any information he gives will be seized on by the Cwm Mountain Residents. "They just want to stick the knife in," he complains. His shoots, which involve three syndicates, are not, Williams insists, about making money but about providing legitimate sport for friends.

Although protesters claim to have discovered carbon dioxide fire extinguishers at badger setts, Williams says nothing untoward is going on and claims the shoots provide employment and put money into the local economy. "Controlling vermin like crows, magpies, stoats and weasels maintains the balance in the countryside," he says. "All the major conservation organisations agree that shooting benefits wildlife, so there can be no environmental objection. We abide by the law and sportsman's rules and behave in the proper way." So what is the sport in killing these birds? "A sportsman shoots to kill cleanly," Williams explains, "but if killing is absolutely certain then the sportsman doesn't shoot, there has to be the element of doubt for it to be sporting".

The protest from the Cwm Mountain Residents is a new experience for Williams and, says a spokesman from the British Association for Shooting and Conservation, it is rare to have organised opposition like this anywhere in the country. There is a reluctance, even from environmental organisations, to take on the shooting lobby. Unlike fox hunting, pheasant shooting has not yet raised much public passion. This may be about to change.

The animal rights and anti-cruelty organisation Animal Aid has just launched a report (The Killing Fields: the pheasant shooting industry) and its devastating impact on "game" birds and British wildlife. This report claims that pheasant shooting is really a multi-million pound agribusiness which subjects millions of birds to the mutilations, disease and stress of intensive rearing. About 36 million pheasants are shot each year but a further 12 million suffer injuries and are never recovered. This also involves the killing of five million wild birds and mammals in so-called "vermin" control and often results in the death of protected species. About 75,000 metric tonnes of lead shot falls on the countryside each year.

Andrew Tyler, director of Animal Aid, says: "I don't believe the public has any idea of the scale and squalid nature of the modern pheasant industry and its devastating impact on the countryside. I commend the efforts of the Cwm Mountain Residents in their valiant battle to protect the ecology and tranquillity of their beautiful part of Britain."

webTitle: Why the oil companies stayed silent during the fuel crisis

fields.headline: Pump and circumstance
fields.standfirst: Why the oil companies stayed silent during the fuel crisis
fields.trailText: In the wake of the fuel crisis, there is increasing evidence that the oil industry colluded with protesters to cut the country's fuel supply. But why?
fields.body:
In the wake of the fuel crisis, there is increasing evidence that the oil industry colluded with protesters to cut the country's fuel supply. But why?

The answer lies in a story of machiavellian political manoeuvring. It is the story of how a group of multinationals can bring the government to its knees, and extract ever greater profits from the public finances. It's a story about tax, but not at the pump - it's about tax in the North Sea.

What happened during the last two days of the fuel crisis was a threat, a flexing of oil industry muscle in a strong warning to the government to leave the North Sea alone. The companies came close to showing they could bring down the government. And if Gordon Brown makes the wrong tax moves, they could try to go the whole way.

Much of today's tax on petrol originated in Norman Lamont's 1993 budget, when he increased petrol duty by 10%, and set up the "fuel duty escalator" which would increase duty by a further 3% above inflation each year. He also introduced the hugely unpopular VAT on domestic fuel.

The oil industry was quiet about these changes - perhaps because the same budget cut North Sea oil taxes. Lamont slashed petroleum revenue tax (PRT) from 75% to 50% on existing fields, and abolished it altogether for fields developed after the 1993 budget. This means new fields pay no royalties at all for oil extracted.

So it was two taxes for the consumer, and a cut for the corporates. This suited the big oil companies. The biggest winner was BP, whose share price immediately rose by 6.4%. Analysts said profits would be boosted annually by £130m to £140m. Shell would gain £40m.

But not all the oil companies were celebrating. Along with PRT Lamont also abolished the tax reliefs and allowances that had been keeping some smaller companies going.

The big oil companies made a killing on the North Sea changes. Profits are much higher in the "upstream" activities of oil exploration and production than in the "downstream" area of forecourt retailing. A rise in fuel duties therefore did not impact on company profitability, as it is mostly passed on to consumers.

In the past 10 years, North Sea oil industry operating profits have almost doubled from £7.5bn in 1988 to £13bn in 1999. But in the same period, government revenues dropped from £3bn to £2.5bn. The UK's North Sea has become the world's second cheapest oil-producing region after Ireland.

Yet things changed in 1997 as Brown, the new Labour chancellor, began exploring options for raising taxation in the North Sea. The subsequent lobbying campaign he faced was one of the biggest the country has ever seen. The might of the oil industry argued vigorously that given the technical unfavourability of the North Sea, and without fiscal advantages, the companies would have no choice but to pull out of the UK. They knew the government would not risk that outcome.

The real clinching argument was that oil prices were also at rock bottom, down to $8 a barrel. Then oil companies successfully argued that their low margins could not sustain an increase in tax. In September 1998, Brown announced that he would not change the tax regime, stating that oil prices were too low.

The industry campaign was, however, based on a lie. While all this was going on, a survey found that in two consecutive years, 1997 and 1998, Britain was the oil industry's favourite investment region, in no small part because of the tax regime.

It's not hard to see why. Oil reserves are legally the property of the crown. In most countries, companies which extract reserves pay the country for what they take away, through royalties and taxation. Yet in Britain, the only charge oil companies pay to the government is corporation tax, which they have to pay anyway. In other words, they take away the oil for free, and go on to sell it at a healthy profit.

But by 1999, two years later, oil prices had nearly quadrupled to more than $30 a barrel, presenting industry with a worry - their main anti-tax argument had fallen away. Brown, faced with growing public support for a cut in fuel duty, was looking for alternatives. The exchequer might try to recoup the revenue upstream from the oil companies to make up for a consumer tax cut.

When blockades began at Shell's Stanlow refinery in Cheshire, Shell could have had the protesters cleared in hours if it wanted to. Panic buying meant that fuel reserves were quickly depleted, catching oil companies, government and police on the hop. But the oil companies fast recognised how they could use the situation. All the key UK players - Esso, BP, Shell, TotalFinaElf and Texaco - have refineries in France which were blockaded. Their first-hand experience left them far more informed in dealing with the situation than protesters, police or the government.

At Britain's nine refineries some had significant protests. Others had fewer than than 20 protesters, not even blocking the road. One might have thought this would present an opportunity for some of the companies to take advantage of their competitors being out of action.

But in fact, all of the companies - whatever the size of the protests outside their gates, however aggressive or meek, however much pressure to supply, or sales to be made - came out with a remarkably uniform response: "We are concerned for the safety of our drivers."

It wasn't until Tuesday afternoon that the government began to realise that the companies were deliberately holding back their drivers. On Tuesday, Tony Blair personally contacted oil company chief executives, ordering them to restart supplies, which they didn't. The following day, the prime minister called company executives in, this time pleading.

At the Wednesday meeting, the companies' made a public statement and action was far weaker than Blair had demanded. The final restarting of supplies under police escort on Thursday morning was both reluctant and late. The damage to the government had been done.

With oil prices at a 10-year high, the North Sea is still ripe for the chancellor's picking. But clearly the oil companies are prepared for a fight.

 Greg Muttitt of Corporate Watch and James Marriott are researchers who have been studying the activities of the oil industry for the last five years

webTitle: TV show's 'satirical' treatment of mental health censured

fields.headline: Ticking off at 11 O'Clock
fields.standfirst: TV show's 'satirical' treatment of mental health censured
fields.trailText: TV show's 'satirical' treatment of mental health censured
fields.body:
The best television and radio treatment of mental illness will be celebrated later this month in the annual mental health media awards. But a ruling this week by the Broadcasting Standards Commission shows some programme makers have a long way to go.

The ruling, against cult Channel 4 programme The 11 O'Clock Show, also offers further evidence that some of those behind "challenging" content of both broadcast and written media appear to regard offensiveness as beyond criticism if it is presented in a supposedly ironic way.

The edition of The 11 O'Clock Show in question referred to "mentals sitting in their own shit and wanking". Complainants to the commission, including Greater London Action on Disability (Glad), said that the language used was going too far - even in the context of a spoof report broadcast late at night.

Last year, Channel 4 was also censured by the commission over complaints about Psychos, its controversial drama series set in a mental hospital. Groups such as Glad have expressed concern that a station known for its good record on equality for minorities has now twice caused offence in the area of mental health.

In its defence, Channel 4 said The 11 O'Clock Show was deliberately sharp and satirical. While it did not set out to cause offence, it could be risqué and provocative.

"From the outset," it said, "the series had established a voice of ironic irreverence, quintessentially defined by its use and distortion of social stereotyping."

The item in question had been an exaggerated caricature of a reporter's tabloid approach to that day's news, Channel 4 said. "In the item, the reporter displayed his ignorance in the way he talked about nurses and their patients and, although he made disparaging comments about mentally disabled [sic] patients, the joke was clearly on him and his ignorant stance."

In its ruling, which covers a number of complaints about The 11 O'Clock Show, the commission says that it accepts the series was satirical and aimed at a young adult audience. It rejects some complaints about the overall style of the programmes and jokes aimed at established figures, but goes on to uphold others about mental illness and a bullied child - saying it was "troubled" by the choice of such targets of satire.

"The commission considered there was a distinction to be drawn between enjoyable mockery and callous disregard for the sensitivity of some subjects, particularly one involving vulnerable groups," the ruling says. The series had "gone beyond acceptable boundaries by undermining basic human dignities".

The case is not the first in which purportedly liberal media have been upbraided for causing offence to people with mental health problems under the cloak of irony. Two years ago, the mental health charity Mind gave its "bigot of the year" award to Andrew Mosby, a columnist on the London listings magazine Time Out, for what was billed as a humorous piece about a bus journey in the capital.

"There are a huge number of nutters on London buses. Presumably they are put there as entertainment," the article said. "Give a schizophrenic a six-zone travelcard and an injection and just leave them at a bus stop."

Karen Mattison, director of training and support group Mental Health Media, which is organising the forthcoming best practice awards, says it is high time that self-styled satirists paused for thought. "Satire and irony are based on the fact that the majority of people understand you are not being serious, but public understanding of mental health problems is not yet at the level that it is clear that the type of thing in The 11 O'Clock Show is satire.

"While 'schizo', 'nutter', 'psycho' and so on are all still acceptable forms of abuse, and while many people still think that behind every diagnosis of mental illness is an axeman waiting to attack them, programme makers have to act with responsibility."

The mental health media awards, run in association with the Guardian, will be presented on October 24.

fields.headline: A man's world
fields.standfirst: The working men's club was always the heart of the community in industrial towns. Now they face a quiet revolution, as  Lynne Wallis  reports
fields.trailText: The working men's club was always the heart of the community in industrial towns. Now they face a quiet revolution, as Lynne Wallis reports
fields.body:
There is a no-smoking conservatory, complete with rattan wicker furniture and ideal for family lunches. There is a children's play area, acoustically insulated like all the other rooms, and the decor is fresh and bright throughout. Last year, it had a turnover of £250,000. Welcome to Calverton Miners' Welfare Club.

The working men's club is undergoing a quiet, if patchy, revolution. The more forward-looking clubs are realising they will not survive much longer by offering just discounted beer, a dart board and a stripper every other Friday night. Today's thriving clubs embrace karaoke, line dancing, live music, bingo, tea dances and sports. They are welcoming women and children and raising substantial sums for local good causes.

By no means all are doing so, however. Some clubs are determined to stick to what they know best - providing as much booze as a man can feasibly drink at the lowest posible cost - and some prejudices seem entrenched.

"What do you mean, what's it there for?" asks John Green, president of the Western Social Club in Middlesbrough, when quizzed on the subject of its men-only lounge. "So our members can get away from all those nagging women, of course."

The once grimy and windowless Calverton club, next to a disused colliery in a suburb of Nottingham, is now operated as both a limited company and charity, having had a total makeover. Viv Corcoran, who runs the club, is clearly a woman with aspirations.

Smartly dressed, the 46-year-old takes the club's modernisation very seriously. "The mine finally closed for good last year, so we're no longer about pulling pints to line up for men coming off shifts," Corcoran says. "We've had to make this a family club to survive; everything's so geared to family these days.

"Luckily we're not an area of high unemployment - lots of people work at the industrial park now - so there is money to spend. But we don't want to be known as the place for cheap beer. It's not enough."

Calverton is hoping for recognition in this month's "club of the year" awards, run by trade magazine Club Mirror. Some 300 clubs have applied for one of the sector's oscars. Calverton is aiming for "best promotion" for a youth tournament it hosts for a local football league. "Nine hundred boys play over a weekend, and their families wait in the bar which means good takings and £3,000 in entry fees for the league," says Corcoran.

Although the pit has gone and there is not much interest in colliery bands any more, Calverton is not about to change its name. "There's too much pride in the history," says Corcoran, "and too many former miners who drink here".

The United Irish Club in Cramlington, Northumberland, is also vying for a promotion award, but represents a rather different approach. "The Irish", as it is known locally, has the biggest barrelage of four local working mens' clubs, despite being the smallest. In other words, it sells the most beer.

Club stewardess Vickie Henderson is doing her best to keep the club full, with special deals like "15 drinks for £15" nights, with a comedian, vocalist and a pie and pea supper laid on. Although there is a late licence, entertainment has to finish by about 10pm. "When members have had a few in, they want to perform themselves, not watch and listen, so we put on a disco or the karaoke," Henderson says.

It is not an affluent area and there are no easy pickings for the club. "People round here haven't got much cash - there's a big elderly population and high unemployment - so I get the money for any special weekend events the previous Tuesday, when they get their income support," Henderson admits.

She has turned the club round over the past year by supplying what members want: cheap drink, pop quizzes, golf and fishing trips. To boost income, she hires a room every week to a computer club. Consequently, profits are up sufficiently for the club now to undergo total and much needed refurbishment. But Henderson is not allowed on the club's committee - it is a men-only body, apparently fearful that women committee members would want to turn the place into a bingo hall.

The Club & Institute Union (CIU) represents 3,000 clubs. Kevin Smyth, its general secretary, is not afraid to admit he believes that the movement has "a reduced future". He says: "There are too many clubs for a start, and they don't appeal to youngsters, although to be fair they never have. Some will close, undoubtedly, and those stuck in a time warp - the cloth cap brigade - need to change their act."

Smyth warns that clubs where racism and sexism is in evidence will have a high price to pay. "Lawsuits are what clubs need to think about because that is the reality for those who don't pay heed, although most comedians will still drop in a racist joke as a matter of course. We're encouraging clubs to give equal rights to women - full membership and access to all areas of the club - but many of them don't enjoy paying the same 'subs' as men!"

Middlesbrough's Western Social Club, a best club award winner in 1986, is doing well despite (or it might say because of) its men-only lounge rule. It has an annual turnover of more than £1.6m and almost £1.3m in the bank. A big chunk of its profit goes straight back into the community to fund children's and pensioners' days out.

"We've got a history of community involvement," says Green, whose 1,700 members pay just 25p a year in dues (their wives pay 5p). But he concedes that clubs like his are a dying breed. "Our appeal used to be cheaper drink, but now, with all these bars opening up offering two-for-one deals and happy hours, it's increasingly hard to compete. But we still get young people in. There are pubs around, but they come here to talk and relax. They don't have to show off to anyone, and there aren't any fights."

If the curtain was ever to go down on traditional working mens' clubs like the Western, it would be a grim day for Elvis impersonators across the country, jobbing comedians, tribute bands and boy/girl duos with names like Knight and Day, Out to Shock and Think Twice. And it would leave hundreds of thousands of club members crying into their (much more expensive) beer.

Paradoxically, the working men's club movement owes its existence to a Unitarian minister and temperance campaigner, the Rev Henry Solly, who helped set up the first clubs in the mid-19th century.

The aim was to provide working people with somewhere to socialise, keeping them away from the gin palaces of the era. In that sense, the original clubs were a natural addition to the self-improvement groups and educational institutes for working men established during the 1850s. Queen Victoria contributed to club funds in those early days.

Ten years after the Club & Institute Union was launched in 1862, beer was introduced in the clubs and Solly resigned in disgust. Today, there is one remaining alcohol-free club - in Walthamstow, north London - which is run as a members' snooker hall.

fields.headline: Readers' letters
fields.trailText: Positive outcome
fields.body:
Positive outcome

It is sometimes said that "dog bites man" is not news, whereas "man bites dog" will guarantee coverage. In that light, can I congratulate you for your thought-provoking and sensitive account of Rufus May's experiences in and around the mental health services (Spying on the psychiatrists, September 20).

The world seems obsessed with headlines such as "Free to kill - lunatics left to roam streets butcher 90 people a year" (News of the World). It is therefore life-affirming to read a story that essentially boils down to "man has psychotic experiences, yet survives the mental health services and goes on to contribute positively to the world".

Thank you for reaffirming at least a minimal faith in the power of journalism.

Peter Kinderman

Reader in clinical psychology, University of Liverpool

Conflict of interest

Joyce Struthers (Letters, September 27) rightly condemns the compromising of independent assessment inherent in government proposals that local authorities should act as scrutineers of health services in whose provision they are themselves involved. A similar conflict of interest arises when, as is increasingly the case, watchdog bodies such as Age Concern are commissioned to provide services like day care centres and emergency call facilities for the elderly. Scrutiny and service delivery functions should surely never be the responsibility of the same organisation.

Bob Heys

Halifax

Charity fat cats

While preparing to write in support of Diana Grimes (Letters, September 6), I was astonished to see in the same issue an advert offering a salary of £75,000 for a director of Oxfam.

I have strongly supported this organisation since its inception because of its high principles, but now wonder whether applicants for this post will apply because they truly wish to work for the cause or just for the high salary. Is £75,000 nowadays really considered the "fair living wage" which I always understood that Oxfam offered its workers? No wonder it is difficult to recruit volunteers.

It seems necessary to scrutinise the annual reports of all charitable organisations much more carefully before giving time or money. I feel cheated of the pleasure of "doing my bit" in good faith.

Beryl Gibson

Nottingham

Risk benefit

Ray and Jean Greek's article advocating a ban on xeno-transplantation (Xenophobia, September 20) did a disservice to your readers as it gave an unbalanced view of the topic.

Those carrying out research in this field are fully aware of the potential risks of transplanting organs or cells from animals to humans, but are also aware of the immense benefits to the community if xenotransplantation could be performed successfully and safely. Many millions suffering from such diverse conditions as diabetes and degenerative brain disease may have the quality of their lives vastly improved.

In those with advanced organ failure, xenotransplantation will be life-saving. In the US, almost 70,000 currently await a human donor organ, but only 20,000 organs will become available this year. At least 10 people die every day while waiting.

The article listed the so-called "alternatives" to xenotransplants. These include efforts to increase human organ donation, which unfortunately will never supply the number of organs and cells required, and approaches such as the use of stem cells, which is a branch of science in its absolute infancy and which may never develop into a medical therapy where it will provide whole human organs for transplantation. Much as we should encourage potential alternatives, on present evidence it seems they will not provide a solution.

Well over 150 patients have been exposed to pig cells in recent years. Cells taken from carefully screened pigs have been used in the treatment of patients with diabetes, certain neurological diseases, or liver failure. There has, as yet, been no definite evidence of the transfer of a porcine infection.

Nevertheless, as with almost every medical or scientific advance, we agree that it will be impossible to exclude all risk, even if this is related only to hitherto unknown pig bacteria or viruses. The ultimate decision whether to employ any new therapeutic agent or medical procedure rests on an assessment of the risk-benefit ratio. As the potential benefits to individuals or society increase, it becomes warranted to accept slightly increased potential risk. Without in any way reducing our obligation to take all possible steps to minimise any perceived risk to society, we surely have a moral obligation to those less fortunate than ourselves to accept a small risk to the community if the new therapy leads to great benefit to many individuals within that community.

David Cooper

President, International Xenotransplantation Association

Montreal, Canada

Us and them

To my concern, I discovered that Michael Simmons's article (Golden oldies, September 27) was one I was not intended to read.

Addressed to your readers with an all inclusive "we", the article asked readers how charitable "we" are towards older people, how much thought "we" give them as they retire or when "we" give them an extra 75p.

I was not aware that the Guardian editorial policy was to exclude older people from its readership. Can "we" Guardian readers be told what the age limit is? Being over 65, I am rather concerned as to when I should stop buying.

Joyce Williams

Rotherham
