webTitle: US elections: The Olympics of spin

fields.headline: The Olympics of spin
fields.standfirst:
With the spin machine in full swing, it was hard to tell who the real winner was in last night's US presidential debate, writes Martin Kettle in Boston
Quotes from the TV debate
fields.trailText: 4 October, comment: With the spin machine in full swing, it was hard to tell who the real winner was in last night's US presidential debate, writes Martin Kettle in Boston.
fields.body:
We were a mere nine minutes into the first presidential debate between Al Gore and George W Bush when the Gore campaign, monstrously efficient as ever, sallied out into the media hall at the University of Massachusetts with their first rapid rebuttal of an evening that would become an orgy of spin.

Reality Check: Big Government was the title on what was to be the first of over a dozen handouts from the two campaign teams to the media over the next 90 minutes. The Gore campaign workers, dressed in red T-shirts bearing the words "Let the day begin...", alternated around our desks with Bush aides offering Setting the Record Straight handouts.

The standard cliche about American presidential debates is that they represent the long-awaited moment when the electorate pauses from its work, rest and play to focus on deciding which way to vote on November 7. But the truth is that the debates are not so much a battle for the voters, as a battle to shape the media's message to the voters. They are, in fact, nothing less than the Olympics of spin.

It's true that somewhere between 60 and 75m Americans were expected to watch at least part of last night's first Gore-Bush confrontation in Boston. All over America, people will have formed their own conclusions last night. Yet the verdict which the two campaigns crave above all is the media's judgment that one side or the other was the winner in the contest.

To that end, the two sides deployed more political firepower on a single evening last night than the Sydney Olympic organisers set off fireworks to mark the end of this years Games.

As the end of the debate neared, both parties began massing their top spinmeisters in a long open area next to the press desks, known as Spin Alley. Each spinner's presence in Spin Alley is marked by a placard, carried by an acolyte, on which the person's name is clearly marked and held aloft. For the Democrats, there were top level pros such as Bill Daley, Bob Shrum, John Kerry and Donna Shalala, For the Republicans, Karen Hughes, John Engler, George Pataki and Condoleeza Rice. And dozens more on either side.

There's only one question that anyone in the press ever seems to ask in the scrums which form around each spinner. How do you think it went? "He did a wonderful job. The country can be as proud of him as I am," said Dorothy Koch, who just happens to be George W's younger sister. "The country saw Al Gore as a man who has a sense of the future," said Shrum, who is the vice-president's campaign strategist. "Gore is like Forrest Gump," suggested Engler, the witty and convivial Michigan governor.

If the presidential debates are really going to shift the momentum of the 2000 presidential contest, then it's here in Spin Alley that the battle will be fought and won. Both sides calculate that their investment in big-name quote merchants will help to tip the struggle for today's headlines their way. And not just today's. Once it becomes the received wisdom that Gore or Bush was the winner, then the perception is hard to shift.

The media can, of course, make the wrong call on these occasions. A couple of weeks ago, Rick Lazio and Hillary Clinton squared off in a televised debate in New York where they are rivals for the vacant US Senate seat next month. Lazio was aggressive, made a lot of strong points. Most of the media awarded him the victory, only to discover that the polls tipped sharply in Clinton's favour over the next few days.

Last night, no one seemed very sure who had "won". The reality is that neither of them did. Neither man forced his opponent to burst into tears, or to admit snorting cocaine, or to confess to fathering an illegitimate child. No one came up with a killer one-liner, or good joke or a well-crafted put-down. The debate was, in fact, a faithful reflection of the campaign of which it is part. Gore was knowledgeable, focused and impressive in a not particularly striking kind of way.

Bush was likeable, tenacious, stuck to his lines and was never quite as bad as he appears capable of being. Both men lived to fight - or to debate - another day. My own sense is that Gore got a bit more out of the Boston debate than Bush did. Gore kept to his issues, while Bush was sometimes rambling and, at the end, negatively personal. Gore is moving ahead once more in the polls after Bush's late September recovery. Last night's debate will not have put the brakes on that new momentum. But you do have to wonder whether all that spinning really makes any significant difference at all.

webTitle: Gore-Bush debate could decide how the US votes

fields.headline: Gore-Bush debate could decide how the US votes
fields.standfirst:
Race for the White House: With 60m expected to tune in for TV head-to-head, Republicans were just hoping their man could get by

Special report: the US elections
Quotes from the TV debate
fields.trailText: Race for the White House: With 60m expected to tune in for TV head-to-head, Republicans were just hoping their man could get by.
fields.body:
Al Gore and George W Bush finally came face to face in the first of this year's US presidential debates last night, with opinion polls showing that up to a third of American voters would decide which man to support on the basis of what they saw and heard in these encounters.

The tension and seriousness with which both camps were viewing the debate was palpable yesterday, as the closest US presidential election contest in 20 years reached what was almost certainly its pivotal moment.

An old-fashioned coin-toss gave Mr Gore, the Democratic candidate, the first question in the 90-minute debate, which took place at the University of Massachusetts in Boston.

The debate was broadcast live on most of the US television networks, and was expected to attract a viewing audience of at least 60m.

"Tonight's not the night for gimmicks," Mr Bush, the Republican candidate, said as he left West Virginia for Boston, preceded by a group of advisers so large that it required a separate jet.

Mr Bush's spin doctors said before the debate began that their man was intending to bring his 10-year programme of tax cuts totalling $1,300bn (£886bn) back to the centre of the political argument.

Mr Gore was said to be planning to use the debate to help soften his image as a stiff policy obsessive.

The Bush camp has spent weeks trying to lower expectations about its man's chances in the debate, in the hope that even a modestly competent performance could be seen as something of a triumph.

Mr Gore, by contrast, faced higher expectations because of his extensive government experience and his formidable reputation in political one-on-ones.

As well as being expected to attract the largest audience of any of the candidates' debates before the US goes to the polls in November, yesterday's TV contest was also the most intensively polled event of the election by both the Bush and Gore campaigns.

The voters' responses to the debate will affect the tone and targeting of millions of dollars of campaign advertising about to be unleashed in key states.

The importance that the politicians attached to the confrontation was not universally shared by television executives, however. fields.headline: England's 13-year itch
fields.trailText: A tour of Pakistan might not be top of England's wish list, but it is certainly making Pakistani players and fans lick their lips in anticipation. It is 13 years since Mike Gatting's late fielding change so infuriated umpire Shakoor Rana that it grabbed the headlines, wasted a day's play, and earned the England players a £1000 "hardship" bonus that deeply offended their hosts.
fields.body:
A tour of Pakistan might not be top of England's wish list, but it is certainly making Pakistani players and fans lick their lips in anticipation. It is 13 years since Mike Gatting's late fielding change so infuriated umpire Shakoor Rana that it grabbed the headlines, wasted a day's play, and earned the England players a £1000 "hardship" bonus that deeply offended their hosts.

At first glance it might have looked like a couple of people singing and dancing. It wasn't. As barely decipherable expletives (in English and Punjabi) exploded from square leg, and chubby fingers exchanged jabs of hate, sporting rivalry turned into outright enmity. Sadly, this legacy has been difficult to shake.

The 1987-88 tour had become intolerable for England, and matched the popular image of Pakistan at the time: a hell-hole for visitors, a stamping ground for biased umpires, and a holiday destination for annoying mothers-in-law. The Pakistanis, naturally, had a different perspective. To them, England were a bunch of whingers insulting their homeland and full of arrogance towards local officials, oblivious to the injustices that Pakistan teams suffered in England. Looming large behind the fracas was the perennial tussle between former colony and colonial master.

England haven't played a Test in Pakistan since 1987-88. You have to go back to 1982 for the last time England won a series against them, and that was at home. Umpire David Constant arguably sealed Pakistan's fate at Headingley that year with an unconvincing bat/pad decision against Sikander Bakht. On their tour of England in 1987 Pakistan unsuccessfully campaigned to have Constant removed from the Test umpiring panel. With England so sure of the quality of their umpires and so dismissive of those from the subcontinent, England's 1987-88 tour of Pakistan was a white-coat nightmare waiting to happen.

And it wasn't sweet dreams afterwards either. The ball-tampering furore was at its nastiest during Pakistan's 1992 tour, then Imran Khan, Ian Botham and Allan Lamb slugged it out in the High Court four years later.

Umpiring disputes, intimidatory bowling and crowd trouble have all been regular themes. I doubt, too, if Wasim Akram and Channel 4's Mark Nicholas shared a joke during their commentary stints about the time the touring Pakistanis reduced Nicholas, then of Hampshire, to tears with childish "pretty boy" jibes.

And there's more. World Cups have been flashpoints. When Pakistan won in 1992, rain saved them from certain elimination in the preliminary round. Their unlucky opponents on that day, England, had run out of steam by the time the teams met again in the final. But the air was so thick with abuse that if the new sledging penalty had been in force then, England might just have won.

Four years later, the one-day circus moved to south Asia. England were dull and Michael Atherton was in the middle of one of his more inscrutable phases. Irritated by a local journalist at a press conference, Atherton called his questioner a "buffoon". Pakistani ears heard "baboon", and all hell broke loose. Fingers jabbed accusingly all over again. By 1999, match-fixing had taken hold: was it fix or fair? Only Pakistan and the cricket mafiosi know the answer. Either way, England have made it clear that Pakistan's handling of the affair far from convinces them. Pakistan, in turn, feel persecuted, not least by England.

So there is hurt on both sides. But it throbs more forcefully in Pakistani minds. Which begs the question: does this series mean as much to England as it does to Pakistan? Before this summer, I would have said no. But with England rampant and a growing reputation to nurture, we can expect a fascinating contest. England have a chance: Pakistan's recent home record is abysmal.

There is a difference this year, however. Pakistan believe that the match-fixing scandal is behind them and captain Moin Khan and coach Javed Miandad have the team's confidence. Miandad was captain when England toured in 1987-88 and he is not one to forget the jabbing fingers of history. That tour also cost him the captaincy. All this augurs badly for England - it might not be as tough as it used to be in Pakistan, but it will not be far off. And there's bound to be some controversy. Life would be so dull without it, especially when England play Pakistan. Fingers ready?

Kamran Abbasi, born in Lahore, brought up in Rotherham, is assistant editor of the British Medical Journal. His Anglo-Asian View appears every other Wednesday on Cricket Unlimited and wisden.com. To read his previous column, on India's search for a new coach, click here.

fields.headline: In brief and casting couch
fields.trailText: • Rumours in the industry press suggest that the producers of Third Eagle, a thriller about a first lady fleeing villains bent on nuclear destruction, are courting Madonna, Sigourney Weaver and Liz Hurley for the lead role.
fields.body:
 Rumours in the industry press suggest that the producers of Third Eagle, a thriller about a first lady fleeing villains bent on nuclear destruction, are courting Madonna, Sigourney Weaver and Liz Hurley for the lead role.

 Star Wars fansite TheForce.net reports that muscleman Arnold Schwarzenegger has challenged the sci-fi saga's muppet grandmaster, Yoda, to a fight. Arnie contemplated the face-off in a response to an email on his official website, which asked who would win in a tussle between the Jedi veteran and the last action hero.

Says Arnie: "This is the funniest question anyone's ever asked me. Actually, I've seen the Star Wars films a few times [and] what I can say about Yoda is that he's character with a strong, serious mind and a disciplined will. To become a Jedi Master, Yoda would have had to work very hard and make tremendous sacrifices. By now, I think you'll see what I'm getting at: becoming a Jedi Master is not unlike becoming a champion bodybuilder, or becoming an actor. and that takes discipline and willpower first. The mind is actually more powerful than the body." Yes, alright Arnie - but get to the point. So who would win? "Possibly Yoda, but I'm sure I'd kick his butt in a pose-down!"

 Juliette Lewis and Gina Gershon are to star in Claire's Hat, a film noir comedy that follows a woman who gets in way over her head when she's in the wrong place at the wrong time.

 Harry Potter director Chris Columbus has cast British stage and TV actress Zoe Wanamaker as Madam Hooch, the teacher responsible for showing Harry how to fly his broomstick.

 Harrison Ford is to star in K-19, in which he'll play a Russian submarine captain trying to stop a nuclear meltdown aboard his vessel. Kathryn Bigelow (Point Break, Strange Days) will direct.

 Gladiator star Russell Crowe has been offered $20m to star in a new World War II movie, Giant. The movie tells the story of a soldier who helps save disabled children from the Nazis by smuggling them into neutral Switzerland. John Frankenheimer may direct.

 British director Peter Howitt (Sliding Doors) has signed on to direct the action thriller Mindhunters, which features the work of the FBI's psychological-profiling division. The plot forces seven trainees to put theory into practice when a killer emerges among them.

fields.headline: Don't expect England to win
fields.standfirst: With England entering the fray in the ICC Knockout Trophy in Kenya tomorrow, Tim de Lisle argues that we shouldn't get our hopes up
fields.trailText: I blame the Olympics.
fields.body:
I blame the Olympics.

The Daily Telegraph is talking about England winning the ICC Knockout. Matthew Fleming, who was a member of the last England one-day team to bring a cup home, thinks they will reach the semi-finals, along with Australia, South Africa and Pakistan.

You only have to study the draw for the tournament for five seconds to see that these views are somewhat optimistic. OK, so it's a knockout, and anything can happen. But in order to win it, England will have to beat South Africa, and almost certainly Australia, and someone from the other half of the draw - either Pakistan, Sri Lanka or New Zealand.

Even Fleming, normally a shrewd analyst of the game, is looking at England's prospects through rose-tinted shades. Australia, South Africa and Pakistan may well be three of the semi-finalists, but if so, England cannot join them. The fourth semi-finalist will, for sure, be either New Zealand or Zimbabwe, who are both seeded because they reached the last six of the 1999 World Cup.

England have certainly improved since those dark days. They are better than Zimbabwe now, as they have shown, home and away, in the past nine months. They are also better than West Indies, but then so are at least seven other teams.

You don't need a rankings table to work out the world one-day pecking order. Australia are far and away the best team. South Africa (who managed to draw with them in a three-match series in Melbourne six weeks ago) are a clear second, flawed only by their tendency to choke on the big occasion. Pakistan, with their brilliance and brittleness, are third.

On the other side of a wide gulf lies the second division - India, Sri Lanka, New Zealand and England. In Africa or Asia, England are probably fourth of these four. With the one exception of Sharjah 1997 - once a shining exception, now a tarnished one - England have been a poor one-day team away from home for as long as any of their players can remember. (Even Alec Stewart, the only one of cricket's current golden oldies playing in Nairobi.)

That could be beginning to change. In South Africa last winter England were at least competitive, and in Zimbabwe after that, when exhaustion could have been setting in, they were ruthlessly efficient. In the summer, against two weak teams, they settled on a strong recipe: Marcus Trescothick and Stewart to give a solid-yet-fluent start, Graham Thorpe to hold together the middle order, and five seamers of varying shapes and sizes - Andy Caddick and Alan Mullally to bowl classical line and length from an awkward height, Darren Gough and Craig White to do the one-day thing with the yorkers and slower balls, and Mark Ealham to do the dibbly-dobbly wibbly-wobbly stuff.

Whether that will work in Kenya, we will soon discover, although the recipe will change at least a little as Mullally is injured. But now that Ashley Giles is out with an injury too, Mullally looks like being replaced by a medium-pacer, Mark Alleyne, rather than by the spare fast bowler, Matthew Hoggard.

It might work for a bit and then not work, as all 11 matches in Nairobi are being played on the same surface, which is bound to turn more as the tournament goes on. The one lucky thing about England's half of the draw is that there is only one outstanding spinner in it: Anil Kumble of India. He hit form straight away against Kenya on Tuesday, but that could backfire in India's next match, when Australia will surely opt to see Kumble off and milk the rest of a fairly tame attack.

England don't need to win this tournament: they just have to do all right, which means beating Bangladesh, their banana-skin first-round opponents, tomorrow, and then giving South Africa a run for their money on October 10. A semi-final place would be a triumph when you consider how England did last time they met South Africa in a big tournament, at The Oval 17 months ago. They let Kirsten and Gibbs get away to a hundred-run flyer, and were then bowled out for 103 in reply to 225 for 7.

This time, they need to command respect, to take some beating. That will mean someone coming through in the middle order. During the summer's one-dayers, either Trescothick or Stewart made runs every time. But then they weren't facing Donald and Pollock, or McGrath and Brett Lee. One of these days, both openers will fail, and then it will matter whether Nasser Hussain is in form, or whether Andy Flintoff has taken his brain out to the middle with him, or whether Graeme Hick has got his Superman outfit on.

All these things are quite possible. Hussain, though never yet a convincing one-day player, is exuding authority as captain, and the odds must be on his bad trot ending soon. Flintoff went to Kenya with the A team three years ago, as a chubby 20-year-old, and made a hundred and a fifty in his only two completed innings. Hick should find Kenya, with its heat and dust and slow turn, as much to his taste as Zimbabwe. He might even take some wickets.

Tim de Lisle is editor of wisden.com. He has just completed a four-year stint as editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly - click here to see what is in his final issue.

fields.headline: So Mum - how was school?
fields.standfirst:
Four years ago, Hadley Freeman was just starting at university while her mum settled into a new job. But now the gym shoe is on the other foot

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Four years ago, Hadley Freeman was just starting at university while her mum settled into a new job. But now the gym shoe is on the other foot
fields.body:
She is very nervous, poor thing. End of September, beginning of term, and it is time for her to start her first year at university after her gap year.

"I'm sure I've fallen out of the practice of studying and writing essays," she moans on the phone. I can hear her biting her nails down the line. "Will the professors be OK with me, do you think? And will you meet me for lunch sometimes?" I mumble vague sentiments of reassurance, replete with memories of my own anxieties before I went to university.

"Yes, yes, but this is different," she responds impatiently. I can offer my mother no more help.

Three years ago, when I was in my second year at university and my little sister, Nell, was in her final year of A levels, my mother decided to go back to school. She already had a university degree but had recently developed an interest in classical civilisation and decided to take one-year A-level courses in ancient history and classics at a special crammer school. She is now about to start a BA in Classics at King's College, London.

As I was living away from home at the time, I paid little attention to my mother's new academic pursuits. When we spoke on the phone, she would enthuse away about her course, her teachers, how certain TV programmes bore distinct similarities to the classical texts she was studying (a favourite topic of hers), while I distractedly leafed through a magazine. Nell, however, found herself in the unusual position of writing essays with her mother at the kitchen table. The night before one of her exams Nell called me in a temper.

"She hasn't even cooked me dinner!" she stormed. "She says she's too busy revising!"

Today she laughs as she remembers those weeks when she and our mother were simultaneously studying for their A levels: "At the time, it was a pain because when you're doing exams you just want to be really self-indulgent and stroppy - but you can't if someone else there is also stressing about exams. But now that she's going to university, I'm just really proud of her. I'm glad her exam results weren't better than mine, though!"

It is a shock for every child to realise that the earth does not revolve around him or her. It is an equally jarring moment when a teenager or young adult learns that she or he is not the sole focus of their parents' lives. The moment I realised I could no longer play the little girl or the sullen teenager was not when I moved into my new flat, nor when I received my first pay cheque; it was the day my mother couldn't pick up my clothes from the dry cleaner's for me.

"Sweetie, I just can't. I've got to register at King's today," she said, with (I noted) little remorse in her voice. It was something of a surprise to realise that my mother now had her own pressing concerns, a new branch of interests divergent from her family, and that my sister and I were no longer able to count on being her primary priority.

But it has been even more interesting to see that some of my mother's contemporaries are equally shocked. Alongside the mainly commendatory applause, the occasional criticism ("Competing with our children, are we?") and sarcastic witticism ("Better not let the family side down with your A-level grades!") that she has received suggests that some of her peers also believe that your own life ends with your children's. Accordingly, any external interests become irrelevant or indulgent, if they are not directly connected to your children, even if they no longer live at home. One's identity, it seems, begins and ends at being a mother, period.

When I hear myself reassuring my mother about her work, I get the same feeling as when I hear myself talking about rent, taxes or relationships - all the trappings of adulthood as I had long perceived it. Namely, I feel surprise that I am now so old. While I am settling into my job, my mother is, concurrently, finding her way around King's College and buying ring binder folders from WH Smith's: a mirror image of where we were five years ago, when my mother was starting her new job while I was wading through my first year at university.

A mother is always a mother, but she can't always be a mum: she has her own interests, which can then move centre stage when the children no longer require her undivided attention. And this provides liberty to the children. No longer do I feel that constant guilty pressure to let her know what I'm doing minute by minute and that I'm not lying dead in an alley. She now has other interests on which to concentrate her energy, and that, in turn, leads to a more adult relationship between all three of us.

I still don't see any similarities between the works of Aristophanes and Steptoe and Son, though.

fields.headline: Proper Charlie
fields.trailText: The oeuvre of bandy-legged clown icon Charlie Chaplin is up for grabs, after the worldwide distributor of his works to the small screen opted not to extend its existing exclusive rights.
fields.body:
The oeuvre of bandy-legged clown icon Charlie Chaplin is up for grabs, after the worldwide distributor of his works to the small screen opted not to extend its existing exclusive rights. The TV and video rights to the star's canon now revert back to Chaplin's family company Roy Export, which is now seeking a new distributor to take on the job. Films now available, according to bulletins in the Hollywood Reporter trade paper, include Chaplin's first feature-length talkie, The Great Dictator, and silent classics such as The Kid and The Gold Rush.

The decision by De Dam Films not to renew its 30-year relationship with Roy Export - who have held theatrical rights to Chaplin's movies since the early-90s - has been taken amicably, insist both parties. Says Mo Rothman, who runs the distributor, "the titles in the collection are true cinematic treasures and we have greatly enjoyed our long connection with the little tramp". Josephine Chaplin, the actor's daughter, said "I know my father was really pleased with the successful re-issue of his films in the 70s thanks to Mo, and although he was no longer there to witness the last twenty years of Mo's distribution period, he would have been very happy."

The relinquishing of rights to fifteen of Chaplin's classics leaves De Dam in control of a remaining twenty-eight 'featurettes', secured under a separate deal with Chaplin's company Black Inc.

fields.headline: Olympics star to go ape
fields.trailText: The teenage star of the Sydney Olympics opening and closing ceremonies, Nikki Webster, has signed on to act in her first Hollywood movie. The Australian Daily Telegraph reports that the curly-haired 13-year-old starlet, whose rendition of the song Under Southern Skies supposedly charmed a worldwide audience, will feature in the film Vanilla Gorilla, to be shot in South Africa in February.
fields.body:
The teenage star of the Sydney Olympics opening and closing ceremonies, Nikki Webster, has signed on to act in her first Hollywood movie. The Australian Daily Telegraph reports that the curly-haired 13-year-old starlet, whose rendition of the song Under Southern Skies supposedly charmed a worldwide audience, will feature in the film Vanilla Gorilla, to be shot in South Africa in February.

The film is about an albino gorilla in captivity which communicates his plight to a young girl using sign language. It is to be directed by Randal Kleiser, who was responsible for the hits Grease and Honey, I Blew Up The Kids. Nikki's manager, Lisa Hamilton, said the call from Hollywood came within moments of the broadcast of Sydney 2000's opening ceremony to the United States. "They sent the script out immediately. I read it and Nikki read it and she absolutely loved it."

The tot first performed on stage at the age of five. She sang a duet with Michael Jackson during his 1996 Australian tour and has starred in Down Under stage versions of the musicals Les Miserables and The Sound of Music.

fields.headline: The best pawn shop scene
fields.standfirst: Snatch
fields.trailText: Snatch
fields.body:
London. Vince (Robbie Gee) enters a pawnbroker's with a large bull terrier on a lead. Sol (Lennie James) stands behind the counter, examining a jewel. Lincoln (Goldie) hovers in the shop. Sol catches Vince's eye.

"Easy."

He turns to Lincoln.

"It's an artificial diamond, Lincoln. It's Mickey Mouse, mate."

Lincoln looks confused. Sol tries to clarify the situation.

"Spurious. Not genuine. And it's worth... fuck all."

Vince shakes his head.

"Bad boy, I keep telling you - stick to being a gangster. Leave this game to me and Sol."

Deeply aggrieved, Lincoln stalks out of the shop.

"Laters."

Sol stares at Vince and his terrier.

"What is that, Vince?"

"This is a dog, Sol."

"You are not bringing that thing in here."

"What's your problem? It's only a fucking dog."

"Where'd you get it?"

"The gyppos. Here -"

He throws Sol a cloth bag.

"They threw it in with a load of moody gold."

Sol examines the contents of the bag.

"Well, it better not be dangerous."

Vince starts to undo the dog's collar.

"And what do you think you're doing now?"

"I want him to get used to the shop, don't I?"

The shop door swings open. The dog runs out. Vince screams in anguish.

"Oi! Stop that dog!"

See also: Trading Places, Underworld, The Pawnbroker

Don't see also: Paulie

Pointless trivia: While filming Snatch, cast and crew operated a fine box for bad behaviour on set, after crew members complained Ritchie was spending too much time talking to Madonna on his mobile phone: by the end of the shoot, the box held nearly £1,000.

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: If you stacked all today's transfer rumours on top of each other, it wouldn't reach the moon
fields.trailText: Michael Owen has intimated that he may quit Liverpool and move abroad. "I don't think there are many players these days who would stay at a club from the age of 11 - like I was when I joined Liverpool - to the age of 30 or 35," he told the Mirror. "There is the option for me to maybe move abroad one day. At the moment, I don't know - I've got a lot of challenges already."
fields.body:
Michael Owen has intimated that he may quit Liverpool and move abroad. "I don't think there are many players these days who would stay at a club from the age of 11 - like I was when I joined Liverpool - to the age of 30 or 35," he told the Mirror. "There is the option for me to maybe move abroad one day. At the moment, I don't know - I've got a lot of challenges already."

Chelsea have made another attempt to sign Real Madrid winger Savio, claims onefootball.com. But their bid, believed to be in excess of £10m, has been turned down as Real are holding out for £12m.

Dennis Bergkamp could be on his way back to Ajax if he fails to agree terms with Arsenal. The 31-year-old striker is a free agent at the end of the season and can sign a pre-contract agreement with another club at the turn of the year.

Roy Hodgson could be the shock choice for the vacant managerial position at Internazionale, according to the Daily Mail. The former Blackburn boss, who has had two spells in charge of the nerazzurri, faces competition from Daniel Passarella, Marco Tardelli, Rangers boss Dick Advocaat and - surprise, surprise - Gianluca Vialli.

Meanwhile, Marcello Lippi, the man Inter sacked yesterday, could be on his way to Barcelona, according to reports in Spain. Current Nou Camp boss Llorenc Serra Ferrer is under severe pressure after losing four of his last five games, and the Catalans are alleged to have already contacted Lippi - who is not allowed to manage another Italian club this season under Serie A rules - about the job.

Bradford have joined Wimbledon in the £1.5m chase for Everton defender Richard Dunne. Teamtalk also claim that Sheffield Wednesday are interested in the Republic of Ireland defender, but the Hillsborough club are unlikely to be able to raise the funds.

B93 Copenhagen defender Per Kroldrup is being watched by Arsenal.

fields.headline: Disney underlines internet commitment
fields.trailText: 10.30am: Michael Eisner, the chairman of Walt Disney, yesterday placed his company firmly on the internet bandwagon in a speech at a US media conference, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Michael Eisner, the chairman of the Walt Disney Company, yesterday placed his company firmly on the internet bandwagon in a speech at a US media conference.

Speaking at the Goldman Sachs "Communicopia" Conference in New York, the head of the world's third largest media company said he was optimistic about the year ahead, offering a bullish assessment of the company's web operations. The Walt Disney Internet Group is listed on Wall Street, but is overshadowed by its parent company.

Mr Eisner said Disney was frustrated by the lack of market attention towards its internet holdings, which include Disney.com and ABC.com. The company is better known as a theme park and resort owner, film studio and proprietor of the ABC TV network, which Mr Eisner referred to as the company's "four cylinders."

"Like all internet enterprises, the Walt Disney Internet Group is still evolving. But, unlike many Internet businesses, ours is based on solid assets that should help to power this fifth cylinder to high performance down the road," he said.

Disney is keen to underline its internet strategy in the face of the AOL and Time Warner merger, which will create the world's largest media company if EU and US regulators give it the all-clear.

"The internet is still in its infancy, but we are getting closer to the day when it will be transformed into a true entertainment medium... and Disney will once again be poised on the cutting edge - and Mickey Mouse will still be helping us out," Mr Eisner added.

Mr Eisner surprisingly supported the AOL and Time Warner mega-merger, saying he expected it to go through, but wanted the new company to ensure it did not discriminate against other content providers.

Disney has also restructured its film making arm in a belt-tightening procedure aimed at cutting spiralling production costs. Another boost for the company is the expanding market for DVD films, with customers replacing their favourite videos with DVD versions.

webTitle: Beckhams made up baby snatch claim, book says

fields.headline: Beckhams made up baby snatch claim, book says
fields.trailText: Footballer David Beckham and his Spice Girl wife Victoria invented a story of a snatch attempt on their son to get Beckham off a speeding charge, an unauthorised biography claims.
fields.body:
Footballer David Beckham and his Spice Girl wife Victoria invented a story of a snatch attempt on their son to get Beckham off a speeding charge, an unauthorised biography claims.

In his book, Posh and Becks, Andrew Morton suggests the couple manipulated the media to exaggerate fears for their safety in public.

David Beckham was banned from driving for eight months in December 1999 after he was caught driving his Ferrari at 76mph on a 50mph road in Stockport, Cheshire. The Manchester United midfielder appealed against the sentence claiming he was pursued by a paparazzi photographer for 10 miles and feared for his safety - although the photographer's car was never traced.

In a five-hour appeal hearing at Manchester crown court, Beckham, 25, told Judge Barry Woodward that a snatch attempt on their one-year-old son at Harrods the same week illustrated his fears. He said the couple were Christmas shopping with Brooklyn when a crazed fan lunged at their son demanding a photograph of the family.

The judge - who called Beckham an "honest and truthful witness" - handed back his licence but upheld the speeding conviction and an £800 fine.

But Morton's book casts doubts over the Harrods incident.

"Strangely, the incident was not captured on film either by the CCTV cameras outside Harrods or by the dozen or so photographers within inches of their Mercedes. A housewife quoted as a witness has proved untraceable," Morton writes.

A photographer who was present adds: "David Beckham had a court case at the time. He used the incident, spin-doctoring to get him off. There was no manic fan."

Morton quotes the Harrods media relations officer, Michael Mann, as saying: "No one saw it, not the doormen and not the photographers. In my opinion it may not have happened and was possibly for the papers."

A spokeswoman for the Beckhams said the couple strongly refuted suggestions that the Brooklyn incident was fabricated and the couple were disappointed that the allegations had been given credence.

"The book does not actually claim that the incident did not happen but simply reports that some people do not believe it. It is a poor attempt to make the book look controversial to generate sales," she said.

Morton's 224-page book, which is serialised in Hello! magazine next week and published next month, was the subject of a high court action in August.

The Beckhams sought an injunction to prevent publication objecting to disclosures about their private life from former bodyguard, Mark Niblett. They settled the claim after 200 words were deleted from the manuscript, rather than the 2,500 they had wanted removed. The couple were left with a £100,000 legal bill.

webTitle: No takers for the Brontes' birthplace

fields.headline: No takers for the Brontes' birthplace
fields.trailText: Three literary geniuses made their newborn squawks in the cramped main bedroom upstairs, but three major institutions have turned down the chance to buy and preserve the birthplace of Charlotte, Emily and Anne Bront.
fields.body:
Three literary geniuses made their newborn squawks in the cramped main bedroom upstairs, but three major institutions have turned down the chance to buy and preserve the birthplace of Charlotte, Emily and Anne Bront.

Gwyn Headley, historian and head of Pavilions of Splendour, a specialist agency trying to find a white knight for the stone cottage, said: "It is much the most important heritage property we have ever been involved with, but all the letters say the same: no thanks."

English Heritage declined even to look round the building in Thornton, West Yorkshire, a village five miles from the tourist-inundated Haworth parsonage.

The National Trust inspected the property but confirmed last week that it was not interested. The Brontë Society, which runs the parsonage, has turned the offer down twice as beyond its resources.

"It's dispiriting," said Barbara Whitehead, a novelist and Brontë historian, who bought the birthplace three years ago when the previous owner, equally unsuccessful at attracting a preservation scheme, offered it for £100,000 with permission to divide it into two cottages. "I wanted to see it become a museum, and we bought an elegant shop opposite to be a cafe and visitor centre, but the local Brontë Birthplace Trust, which was going to run the place, ran out of steam as far as fundraising was concerned."

Mrs Whitehead, who is about to retire, has run a limited Brontë shrine - open four hours a day, Tuesday to Sunday in summer.

webTitle: Lennon's killer fails to win early release

fields.headline: Lennon's killer fails to win early release
fields.standfirst: NetNotes: Mark Chapman
fields.trailText: Mark Chapman, the man who shot dead John Lennon 20 years ago because he wanted to be a somebody, lost his first bid for parole yesterday. The board felt he was still unusually interested in fame.
fields.body:
Mark Chapman, the man who shot dead John Lennon 20 years ago because he wanted to be a somebody, lost his first bid for parole yesterday. The board felt he was still unusually interested in fame.

Chapman, who has apologised to Lennon's family and says that he is well again and should be released to tour the world playing his own music, has almost completed his minimum sentence at Attica prison in upstate New York.

Chapman, 45, was interviewed yesterday morning at the prison by three parole board members, said Tom Grant, a spokesman for the New York state division of parole. He was told of the rejection four hours later.

In its ruling, the board called Chapman's killing of Lennon "calculated and unprovoked". In addition to being one of the most famous musicians in the world, Lennon was also a "husband and a father of two young children", it said.

"Your most vicious and violent act was apparently fuelled by your need to be acknowledged," the board added. "During your parole hearing, this panel noted your continued interest in maintaining your notoriety."

The rejection came as no surprise to Robert Gangi, executive director of the Correctional Association of New York, which monitors prisons.

He said: "If Jesus Christ returned to Earth for the sole purpose of decreeing that it would be appropriate to release Mark Chapman, the parole board wouldn't be willing to take the political heat they would get by doing it."

But even if Chapman were not a notorious murderer, his chances of release in December would still have been remote. Parole has been granted in the past three years to only 17 of the 303 people serving time in the state for murder or attempted murder and making their first application.

A poll conducted by the cable channel Court TV, which showed a documentary including an interview with Chapman the night before the closed-door hearing, showed that only 6% of respondents believed he should be set free.

The board received written submissions, one of them from Yoko Ono, Lennon's widow. It is known that she said she and the couple's son Sean would not feel safe if Chapman were let out of prison.

It will now be two years before Chapman can reapply.

On the Court TV documentary, Chapman talked of the murder - outside Lennon's Manhattan home in 1980 - as though he were describing the actions of someone else. He said of the day of the shooting: "When you look at it, here was a man who was a blowing cauldron, very lucid and very clear. Yet my stomach and heart were disintegrating."

Jack Jones, who conducted the interview, said: "Mark is a creature of fiction to a large extent. He had this fantasy world where he was the fifth Beatle in his mind.

"From an early age he had an elaborate world of little people living in his bedroom. When he was happy and things were going his way he would reward the little people by playing Beatles music. Only Beatles music. He was also eliminating and punishing millions of little people."

fields.headline: The freedom of a straitjacket
fields.trailText: Jonathan Romney: Nothing livens things up like an artistic manifesto - a call to arms, a bit of banner-waving and table-bashing. All hail, then (in principle, at least) the New Puritans, the group of young British writers whose anthology of short stories appears under a 10-point "Pledge" of rules and restrictions.
fields.body:
Nothing livens things up like an artistic manifesto - a call to arms, a bit of banner-waving and table-bashing. All hail, then (in principle, at least) the New Puritans, the group of young British writers whose anthology of short stories appears under a 10-point "Pledge" of rules and restrictions. The Puritans believe in textual simplicity and freedom from rhetoric, insist on the here and now, and honour narrative above all - strictly linear narrative at that, since "the most subtle and innovative form available to the prose writers is always going to be a plot-line".

It's hard to tell whether Nicholas Blincoe and Matt Thorne, the New Puritan editors and ideologues, are simply being playful, trying it on. But the resulting fiction suggests their contributors are not - not remotely. What the rules produce is hardly a radically refreshed fiction but simply the sort of stories that young British realists have always tended to produce. The Pledge does not saddle contributors with tough restrictions that force them to take new paths; it simply formalises business as usual.

The obvious model for the Pledge is cinematic: the Dogme 95 manifesto (acknowledged in the collection only in Ben Richards' story). The New Puritan Pledge may spur its writers to greater strictness and economy, but hardly to new aesthetic invention - the only exception being Bo Fowler, whose compendium of three brazenly inconsequential micro-narratives neatly flouts the whole premise.

There is much to be said for rule-based creation and for a system of maximising art by minimising the artist - that is, forcing creators to step down from their traditional self-image as inspired, lawless souls and obliging them to graft as artisans in the workshop of form. Rules can provide the most liberating straitjacket, as long as they are sufficiently artificial, arbitrary and impersonal. Mechanisms that seem brutally restrictive can lead to innovation.

A case in point is the wildly eccentric French writer Raymond Roussel (1877-1933), the subject of a new critical biography by Mark Ford. Roussel, for reasons both pathological and artistic, wrote his works according to verbal procedures that at their simplest resemble the forced punning of cryptic crossword clues. But one linguistic twist can generate wildly bizarre narrative fugues, often in the form of exotic machines that Roussel describes with the fastidious logic of an industrial manual. Roussel's admirers among the Surrealists may have produced imagery as fanciful, but rarely as hypnotically compelling, because their ethic of total imaginative freedom could hardly envisage the lab-coated decorum of Roussel's style.

Roussel's direct descendants were the writers of the OuLiPo, or Workshop for Potential Literature. Raymond Queneau wrote novels informed by mathematical formulae; Harry Mathews devised verbal "algorithms" as a way of kick-starting invention; most notoriously, Georges Pérec wrote La Disparition, a novel that dispenses entirely with the letter "e". This may seem a nerd algebrist's attitude to literature, rather than a writerly one. But the Oulipeans' masochistic adherence to formal bondage is a highly subversive gesture in the context of French literature, the history of which comprises a punitive repertoire of conventions.

There is no comparable subversive rigour among the New Puritans. As for reacting against any dominant dogma, it is hard to see what that might be, although they do express a sniffy ethical distaste for "the myth of the degenerate artist". But really what the Puritans are doing is restating the bases of a prevalent, long-standing and entirely dreary realist status quo. If English-language fiction were currently over-run by clever-dick fabulists and formalists, if every other young lit pretender were a would-be Pérec or Pynchon or Robbe-Grillet, then there might be something refreshing in the New Puritans' call to order. As it is, their ethic is every bit as reactionary as it sounds: a wholesale rejection of anything fancy-schmancy. What remains is something doggedly, dishearteningly British: fiction that does what it says on the packet.

 All Hail the New Puritans is published by Fourth Estate (£10). Raymond Roussel and the Republic of Dreams by Mark Ford is published by Faber in November.

webTitle: Two Way TV signs first sponsorship deal with Sportal.co.uk

fields.headline: Two Way TV signs sponsorship deal with Sportal.co.uk
fields.standfirst: Two Way TV hires Small to launch games channel
fields.trailText: Two Way TV has signed its first sponsorship deal, teaming up with Sportal.co.uk, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Two Way TV has signed its first sponsorship deal, teaming up with Sportal.co.uk to run its branding across the Two Way TV sports game, Armchair Manager.

The fantasy football game, which is available on the NTL interactive platform, is expected to be extended to Telewest Active Digital within weeks.

No terms of the deal were given, although a Two Way TV spokesman said that "no huge amounts of money changed hands. The sponsorship is based largely on a contra deal where Sportal provides monthly prizes and football news in exchange for a weighty presence on the game.

Two Way TV said it expected to increase cross-promotional activities and marketing as the number of people playing the game increased. At present, there are more than 7,000 fantasy teams in the Two Way TV Armchair Manager league, and it is one of the company's most popular interactive games, despite only launching in July.

Two Way TV's other interactive games are based on trivia and word puzzles.

Two Way TV expects to begin testing its enhanced TV "interactive gameshow" model towards the end of the year.

fields.headline: New media correspondent for ITN
fields.trailText: 9.45am: ITN online editor Fergus Sheppard has been appointed as new media correspondent, working across TV news, news channel, radio and online, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
ITN's online editor, Fergus Sheppard, has been appointed as new media correspondent, working across TV news, news channel, radio and online.

Mr Sheppard, who has worked at ITN online for three years, will be the news provider's first dedicated new media correspondent. The BBC and Sky have both appointed new media or e-business correspondents in the past year.

Sue Inglish, former deputy editor of Channel 4 News and launch editor of LBC radio, will take over as acting editor of ITN online.

Meanwhile, ITN has appointed Peter Burns as marketing manager. Mr Burns joins from Virgin Atlantic, where he was new media executive.

Collette Lux, former head of marketing planning at the BBC and group brand manager at Ven den Bergh Foods, is launching a charity fundraising website called Madapolis.

fields.headline: Leo Burnett wins Handspring account
fields.trailText: 10am:Leo Burnett has been appointed to handle the pan-European account for Handspring's range of palm computers, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Leo Burnett has been appointed to handle the pan-European account for Handspring's range of palm computers.

The first campaign, which will be driven out of the agency's London office, is about to be launched in UK, France and Germany. The UK media spend will be around £3m.

Roy Bedlow, a marketer at Handspring, said, "Having seen a number of agencies we decided to work with Leo Burnett because they exhibited superior thinking for building a consumer brand across Europe. Handspring is working to develop a strong global brand and have already launched in the US."

Handspring's technology is the Springboard platform, which provides a simple method for hardware and software expansion ranging from camera and music players to wireless voice. The product is available both via the internet and through the firm's range of retail outlets nationwide.

Stephen Whyte, managing director of Leo Burnett London, said, "Handspring is a leading innovator in the handheld computing industry and we are greatly looking forward to partnering with them to develop a pre-eminent European brand."

Handspring was founded in 1998 in the US by the creators of the Palm Computing platform.

fields.headline: Channel 4 reprimanded by BSC
fields.trailText: 9.30am: Channel 4 has had its wrist slapped by the Broadcasting Standards Commission over Chris Morris's satirical series, Jam, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Channel 4 has had its wrist slapped by the Broadcasting Standards Commission (BSC) over Chris Morris's satirical series, Jam, which the commission claimed "pushed at the boundaries of acceptability".

Twelve viewers complained about various parts of the sketch series, which they claimed were "tasteless and offensive", according to the BSC's latest complaints bulletin, published today.

Singled out by viewers were a sketch featuring a doctor killing his patients after telling relatives they were suffering from a "symptomless coma" and a wife who received a coffin as a present after having an abortion.

The BSC said it accepted Channel 4's defence that it had a remit to provide "innovative and challenging" programming, but said the channel had not done enough to signpost the material as having the potential to cause offence.

The BSC said "there remained [in Jam] a balance to be struck between creative freedom and the respect for human dignity and vulnerability".

Channel 4 had a further complaint upheld for an edition of the 11 O'Clock Show, featuring a sketch satirising a young girl given a mobile phone to combat bullies. The BSC ruled that the sketch had gone "beyond acceptable boundaries".

The commission upheld in part a complaint against HTV West's news magazine programme, West Eye View. During a programme investigating allegations of institutionalised child abuse, staff at Kingswood School in Bristol were dressed in uniforms resembling those of prison warders, which the programme maker later acknowledged they had not worn.

The BSC, along with the independent television commission, faces rationalisation in the forthcoming White Paper on communications and broadcasting.

Twelve viewers complained about various parts of the sketch series, which they claimed were "tasteless and offensive", according to the BSC's latest complaints bulletin, published today. Singled out by viewers were a sketch featuring a doctor killing his patients after telling relatives they were suffering from a "symptomless coma" and a wife who received a coffin as a present after having an abortion. The BSC said it accepted Channel 4's defence that it had a remit to provide "innovative and challenging" programming, but said the channel had not done enough to signpost the material as having the potential to cause offence. The BSC said "there remained [in Jam] a balance to be struck between creative freedom and the respect for human dignity and vulnerability". Channel 4 had a further complaint upheld for an edition of the 11 O'Clock Show, featuring a sketch satirising a young girl given a mobile phone to combat bullies. The BSC ruled that the sketch had gone "beyond acceptable boundaries". The commission upheld in part a complaint against HTV West's news magazine programme, West Eye View. During a programme investigating allegations of institutionalised child abuse, staff at Kingswood School in Bristol were dressed in uniforms resembling those of prison warders, which the programme maker later acknowledged they had not worn. The BSC, along with the independent television commission, faces rationalisation in the forthcoming White Paper on communications and broadcasting.

fields.headline: Lowe Lintas lands multimillion HSBC task
fields.trailText: 9.15am: Lowe Lintas and Partners is launching it first multimillion pound global branding campaign for HSBC bank, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Lowe Lintas and Partners is launching a multimillion pound global branding campaign for HSBC bank.

TV and print executions will break in the UK next month and run for nine months across a selection of magazines and TV channels including CNN International's five English language networks and across Time, Fortune and Asia Week magazines.

Three TV spots - 'hitchhiker', 'running' and 'train' all use the tagline "our kind of person, your kind of bank" and show people going out of their way to be helpful to others.

All media planning and buying will be handled by Zenith.

Tim Scott Hunter, a group media director at Zenith, said: "We are confident that it will not only powerfully and memorably deliver HSBC's strategic media objectives but will be used by fellow media travellers as a trailblazing global media case study for years to come."

webTitle: Granada game show wins top ratings in Turkey

fields.headline: Granada game show strikes gold in Turkey
fields.trailText: 8.30amGranada Media game show format Win Your Weight In Gold has been reordered in Turkey - after beating the local version of Who Wants to be a Millionaire? in the ratings. By Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Granada Media game show format Win Your Weight In Gold has been reordered in Turkey - after beating the local version of blockbuster UK format Who Wants to be a Millionaire? in the ratings.

Turkish broadcaster ATV has ordered a second 26-part run of the 90-minute show and optioned a third series, after just three episodes of Win Your Weight In Gold have aired.

The third instalment, which went out last Thursday, drew a 17.4% audience share, beating Millionaire, which took 14% on a rival Turkish network.

Win Your Weight In Gold was devised by Granada Media formats consultant Tony McLaren and sold to ATV by Kevin Roast, Granada Media head of international production. Jim Brown, entertainment executive producer at Granada subsidiary Yorkshire TV, has been supervising production of the show in Turkey.

The format has also been optioned in Italy and Spain.

fields.headline: Abbott Mead Vickers bags DfEE science project
fields.trailText: 8am: Abbott Mead Vickers is poised to pick up a £3m DfEE task to promote the Year of Science, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Abbott Mead Vickers is poised to pick up a £3m DfEE task to promote the Year of Science.

The agency won a pitch involving TBWA/London, the Leith Agency and D'Arcy. It will now spearhead the government's latest initiative aimed at getting children more interested in science, achieving better school grades and ultimately to enter a scientific field as a chosen career.

The Year of Science campaign will run this year through into earlier 2001. The government backed a reading and literacy initiative in 1998 and maths in 1999.

Amanda Thomas, a spokesperson for the DfEE, said "I can confirm that we are in the process of awarding the contract to AMV."

fields.headline: BBC switches news to 10
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the future of the BBC
MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The BBC yesterday launched a pre-emptive strike against ITV by announcing it would move its nightly news to 10pm in less than two weeks' time.
fields.body:
The BBC yesterday launched a pre-emptive strike against ITV by announcing it would move its nightly news to 10pm in less than two weeks' time.

The move will pitch the BBC's main news bulletin against ITV which is being forced by regulators to reinstate News at Ten at least three times a week. It also sets the corporation on a collision course with the culture secretary, Chris Smith, who condemned the move.

The decision was taken at an emergency meeting of the BBC governors late on Monday. Earlier indications from the director general, Greg Dyke, who announced the plan in August, had been that the change would not happen until late next year. There had also been some suggestion that the BBC's plans had faltered since ITV confirmed the return of its own 10pm news programme.

Sir Christopher Bland, the BBC chairman, denied using "smash and grab" tactics to gain an advantage over ITV, which is planning to reintroduce a 20 minute version of News at Ten in the new year.

"It is something we thought about for a long time," he said. "Our job is to offer the best possible proposition to viewers. We weren't unaware that there will be a 20 minute overlap with ITV but to think that it alone should have dictated our decision is wrong."

He added: "It was important to get on with it once we had made this decision."

The BBC's nightly news will shift on Monday October 16, to run for six nights a week, including a 15 minute programme on Sunday. It spells the end of 30 years of the Nine O'Clock News.

It will be renamed the Ten O'Clock News but otherwise the format will remain the same. Newsnight will keep its present BBC2 slot, while Panorama will be rescheduled to 10.15pm on Sunday on BBC1.

Mr Smith said he had considerable misgivings. "TV news is vital in our democracy. My concern is that the overall audience for TV news and the quality of the service must not be damaged by any change to the scheduling." It would be incumbent on the BBC governors to watch for a fall in quality or viewer numbers.

The shadow culture secretary, Peter Ainsworth, also expressed regret at the decision, while Norman Baker of the Liberal Democrats said it was further evidence of BBC1 being forced "down market."

An ITV spokeswoman said the network would still wait until the new year before moving its bulletin. "This is a betrayal of BBC1's public service values," she said. "It is clearly bad for viewers and will have a detrimental impact on news audiences."

fields.headline: Viewers fail to tuck into BBC's Breakfast
fields.standfirst: The Media Medium on breakfast TV
fields.trailText: 11.15am overnights: The BBC's new Breakfast shows no sign of waking up BBC1's share of the morning audience, two days after launching, writes Janine Gibson.
fields.body:
After two days, the BBC's new three-hour Breakfast is showing no real improvement in BBC1's share of the morning audience, achieving a consistent average of 0.8m viewers, a 23% share.

According to unofficial overnight ratings figures, week on week, BBC1's breakfast time share has fallen since the launch of new show hosted by Jeremy Bowen and Sophie Raworth on Monday. This, however, is due to the inflated effect of the Olympic Breakfast, which was pulling in an audience share of well over 50%.

More disappointing for the BBC will be the year on year comparisons. Yesterday's show peaked at 1.1m viewers - just 100,000 more than the figure in the week of 3 October 1999, when its predecessor, Breakfast News, peaked at 1m (against GMTV's 1.4m and 0.5m for Channel 4).

Breakfast started well against GMTV. The two were level pegging at 6am with 0.3m viewers, but for the rest of the 6am to 7am news hour, GMTV managed a clear eight to 10 share point lead. It's only GMTV's last 45 minutes - after 8.45am - that pulls down the programme's overall share.

In primetime, My Family, BBC1's above average sitcom starring Robert Lindsay and Zoe Wanamaker, failed to take its impressive opening figures into its third week. It scored 5.7m viewers, a 25% share - not disgraceful but disappointing compared with last week's 7.3m (33% share) and a debut of 8m (35%).

It performed better than Attachments, however, which continues to flounder. The dot.com drama pulled in 1.3m viewers, a miserable 6% share for BBC2 against ITV's Peak Practice and Channel 4's scary series, Why Doctors Make Mistakes. Tony Garnett's internet entrepreneurs lost 100,000 viewers and a share point from last week. Better hope the venture capitalists don't find out.

webTitle: Bank of England spends £51m propping up euro

fields.headline: Bank of England spends £51m propping up euro
fields.trailText: The Bank of England bought 85m euros, worth £51m, against sterling in last month's concerted international operation to prop up the struggling single currency, the Treasury said today.
fields.body:
The Bank of England bought 85m euros, worth £51m, against sterling in last month's concerted international operation to prop up the struggling single currency, the Treasury said today.

The intervention, which was sanctioned by the chancellor, Gordon Brown, was part of a concerted action by the central banks of the leading G7 group of industrialised nations.

The Treasury said the action was taken "because of the shared concern about the potential implications of recent movements in the euro for the world economy".

webTitle: LSE acts to prop up its technology

fields.headline: LSE acts to prop up its technology
fields.standfirst: Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: The London Stock Exchange is reviewing its contract with its technology provider Andersen Consulting in an attempt to tackle one of its major vulnerabilities in the face of the £800m takeover bid by Swedish OM.
fields.body:
The London Stock Exchange is reviewing its contract with its technology provider Andersen Consulting in an attempt to tackle one of its major vulnerabilities in the face of the £800m takeover bid by Swedish OM.

Don Cruickshank, chairman and acting chief executive of the LSE, said that the exchange wanted to replace the standard "outsourcing" contract with an arrangement which was more "dynamic".

"There will be more incentives [for them] and for us to share in the upside," Mr Cruickshank said, explaining it was part of the LSE's attempt to update its business since its demutualisation earlier this year. Modernising the relationship with Andersen was a temporary solution, he said. "It doesn't mean in two years' time we'll still be with them".

Technology has emerged as one of the major issues in the fight against the bid by OM, the Swedish group which yesterday said that it had the backing of 1% of the LSE's shareholders.

Per Larsson, the chief executive of OM, said: "Our offer is now being recognised as the only opportunity to transform the LSE, its technology, its management and its service levels".

Under the terms of the City takeover code, the bid, which has cost LSE chief executive Gavin Casey his job, is still in its early days. The offer has been extended to October 23, and Mr Larsson said OM was making good progress in talks with LSE shareholders.

But Mr Cruickshank insisted yesterday that the exchange "was not up for sale". No talks had been held with rival exchanges and no approaches had been made, he said.

To address the concerns of private client brokers, who were the most vocal opponents of the now abandoned merger with the Deutsche Börse, Mr Cruickshank said he planned to outline "improvements" to the services provided to the brokers.

He will pledge the improvements at this weekend's meeting of Apcims, the private client stockbroker lobby group.

Yesterday, however, the exchange had a setback when it encountered bewilderment over its plan to ask its shareholders to lift the 4.9% limit on ownership by a single shareholder.

It has called a vote later this month on the threshold which would prevent a takeover by OM, but the wording of the resolution is said to be confusing and could lead shareholders to vote against it.

The consolidation among exchanges took another step forward yesterday when the Portuguese stock exchange said it was in negotiations to join Euronext, the alliance of the Paris, Brussels and Amsterdam bourses which came into operation last month.

webTitle: Prodi attacks critics of EU integration

fields.headline: Prodi attacks critics of EU integration
fields.standfirst: Special report: the European Parliament
fields.trailText: Romano Prodi, president of the European Commission, issued a stern warning to EU states yesterday not to reduce integration to mere cooperation between governments.
fields.body:
Romano Prodi, president of the European Commission, issued a stern warning to EU states yesterday not to reduce integration to mere cooperation between governments.

In an unusually hard speech, interpreted as criticism of France and Britain, Mr Prodi told members of the European Parliament at Strasbourg that there was a danger that the EU would become either an "international talking shop" or a "government of bureaucrats" if this trend was not reversed.

Seeking to re-establish his authority after enduring months of criticism and demoralisation in Brussels, Mr Prodi made clear that he expected the EU's 15 members to agree to far-reaching changes - including less use of national vetoes - at their Nice summit in December.

France's president, Jacques Chirac, ruffled feathers in the summer when he called for a "pioneer group" of countries to lead the EU, failing to mention the commission - the unique supranational executive of the EU where elements of sovereignty are pooled.

Diplomats suspected that Mr Prodi was in part trying to make a pre-emptive strike before Tony Blair's heavily trailed speech in Warsaw on Friday: it is expected to call for closer collaboration between EU governments, an implicit relegation of EU institutions.

British officials often privately give the impression they regret the choice of Mr Prodi, a former Italian prime minister, after the fall of the discredited Santer commission last year. EU sources insisted the commission president was not attacking specific national leaders, but was concerned about the general trend.

"This is meant to be a strong warning," said one official.

"Enhancing the intergovernmental model at the expense not only of the commission but also, ultimately, of the council [of ministers] would ... undermine the democratic nature of the whole European structure and would be a seriously retrograde step," Mr Prodi said in Strasbourg.

Much of his speech was devoted to urging governments to settle long overdue institutional reforms, due for review at the Biarritz summit in a fortnight finalisation at Nice.

Limiting national vetoes, Mr Prodi said, was the most important reform needed for an enlarged EU to function properly: decisions requiring unanimity should be restricted to an "absolute minimum".

And in a message that will be especially unwelcome to Mr Blair, Mr Prodi signalled that no one should prevent a group of EU members from achieving closer union - eurospeak for saying that a "two-speed Europe" is a good thing.

Denmark's rejection of the European single currency in a referendum last week - and the probability that Sweden and Britain will delay their own referendums - has made the two-speed option likelier.

Mr Prodi received a rousing ovation, and Pat Cox, leader of the Liberal group of MEPs, said his speech had been the commission president's "finest hour" in his year in office.

He urged governments to do more to promote a positive view of the possible near-doubling of EU membership over the next few years, in hopes of preventing extreme rightwing parties exploiting rising crime and mass immigration.

Controversially, he also called for the commission to be given greater powers in formulating EU foreign and economic policies.
fields.bodyText: Romano Prodi, president of the European Commission, issued a stern warning to EU states yesterday not to reduce integration to mere cooperation between governments. In an unusually hard speech, interpreted as criticism of France and Britain, Mr Prodi told members of the European Parliament at Strasbourg that there was a danger that the EU would become either an "international talking shop" or a "government of bureaucrats" if this trend was not reversed. Seeking to re-establish his authority after enduring months of criticism and demoralisation in Brussels, Mr Prodi made clear that he expected the EU's 15 members to agree to far-reaching changes - including less use of national vetoes - at their Nice summit in December. France's president, Jacques Chirac, ruffled feathers in the summer when he called for a "pioneer group" of countries to lead the EU, failing to mention the commission - the unique supranational executive of the EU where elements of sovereignty are pooled. Diplomats suspected that Mr Prodi was in part trying to make a pre-emptive strike before Tony Blair's heavily trailed speech in Warsaw on Friday: it is expected to call for closer collaboration between EU governments, an implicit relegation of EU institutions. British officials often privately give the impression they regret the choice of Mr Prodi, a former Italian prime minister, after the fall of the discredited Santer commission last year. EU sources insisted the commission president was not attacking specific national leaders, but was concerned about the general trend. "This is meant to be a strong warning," said one official. "Enhancing the intergovernmental model at the expense not only of the commission but also, ultimately, of the council [of ministers] would ... undermine the democratic nature of the whole European structure and would be a seriously retrograde step," Mr Prodi said in Strasbourg. Much of his speech was devoted to urging governments to settle long overdue institutional reforms, due for review at the Biarritz summit in a fortnight finalisation at Nice. Limiting national vetoes, Mr Prodi said, was the most important reform needed for an enlarged EU to function properly: decisions requiring unanimity should be restricted to an "absolute minimum". And in a message that will be especially unwelcome to Mr Blair, Mr Prodi signalled that no one should prevent a group of EU members from achieving closer union - eurospeak for saying that a "two-speed Europe" is a good thing. Denmark's rejection of the European single currency in a referendum last week - and the probability that Sweden and Britain will delay their own referendums - has made the two-speed option likelier. Mr Prodi received a rousing ovation, and Pat Cox, leader of the Liberal group of MEPs, said his speech had been the commission president's "finest hour" in his year in office. He urged governments to do more to promote a positive view of the possible near-doubling of EU membership over the next few years, in hopes of preventing extreme rightwing parties exploiting rising crime and mass immigration. Controversially, he also called for the commission to be given greater powers in formulating EU foreign and economic policies.

webTitle: Lord of the Rings will be 'faithful'

fields.headline: Lord of the Rings will be 'faithful'
fields.trailText: Ian McKellen has gone online at his website mckellen.com to defend the upcoming Lord of the Rings trilogy - in which he stars - from criticism that adaptations are never as satisfying as the books they ape.
fields.body:
Ian McKellen has gone online at his website mckellen.com to defend the upcoming Lord of the Rings trilogy - in which he stars - from criticism that adaptations are never as satisfying as the books they ape. The British actor has made regular postings on his site, soothing fans' anxieties and denying rumours that swirl around the project.

In his latest missive, the Gods and Monsters star describes LOTR as "perhaps the most faithful screenplay ever adapted from a long novel. This is not just because our writing quartet is devoted to the original and would share other fans' resentment if it were "mistreated". Tolkien has an advantage over Dickens, Tolstoy and other epic writers. His storylines have a clear sweep and are less concerned with the byways and subplots which characterise 19th century novels. Consequently the major milestones of the Fellowship's journey are intact."

McKellen goes on to admit that there will necessarily be "some omissions of characters and elisions of events", but argues that to bother about the film's lack of fidelity is to miss the point. "Peter Jackson's movie does not challenge the novel's supremacy any more than the distinguished book illustrations by Howe, Lee et al were meant to replace Tolkien's descriptive words." And just watch the book sales rise as New Line's publicity for the film gears up.

The star ends by comparing Jackson's adaptation with his own work on Shakespeare's Richard III, claiming that "the adaptation of masterpieces from one medium to another is as old as literature - Kurosawa's Throne of Blood, my favourite version of the Macbeth saga, distorts Shakespeare to spectacular effect. The play which inspired it remains intact."
