fields.headline: Sitting astride a dead donkey
fields.standfirst: Special report: Conservative party conference 2000
fields.trailText: "Antes de ques te cases, mira lo que haces!" exclaimed Michael Portillo. He had come out at last, as a Spaniard. It was the first Tory leadership bid to be conducted in a foreign tongue.
fields.body:
"Antes de ques te cases, mira lo que haces!" exclaimed Michael Portillo. He had come out at last, as a Spaniard. It was the first Tory leadership bid to be conducted in a foreign tongue.

"I am half Spanish and proud of it!" he told the conference. Some of us can remember when few Tories would admit to having been to Spain, never mind having caballero blood, still less addressing them in the language. It means, roughly, "look before you leap."

But it was a dazzling show by Portillo mark II. The Spanish half is clearly above the belt. Those thick, fleshy lips, as lavish and plump as a World of Leather sofa. The thick, fleshy hair, curled majestically in what was once a cruel quiff.

But no longer. This was the kindly, inclusive, humble, cuddly Portillo. "We are a party for all Britons, black Britons, British Asians... we are for people whatever their sexual orientation!" Delegates near me stirred uneasily. To some of this lot, an inclusive Tory party is like an inclusive freemasons - it misses the point.

But he was so unrelentingly nice. He even thanked the electors for having thrown him out in 1997 and allowed him to visit the real world, terra incognita for most politicians. Having memorised the speech he could stroll round the stage making inclusive gestures. (A friend saw him rehearsing on Monday, when he was advised to stop making the cupping motion with both hands held upwards. "It looks like, erm, you know..." he was told.)

Now and again he pointed at William Hague and announced that thanks to his wisdom and courage, Tories would win the next election. It was as blatant as that. The man will stop at nothing to get Hague's job. But the most blatant chutzpah came when he announced that the economy was doing so well that the imminent Tory government would be able to increase public spending and cut taxes. "Yes, thanks to Gordon Brown, we are booming as never before!" he somehow omitted to say.

But Portillo's wasn't the only weird proverb. The day resembled that competition for runic rural sayings, e.g. "It is a foolish man who wipes his bottom with a hedgehog."

During a question session in the morning someone announced "I am a farmer and proud of it!" (There's a lot of pride about. No one has yet stood up and said something like "I am a gay Spanish haulier and deeply ashamed of it.") He wanted to know what Mr Hague was going to do for farmers.

The Tory leader blamed the problems of the countryside on the people in Islington wine bars. I must find out which he means, since all the nation's evil seems to be fomented there. The Gay Gaucho, perhaps. "Scrap the pound, blame the victim, and another bottle of your lightly oaked Rioja, Miguel..."

When he first became an MP, a farmer told him, "Mr Hague, if you ever see a satisfied farmer or a dead donkey, sit on it, because you'll never see another". The conference roared with laughter, then fell strangely silent. What could it mean? Why are dead donkeys so rare? And why should you sit on one? Or on a satisfied farmer, for that matter? Was it a new battle cry: "Hague's call to nation: sit on dead donkeys!"

Had he run it past his spin doctors? "D'yer think they'll understand a reference to moribund equines?" "Oh, yes, William, whatever you do, don't drop the dead donkey!"

Grisliest moment of the day was the line up of celebrities onstage for the culture debate. Mike Batt, Jan Leeming, Mitch Murray, Mike Yarwood, Ed 'Stewpot' Stewart - and they were the highlights. The biggest cheer was for Antony Worrall-Thompson, who has actually been on TV within the last decade. The rest were melted down by Madame Tussaud's years ago, possibly to make John Prescott.

fields.headline: Trimble urged to give ultimatum
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: David Trimble, Northern Ireland's first minister, was last night under pressure from some Ulster Unionist allies to reunite the party at its conference on Saturday with a motion to quit the power-sharing executive within three months if the IRA fails to begin destroying its weapons. He is said to be resisting the plan.
fields.body:
David Trimble, Northern Ireland's first minister, was last night under pressure from some Ulster Unionist allies to reunite the party at its conference on Saturday with a motion to quit the power-sharing executive within three months if the IRA fails to begin destroying its weapons. He is said to be resisting the plan.

As Mr Trimble warned that the Good Friday agreement was in dire trouble because of the IRA's failure to begin decommissioning, the deputy leader, John Taylor, said that its days were numbered. Jeffrey Donaldson, seen as a likely future leader, said at a fringe meeting at the Conservative Party conference in Bournemouth that only IRA weapons destruction could save the executive now.

Mr Trimble also faces a Democratic Unionist Party motion of no confidence as first minister in the assembly on Tuesday. It cannot be passed without nationalist backing, but even if he fails to achieve a majority of unionist backing, he would be seriously undermined.

Unionists taking his party whip total 27, and he can count on the support of the two Progressive Unionists. But the DUP and other anti-agreement unionists also number 29.

Although Mr Trimble is expected to survive Saturday's annual conference, the test is likely later in the month. His critics are expected to push for yet another meeting of the Ulster Unionist council, the party's ruling body, to force a withdrawal from the executive, which would signal Mr Trimble's demise.

But Gerry Adams, the Sinn Fein president, accused Ulster Unionists of creating a false crisis to detract attention from policing reform. Mr Trimble wants changes to the RUC to be halted until the IRA decommissions, but Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, will resist any such demand.

Mr Adams appeared to suggest that the IRA would allow the weapons inspectors, Martti Ahtisaari and Cyril Ramaphosa, back to re-inspect the dumps they saw in the Irish Republic. But with Ulster Unionists in crisis after the catastrophic byelection defeat at south Antrim last month, that may well be insufficient.

Mr Adams said: "The IRA ... have said there will be regular inspections and they would re-engage with the independent international commission on decommissioning and it's my view they will do that. I think the attempt to create a crisis around when the IRA bring back the inspectors is bogus.

"I have no doubt there is a crisis within unionism and I think part of that crisis is created by the fact there is no one out there actively promoting the Good Friday agreement, giving a positive, constructive, consistent and strategic lead to unionists who voted for the agreement."

Mr Donaldson said at a Save the Union meeting: "There is no reason why the leadership cannot give a lead and the Ulster Unionist ministers should withdraw from the executive as soon as possible."

He ridiculed arms inspections, and predicted Ulster Unionists would no longer accept that step.

The DUP deputy leader, Peter Robinson, said of Mr Trimble: "I have no confidence in him and the electorate has no confidence in him. It's not the inspection of a few wonky rifles we want, it's the complete destruction of all paramilitary weaponry."

webTitle: UN demand for recount in Yugoslavia

fields.headline: UN demand for recount in Yugoslavia
fields.standfirst:
Milosevic rival agrees to talks in Moscow

Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: A senior United Nations official called for a recount of the vote in last week's Yugoslav election yesterday as the poll victor, Vojislav Kostunica, signalled he could go to Moscow later this week for talks on the post-election crisis with President Vladimir Putin.
fields.body:
A senior United Nations official called for a recount of the vote in last week's Yugoslav election yesterday as the poll victor, Vojislav Kostunica, signalled he could go to Moscow later this week for talks on the post-election crisis with President Vladimir Putin.

In Belgrade, Jiri Dienstbier - the UN human rights rapporteur for present-day Yugoslavia, Croatia and Bosnia - said the ruling party had rigged the results of the September 24 vote. He demanded a recount rather than support the plan by Slobodan Milosevic's regime for a second-round run-off this Sunday.

"The results must have been manipulated," Mr Dienstbier said in the Serbian capital.

Mr Dienstbier, a former Czech foreign minister, has been one of the few international officials in Yugoslavia during the election crisis that many fear could spill into civil war due to Mr Milosevic's evident determination to hang on despite faring poorly in the September vote against Mr Kostunica, the main opposition contender.

"The truth should be discovered and both sides should accept the demand to recount the votes," he said, alleging that the main ballot-rigging occurred in Kosovo.

His remarks put him at odds with Moscow, which is seeking to play the central role in mediating the crisis; President Putin had offered to host Mr Milosevic and Mr Kostunica in Moscow in the next few days.

The Kremlin says Sunday's proposed second round should go ahead, tacitly accepting Mr Milosevic's argument that the opposition did not win an outright majority, although other Russian statements have favoured Mr Kostunica, who has said he would boycott a second-round run-off.

Borislav Milosevic, the Yugoslav ambassador in Moscow and the president's older brother, yesterday insisted that Sunday's second round would go ahead whether or not Mr Kostunica boycotted it. He said he did not know if his brother would accept Mr Putin's offer of mediation and come to Moscow.

Dmitry Rogozin, head of Russia's parliamentary foreign affairs committee, who knows Mr Kostunica and saw ambassador Milosevic yesterday, said the chances of crisis talks taking place in Moscow were slim.

But Mr Kostunica's Democratic party of Serbia told Russian officials in Belgrade that its candidate would travel to Moscow if he was given an audience with the Russian president, who is in India until tomorrow.

"If there is an official invitation and if there are guarantees Putin himself will really see Kostunica, he would go, and that could be [tomorrow]," a party source said.

Moscow's Interfax news agency reported that Mr Kostunica had accepted the Russian offer, but Mr Kostunica, speaking to the Russian daily Kommersant for today's edition, appeared less sure.

"President Vladimir Putin's proposal is very much in my interests," Mr Kostunica said. "All that remains to be done is work out certain details and the format of the meeting in Moscow."

If the meeting goes ahead, its thrust could be to get Mr Kostunica to run on Sunday in return for international monitoring of the vote and Kremlin guarantees that Mr Milosevic will stand by the verdict, Interfax reported.

What is uncertain is whether Mr Milosevic will make such commitments.

The UN war-crimes tribunal has indicted Mr Milosevic for war crimes in Kosovo - and is about to extend the charges to war crimes committed by forces under his command earlier in Bosnia and Croatia.

Russia is a permanent member of the UN security council and formally would be obliged to arrest Mr Milosevic in Moscow.

After talks in Belgrade with Milosevic government officials and the Kostunica camp, Russia's Balkan envoy, Vladimir Chizhov, said both sides remained dangerously far apart.

Returning to Moscow last night, Mr Chizhov called for a solution that "would ensure the legitimacy of a new Yugoslav leadership disputed by no one". That appeared to support Mr Kostunica, since the west will not recognise President Milosevic should he try to hold on.

A website run by advisers to Mr Putin said bluntly that Mr Milosevic was finished and that Moscow should press him to step down.

"The current regime in Belgrade has been dealt a stunning blow from which it can barely recover," it said.

"The fall of Slobodan Milosevic is only a matter of time ... Russia's support could tip the scales in Serbia in favour of the opposition and convince Milosevic not to try to cling to power."

webTitle: Third world debt may soon lose the spotlight

fields.headline: Third world debt may soon lose the spotlight
fields.standfirst:
Campaigners vow to keep on fighting after Jubilee 2000 shuts shop

Special report: debt relief
Jubilee 2000
fields.trailText: There will be bureaucrats within the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund counting down the days to the end of the year when Jubilee 2000, the coalition calling for the forgiveness of third world debt, finally shuts up shop.
fields.body:
There will be bureaucrats within the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund counting down the days to the end of the year when Jubilee 2000, the coalition calling for the forgiveness of third world debt, finally shuts up shop.

The UK-based lobby group has harried the two international financial institutions for more than five years to give the world's indebted countries a break. Human chains around World Bank and IMF meetings and the support of high-profile figures like Bono and the Pope has taken debt from being an obscure backroom issue to front page news. On Monday the lead singer of the band U2 met Bill Clinton at the White House and with religious leaders and senators urged the US to forgive its share of third world debts.

The campaign has achieved some breakthroughs: last year the Group of Seven leading industrialised countries agreed that the existing plan for managing third world debt was slow and inadequate. They promised deeper, speedier debt relief at their Cologne summit in June last year.

But in less than 100 days, the main focus of the debt campaign will shut up shop. Jubilee 2000 has no plans to become Jubilee 2001, even though its leading lights admit their campaign objective of achieving the cancellation of unpayable third world debt is far from won.

There were some crumbs of comfort yesterday for campaigners disappointed by the lack of progress on debt forgiveness at last week's meetings of the World Bank and IMF.

Britain has found a further £100m of third world debt to write off, buried in the books of the Commonwealth Development Corporation, the state-owned development financing body which Labour plans to privatise.

The CDC debt is small beer, however, in comparison to what remains to be done on debt more than a year after the G7's pledge. The bank and the IMF claimed they had made progress in Prague: they have agreed to bend the strict conditions poor countries have to meet to qualify for the west's loans reduction package, to help get 20 countries on to the programme by the end of the year.

But even if the two bodies manage to fast-track 10 more countries over the next three months, the original pledge was to get 24, not 20 countries into the programme. And campaigners argue that the G7's debt deal is too limited: headline promises of 100% debt cancellation apply only to debts owed to individual western countries. The bulk of the debts are owed to the World Bank and the IMF and will be cut rather than written off, leaving many countries still paying more in servicing debt than they do on health and primary education.

Cracks appear
Privately, insiders in the bank admit the holes in the present debt deal are beginning to appear. Crashing commodity prices and the rising cost of oil is hitting the indebted countries of sub-saharan Africa the hardest, undermining the two financial institutions' estimates of what is sustainable debt.

The IMF's figures show that some countries will be paying more on debt servicing after the G7 debt deal than before. But the bureaucrats argue that it took so long to mobilise support for the current deal even if it is flawed that going back to the drawing board is out of the question.

As the deadline set by the G7 looms larger, so does Jubilee 2000's self-imposed deadline. The time limit on the call helped to give Jubilee's campaign its edge, however, the down side is that the coalition cannot extend its mandate to a further round of campaigning without losing its credibility. The debt campaign's leaders - representatives from the faith groups and aid agencies which fund the umbrella body - are determined to stick with the original deadline despite opposition from within the coalition. "You can't turn a sprint into a marathon," says Adrian Lovett, Jubilee 2000's deputy director.

But developing country campaigners feel they are being abandoned by their northern partners with the job not even half done. The response from the coalition is that campaigning on debt will not end with Jubilee: the members will keep the campaign going.

webTitle: Millions in the bag for Dyson after winning dust-up with Hoover

fields.headline: Millions in the bag for Dyson after winning dust-up with Hoover
fields.standfirst: Go-it-alone inventor awaits damages after ruling that rival copied machine
fields.trailText: James Dyson, inventor of the bagless vacuum cleaner, yesterday scored a landmark victory at the high court over his arch rival Hoover, which was ruled to have copied his best dust-busting machine.
fields.body:
James Dyson, inventor of the bagless vacuum cleaner, yesterday scored a landmark victory at the high court over his arch rival Hoover, which was ruled to have copied his best dust-busting machine.

Mr Dyson, a serial inventor who first came to prominence in 1974 with his Ballbarrow - an "easy to steer" wheelbarrow - is hoping to win millions of pounds in damages and prevent further Hoover sales of bagless equipment at a final hearing on October 13.

Hoover had argued that Dyson's technology involved nothing that was not already known inside the industry. But deputy high court judge Michael Fysh QC ruled that Hoover had infringed the patent and dimissed a counterclaim for its revocation.

Hoover said it would appeal in the case, dubbed "floor wars", and has warned that hundreds of jobs at its Scottish production plant could be at risk if it failed.

Mr Dyson, 53, who was used to fighting the sceptics and reluctant financial backers in the early years, said the case was important for his 1,900 workers at Dyson Appliances in Malmesbury, Wiltshire. He saw it as a landmark victory for individual inventors and smaller businesses.

'False claims'

"I spent 20 years developing this technology and I am very pleased to see Hoover, who made a lot of false claims about their product, can't just rip off our designs and copy us," he said.

It is wrong for companies to be able to come in and copy other people's inventions, added Mr Dyson: "This case shows that this can be stopped."

The former interior designer, now feted by government, is not out of the woods yet. Alberto Bertali, managing director of Hoover UK, said its triple vortex cleaner had been a big success with customers and he would battle to the end to keep it on the shelves.

"We believe we were right to fight this case and presented what we thought was compelling evidence of technological and scientific differences [with Dyson's equipment]."

The case against Hoover involved infringement of Dyson's dual cyclone cleaner which uses centrifugal force to separate dirt from air. Hoover's triple vortex machine also dispensed with the traditional vacuum bag.

Prior to Dyson all vacuum cleaners worked on the principle that dirt was sucked up and separated by passing a stream of dirty air through a bag or a filter.

Mr Dyson made the first breakthrough in vacuum cleaner technology in 1979 and it was the first real change since Hoover pioneered a basic technique in 1908. He has spent the intervening years fighting off patent threats all over Europe but getting his revolutionary system off the ground was tough.

He hawked his new design around many of the big manufacturers, including Electrolux, Phillips and Black & Decker but none was interested in moving away from vacuum cleaners without bags.

Eventually, he borrowed £600,000 and set up his own company.

In the first year, Dyson's bagless cleaner clocked up sales of £2.4m. This rose to £10m the following year and by February 1995 the Dyson equipment had become the largest-selling cleaner in Britain. Now Dyson Appliances is selling nearly £300m worth of machines a year and claims to hold half of the British market by volume.

By contrast, Hoover, once the global giant of the vacuum world, has seen its market share dwindle to an estimated 10% following a series of gaffes, culminating in a disastrous marketing campaign in 1992.

Customers were offered free flights for every £100 spent on Hoover products. The open-ended offer attracted 600,000 people with the final cost - estimated at £50m - to Hoover's US owner Maytag which immediately sold off Hoover to its current Italian owner, Candy.

Mr Dyson likes to present himself as a plucky British underdog who has battled and won against the massive odds of multinational corporations.

But he is one of the top 50 richest people in this country - with an estimated personal fortune of £500m - and has recently started doing some of his manufacturing in Malaysia in an attempt to reduce costs and counter the impact of a high pound.

Self-made

Such a self-made industrialist should be a natural ally of the Conservative party but he is an ardent Europhile and has warned that failure to join the euro could encourage him to move more production overseas.

But he is no huge fan of the current government either, despite the fact that he lists Number 10 (along with Buckingham Palace and Elton John's house) as places where you will find his equipment.

He said recently: "In Britain there is more interest in making sure there are lots of dot.com millionaires and no interest in nurturing and caring about manufacturing."

Dyson's personal life revolves between his millhouse and headquarters in Wiltshire, a Queen Anne townhouse in Chelsea and a holiday farmhouse in Provence.

Born to academic parents in north Norfolk, Mr Dyson was educated at Gresham's School in Holt before going on to become a student of interior design at the Royal College of Art.

Design is a passion he shares with his wife, Deirdre, who he met when they studied together earlier in his student career at Byam Shaw art school.

fields.headline: Archer bailed on 5 counts
fields.trailText: Lord Archer was remanded on bail for six weeks yesterday on charges of perjury and perverting the course of justice relating to his successful 1987 libel case against the Daily Star.
fields.body:
Lord Archer was remanded on bail for six weeks yesterday on charges of perjury and perverting the course of justice relating to his successful 1987 libel case against the Daily Star.

The former Conservative candidate for London mayor appeared at Bow Street magistrates court, London, with his former friend Ted Francis, a television producer, who was charged with perverting the course of justice.

Last November Mr Francis claimed in the News of the World that Lord Archer had asked him to provide an alibi for use in the libel trial, and that he had done so. The revelation led Lord Archer to withdraw from the mayoral race and prompted a Scotland Yard investigation.

The pair did not acknowledge each other as they sat a metre apart in the dock. Lord Archer, 61, stared straight ahead. Both men are charged with perverting the course of justice in relation to Mr Francis's claim that Lord Archer asked him to write to his solicitors to say they had dined together at a Chelsea restaurant on September 9 1986.

The request was alleged to have come before the libel trial in which Lord Archer won £500,000 damages from the Daily Star which had accused him of sleeping with a prostitute, Monica Coghlan.

The alleged letter was not offered in evidence for the newspaper changed its evidence, claiming that Lord Archer slept with Ms Coghlan the previous day, a charge he has always denied.

Lord Archer was indicted on a further four charges relating to diaries presented in evidence at the libel trial. The second count of perverting the course of justice alleges that, knowing he was required to produce diaries or similar records relating to September 1986, he wilfully failed to produce his office diary.

It says he gave his secretary, Angela Peppiatt, a blank diary and details of entries which he told her to write in, and then passed the new diary to his solicitors for use in the trial, claiming it was his original office diary. There is a further charge of using a false instrument in relation to the diary.

Two counts of perjury state that on June 23 1987 he took an oath that he knew to be false relating to two further diaries and a daily appointments list and that on July 8 1987 wilfully gave false evidence concerning the time that his appointments for September 8 and 9 1986 were entered into his diary.

The two were ordered to return to court on November 14 and prohibited from contacting any civilian prosecution witnesses from the libel trial.

Perverting the course of justice carries a maximum penalty of life imprisonment, using a false instrument 10 years and perjury seven years.

webTitle: Parents create baby to save sister

fields.headline: Parents create baby to save sister
fields.standfirst:
Parents' 'donor' baby raises ethical worries
Special report: the ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: Doctors have used genetic screening to select a test-tube baby with precisely the right cells for him to act as a donor to his seriously ill older sister.
fields.byline: Julian Borger  in Washington and James Meek
fields.body:
Doctors have used genetic screening to select a test-tube baby with precisely the right cells for him to act as a donor to his seriously ill older sister.

The case, the first of its kind to come to light, is certain to open a fierce debate on the ethics of designing babies with specific genetic traits.

The procedure, based on a selective form of in vitro fertilisation, could save the life of the six-year-old girl, who is suffering from a rare inherited disorder called Fanconi anaemia, which stops cell production in the bone marrow. But it has raised the fear that the technique could be extended to enable parents to "design" children with a variety of genetic traits.

Researchers in the rapidly developing genetic sciences say they believe there have been several similar cases which have not been made public.

Many couples with children with inherited diseases face the dilemma of deciding whether to have more babies, knowing that they too could also be born with the disorder. Some have conceived only to abort the foetus as soon as they discovered that it shared the defective genes. In vitro selection offers a less traumatic alternative.

Adam Nash, the baby at the centre of the case reported yesterday, was born on August 29. At his birth, doctors collected cells from his umbilical cord, which were then infused into his elder sister, Molly.

Fanconi anaemia is universally fatal without a transplant, but Molly is now said to have a 85-90% chance of recovering.

Their parents, Lisa and Jack Nash, had a 25% chance of passing on the Fanconi gene to any new child and were afraid of conceiving normally. So they made use of a new technique called pre-implantation genetic diagnosis.

Twelve embryos were created by standard in vitro fertilisation and single cells were taken from each of them to test for the Fanconi gene, as well as other measures of compatibility with Molly. Two of the embryos was found to have both these attributes and one of those was considered healthy enough to transfer to Lisa Nash's uterus.

Mrs Nash said she had decided to publicise her case because it would help other couples facing the same problem.

"We just wanted people to know that the technology was out there," she said.

Dr Paul Veys, a bone marrow transplant specialist at Great Ormond Street children's hospital in London, said he believ ed the Illinois case was a rare instance in which designing a child to be a donor was ethically justified.

"In this case, hopefully, you're going to end up with two children who are healthy. How can you argue against that? It's difficult," he said.

He said his department always recommended parents against naturally conceiving children to be donors for more common, non-genetic, diseases which require bone marrow transplants, such as leukemia.

"The ethics of having a child as a donor for an existing child is in principle wrong and we would never encourage it. The child conceived might have the same disease as its sibling, and it's likely to lead to unhappiness for the child so born, especially if the transplant doesn't work."

He said he was sure some parents had ignored the advice and conceived a child as a transplant donor, but there was no way to be certain, since the parents might have wanted another child in any case.

To some bioethicists, the apparent success of the Nash case is a mixed blessing. While saving the life of a child, it also presages a possible future in which parents can choose "boutique babies" from a whole range of genetic traits.

"You could say it's quickly becoming like buying a new car, where you decide which package of accessories you want," Jeffrey Kahn, director of the University of Minnesota's centre for bioethics, said.

"I suspect that it's only because we don't yet have the tests that we're not having parents asking for embryos without a predisposition to homosexuality or for kids who will grow to more than 6ft tall."

Mrs Nash rejected the suggestion that she may have opened a genetic Pandora's box.

"I'm not forcing this on anyone, just as I don't want anyone else to force their views on me. I just wanted to do what was best for my family," she said.

Paul Billings, a co-founder of the genetic research company GeneSage, said: "This is not the first case of its kind. There have been others but they have not wanted publicity."

Dr Billings, who is on the board of the Council for Responsible Genetics, said: "On the one hand this could theoretically commodify children, but on the other hand there is no evidence that children conceived this way are loved any less.

"There is a danger we are making a mountain out of a personal tragedy. I don't think that people are going to rush to IVF treatments, which are an alienating and expensive procedure ...

"As long as this family loves the child, then we should stay out of their business."

webTitle: Pit strike leaders accused of sabotage

fields.headline: Pit strike leaders accused of sabotage
fields.standfirst:
Government begins crackdown on wave of demonstrations as students blockade streets of Belgrade

Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: In the first direct challenge to the wave of demonstrations against President Slobodan Milosevic, 11 striking miners and two Serbian opposition leaders were ordered to be detained on suspicion of sabotage yesterday.
fields.body:
In the first direct challenge to the wave of demonstrations against President Slobodan Milosevic, 11 striking miners and two Serbian opposition leaders were ordered to be detained on suspicion of sabotage yesterday.

The miners are members of the strike committee at Serbia's largest coal mine, Kolubara, where 4,500 workers have been on strike since Friday.

The two opposition leaders, Nebojsa Covic and Boris Tadic, visited the mine on Sunday night, when police sealed off the area. Mr Covic is the leader of the Democratic Alternative, a relatively small party within the opposition. Mr Tadic is deputy head of the larger Democratic Party.

The Belgrade public prosecutor demanded an investigation, saying there was a suspicion that they had "been accomplices in criminal sabotage".

Meanwhile, in the Yugoslav capital, tens of thousands of students walked out of exams and joined hands to form chains across major highways.

Anti-riot squad police stood by in blue camouflage fatigues as the students moved down the road toward Beli Dvor, the white palace of President Milosevic, shouting "Save Serbia and kill yourself, Slobodan" to the accompaniment of blaring car horns.

Two coachloads of the intervention squads were guarding Mr Milosevic's home, but the students sought disruption, not confrontation and when the road was blocked, they diverted to a square and another road.

Another group of tens of thousands of students marched from Plato square to Autokomanda square, just below the leafy suburb of Dedinje, home of Belgrade's rich.

The embattled government issued a statement threatening to crack down on the opposition, calling them subversive elements waging warfare through strikes and blockades.

In a statement, read on state television, it was announced that judges could jail those involved in civil disobedience for two to three months.

Dissenters in the judiciary were told to resign. But opposition leaders and supporters remained defiant and insisted that Mr Milosevic accept his landslide election defeat. They claim their results show that presidential challenger Vojislav Kostunica won the election outright and that the regime committed massive voting fraud.

A campaign of strikes and civil disobedience combined with legal appeals is being used to pressure the state election committee, which claims Mr Kostunica was not the outright winner of the presidential poll and is calling for a second round.

The opposition has ruled out participation in Sunday's planned run-off.

"No one has the right to so bluntly annul the people's will," said Mr Kostunica.

The opposition claims that a computer diskette thrown through a window of the Yugoslav statistics office building has provided them with evidence of the real results of the election on September 24.

Mladjan Dinkic, leader of the G17 independent think tank told a news conference: "We've got the proof now, but the electoral commission is the one to present the real results to the public."

Across the country, particularly in towns that fell to the opposition in last month's elections, strikes and blockades are crippling all activity.

On Monday night miners at the Kolubara complex ignored an appeal to return to work by the Yugoslavia army chief, Gen. Nebojsa Pavkovic - the first time Mr Milosevic has called on the military to help end the protests.

"We are under pressure from the police, psychological not physical pressure," said Predrag Stepanovic, a member of the strike committee.

fields.headline: Reporters rebel against Milosevic
fields.standfirst:
Media call for truthful coverage leads to sacking

Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: Hundreds of journalists working for state-controlled broadcasters and newspapers in Yugoslavia are demanding the right to report the news impartially, as Slobodan Milosevic's strangehold on the media begins to loosen.
fields.body:
Hundreds of journalists working for state-controlled broadcasters and newspapers in Yugoslavia are demanding the right to report the news impartially, as Slobodan Milosevic's strangehold on the media begins to loosen.

Their rebellion follows the failure of the state election commission to recognise the outright victory claimed by opposition presidential candidate Vojislav Kostunica in last month's presidential poll.

Yesterday the head of French and Italian programmes at Radio Yugoslavia - the closest thing in Belgrade to the BBC World Service - was fired for seeking a more balanced editorial policy.

Vladimir Pavlovic, who had worked for the broadcasting service for 26 years, said: "The editorial policy of Radio Yugoslavia comes from federal government - and in reality it comes from Milosevic and his wife, Mira Markovic."

The chief of Radio Yugoslavia, Ivan Markovic, is the minister of telecommunications and the spokesman for Ms Markovic's political party, the Yugoslav United Left.

"We have been all the time feeling bad about what Radio Yugoslavia does," Mr Pavlovic added. "But I'm a professional and it is my job."

He said that after the election eight journalists - out of a total of 200 employees at the service - formally requested a more balanced editorial policy.

"There's a big amount of repression. People are scared. I have a child I have to look after," he said. Despite his concerns for his job, he agreed to sign the journalists' written request.

"The petition is saying that we journalists of Radio Yugoslavia ask our general manager and editor to change the editorial policy, and to admit an alternative point of view. We want to make it possible for other voices to b e heard," he said.

When Mr Pavlovic went into work yesterday a security guard at the door confiscated his identity card.

Belgrade-based staff from the culture department of Radio Television Serbia (RTS), which is also controlled by the state, were yesterday planning a similar written request for more open coverage. Six employees working for RTS in Novi Sad, the second largest city, who circulated a petition calling for objective reporting have been sacked.

A number of local radio and TV stations that were within the RTS system have been boycotting the state news, which serves as the biggest television propaganda outlet for the Milosevic regime.

According to information gathered by the Belgrade-based Association of Independent Media, nine stations have stopped broadcasting RTS news. They include three broadcasters in the eastern town of Zajecar, previously a heartland of support for President Milosevic's coalition.

In the capital, more than 60 employees - including journalists - working for state-controlled Radio Belgrade are reported to be circulating a petition demanding a change in editorial policy.

A second Radio Belgrade channel is also said to be disrupted by protests, with staff also said to be calling for fair reporting.

Fifty reporters at the Vecernje Novosti newspaper are said to have called for a new editorial line. An open letter is also reportedly circulating demanding that the paper adopts an independent stance.

Of all the cities across Yugoslavia, Belgrade has been the most affected by a clampdown on all non-government broadcasting media, with the exception of a small student radio station.

In May police stormed the Belgrade City Studio B Station, the only non-government radio and television station with national reach. The station broadcast opposition viewpoints and was controlled by the opposition Serbian Renewal Movement.

Western European governments have sought to break the media isolation by funding a non-government radio station, Studio B292, which runs a website and can be heard by those with a satellite dish. Most people in the capital cannot afford such luxuries.

The B292 reports have been circulated and made available to radio stations in towns controlled by the opposition. As a result, residents of several provincial towns are far better informed about non-government activity than many people living in the capital.

webTitle: All you need is £50, Epstein told Beatles

fields.headline: All you need is £50, Epstein told Beatles
fields.trailText: Beatles manager Brian Epstein tried to persuade them to accept a fixed income of £50 a week, allowing him to pocket the millions they earned, the band's autobiography discloses.
fields.body:
Beatles manager Brian Epstein tried to persuade them to accept a fixed income of £50 a week, allowing him to pocket the millions they earned, the band's autobiography discloses.

In the first full account of their rise to fame in the 1960s, the three surviving Beatles reveal that the late Epstein had wanted the group to agree to the weekly pay deal for the rest of their lives. By this year they would have earned only £100,000.

The surviving band members, George Harrison, Ringo Starr and Sir Paul McCartney, collaborated with Yoko Ono, widow of John Lennon, to compile their story, The Beatles Anthology, which goes on sale on Thursday.

Harrison says in the autobiography: "We got 25 quid a week in the early sixties when we were first with Brian Epstein, when we played the clubs. My dad earned £10 a week, so I was earning two and a half times more than my father."

He adds: "Then we started earning much more, but Brian would keep it and pay us wages. He once tried to get us to sign a deal saying he would guarantee us £50 a week forever and he would keep the rest. We thought, 'No we'll risk it, Brian. We'll risk earning a bit more than £50 a week'."

The book also discredits the popular belief that Bob Dylan introduced the band to marijuana in the US in 1964. Quotes from Lennon, who would have been 60 next week, suggest they first tried it in 1960.

Harrison adds: "We first got marijuana from an older drummer with another group in Liverpool. Everybody was saying 'this stuff isn't doing anything'. It was like that old joke where a party is going on and two hippies are up floating on the ceiling and one is saying to the other 'this stuff doesn't work, man'."

More than 1.5m orders have been placed for the £35 book, which is to be published around the world simultaneously.

webTitle: Prague protesters say they were beaten in jail by police

fields.headline: Prague protesters say they were beaten in jail by police
fields.standfirst: Special report: the IMF and World Bank in Prague
fields.trailText: Human rights observers in Prague are expressing concern over allegations that protesters still behind bars have been mistreated after last week's anti-globalisation demonstrations in the Czech capital.
fields.body:
Human rights observers in Prague are expressing concern over allegations that protesters still behind bars have been mistreated after last week's anti-globalisation demonstrations in the Czech capital.

Assertions by released detainees that sexual and physical abuse has taken place are being investigated by Amnesty International as an increasing number of protesters come forward.

A spokesman for the British embassy in Prague said no complaints from Britons had been received. "Stories of Czech brutality or abuse are highly implausible, but if we get any official complaints we'll pass them on to the ministry of foreign affairs," he said.

Between 850 and 1,000 people were arrested during and after demonstrations which coincided with the annual meeting of the World Bank and IMF last Tuesday and attracted between 12,000 and 15,000 activists from around the world.

Legal observers say that "a few hundred" are still in custody and that the whereabouts of many are unknown, though a number have probably gone quietly home.

Groups of protesters have been campaigning this week at Czech embassies around Europe, including Britain, Italy, Norway and Poland, against the alleged police brutality.

Around 500 foreigners are believed to have been arrested, including a large number of Germans and Spanish.

According to police, 25 people have been charged, including six Czechs. All 34 Britons arrested are believed to have been released. A 21-year-old university student from London told the Guardian he was picked up at a pub by police on the evening after the September 26 demonstration outside a meeting of international financiers.

His hands were bound with plastic so tight, he said, that his wrists swelled. He was strip-searched, his fingerprints and photograph were taken and he was then kept in a four metre by four metre cell with 35 other people.

Anyone who tried to sleep was woken up by bright lights and an officer running a stick along the cell bars. People were strip-searched in front of him and slapped when naked.

"I got off fairly lightly in comparison to the Italians and Israelis who they pointed at and beat up in a very fascistic way," he added.

"When they took 25 of us to the third destination we had to run towards the bus through two lines of police who hit us in the kidneys with their truncheons and fists. There were women as well, and they laughed as they hit us. Afterwards there were several bleeding noses."

Like other detainees, the student said he was denied access to a translator most of the time, forced to sign Czech documents he did not understand and deprived of sleep and food.

According to OPH - a group whose members, including several lawyers, monitored the observance of justice during the protests - two Norwegian tourists who went to a police station in the north of Prague to report a stolen mobile phone, saw "a number of people handcuffed to the wall who were being beaten severely".

Other reports claim that arrested women were asked to strip and perform physical exercises in front of male officers.

A British woman in her 20s, who suffers from epilepsy, was reportedly forced to mime her condition to prison officers and was then hit for refusing to take the medicine made available to her.

Both legal observers and Inpeg, the organiser of the main demonstration, say that medical reports confirm the physical abuse.

While the Czech police were widely praised for their handling of the street violence, most of those arrested appear to have been picked up on the streets long after the demonstration and had no direct connection with the violence launched by a few hundred hardcore anarchists.

Legal observers and Inpeg say they are hiring lawyers to fight cases of alleged maltreatment. OPH also plans criminal complaints against the Czech police who have so far barely commented on the allegations.

"This is not some strange country like the Ukraine, and we have no information on anyone being badly treated," said a spokeswoman for the Prague division of Czech police. "It's nonsense, but if anyone feels they have been badly treated they can go to the department of complaints and control."

webTitle: Portillo claims he has room for tax cuts reinvention

fields.headline: Portillo claims he has room for tax cuts reinvention
fields.standfirst:
Economy: Annual rise in spending promised

Special report: Conservative party conference 2000
fields.trailText: Michael Portillo yesterday returned from exile to the Conservative conference platform with an extraordinary mixture of the new "touchy-feely" confessional politics and the traditional Tory promise to combine better public services with lower taxes.
fields.body:
Michael Portillo yesterday returned from exile to the Conservative conference platform with an extraordinary mixture of the new "touchy-feely" confessional politics and the traditional Tory promise to combine better public services with lower taxes.

"I plan to spend more on public services in every year than Labour has spent in any year. But I don't intend to spend money the country hasn't earned. I will leave room for tax cuts," said Mr Portillo - setting out the election formula he has agreed with William Hague.

Treasury ministers leapt on that last night because Mr Portillo later admitted on BBC2's Conference Live that his pledge to match Labour's spending on the NHS does not "at the moment" extend to education or transport.

Labour renewed its claims that a Hague cabinet would gouge £16 billion from Gordon Brown's spending plans, though aides confirmed yesterday that the shadow chancellor has told his leader that he will initially stick to Labour's spending plans.

That would mean only gradually moving to get spending growth below the underlying trend growth in the economy, 2.2% a year, compared with Mr Brown's promised 3.3%.

But what Mr Portillo called "dry economics" was not what caught the conference's attention. It was his relaxed style, enhanced by the fact that his 30 minute speech had been memorised by heart.

In his first appearance as shadow chancellor since returning to Westminster last winter, Mr Portillo went out of his way to show how he has changed since his hard-line "Who dares?" speech in the same Bournemouth conference hall in 1995.

"I was devastated by my defeat (in Enfield in 1997)....but the British electorate did me a favour. My period out of parliament was a chance to connect with the Britain of today," Mr Portillo declared, explaining that his exposure to poverty and illness - as a TV reporter and hospital porter - had left an indelible mark.

"My job is not just about dry economics. The quality of life cannot be measured in material terms alone. We are the party that understands how much the world has changed," he told party activists.

Mr Hague has been pushing the moderate "hot buttons" in Bournemouth in what is likely to be the last pre-election conference. At a Bow Group rally yesterday, the shadow foreign secretary, Francis Maude, admitted that politics is held in "widespread contempt". But Mr Portillo's contrition was the most dramatic. He spoke out for "rich ethnic diversity" - exemplified by Britain's Olympic success - for respect towards sexual minorities, for state school pupils like himself and William Hague and even for asylum seekers "who come to Britain in fear of their lives.

"That's how my father came," Mr Portillo, son of a leftwing professor who fled the Spanish civil war, reminded his audience. Later he denounced "Little Englandism" - with which he was once associated - asking how a half-Spaniard could be one.

During his denunciation of the European single currency which "fails to respect Europe's differences" the former defence secretary even lapsed briefly into a Spanish proverb, a version of "look before you leap." This was a new Portillo, clearly meant to be less macho or arrogant than in his Thatcherite heyday.

There was a political motive behind his portrait of the new Britain as flexible, self-reliant and responsible. Britain would be stronger "if we had fewer politicians passing fewer laws, raising fewer taxes and intruding less in our lives. Young people reject the Labour party's bossiness, meddling, banning and regulating," he said.

The core of the shadow chancellor's economic message yesterday was therefore a renewed pledge to cut taxes -on business and enterprise - focus public spending effectively, to simplify both Labour regulation and over-complicated taxes.

He also accused Gordon Brown of stealth taxes on the poor which are unfair. "There is no social justice in high taxation,"he said.

Another priority will be to increase the savings ratio - the amount of income which households save - down from 10.6% in 1997 to 3% according to figures issued yesterday.

Justifying his much-trailed gamble on using private health insurance to generate more cash for the NHS, Mr Portillo claimed: "there's a consensus among the parties that we should spend much more money on the NHS, but not on how to spend it or how that money can be supplemented."

In his speech yesterday Mr Maude set out rules for the New Toryism - starting by making "relentless honesty" its first hallmark. Integrity and a willingness to "admit it when we have got things wrong and to apologise," are also necessary to regain public respect.

Like Mr Portillo he deplored Little England attitudes and said the Tories must be a national party. Mr Maude called for sexual tolerance and made a Portillo-esque reference to his own private life, his gay brother who died of Aids.

fields.headline: Fresh gunfire shatters Israeli truce
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: A truce between Israel and the Palestinians survived barely half a day yesterday before dying in the roar of automatic fire and rockets from helicopter gunships.
fields.body:
A truce between Israel and the Palestinians survived barely half a day yesterday before dying in the roar of automatic fire and rockets from helicopter gunships.

The rupturing of the truce, agreed by Israeli and Palestinian security officials overnight, undermines the hope that a US-sponsored meeting between the leaders of the two peoples in Paris today can stem the bloodshed.

The first shots yesterday were fired during the funeral procession of a Palestinian teenager in the West Bank city of Nablus. Gunmen in the crowd of 3,000 mourners opened fire on an isolated Israeli army post guarding a Jewish pilgrimage site.

Within an hour Israeli soldiers firing sub-machineguns in the Gaza Strip had shot the face off a Palestinian in a group advancing on an outpost at Netzarim junction. About a dozen rockets were fired from the gunships overhead.

Netzarim is infamous as the site of the bloodiest clashes in the past six days, the setting of the horrifying death of a 12-year-old boy broadcast around the world at the weekend.

Yesterday the Israeli army admitted that snipers firing from the fortified post had killed Mohammed al-Direh. It said the boy, shot four times as he cowered in his father's arms, had been mistaken for a gunmen.

By nightfall last night the death toll from six days of violence stood at 55: 43 Palestinians, nine Arab Israelis, an Israeli border policeman, an Israeli soldier and an Israeli Jewish civilian. "Our estimate is that the climax of this thing lies before us, and his wave of violence will continue," the Israeli deputy army chief, Major- General Moshe Yaalon, said.

Nevertheless, the US secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, remained optimistic. "We are going to defuse this," she told reporters.

But the collapse of the third ceasefire since the violence began has increased the fear that it may have grown beyond Mr Arafat's powers to control.

The sheer fury of the rioters, and their willingness to court death, has come as a shock to Palestinian officials.

fields.headline: Tories' £1bn for married mothers
fields.standfirst: Special report: Conservative party conference 2000
fields.trailText: The Conservatives are planning the strongest signal yet of their support for marriage by offering a transferable personal tax allowances exclusively to married couples with young children.
fields.body:
The Conservatives are planning the strongest signal yet of their support for marriage by offering a transferable personal tax allowances exclusively to married couples with young children.

The plan would remove many of the current tax disadvantages facing a family when the wife wishes to stay at home to look after young children.

At present the first £4,500 of earnings is tax free. Making the notional allowance of a wife staying at home transferable to her husband would give him £9,000 tax free.

Shadow ministers are studying proposals for a £1bn fund aimed at 3m married couples with young children. They believe the proposal would recognise marriage, extend women's choice, and help families with children at a time of particular financial pressure.

The idea, supported by David Willetts, the shadow social secretary, was drafted by a welfare policy committee set up his predecessor, Iain Duncan-Smith. Its technical aspects have been tested by the Institute of Fiscal Studies.

It is being studied by the shadow Treasury team. Michael Portillo, the shadow chancellor has been cool about the proposal, first floated in the 1997 Tory manifesto, but is under pressure to accept it.

The package is likely to replace the party's support for the return of the married couples allowance, a benefit enjoyed by all couples whether or not they had children, abolished earlier this year.

The committee was initially divided on whether to suggest specific help to married couples, fearing that it would expose the party to a repetition of the disastrous era of "back to basics", when its MPs found their private lives did not matchparty policy.

The suggestion that the allowance should be transferred only between married partners and not those cohabiting will prove controversial.

However, the Conservatives have seen surveys which suggest that 75-80% of single parents would like their children to marry eventually and show that, despite the spiralling divorce rate, support for marriage remains stubbornly high among those not yet married and the formerly married.

William Hague told the Conservative conference yesterday: "I will restore the recognition of marriage in our tax and benefit system."

He stressed that he did not want the party to insist that everyone had to live in a married family, but said: "I do believe it is much the best thing for our society if the vast majority of people are in stable and happy families - and marriage is usually the cornerstone of a stable and successful family."

Stressing that it was his personal view that transferable tax allowance should be restricted to married couples, Mr Willetts, one of the most experienced minds in welfare reform, said: "Something happens when people marry that does not happen when they co-habit. It marks a public commitment."

He added: "If you become one family unit, the benefit system has no difficulty recognising this, but the tax system does not do so well in recognising marriage."

He believes it is difficult to establish a watertight definition of cohabiting with which the Inland Revenue could be happy. In France experiments with so-called solidarity pacts between unmarried couples have proved flawed and liable to benefit abuse.

He would like to see the transferable tax allowance aimed at the 3m families with children under five.The tight focus would have greater financial impact than helping all 13m married couples.

The Conservatives believe that the policy chimes with the aspiration of many women who want to stay at home during their child's early years. They believe Labour may have misread the mood of many women by putting so much emphasis on helping them to go out to fulltime work and considering paid paternity leave.

webTitle: What unemployed people are watching on television

fields.headline: Random views
fields.standfirst: What unemployed people are watching on television
fields.trailText: What unemployed people are watching on television
fields.body:
Ben Still:
"I like watching the kids' programmes, like S Club Go Wild, I really like it. I think it's ridiculous that a group who sing about nothing at all get to go and save monkeys and elephants and things. They take it so seriously! What a load of bollocks! I like TV, keeps me interested. I'm a musician but I do find I write songs better when I'm watching Countdown. I get pissed off with the adverts though, for housewives. They should do them for unemployed people. 'Get stoned! It wastes most of your day!' Things like that."

Harriet Lofthouse:
"I tend to watch things like the news so I feel I'm doing my brain some good, otherwise it turns to sponge if you watch Richard and Judy every day. Have you noticed how serious the new series is? It's all about death and depression, it's really dull. I like things like Morse and I like mystery things too."

Dylan Blue:
"I like listening to music more, but I probably have the TV on at night when my boyfriend gets back from work. I think it's boring. Last thing I watched? I was trashed at the weekend and I did see something about - what was it about? Some film or other I think - no, it was that awful thing on Friday, Eurotrash."

Carol France:
"I don't watch a lot of telly unless I'm at friends' houses. I don't have a TV at home at the moment. The old one broke. I bought one from Brixton market but it only worked for two days, so I turned it into a blackboard and write my daily lists on it. I like Coronation Street and the soaps, I get really involved."

Jo Fennel:
"I like The Cops and the new one, what is it? Applications? Attachments, that's it. I like that hand-held stuff, yeah. I like Friends as well, though why to god that music says they've had a bad week and month and year - they've got boyfriends and money. None of them are boring. It's not like real life at all. They should show my flatmates, look at all the dodgy people you find on your sofa."

Sian Pattenden spoke to people claiming benefit in London

fields.headline: Hague welcomes live TV debates
fields.standfirst:
Challenge

Special report: Conservative party conference 2000
fields.trailText: The prospect of unprecedented live TV debates during the coming general election grew yesterday when Labour said it would examine closely a call from William Hague yesterday for the parties to hold TV debates free from advisers and spin doctors.
fields.body:
The prospect of unprecedented live TV debates during the coming general election grew yesterday when Labour said it would examine closely a call from William Hague yesterday for the parties to hold TV debates free from advisers and spin doctors.

Plans for a similar debate foundered before the 1997 election when John Major insisted he would not debate with Tony Blair if the then Liberal Democrat leader Paddy Ashdown also participated.

However aides to Hague said yesterday he would be willing to see Charles Kennedy, the Liberal Democrat leader take part. They believe Hague is such a good debater he would be able to wipe the floor even if he was effectively up against the combined attack of Blair and Kennedy.

There have already been informal contacts between the parties and the broadcasters to discuss the format.

Privately the Liberal Democrats believe Blair as the front runner will try to manoeuvre his party out of a debate, possibly citing the need to accommodate the nationalist parties,

However, the Labour Party responded cautiously yesterday saying they would study any proposals carefully, but had no objection in principle to TV debates.

Hague made his challenge yesterday saying: "At the next election there should be a live televised debate without any advisors or spin doctors between Hague and Blair".

Hague also used a confident performance to say that if he had children he would send them to the local state school "because there are good state schools around where I live". The true solution to successful schools, he said, lay not in endless regulations, but in good quality headteachers.

He also sought to allay fears that the party's plans to expand private health care would undermine the NHS. He said "Don't let anyone lecture us about how the Tories don't believe in the NHS.

"He claimed Labour's reorganisation of the NHS had led to bureaucracy and inefficiency, putting Britain at the bottom of the league table in treatment of cancer and heart treatment.

fields.headline: Bournemouth diary
fields.standfirst: Special report: Conservative party conference 2000
fields.trailText: • Biggest Willieville joke is Jim Davidson who thinks Tony Blair is a dangerous socialist and Europe the new Soviet threat. The BBC's nick-nick is so right-wing he is in danger of disappearing off the Tory map as he utters very non-one nation views on race, gays and Michael Portillo. His peculiar brand of bonhomie was on parade at a late night party hosted by Conservative chairman Michael Ancram. Davidson, leaning against a wall after   a hard day, swore at anyone who crossed him. Ancram, a decent Tory toff, then sat the comic next to Denis Thatcher while the handbag woman appeared on the platform. Davidson was the star turn at last night's chairman's ball. If the Generation Game host tried to play it in Bournemouth, the dearth of young people would force him to pit the over-65s against the over-85s.

Ancram, a decent Tory toff, then sat the comic next to Denis Thatcher while the handbag woman appeared on the platform. Davidson was the star turn at last night's chairman's ball. If the Generation Game host tried to play it in Bournemouth, the dearth of young people would force him to pit the over-65s against the over-85s.

 Tonytown's wire fences kept demonstrators out last week, Willieville's keep them in this week. Swivel-eyed Europhobes, hangers and floggers, tweedy fox hunters, heavily subsidised farmers and angry shopkeepers strut their stuff in the Tory fiefdom. There is no whiff of power, however, no indication they really believe they might win the election. A lifesize cardboard cut-out of Tony Blair was auctioned off in Brighton for £275. The highest bid for a virtual William Hague? £5.

 Hague has at least one genuine admirer (spin doctors insist Ffion is another) in the shape of Nigel, his dad. Pop Hague sauntered over to the Politico's book stall to buy three copies of a flattering biography of his son. That is one more than Michael Heseltine sold all day.

 Lager costs £3 a pint in Willieville, 25p more than in Tonytown and equivalent to £5.28 a litre or £24 a gallon. Food prices have also gone up, a tenner being added to the Royal Bath hotel's fixed dinner menu that cost £30 a fortnight ago when the Lib Dems were in town and is now £40. Perhaps they do have more money than sense.

 The Tories have won one poll against Labour. In Tonytown at Brighton, 9.18am was the earliest the Scotch Whisky Association was asked for a free sample. In Willieville, one representative developed a thirst at 9.04am. Hague is reformed, however. Asked if he was going for a pint, he yelled "yes" before holding up a solitary finger.

 Lady Thatcher received a spic and span welcome yesterday from Tory bigwigs. Before she walked on stage yesterday, an official was sent out to hoover the blue carpet.

webTitle: New Sudan rises from the ruins of war

fields.headline: New Sudan rises from the ruins of war
fields.standfirst: Riven for decades by bloody conflict, the giant of Africa finally looks ready to take its place in the world
fields.trailText: For the first time in nearly two decades there is a chance of an end to the war in southern Sudan which has taken half the country out of the control of Khartoum, and plunged its people back more than half a century into isolation and backwardness.
fields.byline: Victoria Brittain in Yirol, southern Sudan
fields.body:
For the first time in nearly two decades there is a chance of an end to the war in southern Sudan which has taken half the country out of the control of Khartoum, and plunged its people back more than half a century into isolation and backwardness.

"I went six years without tasting salt, we used tree bark for washing - this was our life," says Bishop Reuben, one of the few senior church figures to have stayed in the small town of Yirol rather than heading for the comfort of Nairobi, or even, as some have, to Khartoum.

Today Sudan's new international prominence, with a likely seat on the United Nations security council as the candidate of the Organisation of African Unity, its immense new oil riches, combined with major shifts in internal and regional politics, may have created an international impetus to end the long conflict.

Two million people have died; twice as many displaced internally; hundreds of thousands live as refugees in the shanty towns of the north or in exile and southern culture and society have been fractured by guns and warlords.

But in the last year clan elders, church leaders, and a number of former commanders in the Sudan People's Liberation Army (SPLA) have started something new in places like Yirol - organising peasants for what they call New Sudan.

Sudan is the biggest country in Africa. Since independence from Britain in 1956 there has been continuous war between the Arab north and the marginalised African south, except for one decade from 1972. The imposition by Khartoum of Islamic sharia law in 1983 unleashed a far more serious war which has spread from the south to the eastern front, the Nuba mountains, and is increasingly concentrated around the oilfields in the centre.

Last week, in an unprecedented gesture, President Omar el Bashir travelled to the Eritrean capital, Asmara, to meet leaders of the National Democratic Alliance (NDA) which links the southern SPLA with opposition groups from the north in a military alliance which has inflicted major defeats on Khartoum.

This was just one of a number of diplomatic meetings, with others in Uganda and Kenya at the same time. Egypt has become a key player.

For several months Washington has been canvassing a Dayton-type scenario for Sudan with all the myriad opposition groups forced together to hammer out a settlement under international auspices.

And Washington has begun to disburse $3m to civic projects in southern Sudan, such as a judicial system, which will soon trickle through to towns like Yirol.

Bomb shelters

The SPLA has taken control of almost this entire region, mainly of Dinka cattle-rearers, in the last three years. Earlier, control swung back and forth between rebels and government. Across the south the government controls only garrison towns supplied mainly from the north by air, though some traders cross between control areas.

The only contact most southerners have with the government is the periodic bombing of church compounds, hospitals, airstrips, markets and boreholes, in retribution for SPLA military gains. In two weeks of August more than 100 bombs were dropped. Every church compound has a bomb shelter.

The UN's Operation Lifeline Sudan (OLS) has a 10-year-old programme with the government to fly in humanitarian supplies to designated sites in the south agreed by Khartoum. But, increasingly, aid agencies such as Christian Aid, Concern, and Norwegian People's Aid are flying in defiance of Khartoum, sending small civilian supply planes from northern Kenya to a dozen or more airstrips cut through the long grass. They are helping some 5m people in SPLA areas.

Food, cement, even a generator, were on our plane, chartered by a church group and flown by a Russian former MiG pilot.

Roads in the liberated areas are few and in terrible condition. A 100-mile drive took us eight hour. Many bridges and ferries have been destroyed and only canoes cross the wide tributaries of the Nile which criss-cross the area. The traders, who now bring salt, sugar, tea and cloth to Yirol's market, walk for a month to Uganda for supplies.

But Yirol is a symbol of the extraordinary resilience which has kept the society from disintegrating under the squeeze of isolation. The old ways live on and an enthusiastic crowd soon gathers around a wild group of young men who have come into town from the huge cattle camp outside.

Bunched tightly together by older men in skins and carrying spears, they perform a ceremonial dance to insistent drumming. They are celebrating the end of an initiation ceremony in which they have spent three months playing together, being fattened on milk, and looked after by a young girl who is then carried in on the shoulders of a group of men. This custom was officially banned by the SPLA last year, but some groups continue the tradition.

"If any of our old practices deserves to be banned it is this one - the most productive group sits idle for three months before becoming a man - this is just not sustainable given how people are living now with the war," said one former SPLA commander.

He, and several others in the town, are dragging their people into the modern world and the New Sudan through a new organisation called the Bahr el Ghazal Development Association (BYDA).

"Look what happened in Somalia when they got rid of Siad Barre [the president], but hadn't prepared the society for a new situation - a decade without government. We cannot afford to wait for peace and then build a new society, we have to start now," said one senior ex-commander, Mario Muor Muor.

End of isolation

BYDA has introduced ox-ploughing and micro-credit - staples of modest rural development elsewhere but in this context as revolutionary as the microchip.

It took six months of discussion before the SPLA allowed BYDA to operate, accepting it as a partner, not a rival. The organisation, with its many ex-SPLA commanders, is a product of dissent within the south's historic movement.

The SPLA's unchallenged leader, John Garang, has been fighting for the south since the mid-1950s. But in the last 17 years of war the SPLA has been split by betrayals and factionalism. It has lived by a military culture imbued in years of training in Ethiopia which gave the movement military strength at the price of a culture of silence, according to Mr Muor. Despite a major conference in 1994 in which resolutions were passed to involve and empower the people they were fighting for, change never came within the SPLA.

However, in the last year, the New Sudan Council of Churches (NSCC) succeeded in organising a series of peace meetings which has ended muchof the south/south fighting which has been a constant strand of the north/south war.

Mr Muor was part of the coalition that put together the first historic meeting at Wunlit, in March 1999. Three hundred youths were mobilised to build a road and airstrip. Elders, clan leaders and commanders were brought together by the NSCC and committed themselves to end the periodic fighting between the Dinka and Nuer tribes and the shifting alliances with the government against the SPLA.

Last week, in an unprecedented gesture, President Omar el Bashir travelled to the Eritrean capital, Asmara, to meet leaders of the National Democratic Alliance (NDA) which links the southern SPLA with opposition groups from the north in a military alliance which has inflicted major defeats on Khartoum. This was just one of a number of diplomatic meetings, with others in Uganda and Kenya at the same time. Egypt has become a key player. For several months Washington has been canvassing a Dayton-type scenario for Sudan with all the myriad opposition groups forced together to hammer out a settlement under international auspices. And Washington has begun to disburse $3m to civic projects in southern Sudan, such as a judicial system, which will soon trickle through to towns like Yirol. Bomb shelters The SPLA has taken control of almost this entire region, mainly of Dinka cattle-rearers, in the last three years. Earlier, control swung back and forth between rebels and government. Across the south the government controls only garrison towns supplied mainly from the north by air, though some traders cross between control areas. The only contact most southerners have with the government is the periodic bombing of church compounds, hospitals, airstrips, markets and boreholes, in retribution for SPLA military gains. In two weeks of August more than 100 bombs were dropped. Every church compound has a bomb shelter. The UN's Operation Lifeline Sudan (OLS) has a 10-year-old programme with the government to fly in humanitarian supplies to designated sites in the south agreed by Khartoum. But, increasingly, aid agencies such as Christian Aid, Concern, and Norwegian People's Aid are flying in defiance of Khartoum, sending small civilian supply planes from northern Kenya to a dozen or more airstrips cut through the long grass. They are helping some 5m people in SPLA areas. Food, cement, even a generator, were on our plane, chartered by a church group and flown by a Russian former MiG pilot. Roads in the liberated areas are few and in terrible condition. A 100-mile drive took us eight hour. Many bridges and ferries have been destroyed and only canoes cross the wide tributaries of the Nile which criss-cross the area. The traders, who now bring salt, sugar, tea and cloth to Yirol's market, walk for a month to Uganda for supplies. But Yirol is a symbol of the extraordinary resilience which has kept the society from disintegrating under the squeeze of isolation. The old ways live on and an enthusiastic crowd soon gathers around a wild group of young men who have come into town from the huge cattle camp outside. Bunched tightly together by older men in skins and carrying spears, they perform a ceremonial dance to insistent drumming. They are celebrating the end of an initiation ceremony in which they have spent three months playing together, being fattened on milk, and looked after by a young girl who is then carried in on the shoulders of a group of men. This custom was officially banned by the SPLA last year, but some groups continue the tradition. "If any of our old practices deserves to be banned it is this one - the most productive group sits idle for three months before becoming a man - this is just not sustainable given how people are living now with the war," said one former SPLA commander. He, and several others in the town, are dragging their people into the modern world and the New Sudan through a new organisation called the Bahr el Ghazal Development Association (BYDA). "Look what happened in Somalia when they got rid of Siad Barre [the president], but hadn't prepared the society for a new situation - a decade without government. We cannot afford to wait for peace and then build a new society, we have to start now," said one senior ex-commander, Mario Muor Muor. End of isolation BYDA has introduced ox-ploughing and micro-credit - staples of modest rural development elsewhere but in this context as revolutionary as the microchip. It took six months of discussion before the SPLA allowed BYDA to operate, accepting it as a partner, not a rival. The organisation, with its many ex-SPLA commanders, is a product of dissent within the south's historic movement. The SPLA's unchallenged leader, John Garang, has been fighting for the south since the mid-1950s. But in the last 17 years of war the SPLA has been split by betrayals and factionalism. It has lived by a military culture imbued in years of training in Ethiopia which gave the movement military strength at the price of a culture of silence, according to Mr Muor. Despite a major conference in 1994 in which resolutions were passed to involve and empower the people they were fighting for, change never came within the SPLA. However, in the last year, the New Sudan Council of Churches (NSCC) succeeded in organising a series of peace meetings which has ended muchof the south/south fighting which has been a constant strand of the north/south war. Mr Muor was part of the coalition that put together the first historic meeting at Wunlit, in March 1999. Three hundred youths were mobilised to build a road and airstrip. Elders, clan leaders and commanders were brought together by the NSCC and committed themselves to end the periodic fighting between the Dinka and Nuer tribes and the shifting alliances with the government against the SPLA.
