webTitle: Fixed penalty plan for soft drug users

fields.headline: Fixed penalty plan for soft drug users
fields.standfirst:
Crime

Special report: Conservative party conference 2000
fields.trailText: Ann Widdecombe will today unveil new hardline Conservative policies against the recreational use of soft drugs when she announces a £100 automatic fixed penalty for possession of cannabis.
fields.body:
Ann Widdecombe will today unveil new hardline Conservative policies against the recreational use of soft drugs when she announces a £100 automatic fixed penalty for possession of cannabis.

The Tory leadership remains as hostile as Labour to calls for cannabis to be decriminalised and today's creation of the equivalent of a parking ticket - paid without a court appearance - is not intended to signal a softer line.

Some 90,000 people a year are fined for possession of cannabis and many more are cautioned in those police authorities where a less severe view is taken. Under Tory plans the caution option would be closed.

In her speech to the party conference in Bournemouth the shadow home secretary - currently darling of the Tory activists - will underline the traditional view by urging substantially higher penalties for anyone caught in possession of larger amounts that may be used for dealing purposes.

Under a Hague government the police would also gain further powers to raid crack houses. Only last week Tony Blair told his conference that he wants the police to be able to "do more damage" to the illegal drugs industry than it does to society at large.

As part of her law and order package Miss Widdecombe will also back calls for a new penalty of driving under the influence of drugs, closing an anomaly which allows drunken drivers to be heavily penalised but drug-users to escape.

She has already called for "cops in shops" this week, a scheme requiring policemen and women to write up their reports in public places. Miss Widdecombe also wishes to introduce a scheme allowing 16-year-olds to become part-time police cadets used on duty by adult police. She believes this would encourage full recruitment at 18 and might discourage anti-police attitudes.

webTitle: Clarke scorns shadow chancellor's euro view as 'blithering nonsense'

fields.headline: Clarke scorns shadow chancellor's euro view as 'blithering nonsense'
fields.standfirst:
Europe

Special report: Conservative party conference 2000
fields.trailText: Conservative divisions over Europe were laid bare in public yesterday when Kenneth Clarke rounded on Michael Portillo for talking "blithering economic nonsense" about the single currency. Angered by a fiercely Eurosceptic speech to the conference by the shadow chancellor, Mr Clarke told the Tory leadership that it should learn to develop "grown up" policies if it wants to win the election.
fields.body:
Conservative divisions over Europe were laid bare in public yesterday when Kenneth Clarke rounded on Michael Portillo for talking "blithering economic nonsense" about the single currency. Angered by a fiercely Eurosceptic speech to the conference by the shadow chancellor, Mr Clarke told the Tory leadership that it should learn to develop "grown up" policies if it wants to win the election.

The former chancellor, who once worked happily with Mr Portillo at the Treasury, launched the scathing verdict on his former colleague during an appearance on the BBC's Conference Live programme. "When he got to the obligatory euro bit [in his speech] that was the only thing they cheered to the echo," Mr Clarke said. "It was what I sadly regard as blithering economic nonsense."

Mr Clarke's outspoken attack on one of the most senior members of the shadow cabinet demonstrated that the Tory civil war over Europe is likely to intensify in the run up to the election.

The former chancellor demonstrated his determination to defy the leadership throughout the day yesterday. At lunchtime Mr Clarke lambasted William Hague over Europe at the very moment that the Tory leader told a Keep the Pound rally that the pound would form the centrepiece of his election campaign. Standing on the back of his trademark truck in the rain, Mr Hague said that no sane business would join a bankrupt or loss making forms such as the European Union economy.

Francis Maude, the shadow foreign secretary, stepped up the leadership's attacks on the euro when he claimed that "economic union always led to political union".

He added: "All the evidence of history shows currency union ends in political union. We need to rely on theory to find that out. You just have to listen to what politicians on the continent are saying." Mr Clarke hit back with a warning against extremism over Europe. "The Conservatives will not win the general election if we adopt a policy of extreme Euroscepticism," he told a Conservative Group for Europe fringe meeting. "The support of pro-Europeans is crucial if we are to win the next election."

webTitle: New plan to aid poorer pupils ballots

fields.headline: New plan to aid poorer pupils ballots
fields.standfirst:
Education

Special report: Conservative party conference 2000
Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The Conservatives will scrap ballots to abolish grammar schools and revive subsidised places for poorer students in the independent sector, the shadow education secretary, Theresa May, pledged yesterday.
fields.body:
The Conservatives will scrap ballots to abolish grammar schools and revive subsidised places for poorer students in the independent sector, the shadow education secretary, Theresa May, pledged yesterday.

In a new version of the assisted places programme, money spent on a bright secondary pupil from a poorer background in the state sector could be transferred to help fund their private school place. Unlike the old scheme, phased out by Labour, the school would make up the shortfall.

Under the Tories' "free schools" plan, which strips powers from local authorities and allows headteachers and governors to set their own admissions policy, the party can no longer promise a grammar school in every town.

But Mrs May told the conference she was "confident that yes, there will be more grammar schools". Later she said she supported a "mixed economy" of selective and non-selective education.

Only one ballot on selection, in Ripon, North Yorkshire, has been held, which was won decisively by supporters of grammar schools. Anti-selection campaigners have complained that rules of the polls have made it all but impossible to get them off the ground.

Mrs May promised to give heads and governors complete autonomy to expel pupils, denying parents the right of appeal to local authorities.

"Teachers are more vulnerable than any other group of professionals to false allegations of abuse from children," she said. The law would be changed to give teachers media anonymity when they were accused of abuse, until charges were brought.

In higher education, Mrs May repeated the promise to "progressively endow" universities, giving them lump sums from the sale of government assets such as the radio spectrum. They could use the interest to ensure financial freedom.

She attacked the chancellor for his explosive intervention in the debate on university admissions. "In one speech [Gordon Brown] has done more to discourage state school pupils from aspiring to go to our leading universities than anyone else."

webTitle: Dredger captain says saving victims from Marchioness 'not top priority'

fields.headline: Dredger captain says saving victims from Marchioness 'not top priority'
fields.standfirst: More about the Marchioness disaster
fields.trailText: Eleven years after he captained the dredger Bowbelle when it collided with the pleasure boat Marchioness, Douglas Henderson sat before survivors and relatives of the 51 dead yesterday and declined to express remorse.
fields.body:
Eleven years after he captained the dredger Bowbelle when it collided with the pleasure boat Marchioness, Douglas Henderson sat before survivors and relatives of the 51 dead yesterday and declined to express remorse.

The captain, now 42 and still a serving seaman, admitted misleading police about the number of people on lookout duty that night. He admitted drinking six pints and then sleeping for a little under three hours before the Bowbelle's night-time journey. He also declared that rescuing the drowning passengers of the Marchioness "was not one of my top priorities".

Mr Henderson was tried in 1991 on a charge of failing to keep a proper lookout. The jury failed to reach a verdict, as did another jury at a second trial and he was acquitted.

Under cross-examination yesterday, the captain defended his decision not to release the dredger's lifebuoys when he realised that his ship had struck another: "At the time it was not a matter that was one of my top priorities. I did not give any consideration to releasing them."

He went on: "I realised something was wrong and ran to the stern of the vessel. I left the helmsman at the bridge.

"I can't recall exactly what happened because it all became a blur."

The captain said he concentrated on the safety of his own vessel, deciding "the best course of action was to get clear of the area."

Nigel Teare, QC, counsel for the attorney-general, asked: "At what stage did you start to hear cries from the water?"

The captain replied: "I do not like to recall - I just don't know."

Asked by Michael Mansfield, QC, acting for a group of 87 Marchioness relatives, "Was there anything you would have done in a different manner?" he declined to speak of rescue, saying: "I would have made sure the lookouts had written instructions ... because it would have saved a lot of questions, the ones I've just faced."

Questioned about the look-out on the Bowbelle, Mr Henderson admitted telling police misleadingly that two men, Terence Blayney and Edward Quantrill, were posted as lookouts on the night.

In fact, he said yesterday, only Mr Blayney was a lookout and the other crewman was assigned to different duties on the Bowbelle.

The captain admitted drinking six pints on a pub crawl on his own. However, he insisted he had not been affected by the drink.

The inquiry heard that the ship's cook was so drunk that he had gone to sleep and was not available to help in the emergency.

The ship's helmsman wore thick glasses and a hearing aid, but the captain denied that this meant he could not see dangers or hear warnings clearly.

The captain admitted that in June 1989, the year of the tragedy, he had captained the Bowbelle when it was involved in a collision with a commercial vessel at Newhaven harbour in East Sussex.

But he denied Mr Mansfield's suggestion that the cause of that accident was "a lack of liaison between the bridge and the engine room."

Mr Mansfield pressed the captain on whether he saw the pleasureboat passengers' desperate battle to survive.

Mr Mansfield: "Did you see people in the water ?"

Mr Henderson: "I'm not sure whether I did or not."

Mr Mansfield: "Would you want to know whether you had -"

Mr Henderson (interrupting): "The whole thing went very quick and I cannot - I had difficulty then and I have difficulty now coming to terms - and I do not ..."

Mr Mansfield: "Were you concerned whether anybody was injured in this collision?"

Mr Henderson replied: "Of course I was."

The inquiry continues today.

webTitle: Bolivia bails Briton jailed on drug charge

fields.headline: Bolivia bails Briton jailed on drug charge
fields.trailText: A British anthropologist jailed in La Paz two years ago on drugs charges has been released on bail after reforms in the Bolivian penal code.
fields.body:
A British anthropologist jailed in La Paz two years ago on drugs charges has been released on bail after reforms in the Bolivian penal code.

Alison Spedding, 38, who is a novelist and a former university lecturer, received a 10-year sentence in 1998 when a judge ruled that 2kg of cannabis found at her home was intended for trafficking. She was allowed to leave jail last Friday on payment of a £1,300 surety and on condition she stays in La Paz until the supreme court makes a final decision on her case.

Speaking from a friend's house yesterday, she said: "I am out but I wouldn't use the word 'free'. I don't know when my case will be heard, so it is not that great."

Ms Spedding's arrest and imprisonment shocked the academic community in Britain, who petitioned the Foreign Office to demand her release. She did not deny possession of the cannabis but said that it was for personal use.

It has been argued that her imprisonment was political since she has been a prominent opponent of the Bolivian government's crackdown on peasant coca farmers. Ms Spedding has lived in Bolivia since 1989 and taught at La Paz's San Andres university, specialising on the Aymara culture, as well as writing the historical-fantasy trilogy The Road and the Hills.

During the first year of imprisonment her students were allowed to enter the jail to attend tutorials, but last year the university, she said, "wiped her off" its books. Her first priority is to speak to her former head of department. "I am going to see if I can get my job back at the university."

She added that she had no intention of trying to return to England. "What would I do, sign on the dole? That's if there is dole any more."

Ms Spedding's fortunes changed in June when the Bolivian government introduced changes to bail procedures in a new penal code. Even though she was convicted, her sentence was not confirmed by the supreme court in Sucre, which en titled her to bail. It was five weeks after her bail hearing on August 25 that she was released, however, because the prosecutor lodged an appeal.

She claimed she was being dealt with harshly because being a middle class academic she did not fit the stereotype of a drug dealer.

Ms Spedding said the only difference between being on bail - where she has to report to court three times a week - and being in prison is that she can now sleep in a room on her own and go to the chemist's.

"Bolivian prisons are extremely lax. You are never locked in your cell and can freely associate with the other prisoners. Letters are not censored and you are free to receive visitors."

Ms Spedding grew up in Maidenhead and Reading and studied at King's College, Cambridge, before gaining a doctorate at the London School of Economics.

fields.headline: 30% of frozen chickens 'exceed water level'
fields.trailText: Nearly a third of frozen chickens on sale in Britain contain more than the EU limit on added water, the food standards agency said yesterday.
fields.body:
Nearly a third of frozen chickens on sale in Britain contain more than the EU limit on added water, the food standards agency said yesterday.

It also reported "completely unacceptable" water levels in chicken portions during checks conducted by government officials nine months ago.

They found offenders among both home-produced meat and imports, where previously frozen products sold as fresh contained as much as 37% added water.

Suzi Leather, the agency's deputy chairman, said: "The bottom line is that in too many cases, consumers are paying for water when they should be paying for chicken...

"The main problem is that the legislation in this field appears to be incomplete and inconsistent."

She added: "We will be pushing for changes in EU procedures as a matter of urgency."

Frozen chicken is allowed to contain up to 7% water depending on the method used for freezing, but 30% of those bought from supermarkets, cash and carries, butchers and other outlets, exceeded this limit.

Samples from Britain's largest producer, Grampian County Food Group, recorded readings as high as 16% extra water.

Several imports from France, including some on sale in Sainsbury's, also greatly exceeded permitted levels.

Out of 1,000 chicken parts analysed, 17% had added water content of between 2% and 17%. Producers represented by the British Poultry Meat Federation pointed out that the agency had only used one of the two available tests for frozen chicken, and there was a discrepancy with results from checks made by manufacturers.

Frozen chicken accounts for less than 10% of chicken consumed in the UK, while fresh whole chicken and portions account for another 40%. Most of the remainder is contained in prepared meals.

fields.headline: Woman sues over cancer diagnosis
fields.standfirst: After 12 operations patient was told she had not been ill
fields.trailText: A woman who underwent 12 major operations after a diagnosis of invasive cancer, only to learn years later that she never had the disease, took her damages claim to the high court yesterday.
fields.body:
A woman who underwent 12 major operations after a diagnosis of invasive cancer, only to learn years later that she never had the disease, took her damages claim to the high court yesterday.

Jennifer Cormack, 63, claims she left her career as a child nurse manager because she believed she had only a short time to live.

After she was wrongly told that she had breast cancer by a doctor at the London Hospital in December 1985, she underwent a double mastectomy, seven reconstructive breast operations, a hysterectomy, two hernia repairs and a partial thyroidectomy.

Mrs Cormack, who had a history of benign breast lumps, took part in a trial of the drug danazol, which treated the condition, in the 1980s. In 1985 she had a biopsy as part of the trial and was told she had invasive cancer.

In 1994 she was recalled by the hospital, which was reviewing the results of biopsies after another woman who was misdiagnosed started legal action. She was told she had never had cancer.

East London and the City health authority, which runs the hospital, now the Royal London, contested her negligence claim, arguing that the mastectomy was beneficial because it stopped her from developing cancer.

It admitted liability only the day before the case came to court but is still contesting the amount of Mrs Cormack's claim, more than £346,000.

Mrs Cormack, of Kenninghall, Norfolk, had to have the hysterectomy after problems with the cancer drug tamoxifen, and the hernias were caused by the removal of muscle from her stomach to reconstruct her breasts. She had her thyroid partly removed after developing a nodule on the gland. This turned out to be benign, but doctors had operated without a biopsy because of her supposed history of cancer.

Two years before she was told of the misdiagnosis, in the belief that she had only a short time left, she retired from her job with its good promotion and pension prospects and moved to Norfolk with her third husband, David.

She also travelled widely - to Gambia, Sri Lanka and Belize. "I was quite determined to make the most of the time I had left," she told Mr Justice Buckley at the high court in London.

"Friends and colleagues have said that now I have lost that haunted look, because it always hung over me. I carried this diagnosis around with me."

She said she could no longer do work involving lifting, bending or stretching in her large garden or take on many household tasks. She had to wear a support girdle and to rely on her husband and friends for help.

She had refused to discuss what she thought was her condition, which was "difficult for my colleagues and friend ... It didn't make it go away, but I could not cope any other way."

She is claiming compensation for loss of earnings, loss of pension rights, the cost of care, and the pain and suffering caused by the surgery and its effects. Her solicitor, Gillian Gadsby, said: "In a sense it was a relief to be told she did not have cancer, but there was enormous anger from losing so many years of her life and living under that threat for so long."

The hearing is expected to finish today.

fields.headline: Garden of Eden
fields.standfirst: British rainforest takes root
fields.trailText: Visionary plans to grow a tropical rainforest deep in the heart of a redundant china clay pit in Cornwall have become reality with the planting of the first of hundreds of exotic trees in the specially prepared soil of the world's largest greenhouse.
fields.body:
Visionary plans to grow a tropical rainforest deep in the heart of a redundant china clay pit in Cornwall have become reality with the planting of the first of hundreds of exotic trees in the specially prepared soil of the world's largest greenhouse.

Trees normally found in South America, West Africa, Oceania and Malaysia are being carefully winched into place on the steep landscaped slopes of one of two "biomes" at the £80m Eden Project at St Blazey, near St Austell.

The humid tropic biome, large enough to accommodate the Tower of London, will eventually house a 30m waterfall and more than 12,000 plants, including mahogany, teak and balsa trees, some capable of growing to 52m (170ft). The tallest tree in place so far is a 15m kapok tree. When completed the biome will be kept humid by using 180 spray nozzles and the temperature maintained between 18-32C.

Eden is not due to open until next Easter. But the project to transform the 24-hectare pit (60 acres) has been quick to capture the public imagination with around 400,000 people paying to view its progress from a visitor centre that opened in May.

Eden, which is backed by £40m of millennium commission money, says its aim is to awe visitors with man's relationship with and dependence on plants.

The second biome will contain plants from southern Africa, the Mediterranean and California, while the outside grounds - including 10 miles of paths - will include plants from Chile and Australasia as well as those native to Cornwall.

Many of the plants have come from Eden's nursery, while others have arrived from universities and nurseries in Holland.

Among the more unusual species is the Cananga Odorata from Malaysia, which is used to make the classic fragrance Chanel No 5.

Robin Lock, curator of the humid tropic biome, said: "We will have a real variety of plants here and the challenge is getting the right combination."

Horticulture director Philip McMillan Browse, said: "When we first thought up the Eden Project we said why don't we build the biggest greenhouse in the world and put a rainforest in it? Now at last we are doing just that."

fields.headline: Sex bias scientist wins £38,000
fields.trailText: A government scientist who claimed that her male boss subjected her to a vindictive campaign of harassment because she was a woman has been awarded almost £40,000 after taking her case to an employment tribunal.
fields.body:
A government scientist who claimed that her male boss subjected her to a vindictive campaign of harassment because she was a woman has been awarded almost £40,000 after taking her case to an employment tribunal.

Rosemary Lee, 49, said she had worked in male dominated industries all her life. But she had never before encountered the level of harassment that forced her out of her £97,000 a year job with the Defence Evaluation Research Agency.

The tribunal heard that her line manager, Michael Goodfellow, barely spoke to her when she took up the job in Farnborough, Hampshire, and constantly undermined her authority in the two years she was a sector director.

Dr Lee accused the agency of sexual discrimination and won her case at a tribunal in Southampton after a 64 day hearing. Yesterday, the tribunal awarded her £38,747 in compensation, £25,000 of which was for injury to her feelings.

In its report the panel said the only explanation for Dr Goodfellow's treatment of Dr Lee was that she was a woman."We cannot escape the conclusion that Dr Goodfellow was so opposed to the position of director being occupied by a woman that he acted as he did. From the beginning Dr Goodfellow resented Dr Lee in her position.

"So many issues could have been dealt with by him so very differently. In many cases we have found his explanations unreasonable and extraordinary."

The tribunal also criticised the way Dr Lee's complaints were handled by the agency and said the organisation had not investigated her grievances thoroughly.

Dr Lee worked as the director of the agency's project management and consultancy group, where her role was to develop business in the private sector. Colleagues described her work as inspirational and the agency's chief executive, Sir John Chisholm, told the tribunal she had "magical talents."

Dr Lee, who now works for the Home Office, left the agency in September 1998 because of the way she had been treated. She told the tribunal: "Defence is a male dominated occupation and there are men within it who would prefer to keep women out of their domain. I was put in a situation where I had to report to one such man and this devalued my role.

"Over time I became more and more convinced it was because I was a woman in a man's job and like a good little woman I should have been subservient to him."

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: In yesterday's front page report from Israel we referred to the first death of an Israeli civilian on Monday. We should have said the first Israeli Jewish civilian. Seven Israeli Arabs also died in the violence on Monday.
fields.body:
In yesterday's front page report from Israel we referred to the first death of an Israeli civilian on Monday. We should have said the first Israeli Jewish civilian. Seven Israeli Arabs also died in the violence on Monday.

A report on page 28, Jobs & Money, September 30, began by saying that earlier this year, the Home Office minister Barbara Roche described some asylum seekers as "vile". That is not true. Ms Roche explained in a letter to the Guardian on September 7: "I have never described asylum seekers as vile, though this is precisely what I think of the practice of using children as an aid to begging." The distinction was clearly made in the original interview on The World This Weekend, March 19, this year, which has since been misquoted.

In a front page report headed Ministers vent fuel fury, Septmber 16, we said that the education secretary David Blunkett had accused protesting farmers of being self-interested subsidy junkies. In fact, the phrase "self-interested subsidy junkies" was ours and not Mr Blunkett's; sorry if it appeared otherwise.

In a review of an exhibition at Tabley House, Knutsford, published on page 16 of some editions, October 2, the small sculptures we referred to are the work of Elizabeth LeMoine, not Alison Moines. Apologies.

The Country Diary from South Yorkshire published on September 30 was accidentally repeated on October 2. Apologies.

It is the policy of the Guardian to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Please quote the date and page number. Readers may contact the office of the readers' editor by telephoning 020-7239 9589 between 11am and 5pm Monday to Friday. Surface mail to Readers' editor, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. Fax 020-7239 9897. Email: reader@theguardian.com

webTitle: Childhood bond 'led to rape and murder'

fields.headline: Childhood bond 'led to rape and murder'
fields.standfirst: Old Bailey jury hears of convicted man's allegations of best friend's role in four-year campaign of killings and sex attacks
fields.trailText: Two best friends murdered three women and raped seven others in a terrifying four-year campaign, "hunting" for victims late at night while listening to the Michael Jackson album Thriller to psych themselves up, the Old Bailey heard yesterday.
fields.body:
Two best friends murdered three women and raped seven others in a terrifying four-year campaign, "hunting" for victims late at night while listening to the Michael Jackson album Thriller to psych themselves up, the Old Bailey heard yesterday.

Wearing balaclavas and bound by a "unique" and twisted friendship, David Mulcahy and John Duffy fed each other's "excitement and anticipation", becoming more aggressive with each successive attack.

Their victims were gagged, blindfolded, threatened at knifepoint and subjected to harrowing sexual abuse, said Mark Dennis, prosecuting.

"Seven involved prolonged and multiple rape and the remaining five were only saved from a similar fate by the attackers breaking off and fleeing. Sometimes they were left naked and told to give their attackers their names and addresses, a clear attempt to frighten them."

Mulcahy, however, was not satisfied. As time passed, "his hunger for excitement needed to be fed with a higher level of cruelty and violence," Mr Dennis told the jury. He wanted to dominate women completely.

Alison Day, 19, Maartje Tamboezer, 15, and Anne Lock, 29, were murdered between December 1985 and May 1986. They were raped before being strangled or suffocated with their own clothes. Miss Tamboezer, the daughter of a Dutch businessman, had only been in the country a year.

Duffy was convicted in 1988 of two of the murders, five rapes and a serious sexual assault and sentenced to a minimum of 30 years in prison, the court was told.

Mulcahy, 41, a builder, from Chalk Farm, north London, was arrested at the time but not charged. He denied any involvement in the cases.

But in late 1997, after a series of counselling sessions, Duffy confessed to 17 other crimes and implicated Mulcahy, Mr Dennis said.

"Ten years into his sentence and aged nearly 40, John Duffy finally decided to come to terms with his past. He was able to start a process of cleansing his conscience and setting the record straight," said Mr Dennis.

"He is prepared to name [Mulcahy] as his partner and describe his part in the murders. He is prepared to come before the court and give evidence."

With Duffy's admissions Mulcahy, a married father of three, was charged with murdering Miss Day, Miss Tamboezer and Anne Lock. He also faces seven other charges of rape and five of conspiracy to rape between October 1982 and May 1986. He has denied all the offences.

Mulcahy and Duffy met at secondary school when they were 11, the court heard. They were both bullied and this shared experience bonded them in a "unique and wicked" way.

After leaving school Mulcahy, who worked part-time as a minicab driver, told a colleague he liked to have "complete power over women," Mr Dennis said. "He said his wife was completely submissive to him and did everything he told her to do."

Mulcahy and Duffy talked about raping women when they were teenagers, and soon began plotting their first attack.

Driving around in a car, they struck on October 24, 1982, the court heard. They spotted a 21-year-old woman who was walking home along Kilburn High Road, in north London, clutching a teddy bear.

She saw two men jogging towards her, Mr Dennis said. They grabbed her and dragged her into a side street, saying they only wanted her toy.

When she struggled, one of them threatened her with a knife. She was stripped and they took it in turns to rape her as the other kept look out, it was alleged.

"They had been thrilled by what had happened. They spoke about what they had done and agreed it was easy, exciting and they would do it again," Mr Dennis told the court. "They called it going out hunting."

Before their next attack, they stole a tape of Michael Jackson's Thriller album, the court heard. "The tape was to become a part of their kit. It seemed to motivate them as they were driving," said Mr Dennis.

"Both seemed able to dissociate themselves from the awful reality of what they were doing and treated their victims only as objects rather than people."

Over the next three years the men carried out a series of attacks in London, it was alleged. Mulcahy was more aggressive with victims because he found it hard to get aroused, the court heard.

He allegedly told one woman he would "gouge out her eyes and slice off her ears and nipples" if she failed to excite him with oral sex.

Their victims included au pairs from France, Denmark and Germany, a solicitor's clerk, and a social worker, the court heard.

Duffy, though, was becoming concerned about his partner's behaviour, Mr Dennis said. He aborted an attack on their ninth victim on Hampstead Heath, north London, fearing Mulcahy had more than rape on his mind.

"It seemed to Duffy that the defendant was displaying a different sort of aggression," said Mr Dennis.

Duffy intervened in another attack in Hampstead, the court heard, because "he had never seen a victim react in such a terrified way".

Mr Dennis said: "It was only a comparatively small step to the ultimate exercise of power - killing victims."

Miss Day, from Romford, Essex, was the first to die. The men attacked her as she got off a train at Hackney Wick, east London, on December 29, 1985. She was on her way to see her fiance, the court heard.

She was forced to walk to the River Lee where they took it in turns to rape her, Mr Dennis said.

After falling in the water, Miss Day tried to escape, but was caught. "Mulcahy was enraged," said Mr Dennis. "He tried to rape her once again. He led her across a playing field, took out a knife and cut up her blouse and put a tourniquet round her neck. He twisted the loop tight as she knelt before him on the ground."

Her body was found by police divers at the bottom of the river, weighed down by stones.

Mulcahy and Duffy ventured to Horsley, Surrey for the next attack on April 17, 1986, the court heard, grabbing Miss Tamboezer as she cycled home.

Duffy said a fishing line was tied across the path to trip her up. The teenager was hit across the face, bundled into a muddy field and raped by Duffy, the court heard.

Mulcahy then struck her across the head with a heavy stone, it was alleged. Mr Dennis said Mulcahy tied the girl's belt around her neck and told Duffy: "I did the other one. It's your turn to do this one."

Duffy twisted a piece of wood with the belt and killed the girl, the court heard. When police found her body, it was badly burned.

The last victim, Miss Lock, a secretary, had just returned from honeymooning in the Seychelles. She was attacked on May 18, 1986, at Brookmans Park station in Hertfordshire as she returned home from work.

"She was seized, led down the railway tracks to a field where she was raped and murdered," said Mr Dennis.

Her badly decomposed body was found two months later in undergrowth.

One of her socks was inside her mouth and the other had been tied round her jaw. Death was caused by suffocation. An attempt was made to burn her.

"Duffy was acquitted of this murder. He has now admitted his involvement in this offence and last year admitted her rape," said Mr Dennis.

He added: "[Duffy] has come clean and put the record straight. It is now time for this defendant [Mulcahy] to face up to his past, a past which has caught up with him."

The trial continues today.

Background

David Mulcahy was strong, outgoing, something of a show-off and always wanted to be the centre of attention, the court heard. By contrast John Duffy was small, quiet and introverted.

The two, who were best friends from the age of 11, were drawn together by their differences and bonded by a desire to "dominate and exploit" women, the Old Bailey heard.

Both had been singled out for bullying at Haverstock Hill secondary school in Hampstead.

Through this experience, they became inseparable, truanting together and abandoning studies to go to work at the age of 16.

At that stage they showed little interest in girls, the court heard, but were obsessed by martial arts and watched kung fu films.

In their late teens they began fantasising about abusing women, Duffy later told police.

They also enjoyed frightening people. A favourite prank was to surprise courting couples and homosexuals on Hampstead Heath, the court heard.

"They would jump out at them wearing Halloween masks," said Mark Dennis, prosecuting. "This behaviour may have been understandable from teenagers, but they were in their 20s."

Being married and having children did not affect their friendship.

They lived close to each other in north London, both worked for Westminster city council, and continued to see each other constantly, the jury was told.

When they raped their first victim, the original plan was for one of them to hold her while the other got the car.

But neither of the men wanted to be alone with her, the court heard, so they took turns to rape her. In subsequent attacks they often they flipped a coin to see who would go first.

"Each supported the other, knowing what had to be done. Each had complete confidence in the other. There was a unique but wicked bond that existed between them and sustained them," Mr Dennis said.

He twisted the loop tight as she knelt before him on the ground." Her body was found by police divers at the bottom of the river, weighed down by stones. Mulcahy and Duffy ventured to Horsley, Surrey for the next attack on April 17, 1986, the court heard, grabbing Miss Tamboezer as she cycled home. Duffy said a fishing line was tied across the path to trip her up. The teenager was hit across the face, bundled into a muddy field and raped by Duffy, the court heard. Mulcahy then struck her across the head with a heavy stone, it was alleged. Mr Dennis said Mulcahy tied the girl's belt around her neck and told Duffy: "I did the other one. It's your turn to do this one." Duffy twisted a piece of wood with the belt and killed the girl, the court heard. When police found her body, it was badly burned. The last victim, Miss Lock, a secretary, had just returned from honeymooning in the Seychelles. She was attacked on May 18, 1986, at Brookmans Park station in Hertfordshire as she returned home from work. "She was seized, led down the railway tracks to a field where she was raped and murdered," said Mr Dennis. Her badly decomposed body was found two months later in undergrowth. One of her socks was inside her mouth and the other had been tied round her jaw. Death was caused by suffocation. An attempt was made to burn her. "Duffy was acquitted of this murder. He has now admitted his involvement in this offence and last year admitted her rape," said Mr Dennis. He added: "[Duffy] has come clean and put the record straight. It is now time for this defendant [Mulcahy] to face up to his past, a past which has caught up with him." The trial continues today. Background David Mulcahy was strong, outgoing, something of a show-off and always wanted to be the centre of attention, the court heard. By contrast John Duffy was small, quiet and introverted. The two, who were best friends from the age of 11, were drawn together by their differences and bonded by a desire to "dominate and exploit" women, the Old Bailey heard. Both had been singled out for bullying at Haverstock Hill secondary school in Hampstead. Through this experience, they became inseparable, truanting together and abandoning studies to go to work at the age of 16. At that stage they showed little interest in girls, the court heard, but were obsessed by martial arts and watched kung fu films. In their late teens they began fantasising about abusing women, Duffy later told police. They also enjoyed frightening people. A favourite prank was to surprise courting couples and homosexuals on Hampstead Heath, the court heard. "They would jump out at them wearing Halloween masks," said Mark Dennis, prosecuting. "This behaviour may have been understandable from teenagers, but they were in their 20s." Being married and having children did not affect their friendship. They lived close to each other in north London, both worked for Westminster city council, and continued to see each other constantly, the jury was told. When they raped their first victim, the original plan was for one of them to hold her while the other got the car. But neither of the men wanted to be alone with her, the court heard, so they took turns to rape her. In subsequent attacks they often they flipped a coin to see who would go first. "Each supported the other, knowing what had to be done. Each had complete confidence in the other. There was a unique but wicked bond that existed between them and sustained them," Mr Dennis said.

webTitle: Russian left critically ill after methanol mix-up

fields.headline: Russian left critically ill after methanol mix-up
fields.trailText: A Russian professor was last night critically ill in an Oxford hospital after drinking toxic methanol which he is believed to have mistaken for ethanol.
fields.body:
A Russian professor was last night critically ill in an Oxford hospital after drinking toxic methanol which he is believed to have mistaken for ethanol.

The academic, 44, was a visiting virology professor at the government-funded Centre of Ecology and Hydrology, an Oxford research institute. He was found collapsed in the street on Monday evening by a passer-by near the laboratory where he was based and was last night being treated at the John Radcliffe Hospital.

Toxicology tests confirmed he had levels of methanol in his blood stream. Methanol is flammable and like ethanol is a clear liquid. Police are investigating why he drank the poisonous substance.

Duncan McGraw, a spokesman for Thames Valley police, said the professor's poisoning was not believed to be suspicious.

webTitle: Sale talks open as Powernet fails

fields.headline: Sale talks open as Powernet fails
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Arthur Andersen was yesterday appointed by the high court as administrators to Powernet Telecom, the Manchester communications and internet company.
fields.body:
Arthur Andersen was yesterday appointed by the high court as administrators to Powernet Telecom, the Manchester communications and internet company.

Staff and telecoms companies have not been paid as a result of the failure of the firm, founded by Ian Carey, a former Saatchi & Saatchi executive whose wealth was recently valued at £100m. The administrators are looking for a quick sale and are understood to be talking to interested parties.

"Powernet Telecom has been unsuccessful in raising the new finance it had been seeking to support its operations and the directors have had no option but to ask for the appointment of administrators," said Simon Allport, business recovery specialist at the accountancy.

Powernet Telecom's 90 staff have not been paid wages for September and yesterday were waiting to know if they were going to keep their jobs. Police were called to the company last week to maintain order as staff left the building.

Powernet Telecom runs a business telecoms network, owns internet service provider Totalserve and net incubator fund Powerten. The group was planning a £600m stock market flotation a few months ago and in August failed to reverse Powerten into a cash shell called Internetaction.com. Analysts said it had difficulty raising money in a crowded sector that had fallen out of favour with investors.

Mr Carey's business record became a focus of attention after it emerged he had been disqualified from acting as a company director for five years after his last venture, Callfree Directories, went into voluntary liquidation. The ruling was overturned on appeal, allowing him to continue to build Powernet Telecom, which had signed deals to work with companies such as Cisco and Sun Microsystems.

Mr Carey held a majority of the voting rights in Powernet.

fields.headline: Dot.eu on the way
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: The ".eu" domain name as an alternative for European business to dot.com should be operational early in 2001, European commission officials said yesterday.
fields.body:
The ".eu" domain name as an alternative for European business to dot.com should be operational early in 2001, European commission officials said yesterday.

European telecoms commissioner Erkki Liikanen said the commission was making progress on winning international approval for use of ".eu" as an internet domain name by EU companies for electronic commerce sites.

He said that ICANN, the international governance body for the internet, has decided that International Standards Organisation-protected symbols, such as "eu" can be used as top- level domain names by regional authorities.

Launch of the ".eu" domain name as an alternative for European business still needs agreement on the registry to run the registration of those organisations adopting ".eu", he said.

fields.headline: What hope for peace?
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Amira Hass (Beaten and betrayed, October 3) clearly states the hard facts about Camp David and the post-Camp David era. On the other hand, we read with mounting bewilderment the second part of your leader on the same subject, which showed no understanding of Israeli-Palestinian history.
fields.body:
Amira Hass (Beaten and betrayed, October 3) clearly states the hard facts about Camp David and the post-Camp David era. On the other hand, we read with mounting bewilderment the second part of your leader on the same subject, which showed no understanding of Israeli-Palestinian history.

How else could anyone say, "a few short months ago existed the real hope of a grand final settlement with the Palestinians"? To give just one example, Israeli and US proposals held out no hope of the fulfilment of UN resolutions on refugees: no right of return to or Israeli compensation for homes, businesses and land from which the Palestinians, their parents and grandparents had been forced to flee by Israeli arms and terror.

This last Camp David, like all preceding "agreements", offered no hope of a final settlement. Such a settlement must be based on the UN resolutions which give refugees right of return and compensation. It must reverse the Israeli occupation of Jerusalem, internationally recognised as illegal. It must grant full equality to Israel's own Arab citizens. Unless these conditions are met, there is no hope of lasting peace in the Middle East.
Sheila and Donald Miller Ringmer, East Sussex
Shedon1509@aol.com

 As a Jew whose two cousins were shot dead during the holocaust, I looked at the picture of the little Palestinian boy gunned down by Israeli troops with particular horror. For many years, holocaust remembrance and support for Israel have been the twin pillars of Jewish identity in this country. Now the time has come to choose between the two: what Israel's allegedly peace-seeking government is doing to innocent people mocks any moral claim about holocaust remembrance.
Elfi Pallis
London

 Everyone in Israel knows the words of the national poet, Bialik, written after a pogrom in Kishinev in 1903: "The penalty for the death of a small child/Has not yet been invented by Satan."
Roland Rance
London
roland@rantam.net

 I wonder what the west's response would be if Slobodan Milosevic ordered helicopter gunships to open fire on stone-throwing demonstrators in downtown Belgrade or if Saddam Hussein was machine-gunning unarmed Kurdish children.
Steve Bremner
Borehamwood, Herts

 Those who are appalled at Israel's recent actions should know that many Jews here, in Israel, in the US and elsewhere are similarly appalled and support peace with justice for the Palestinians. This means a Palestinian state on the West Bank and in Gaza with East Jerusalem as its capital. Palestine must also get a fair share of the scarce water in the region and the harassment of Palestinians at Israeli border posts must end.
Bernard Misrahi
Jewish Socialists' Group, London
misrahi.intersect@virgin.net

You report (Ariel Sharon: the bloodstained past, October 3) that "69 civilians (most of them women and children) were killed by accident at Qibya, a Jordanian village". Not even the Israeli government at the time claimed that this massacre was an accident. As UN military observers reported: "Bullet-riddled bodies near the doorways and multiple bullet hits on the doors of the demolished houses indicated that the inhabitants had been forced to remain inside until their homes were blown up over them."
Marion Woolfson
Edinburgh
MarionWoolfson@ compuserve.com

 New audience

A British online shop for investors in initial share offers, EO announced that it has signed a deal to make its issues available through the moneyextra.com personal finance website. The deal will increase EO's retail audience to include the 540,000 people who use moneyextra.com every month. Yesterday Moneyextra shares fell 1p to 31.5p.

 E-brokerage

Online brokers from Germany still dominate the European market in user friendliness but Italian and Spanish rivals are gaining ground, according to quarterly ratings from Blue Sky, which provides net research for banks and brokers. The criteria include ease of navigation, simplicity and customer service response. Mainland European brokers dominated cross-border moves at the expense of their US and British competitors, the agency said.

Internet service provider Microsoft MSN said that it has renewed and expanded an agreement with Amazon.com to extend the availability of music and video products.

webTitle: Europe goes last mile for net revolution

fields.headline: Europe goes last mile for net revolution
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: In a far-reaching move which promises to lead to cheaper and faster internet access, the European Union yesterday agreed that the last mile of telephone lines into people's homes should be opened up to competition in January.
fields.byline: Ian Black  in Brussels and David Teather
fields.body:
In a far-reaching move which promises to lead to cheaper and faster internet access, the European Union yesterday agreed that the last mile of telephone lines into people's homes should be opened up to competition in January.

Telecoms ministers meeting in Luxembourg reached agreement on a European commission proposal to unbundle the local loop in a deal that is likely to be approved by the European parliament later this month.

The agreement was signed as the controversy continued surrounding the break-up of BT's local network.

Cable & Wireless said it had joined the chorus of rivals making a formal complaint against BT in the row over access to the company's local exchanges.

Mike McTighe, chief executive of C&W's global division, said the company had made its feelings known to the industry regulator, Oftel.

"The local exchanges they're making available are the ones that are least attractive from a commercial perspective.

"They've produced this wonderful blacklist of exchanges that are 'full'. Well, surprise, surprise, the exchanges that are full are more likely to be exchanges that are most likely to be commercially viable.

"While they've been prevaricating they've been able to deploy their own DSL [digital] equipment and take the space in those exchanges. So how fair does that sound? Is that a level playing field?"

Under the proposal the EU's 15 member states have to scrap remaining monopolies on phone lines into people's homes and offices. This will enable hi-tech firms to compete to install digital technology capable of squeezing even television pictures down the line.

"We have completed liberalisation of the sector," said Erkki Liikanen, the commissioner for the industry. "We had done that with international and long distance calls but not with local. This last step is of growing importance because of the internet."

Patricia Hewitt, the DTI minister for e-commerce, said after yesterday's meeting: "It is an enormously important issue for the development of e-commerce across the EU."

The agreement is expected to be a big boost for industry and the internet, and crucial in helping Europe catch up with the online revolution in the US and Asia.

Telecoms liberalisation was a key feature of the Lisbon economic summit last March, in which Britain and the commission played a leading role.

British officials made much of promising cheaper, better and faster net access, and yesterday hotly denied suggestions that they had attempted to delay the agreement.

Only Germany and Denmark among EU members have open local loops, while France, Ireland and Belgium are some way behind the proposed liberalisation schedule.

In Britain, Oftel is aiming to allow BT competitors to offer services on its local loop from July 2001, six months after the EU's target.

"Unbundling" means identifying individual lines from the thick groups of wire inside a telephone exchange.

The EU regulation goes further than some national unbundling already undertaken by requiring full access to the local loop for entrants as well as shared access - where the incumbent would continue to provide voice services but a new entrant would provide internet access through the same copper wire.

webTitle: Stay of execution Napster wins time on piracy charges

fields.headline: Stay of execution Napster wins time on piracy charges
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Online music company Napster received a stay of execution yesterday as a US appeal court allowed it to continue business until a final verdict on its future had been reached.
fields.body:
Online music company Napster received a stay of execution yesterday as a US appeal court allowed it to continue business until a final verdict on its future had been reached.

Napster, which allows its 32m users to download music without charge is being sued for copyright infringement by the entertainment industry.

After the hearing, Hank Barry, Napster's chief executive, claimed the industry had "stonewalled" his proposals to reach a settlement.

Mr Barry said he had suggested that his company charged its millions of users a fee to download music, which would go towards compensating the recording artists.

"We're willing to pay very substantial amounts to the artists," Mr Barry said.

"With a very conservative estimate, the first-year payments to the artists would be in the neighborhood of a half a billion dollars." The federal appeals court is considering arguments in the copyright case the US music industry has brought against Napster.

The case is viewed as a landmark in the issue of copyright on the net. After hearing both sides' arguments the San Francisco court on Monday adjourned to consider a verdict. Lawyers for Napster argued that the company was no more than a service provider which could not be held responsible for the activities of its users. Crucial to Napster's case is a 1984 supreme court decision that allowed Sony to continue making video recorders capable of duplicating copyright-protected material.

But the Recording Industry Association of America argued that Napster's service was tailor-made for piracy. Yesterday there was still no sign the industry was ready to strike a deal. Some observers suggested a deal might still be made if the music companies sensed the case might turn against them. Gene Hoffman of ISP EMusic.com, was sceptical about a late deal. "The record companies do not have much of a incentive to settle when it is not proven Napster can make a dime off their customer base."

fields.headline: Stranger than fiction
fields.trailText: You Can't Take It With You | Marion And Geoff | Animal Hospital
fields.body:
Radio Times says You Can't Take It With You (Channel 5) is "An American comedy series based on the stage play by Moss Hart and George Kaufman, about a family of eccentrics living on Staten Island, New York, at the turn of the century." This is probably actionable under the sale of goods act. Not an American comedy series at all, it was, in fact, about an old dear distributing her bits and pieces between three politely unenthused daughters.

Rather like King Lear without the name calling and double pneumonia.

The idea of You Can't Take It With You is that Eric Knowles - he of the waggish moustache and bright bow tie - should value the possessions you are going to share among your family and sit in on the subsequent carnage. Dividing up the dibs is always delicate. I cannot repeat in the modesty of print what my mother said when she saw my aunt sneaking downstairs with my deceased father's trousers. Her explanation, that she was trying to spare my mother's feelings by removing the trousers from view, cut little ice, but it certainly cut down the sobbing and gave us all an appetite for the baked ham.

The idea might have worked better if the family concerned had been American eccentrics. Happily, Connie, the mother, had a mother lode of mischief ("It's a game to her. I think she likes to wind us up, one against the other") which promised well. The daughters, while perfectly pleasant about her little treasures, naturally all had their eye on the family home. Hence the force of Connie's wicket-splintering last words, "You all think you're going to get a third share of the house, but I'm going to sell it and travel the world." The daughters were terribly nice about it in a slightly dazed way.

I warm towards anything 10 minutes long. Almost everything in life, including life, is too long. Anything important can be said in 10 minutes. Trivia, naturally, takes longer. Marion And Geoff (BBC2) is 10 minutes long. Of course, if you stick the 10 episodes together, it is 100 minutes long. Keith would point out something like that. Keith, like the duckbilled platypus, is funny, endearing and wholly unfitted for life on this planet or any other.

Neither Marion nor Geoff appear in Marion and Geoff. It is a monologue by Keith (Rob Brydon), a minicab driver, who is making a video diary in an unfortunate choice of shirts during the longeurs of waiting for a fare. Marion, his wife, has left him for Geoff, taking their two terrifying children. "Reece is a very sensitive child. He likes to draw. Anywhere. He'll draw anywhere. Alun is a different kettle of fish altogether. A very violent child."

Keith seems to skip across the tragedy of his life like a water boatman without getting his feet wet or even realizing he should be drowning. In the first episode he is driving to Wales to see his children. "The kids aren't that far away if you think about it. It's motorway all the way. I can do it now in a flat four-and-a-half hours." The world passes continuously across his window without ever touching him. He never actually seems to see his children nor hand over his carefully chosen presents: the drawing kit, the action man. "He likes this a lot - Marion said. But he's into charcoals now, which is good. And this, would you believe it, he's got it! He's got the whole range! That's Geoff, you see. Little tinker!"

Geoff, who seeps out between the lines of Keith's innocent monologue, is something randy in pharmaceuticals. Keith consoles himself that his sons regard him as a figure of romance. "I'm elusive in the fact that I travel around a lot and that, I think, can be quite romantic. A bit like Zorro, but without the mask. I couldn't wear a mask in this job though, it would create more problems than it would solve." Yesterday he produced a rifle, a treasured souvenir of his father, who shot himself. webTitle: Documents indicate tobacco firms still target new smokers

fields.headline: Documents indicate tobacco firms still target new smokers
fields.standfirst: Special report: smoking
fields.trailText: The devious tactics employed by advertising agencies on behalf of the tobacco industry, in their attempts to expand the cigarette market and undermine government anti-smoking policy, are revealed in a new report published today.
fields.body:
The devious tactics employed by advertising agencies on behalf of the tobacco industry, in their attempts to expand the cigarette market and undermine government anti-smoking policy, are revealed in a new report published today.

The report is an analysis of thousands of documents from the five main advertising agencies used by the tobacco industry in the UK, which were released after sessions of the House of Commons health committee which investigated cigarette promotion this year. It is published by the Cancer Research Campaign and the British Medical Association.

The report provides evidence that the tobacco manufacturers have not given up the battle to expand their markets, in spite of fierce opposition. One of the internal documents reveals the tactics that were considered at the time that Tessa Jowell, then minister of public health, was pushing ahead with the tobacco advertising ban which has still not become law because of challenges by the industry in the courts.

The document, from an advertising agency brainstorming session, suggests they should "undermine Ms Jowell, (and) position her as the Minister of Bans, undemocratic and rash/hasty decisions" and "undermine other supporters, eg Branson (cite connections with Rizla/Virgin)".

The papers belie industry claims that it is not trying to recruit smokers, but compete for market share. "Ultra has yet to demonstrate a consistent ability to attract new smokers," says a memo.

They reveal that imagery emphasising "street cred" is used to woo young smokers. The agencies make it plain that formula one motor racing - whose exemption from the planned advertising and sponsorship ban became controversial after revelations that its boss Bernie Ecclestone was a major donor to the Labour party - was a useful source of seductive imagery.

"... It lent associations to the brand [Benson and Hedges] with young, racy, adult, exciting, aspirational environments," says another document.

Other documents analysed by Gerard Hastings and Lynn MacFadyen of the CRC's Centre for Tobacco Control Research at Strathclyde University show that the agencies were willing to condone cigarette smuggling if it helped to establish a new brand. Discounts and gifts were used to target the poor, the report says, while brands such as Marlboro targeted students.

The authors argue that the documents prove that voluntary controls on tobacco advertising are useless. Gordon McVie, director general of the CRC, said: "These companies stop at nothing to ensnare, keep and recruit new smokers."

fields.headline: Gameplay buys stream ability
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Gameplay.com yesterday completed its twelfth and potentially most significant acquisition of a busy first full year's trading on the stock market by buying an Israeli technology firm that will enable it to "stream" computer games down telephone lines.
fields.body:
Gameplay.com yesterday completed its twelfth and potentially most significant acquisition of a busy first full year's trading on the stock market by buying an Israeli technology firm that will enable it to "stream" computer games down telephone lines.

The firm said the £34.1m purchase of Pixel Broadband Studios from Nasdaq-listed Take-Two Interactive Software will be paid for in shares and warrants and allow its gamers to buy or rent games over the internet and play them on a variety of platforms.

"Users of the future will be able to access one set of unified games services offered by Gameplay, whether from the PC at work, TV at home or mobile phone whilst waiting for a bus," said the firm's chief executive, Mark Bernstein.

Gameplay, which listed in August last year, has already bought several games distributions businesses in Europe and made a couple of content-related acquisitions. Yet analysts believe the Pixel deal could prove to be most lucrative because games bought over the web generate margins of about 70% compared with a far lower figure for those bought through shops and are expected to become the preferred method of purchase.

"This is one of the final pieces of our jigsaw," Mr Bernstein said. "The year ahead will be one of doing the knitting, bedding down our businesses and working on margins."

In the year to July 31 Gameplay reported figures in line with expectations by generating revenues of £23.2m and registering a pre-tax loss of £33.4m. Margins improved from 17% to 21% and the firm had £47.8m cash at the end of July.

Marketing expenses accounted for most of the losses but Mr Bernstein said that a newly announced partnership with pop star Robbie Williams' official website was evidence that Gameplay had built strong brand recognition among young people.

Despite Gameplay's bullish results and news of the acquisition its shares climbed just 6.5p to 235p, and still languish below the high of £11.02.5p touched earlier in the year.

webTitle: Vosper warns on loss of 650 jobs

fields.headline: Vosper warns on loss of 650 jobs
fields.standfirst: Workforce at risk unless new orders are secured by end of the year
fields.trailText: Vosper Thornycroft yesterday warned that it may have to halve its shipbuilding workforce because of a lack of short term work.
fields.body:
Vosper Thornycroft yesterday warned that it may have to halve its shipbuilding workforce because of a lack of short term work.

The company said 650 jobs were at risk unless it could secure a batch of new orders by the end of the year.

But Martin Jay, chief executive, said he hoped to avoid any redundancies and revealed he was already in negotiations for two contracts.

Vosper's problems were caused by a gap between orders as the current seven ship order for Royal Navy minehunters is coming to an end, he said.

Although the company is expected to be part of the £1bn contract for three Type 45 warships, awarded to BAE Systems by the Ministry of Defence, production is not scheduled to start until 2002.

There is also an air of uncertainty over the deal as a contract is yet to be signed.

Mr Jay admitted that he could not say it was definitely coming to Vosper until the deal was finalised, but insisted there had not been a significant delay.

"We have had a lot of discussions since July as they are highly complicated but there is nothing abnormal [about the time scale]," he said.

"I need to find some short term work to bridge the gap between now and then. I am confident we are going to be able to do this."

Yesterday's news was broken to workers in a series of meetings at the company's bases in Southampton and Portsmouth.

Trade unions, which have 90 days to discuss the proposed job cuts, spent much of the day in talks with Vosper's management.

Senior officials said last night that they thought it was a serious situation but one which could be resolved.

Sir Ken Jackson, general secretary of the AEEU, said that if the problem was contracts not being signed, they would do everything in their power to speed up the process.

An announcement released to the stock market yesterday morning said: "We are taking this action as a precautionary measure.

"No company can keep people employed indefinitely on maintenance and other temporary work without damaging its overall prospects."

The market reacted badly to Vosper's announcement although some industry observers said it did not come as a total surprise.

They said that the shipbuilding industry had been suffering for years and this was a symptom of the "feast and famine" syndrome which often occurs.

Vosper's shares slipped 62.5p to £12.25 by the close of trading last night. This is well off its £14.05 year high, but still comfortably ahead of the £9.30 low.

Analysts said that the decline could have been greater had the company not looked to diversify in the early 1990s.

"Vosper has been very successful in diversifying its sales away from the core shipbuilding business and more than 50% now comes from support services," said one.

webTitle: Jail for trader who destroyed City firm in 92 minutes

fields.headline: Jail for trader who destroyed City firm in 92 minutes
fields.trailText: A rogue City trader who destroyed a leading independent broker in an afternoon of madness was yesterday jailed for three years and nine months.
fields.body:
A rogue City trader who destroyed a leading independent broker in an afternoon of madness was yesterday jailed for three years and nine months.

Stephen Humphries ran up huge losses in a 92-minute period and repeatedly lied about his trading to superiors at Sussex Futures.

But when he finally cracked and fled the building, he left a fatally wounded company which collapsed the next year with losses of £2.3m, London's Southwark crown court was told. Martin Hicks, prosecuting, said Humphries' actions plunged the company £750,000 into the red, forcing the bankers to withdraw facilities and prompting an investigation by the Financial Futures Authority.

"During a period of one hour and 32 minutes, the company's hard-earned reputation and value was destroyed at a stroke," he said.

Sussex Futures, which had been a "success story" with a £6m annual turnover, finally went under with 20 traders losing their jobs.

The court was told that Humphries had wiped out two-thirds of his £17,000 trading deposit by lunchtime on the day, but the situation worsened when American employment figures were released, showing the economy was in robust health.

Simon Ward, defending, said: "This is a tragic and very upsetting case. He was 24, under intense financial and personal pressure and, in effect, lost his head at the roulette table. The London International Financial Futures Exchange is a little bit like gambling."

Humphries, 25, admitted one count of fraudulently trading in gilt futures.

Jailing him, Judge Denis Levy, said: "You ruined not only your own career, but the career of many others and you caused a prosperous company, Sussex Futures Limited, to go into liquidation."

webTitle: Euro drifts down as market tests ECB resolve

fields.headline: Euro drifts down as market tests ECB resolve
fields.standfirst: Fed leaves rates on hold
fields.trailText: The euro was under renewed pressure on the foreign exchanges yesterday as markets tested the resolve of the European Central Bank to support it with higher interest rates.
fields.body:
The euro was under renewed pressure on the foreign exchanges yesterday as markets tested the resolve of the European Central Bank to support it with higher interest rates.

The euro drifted down to the levels at which it was standing before the G7 central banks stepped in to defend it 12 days ago, closing at 87.6 US cents.

Most analysts believe the slight fall in oil prices and the steadying of the euro following the support operation will result in the ECB's leaving interest rates unchanged at tomorrow's meeting. Last night the US Federal Reserve decided to leave borrowing costs at 6.5%

Since hitting a record low of just under 84.5 US cents two weeks ago, the euro had stabilised at about 88 cents, while oil prices have dropped in response to the US decision to release crude from its reserves.

Michael Schubert of Commerzbank said both factors relieved some of the immediate pressure for a further rate increase. "No further upward risks for price stability have emerged since the last rate hike on August 31. Oil prices have fallen by $5 a barrel and - due to the ECB's intervention - the euro's effective exchange rate has remained unchanged compared with the level at the end of August."

Last night's announcement by the Fed that it was leaving rates unchanged meant there was less pressure on the ECB to tighten policy in the 11-nation eurozone.

However, with the Fed still warning of the dangers of higher inflation in the US, analysts believe any respite may be short-lived. They have pencilled in a tightening of monetary policy for later this month or early October, believing the impact of higher oil prices - exacerbated by the weakness of the euro - makes higher interest rates inevitable.

David Brown of Bear Stearns said the hawkish line expounded by ECB member Otmar Issing at last week's IMF meeting in Prague suggested a deal may have been done which involved a rate increase.

"The fact that he came out so categorically making those kinds of statements makes you wonder whether the horsetrading that went on at G7 was basically that the US would support intervention as long as the ECB tightened up the monetary reins," he said.

fields.headline: The rights we want
fields.trailText:
Your leader on the Human Rights Act (October 2) highlighted the paradoxical nature of citizenship by reminding us that "in this realm we are still subjects not citizens". What will it take to make me a citizen? I would have thought that a relatively modest piece of legislation could effect this change; but I fear that I would be told that it could only be the final stage in a complicated constitutional upheaval involving the monarchy, and therefore not worth attempting. I do not wish to be a subject but a citizen and to be recognised as such. Why should that seem so much to ask?
Alan Nugent
Lincoln
fields.body:

What will it take to make me a citizen? I would have thought that a relatively modest piece of legislation could effect this change; but I fear that I would be told that it could only be the final stage in a complicated constitutional upheaval involving the monarchy, and therefore not worth attempting. I do not wish to be a subject but a citizen and to be recognised as such. Why should that seem so much to ask?
Alan Nugent
Lincoln

 The Human Rights Act, as flawed a piece of legislation as any other (eg the Disability Discrimination Act), at least adds weight to the view that every life, however it is lived, is precious and can be OK, if not beautiful. Therefore, the temptation to prescribe death as the remedy for "cruel, inhuman and degrading treatment", even, or especially, when the victim cries out for it (Letters, October 3), must be resisted vehemently.

For more than 20 years, disabled people's organisations have been arguing for the right to choice and control over our own lives and bodies and now, with the help of the Human Rights Act, we may get it. At last, we have the means with which to challenge the dominant and economically convenient view that a disabled life is a life not worth living.
Deborah Sowerby
