fields.headline: Why pensioners feel short-changed
fields.trailText: You continue to propagate the myth (Leader, September 29) that those with occupational pensions are well off, many retiring with pensions of £20,000 or more. This is possible for a middle manager on £30,000 who retires at 65 with a pension of two-thirds his final salary, but it is far from typical since most such people are retired far earlier.
fields.body:
You continue to propagate the myth (Leader, September 29) that those with occupational pensions are well off, many retiring with pensions of £20,000 or more. This is possible for a middle manager on £30,000 who retires at 65 with a pension of two-thirds his final salary, but it is far from typical since most such people are retired far earlier.

If this man had "retired" 10 years early in 1990 in a bout of corporate downsizing, he would only be half as well off. The calculation is as follows: between 1990 and 2000, earnings rose by 53% and prices by 31%. His salary in 1990 would have been about £19,600 but, with only 30 years' service, he would get a pension of £9,800. Then an actuarial adjustment is applied; since he is younger than 65 he is likely to live longer, so his pension is reduced by 30% (3% for each year below 65). This gives him a more modest £6,863. By 2000, this has risen to £8,990 if indexed by prices and £10,500 if indexed by earnings. This is why many occupational pensioners, particularly those who retired early, feel short-changed by a system which relates pensions to prices instead of earnings. They laid the foundations for the prosperity now being enjoyed by those still in work, but are denied the opportunity to share in the benefits.

The issue is a separate one from ensuring that the state pension is set at a level that allows old people to live with dignity without having to register for handouts.
David C Dryburgh
Belper, Derbyshire
dcdryburgh@dial.pipex.com

 When - or is it if? - the chancellor makes his much-anticipated announcement about an increase in the state pension, I wonder whether he will be frank enough to tell us how many thousands of the pensioners who anticipated his statement will have died before it is made? Even more importantly, will he tell us how many tens of thousands his Treasury statisticians forecast will have died before any change comes into effect?

To the Treasury we represent a saving of millions of pounds which will not have to be paid out. To us, the over-75s, in failing health and ever more straitened financial circumstances, it is only a beckoning beacon of hope which will be extinguished before we can reach it.
Muriel Hinchliffe
Sheffield
fields.bodyText: You continue to propagate the myth (Leader, September 29) that those with occupational pensions are well off, many retiring with pensions of £20,000 or more. This is possible for a middle manager on £30,000 who retires at 65 with a pension of two-thirds his final salary, but it is far from typical since most such people are retired far earlier. If this man had "retired" 10 years early in 1990 in a bout of corporate downsizing, he would only be half as well off. The calculation is as follows: between 1990 and 2000, earnings rose by 53% and prices by 31%. His salary in 1990 would have been about £19,600 but, with only 30 years' service, he would get a pension of £9,800. Then an actuarial adjustment is applied; since he is younger than 65 he is likely to live longer, so his pension is reduced by 30% (3% for each year below 65). This gives him a more modest £6,863. By 2000, this has risen to £8,990 if indexed by prices and £10,500 if indexed by earnings. This is why many occupational pensioners, particularly those who retired early, feel short-changed by a system which relates pensions to prices instead of earnings. They laid the foundations for the prosperity now being enjoyed by those still in work, but are denied the opportunity to share in the benefits. The issue is a separate one from ensuring that the state pension is set at a level that allows old people to live with dignity without having to register for handouts. David C Dryburgh Belper, Derbyshire dcdryburgh@dial.pipex.com  When - or is it if? - the chancellor makes his much-anticipated announcement about an increase in the state pension, I wonder whether he will be frank enough to tell us how many thousands of the pensioners who anticipated his statement will have died before it is made? Even more importantly, will he tell us how many tens of thousands his Treasury statisticians forecast will have died before any change comes into effect? To the Treasury we represent a saving of millions of pounds which will not have to be paid out. To us, the over-75s, in failing health and ever more straitened financial circumstances, it is only a beckoning beacon of hope which will be extinguished before we can reach it. Muriel Hinchliffe Sheffield

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Madame Bovary | Meet Joe Black | White Palace | Last Year In Marienbad
fields.body:
Madame Bovary

(Vincente Minnelli, 1949)

10.15am, TCM

Not as impressive a screen interpretation of Flaubert's classic novel as Renoir's or Chabrol's, but the lavish MGM production values help compensate for lacklustre direction: Minnelli thrived on less soulful projects. Jennifer Jones stars as the bored wife of dull provincial doctor Van Heflin; Louis Jordan is her too-smooth lover and James Mason appears as the novelist.

Meet Joe Black

(Martin Brest, 1998)

9pm, Sky Premier

Brest, who directed the inter minable Scent Of A Woman, takes a leisurely three hours over his adaptation of a slight 1934 film, Death Takes A Holiday. It's the tale of the Grim Reaper, embodied pleasingly in the form of Brad Pitt,(pictured) taking a tour of modern life. His guide is Anthony Hopkins's ailing media tycoon, who is buying a little more time; his daughter (Claire Forlani), meanwhile, is attracted to the enigmatic stranger. A handsomely mounted, lustrous production, but it lasts an eternity.

White Palace

(Luis Mandoki, 1990)

10.15pm, 3.15am, Sky Cinema

Beautifully acted sloppy love story, with James Spader a sharp young exec and widower; the exquisite Susan Sarandon a middle-aged fast-food waitress grieving for a dead son. Will their passion transcend all obstacles (age, class, painful memories)? You'll really want to know...

Last Year In Marienbad

(Alain Resnais, 1961)

4.15am, FilmFour

Grand passion in a cavernous old hotel, where "X" (Giorgio Albertazzi) meets "A" (Delphine Selrig) and tries to persuade her that they were lovers the year before. Scripted by Robbe-Grillet, the time scheme swirls between past and present. For some it's an enigmatic and ingenious modernist classic from a great auteur; for others it's absolutely maddening.

fields.headline: Gold fund
fields.trailText: I have repeatedly said the budget for the world class performance programme will, at the very least, be maintained at its current level (Redgrave attacks funding cuts, October 2). This is a clear commitment to sustain the funding for our very best athletes through the whole of the next four years.
fields.body:
I have repeatedly said the budget for the world class performance programme will, at the very least, be maintained at its current level (Redgrave attacks funding cuts, October 2). This is a clear commitment to sustain the funding for our very best athletes through the whole of the next four years.

We are also increasing the wider budget for sport as a whole. By 2003, the annual budget for sport will be around £600m. This compares very favourably with the total figure of £40m a year six years ago. This government has made sport a priority. I hope our athletes will continue to respond with the excellence they showed in Sydney.
Chris Smith MP

fields.headline: How it all adds up
fields.trailText: My wife and I are both graduate mathematicians. We applaud the proposal by Steve Bramall and Paul Ernest to reduce the level of maths education in schools (Academics query compulsory maths, October 3). As members of the "small elite who control the information systems", we agree that the vast majority of the population has no need of the arcane skills that we possess.
fields.body:
My wife and I are both graduate mathematicians. We applaud the proposal by Steve Bramall and Paul Ernest to reduce the level of maths education in schools (Academics query compulsory maths, October 3). As members of the "small elite who control the information systems", we agree that the vast majority of the population has no need of the arcane skills that we possess.

After all, the government would never hoodwink the public with dodgy statistics, would it? And the public can trust the experts in the banks and insurance companies to give them honest advice on pensions and endowment mortgages, can't they?

Besides, if everyone were able to understand maths to GCSE level, we mathematicians would never enjoy the exquisite feeling of smugness at dinner parties when introduced to someone who says "Maths? Oh no, I could never understand maths at school."
Dr David Harper
Cambridge
adh@sanger.ac.uk

 Steve Bramall denigrates the social value of maths and pushes the virtues of sociology. But this surely neglects the fact that, properly taught, this subject requires a sound grasp of statistics. In any case, his proposal to drop compulsory maths from the curriculum would result in a two-tier society, with those who understood maths nicely placed to exploit those who had no inkling of it. That should certainly give his sociologists plenty to think about.
Peter Rowland
London
PeterRowland@compuserve.com

 Congratulations to Mr Bramall and Profs White and Ernest for having the guts to say what has needed to be said for a very long time. In an age of widely available calculators and computers, the intellectual role of school mathematics is becoming more like penmanship than grammar.

It is worth remembering that the history of technology has largely involved the displacement of effort from humans to machines. It is only because the effort is exerted by the brain that we continue to think that maths is somehow special in this respect.
Prof Steve Fuller
University of Warwick
s.w.fuller@warwick.ac.uk

 The main reason why mathematics ( and science ) should be taught in schools is so people can recognise its limitations and not be taken in by its misuse in advertising, politics and the media.
Prof MH Freeman
Denbigh, Denbighshire
mikefreeman@btinternet. com

fields.headline: Taliban on the warpath
fields.standfirst: Afghan zealots spread the word
fields.trailText: Four years after overrunning Kabul, the fundamentalist zealots of Afghanistan's Taliban are coming in from the cold.
fields.body:
Four years after overrunning Kabul, the fundamentalist zealots of Afghanistan's Taliban are coming in from the cold. Not that recent meetings with the US, France, the UN, and old regional foes like Uzbekistan signify an overdue lurch to moderation by the bloody-minded, misogynistic men from the Ministry of Vice and Virtue and other bastions of intolerance. Possibly definitive military successes against rump government forces in the north-east and the fomenting of a destabilising, expanding Islamic militancy in central Asia are lending the hitherto isolated, ostracised Taliban a new and menacing international clout.

China, concerned about the impact on its restless Muslim minority, has joined Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan and Tajikistan in condemning cross-border incursions by Taliban-backed radicals from Uzbekistan's Fergana valley. Russia, the former regional superpower expelled from Afghanistan in 1989, is also alarmed. Last June, Moscow and Washington jointly decried the "growing influence of extremist groups". Both have stepped up military aid to Afghanistan's northern neighbours. Russia, which maintains 25,000 border troops in Tajikistan, has threatened air strikes. Last month, the US sent Central Command chief General Tommy Franks to Kyrgyzstan with a $3m cheque for army training. India, meanwhile, complains about Pakistani and Afghan-backed violence in Kashmir.

The Taliban provide a common link in a wide range of escalating problems. The civil war has created an enormous, unaddressed refugee crisis on the Tajik border, exacerbated by the most severe Asian drought for 50 years. The Taliban's growing ascendancy has coincided with an upsurge in heroin smuggling (Afghanistan is the world's largest opium producer). The regime continues by all accounts to train and harbour other people's terrorists, notably Osama bin Laden, the alleged 1998 bomber of US embassies in Africa who is now also linked to an August assassination attempt on Vladimir Putin by Chechens in Yalta. The Taliban's close military collaboration with Pakistan's loose-cannon leader, General Pervez Musharraf, is another geo-strategic wild card. Crucially, this instability hinders regional development, incites repressive governance, and compounds the poverty on which militancy feeds. Little wonder then that, repulsive though they remain, the world suddenly wants to talk to the Taliban.

fields.headline: Premium premiers
fields.standfirst:
None has suffered as much as Mr Hague
Special report: Conservative party conference 2000
fields.trailText: It is no new thing for political leaders to feel the hot breath of their predecessors on their apprentice necks.
fields.body:
It is no new thing for political leaders to feel the hot breath of their predecessors on their apprentice necks. The Liberal leader the Marquis of Hartington, invited in 1880 to form a government by the Queen, said he could not possibly do so when such a great man as Gladstone was still around. Anthony Eden took office with Churchill murmuring in the background that he feared the young man (he was 57) might not be up it (and he wasn't). Even Margaret Thatcher had little local difficulties from time to time with Harold Macmillan. But few can have suffered the burden of William Hague, who now that old leaders live longer and new ones take office younger, has no fewer than three of his forerunners, all vigorous and voluble, hanging around. How he must wish he could find them pleasant sinecure posts to while away their retirements in faraway colonies with lousy communications.

John Major, who was airbrushed out of last year's proceedings, is this year being airbrushed back in, so his invocation of the party's One Nation traditions came in what newspapers call a coded message: that is to say, he spoke in ways which every politician and journalist could at once see to be chiding, while others could have it explained later. Edward Heath, who gave up coding years ago, was brutal and derisive - though at least he launched his assault from a studio in London, not Bournemouth.

And who, in the midst of this aggro, curbed her tongue, sitting silently through the defence debate in the company of Sir Denis and that epitome of Victorian values, Jim Davidson, acknowledging standing ovations with a gracious wave, not with an outburst? Why, that former conference termagant, Baroness Thatcher! Could it be that she's mellowed? Probably not. More likely, her scorn for both Heath and Major has driven her to conclude that embarrassing one's successors in conference week is not the way that decent people behave.

fields.headline: Tory attack on women doctors
fields.standfirst:
Health shake-up Front bench spokesman makes extraordinary efficiency claim in private briefing
Special report: Conservative party conference 2000
fields.trailText: The scale of the Conservative plans for a revolutionary increase in the use of private health care were laid out yesterday at a private meeting of Tory MPs addressed by the party's front bench spokesman Philip Hammond.
fields.byline: Patrick Wintour, Sarah Hall  and John Carvel
fields.body:
The scale of the Conservative plans for a revolutionary increase in the use of private health care were laid out yesterday at a private meeting of Tory MPs addressed by the party's front bench spokesman Philip Hammond.

At the private meeting in Bournemouth, Mr Hammond admitted that the party had not yet worked out the detail of its policy since the party "did not know if the granting of extra tax relief would deliver a greater amount of additional health care spending into the pot". Mr Hammond said he was making the admission because he was speaking "within these four walls".

Mr Hammond also told the MPs "as a statistical fact" that female doctors are less productive than male doctors.

He said that over a lifetime you would about 20% less work out of women doctors than you would do out of male graduates. "So when Alan Milburn (the health secretary) tells you that he's going to produce an extra 8,000 doctors, you need to ask him what gender they are going to be," he said. His remarks come soon after the Conservatives were criticised for attacking the number of foreign doctors.

Speaking at the same meeting, Michael Goldsmith, the Conservative health guru and chairman of the Conservative Medical Society, told Tory candidates that the private health industry needed to get ready for the revolution in health care and said the insurance industry would have to go back to the drawing board.

In public shadow ministers have insisted the incremental plans to increase private health insurance would not reduce the NHS to a core service providing mainly acute operations.

But Mr Goldsmith said the private sector and public sector would provide distinctive services. He said: "The insurance policies need to be redesigned. We need to have what I call top-up insurance policies. We need to have something that is complementary to the NHS and deals with the particular risks the NHS would like to farm out - to allow the NHS to do other things."

Mr Hammond admitted to the candidates that the Tories' planned revolution had not yet been fully worked out. He said: "Speaking within these four walls one of the issues that we have to address is the return that we get from any commitment to tax relief. We have to be sure that in foregoing the revenue to the Treasury, we will deliver a greater amount of additional health care spending to the pot."

Justin Keen of the King's Fund, an independent health think tank, said the Conservative proposals for private health would change little. "The private medical insurance market is saturated. About 12% of people are cov ered and this has remained fairly static over the last 10 years." Modest tax relief for the over-60s from 1991 to 1997 brought no significant increase in take-up.

But Tim Baker, commercial director of Norwich Union Healthcare, said there was plenty of scope for growth if tax reliefs were targeted at people close to average earnings and denied to the more wealthy. Employers offering health insurance were meeting resistance from workers who did not want to pay more tax on this benefit in kind. That disincentive could be removed.

Bupa, the private healthcare provider, said abolition of tax reliefs since 1997 had not affected the market. Its research showed people were more con cerned about tailoring health insurance to meet their individual circumstances than they were about price.

Later the shadow health secretary, Liam Fox, said a Tory government may fine people who call out doctors for trivial complaints, miss hospital appointments, or "treat ambulances as a taxi service". Dr Fox, a GP, said: "The last thing I want to do is to introduce more bureaucracy or expense but I've just started looking at the benefits of imposing some kind of fines. We don't know how much these would be - but they might work like speeding fines."

fields.headline: In tune with populism
fields.trailText: If Channel 4's programme about William Hague was "a 55-minute election broadcast for the Conservatives" (Leader, October 3), can someone explain why this featured a very loud accompaniment of music from Trumpton?
fields.body:
If Channel 4's programme about William Hague was "a 55-minute election broadcast for the Conservatives" (Leader, October 3), can someone explain why this featured a very loud accompaniment of music from Trumpton?
Linden Stafford
Skipton, North Yorkshire
linden@linden-ed.demon.co.uk

 Given William Hague's mania for all things populist, when can we look forward to his fulsome tribute to Reggie Kray?
Simon Bayliss
Birmingham
simon@bayliss.net

 The "comedian" Jim Davidson claims to be supporting the Tories because they make him feel better about himself. Any party that can pull that off is a force to be reckoned with, and ought not to be taken lightly.
Doug Macari
Langley, Kent

 I note (Interview, October 2) that Peter Stringfellow feels that it would be "cruel" for him to have a relationship with a woman in her 50s. Looking at his photograph, I find I am in complete accord with him, though I do wonder why he confines his thoughtfulness to this one age group.
Danuta Reah
Sheffield

 May I congratulate you on the excellent Pat Pottle obituary (October 3), and for having the wisdom to print by its side his address to the jury at his 1991 trial. There could hardly be a better defence for retaining our jury system, now under threat.
Patricia Troop
Petersfield

 It puzzles me to read that our universities have puzzled over difficult questions for "thousands of years" (Needed: academic high-flyer with a taste for airline food, October 3). I've heard of the University of the New Age, but not of the University of the Iron Age.
Michael Dixon
Lyme Regis, Dorset

fields.headline: Back in the hunt
fields.standfirst:
Two years ago the Countryside Alliance was in disarray, just a motley bunch of farmers, fox-hunters and blokes in Barbours. But last week's march in Brighton and today's show of strength in Bournemouth signal a stunning revival for a group Labour dismisses at its peril. By Gary Younge

Special report: the hunting debate
fields.trailText: Two years ago the Countryside Alliance was in disarray, just a motley bunch of farmers, fox-hunters and blokes in Barbours. But last week's march in Brighton and today's show of strength in Bournemouth signal a stunning revival for a group Labour dismisses at its peril. By  Gary Younge
fields.body:
Back in November, when Labour was worried that its poll lead had dropped to a mere 10%, the chairman of the Countryside Alliance, John Jackson, wrote to the home secretary, Jack Straw. It started with a complaint about "an imminent announcement on fox-hunting". But it ended with a warning: "I must tell you," wrote Jackson,"that the rural temperature is very high and the political landscape in the countryside is tinder dry."

Straw "noted" concerns, assured Jackson that media reports had been "entirely speculative" and promised to "bear the matters raised in mind". His response was prompt, polite and essentially dismissive.

It would be easy for the Labour leadership to dismiss the Alliance. This is an organisation with a predominantly Tory membership whose central aim has been to preserve the right to kill foxes and which readily compares Tony Blair to Adolf Hitler. One poster which bore its logo depicted the gay agriculture minister, Nick Brown, as a man "who loves gays and buggers the countryside". The logo also appeared in the magazine Earth Dog, Running Dog - from which the Alliance distanced itself. The publication described the black MP for Bethnal Green and Bow, Oona King, as "typical of her species", and told her to "direct her talents to advising her scrounging supporters on how to claim more handouts".

To dismiss the Alliance would be a mistake. It may look like the provisional wing of the landed gentry, but since it started broadening its political horizons it has also broadened its base of support. Today, in Bournemouth, it will take pride of place at the working country fair, a Tory-backed event to show the party's concerns about the plight of rural Britain that will be attended by William Hague. It boasts 80 full-time staff, including 10 regional press and public relations officers, 90,000 individual members at £35 a time, and 300,000 affliated members. All this is maintained with an annual budget of £4.5m, from a range of very wealthy members. "You can easily raise a few thousand pounds at a hunt meeting. There's a lot of money swilling around," says one former Alliance employee who did not wish to be named.

Politically it has now become the most vocal and visible opponent of a weakened government. "They have the potential to be a very potent, electoral force," says Michael Jacobs, the general secretary of the Labour-supporting Fabian Society. "At the moment they have the capacity to mobilise opinion against Labour."

Last week, nine months after Jackson wrote to Straw, on an overcast autumn day in Brighton and an altogether radically different political climate, the Countryside Alliance marched on the Labour party conference with a spring in its step.

To the backing of whistles and hunting horns one member carried a placard stating: "I love the countryside, I fear my government." One was dressed as Tony Blair with a noose around his neck. Numbering more than a thousand they strode purposefully in smart sweaters and pressed jeans, angry yet orderly, between metal railings and a considerable police presence, as Labour delegates in suits looked on bemused, as though viewing exhibits in a zoo.

The day before, deputy prime minister, John Prescott, had rallied the conference with a blistering attack on the party's rural opponents. "Every time I see the Countryside Alliance and their contorted faces, I redouble my determination to vote in the House of Commons to abolish fox-hunting for ever," he raged. Now the hunters and their allies are coming in for the kill.

It is a stunning revival for an organisation which began life as a hybrid of three minority-interest groups - the British Field Sports Society, the Countryside Movement and the Countryside Business Group. The Countryside Movement was set up in 1995, with the former Liberal leader Sir David Steel as its executive chairman. "The aim was that it would be a campaigning organisation rather than a membership organisation, that dealt with issues affecting the countryside in general," says Alex Armstrong, deputy chief executive of the Alliance who used to work for the Movement. "But it was not terribly successful."

Despite several wealthy backers the Movement, which was pro-hunting and received donations from the gun lobby, heavily outspent its budget and had to be rescued with £1m from the Duke of Westminster.

The Countryside Business Group was set up by the American financier, Eric Bettelheim, to raise funds to support the hunting lobby. Both were new organisations set up in response to, or anticipation of, a Labour government with a manifesto commitment to ban hunting. Neither had a particularly large following or could claim any great successes other than their ability to raise funds.

The linchpin to the Alliance's creation and continued political presence is the now-defunct British Field Sports Society - an organisation dedicated to defending the right to hunt which bequeathed its offices to the Alliance. "Two limping organisations were swallowed up by the BFSS," says a former Alliance employee . "It was effectively a takeover. The idea was to wrap up hunting in the warm glow of the countryside and everyone will love it."

What followed was a skilful exercise in rebranding which coincided with a dramatic slump in the fortunes of rural Britain. Sheep were being auctioned for seven pence each; farmers were selling pigs for a £20 loss; hens couldn't be given away, suicides rose. These problems may or may not have been caused by the government, but it was to the government they looked to put things right. "Rural people feel they have been victimised," says Nigel Henson, director of communications for the Alliance. "They feel that urban Britain couldn't give a monkey's about them."

The Alliance, with its recent makeover, was perfectly poised to step into the void and bring together the disparate discontent in the countryside.

Initially it fared poorly. Its first national demonstration in London in 1998 was large but undermined by a poll which revealed that 80% of the demonstrators were Conservatives, leaving the government with few concerns about losing votes. No sooner had they arrived in the capital than stories emerged of employers coercing their employees into making the trip. If ever there appeared to be a battle between old and new Britain, between the forces of modernism and the agents of privilege then this was it; the squirearchy on parade waging a class war against a culturally metropolitan and ostensibly liberal Labour government

When questioned about rural issues other than hunting, employees would simply make up a position on the spot. "All we knew about was hunting. It was all we cared about too," says one.

Then a change of management followed bitter in-fighting. A few months after the march the newly-appointed head of the Alliance, Edward Duke, resigned after all the regional chairmen demanded his removal. "Our quest to be taken seriously is in tatters," said hunting's in-house journal, Horse & Hound. "We have been torn apart by ambition, power struggles, prejudice and the inability to see the bigger picture."

Faced by a huge parliamentary majority, supporters took to the streets to make their grievances known. Its shambolic determination recalled the hard left of the 80s. It was riven with internal splits, the leadership was constantly denounced by the membership for selling out the cause, and it attempted to emulate the age-old leftist tactic of entryism. Through an organisation called Friends of the National Trust, Alliance supporters' attempts to infiltrate the upper echelons of the National Trust, which banned stag-hunting on its land, have so far proved unsuccesful. When they demonstrated in London two years ago one passer-by shouted: "We subsidise you," while another asked: "Why don't you get proper jobs?" Replace the Barbours with donkey jackets and Labour with the Tories and they are, in many ways, a mirror image of how the hard left behaved and was perceived.

This undoubtedly was the calculation Prescott made when he delivered his speech last week, when he treated the Alliance to the same contempt that Margaret Thatcher showed to CND supporters and miners. "Fox hunters are one of the few enemies the Labour party allow themselves nowadays," says Jacobs.

However, since its early, disorganised days the Alliance has developed policy on everything from pubs to poverty and abbatoirs to employment. Its chief executive, Richard Burge, is a Labour party member; neither he, his deputy, his chairman or Henson are hunters. The key issues for the countryside, Henson admits, are "the demise in the economic and retail sectors which are crippling the social infrastructure". The priority for the Alliance however remains saving the hunt. "If you looked at our membership you will inevitably find a leaning towards people who joined for country sports reasons," says Henson. "The reason we have concentrated on that recently is that it is immediately under threat. The Labour party is going to ban hunting, they are not going to ban rural post offices."

Its project of acting as the hegemonic voice of rural Britain is by no means assured. "We are a new organisation in a period of transition," says Henson. The failure of the Alliance to back the fuel protests, on the grounds that it would alienate it from public opinion, was received angrily by many in rural areas. "There are completely contradictory forces involved," says Jacob. "There is no coherent base apart from geographic proximity."

Some wish it would ditch its support for the hunt in order to broaden its appeal. Others are concerned that it is diluting its central purpose to save its political skin. "People think they are preparing for life after fox- hunting," says a former employee. "But it won't have a life after fox- hunting. Most of its members joined to save the hunt. When that goes they'll leave." In the Daily Telegraph last week, the publisher of Gun Trade News, Simon Baseley, warned: "Members and others should be rightly suspicious of the Countryside Alliance re-branding. This has given rise to a feeling that the alliance has at some level accepted that the fight for hunting is lost and is beginning to prepare a retreat to a better prepared position."

None the less they represent a serious problem for Labour. Tory dominance in rural areas is much overstated and the countryside is an ideal battleground for Hague to recoup some of its losses. While hunting, and particularly hunters, remain unpopular with the general public, rural Britain is not. The more sucessful the Countryside Alliance becomes at presenting itself as the voice of impoverished rural Britain, the more sophisticated Labour will have to become about the manner in which it deals with them. To dismiss them will be perceived to be dismissing the countryside.

Henson's claim that the Alliance is "resolutely apolitical" is laughable, but it remains to be seen just how party political it will be come the election.

From the podium Prescott asked why they weren't outside the Tory party conference "when Tories were shutting 2,000 post offices, selling off 10,000 council houses, ending bus services and closing village schools". The Alliance replied that they simply did not exist then. "If we did then of course we would have protested." Given the present complexion of its membership, it is doubtful they would have attracted much support for such a protest against a Conservative government. None the less, given the remit it has claimed for itself, it is doubtful it would have got away without organising one.

"We're looking at the seats that are swingable to persuade the candidates to get real about the countryside," says Henson, referring to Prescott's speech. "But if that's the way the Labour party is going to act they are not going to get much support from us."

Says Michael Jacobs: "They need to treat the Countryside Alliance with a level of maturity that the Alliance itself arguably does not have." That, at least, is a warning Labour would do well not to wait nine months to heed.

fields.headline: The president most Americans prefer...
fields.trailText: Just in case you thought the big presidential story in the US this morning had anything whatever to do with Al Gore or George W Bush, or with last night's candidates' debate in Boston, think again.
fields.body:
Just in case you thought the big presidential story in the US this morning had anything whatever to do with Al Gore or George W Bush, or with last night's candidates' debate in Boston, think again.

For millions of Americans, today's really compelling political story concerns the fate of US president Josiah Bartlet and the answer to the question being asked with increasing intensity this autumn: who's been hit?

Tonight, NBC will air the first episode of the new season of its Emmy award-winning White House saga, West Wing, and the audience may well rival the viewing figures for the real live political contest last night.

The plot left viewers with a classic cliffhanger at the end of the last series. Tonight, Americans will finally learn whether the president, or any of his staff, have been shot by racist assassins.

President Bartlet, played by Martin Sheen (below), is a New Hampshire Democrat halfway through his first term in the White House. At the end of the last series, Mr Bartlet travelled out of Washington to deliver a speech to Virginia university students along with his daughter Zoe, who is dating the president's black aide, Charlie Young.

As the Bartlet entourage left the hall in Virginia, a pair of stony-faced young white racists started shooting.

"Who's been hit?" NBC has repeatedly asked in its trailers throughout the summer. President Bartlet, most series fans believe, has survived the fusillade. But the fate of Zoe, her secret service agent, Lisa, and Charlie is less clear.

fields.headline: Good day, bad day
fields.standfirst: Special report: Conservative party conference 2000
fields.trailText: Iain Duncan Smith. Lady Thatcher turned up at conference especially early to hear the speech of her protege, the shadow defence secretary. She heard him call for the armed forces to be exempt from the terms of the new Human Rights Act to prevent them being undermined by "campaign junkies, jobbing lawyers and even judges".
fields.body:
Good day

Iain Duncan Smith. Lady Thatcher turned up at conference especially early to hear the speech of her protege, the shadow defence secretary. She heard him call for the armed forces to be exempt from the terms of the new Human Rights Act to prevent them being undermined by "campaign junkies, jobbing lawyers and even judges".

Pledge of the day

Shadow foreign secretary Francis Maude was judged sincere when he made his plea for tolerance. He said: "Our party has always contained its representative share of gays, including my late brother. A national party has to be serious about being inclusive and tolerant. Tolerance is not an optional addition to this party's values; it is an absolutely vital part of it which sustains us."

Bad day

Kenneth Clarke. The former chancellor entered the who can sweat more contest as he did the rounds banging his drum for the euro. Following the prime minister's soaked shirt episode last week the veteran MP also showed the danger of wearing a blue shirt in front of the lights.

Offer of the day

The pub in Bournemouth offering a free 14 pints of bitter or lager - but only to William Hague.

Delegate of day

Miss Barbara Stroud, 83, vice-chair of the women's committee in Poole, Dorset. "The highlight of today was William Hague's question and answer session. He was extremely good at answering all the questions, he came across as a very strong leader and he showed real humour. The quality of the speakers from the floor in the health debate was first class and Michael Portillo showed his softer side in his speech: he wasn't behind the desk, and he seemed far more humourous

Do I prefer this side to him?

Well, I think, for him, it was necessary. But I was quite disappointed that he didn't say much about his job as shadow chancellor. Really you'd almost say it was more like a leadership speech."

Today

9.30am David Willetts, shadow social security secretary on welfare state reform 10.30am Ann Widdecombe, shadow home secretary, is expected to give her annual rumbustious crowd pleasing performance

11.30am Tim Yeo on agriculture 2pm David Heathcoat-Amory, speaking on trade and industry

4pm Francis Maude, foreign affairs

fields.headline: Trimble is vital
fields.standfirst:
His absence could risk more bloodshed
Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Even colleagues who have little time for Peter Mandelson must feel for him now. The Ulster Unionists' loss of South Antrim to the Democratic Unionist Party has triggered events which now threaten a second suspension of the province's devolved institutions and even the possible loss of the whole peace process.
fields.body:
Even colleagues who have little time for Peter Mandelson must feel for him now. The Ulster Unionists' loss of South Antrim to the Democratic Unionist Party has triggered events which now threaten a second suspension of the province's devolved institutions and even the possible loss of the whole peace process. The DUP was not alone in finding South Antrim gratifying. It also brought hope to that sizeable force of Ulster Unionists who want to remove Mr Trimble in the hope that the Good Friday Agreement could then be renegotiated or, more practically, ditched. Other developments too have stacked up the odds against Mr Trimble as he prepares to face his party conference on Saturday. Mr Mandelson has said that convicted IRA terrorists on the run in other countries will not be further pursued; also that further reductions in the security forces are planned. And on Monday the Daily Telegraph, eager as ever to undermine the agreement, reported, on the basis of evidence from "senior security sources", that leading Provisionals have been touring the province assuring their supporters that there will be no further movement on decommissioning until a united Ireland is certain.

All of which leaves Mr Trimble dangerously vulnerable, with the very real prospect that a month or so from now the Ulster Unionist council will once more be asked to choose between backing and sacking him. In an article for yesterday's Telegraph, he implicitly appealed to Mr Mandelson to throw him what he sees as the only feasible lifeline: the rescinding of the government's commitment to implement the Patten report on the future of the RUC. To save the agreement, he says, the government must agree to a moratorium on Patten until decommissioning has occurred, and to a "complete reopening" of the argument over its name.

If the fate of the agreement is to hang on complete decommissioning, rather than just further progress (Mr Trimble here is ambiguous) then the agreement is finished, with all the consequences that means for the province. But there may be some leeway here if, as is also suggested, the two special investigators, Martii Ahtisaari and Cyril Ramaphosa, are swiftly invited back for a second tour. That certainly ought to happen. But it is not, on any calculation, something within the power of the Northern Ireland secretary to deliver. Patten is different. Here, it is well within Mr Mandelson's powers to assent to what Mr Trimble is asking. Yet to do that would merely swap one intractable problem for another, no less intractable. Sinn Fein, which has listed London's failure to move faster on Patten as one of the reasons why dissident republican groups are flourishing, would not be alone in condemning it. The SDLP would find it a surrender too far: so would Dublin. Nor, crucially, would it serve the long-term interests of Northern Ireland. It must be as clear to politicians in London as to those in Dublin that the province cannot move to consensual policing if the RUC is sustained in anything like its present form.

The terms in which Mr Trimble has made his bid have as much to do with his party audience as they have with the Northern Ireland secretary's agenda. He has to be heard talking tough. Because Mr Trimble is virtually irreplaceable, Mr Mandelson needs to explore all possible ways of helping him; but not where, as here, they would amount to a sell-out. And unhappy as they are, unionists at all levels ought to consider this. No Trimble is likely to mean no agreement. And what no agreement is likely to mean is already written in blood across Northern Ireland.

All of which leaves Mr Trimble dangerously vulnerable, with the very real prospect that a month or so from now the Ulster Unionist council will once more be asked to choose between backing and sacking him. In an article for yesterday's Telegraph, he implicitly appealed to Mr Mandelson to throw him what he sees as the only feasible lifeline: the rescinding of the government's commitment to implement the Patten report on the future of the RUC. To save the agreement, he says, the government must agree to a moratorium on Patten until decommissioning has occurred, and to a "complete reopening" of the argument over its name. If the fate of the agreement is to hang on complete decommissioning, rather than just further progress (Mr Trimble here is ambiguous) then the agreement is finished, with all the consequences that means for the province. But there may be some leeway here if, as is also suggested, the two special investigators, Martii Ahtisaari and Cyril Ramaphosa, are swiftly invited back for a second tour. That certainly ought to happen. But it is not, on any calculation, something within the power of the Northern Ireland secretary to deliver. Patten is different. Here, it is well within Mr Mandelson's powers to assent to what Mr Trimble is asking. Yet to do that would merely swap one intractable problem for another, no less intractable. Sinn Fein, which has listed London's failure to move faster on Patten as one of the reasons why dissident republican groups are flourishing, would not be alone in condemning it. The SDLP would find it a surrender too far: so would Dublin. Nor, crucially, would it serve the long-term interests of Northern Ireland. It must be as clear to politicians in London as to those in Dublin that the province cannot move to consensual policing if the RUC is sustained in anything like its present form. The terms in which Mr Trimble has made his bid have as much to do with his party audience as they have with the Northern Ireland secretary's agenda. He has to be heard talking tough. Because Mr Trimble is virtually irreplaceable, Mr Mandelson needs to explore all possible ways of helping him; but not where, as here, they would amount to a sell-out. And unhappy as they are, unionists at all levels ought to consider this. No Trimble is likely to mean no agreement. And what no agreement is likely to mean is already written in blood across Northern Ireland.

fields.headline: Rocky fellow cleans up
fields.trailText: The name itself was a magnet for well-to-do New Yorkers taking their ease in their summer playground at the Hamptons, east of the city. And when Christopher Rockefeller offered them a painless way to enhance their financial insulation, it seemed silly not to go along with his scheme.
fields.body:
The name itself was a magnet for well-to-do New Yorkers taking their ease in their summer playground at the Hamptons, east of the city. And when Christopher Rockefeller offered them a painless way to enhance their financial insulation, it seemed silly not to go along with his scheme.

So what if, for some reason, he had a French accent? Yes, it might also have been odd that he had more experience with tattoos than fine wines but, as a Rockefeller, he boasted a family name historically synonymous with New York city wealth, philanthropy and public service.

However, Christopher was a different kind of Rockefeller: in fact he was not a Rockefeller at all but a con man and killer, according to police who are hunting the man they know Christopher Rocancourt, 33, from Honfleur, Normandy.

He is said to have relieved the Hamptons' elite of nearly $900,000 (£613,000) before being charged with impersonation and defaulting on a $19,000 (£13,000) hotel bill, on top of previous activities conducted in Beverly Hills, Miami, San Francisco and Hong Kong that made him millions more.

Investigators also say he was linked to a diamond smugglers in Zaire, a jewellery robbery in Geneva and the shooting of a drug dealer's bodyguard in California.

"He's a criminal, a fugitive on the run and he needs to go to jail," said George Mueller, supervising investigator for the Los Angeles district attorney's office.

Resident Tom Gregory, on the other hand, thought Rocancourt had some interesting things to say, even if he was not much good at tennis.

They came to a deal whereby Rocancourt would wire a $500,000 (£341,000) loan to Mr Gregory's account in return for a payment of $50,000 in cash. The transaction might have seemed more satisfactory had the loan shown up.

Ultimately, Rocancourt met his match in a Spanish painter, Gines Serran-Pagan, who threw a dinner party for the rogue and then unmasked him after becoming suspicious of his manner and accent.

But even when Rocancourt was arrested for impersonation and then freed on $45,000 bail police remained unaware of his identity. He is now thought to be in Venezuela.

fields.headline: Professor denies causing measles epidemic
fields.standfirst: Oxford scientist hits back at allegations that team may have deliberately triggered outbreak of disease among South American Indians
fields.trailText: An Oxford University professor involved in giving South American Indians a measles vaccine in the 1960s has rejected allegations in the US that he and other scientists may have deliberately triggered an epidemic of the disease.
fields.body:
An Oxford University professor involved in giving South American Indians a measles vaccine in the 1960s has rejected allegations in the US that he and other scientists may have deliberately triggered an epidemic of the disease.

Speaking for the first time about his role in the project, Ryk Ward, professor of biological anthropology at Oxford, said he and other scientists saved Indians stricken by a measles outbreak which had begun just before they arrived.

The source of the accusations, which have shaken the world of anthropology, is a soon to be published book, Darkness In El Dorado, by the journalist Patrick Tierney.

In an email leaked to the Guardian last month, two anthropologists who have read proofs of the book say it shows that the leader of the measles expedition, James Neel, was a callous, manipulative figure, who coldly observed without intervening as hundreds of Indians fell victim to a disease he either started deliberately or, at best, let rage unchecked.

Dr Neel, professor of human genetics at the University of Michigan, died in February. Prof Ward is one of the few survivors of his expedition to the Yanomami Indians of Venezuela in 1968, when the measles epidemic hit, yet he says Mr Tierney - who has spent 10 years researching his book - has never been in touch with him.

One of the anthropologists who has seen the book, Terry Turner of Cornell University, says that Dr Neel deliberately used an unsafe measles vaccine on the Yanomami, without consulting medical experts or the Venezuelan government, held his team back from giving medical help to the sick and dying, and sought to use the tragedy to back up his "fascistic" theories of the survival of the fittest humans.

New Zealand-born Prof Ward, who joined Dr Neel's group as a young postgraduate and delivered the vaccine from Guyana to the expedition's jumping off point in Caracas, said all the allegations were demonstrably false. He was less troubled by the book than by the role of Prof Turner and others, who, he claimed, had assumed it was accurate without trying to find out what had really happened.

"These kind of unjustified allegations can only convince the public that scientists are up to no good, that their work is suspect and shouldn't be funded," he said.

"Although they don't directly refer to me, I was part of the team, I was directly involved in getting the measles vaccine into Venezuela and I felt then, and still feel now, that the decision to vaccinate was the correct and ethically responsible thing to do."

According to Prof Ward, 57, the expedition's main purpose was to study the genetic makeup of the Yanomami. But like many of his contemporaries Dr Neel was concerned that the spread of missionaries, loggers and prospectors into the Yanomami territory, around the Orinoco river, could expose them to diseases to which they had no immunity, such as measles.

He suggested vaccinating Indians in the villages the team visited, and after consulting with the centre for disease control in Atlanta, the pan-American health organisation and the Venezuelan authorities, arranged for a vaccine called Edmonston B to be used. The Yanomami were not consulted.

This vaccine tended to trigger mild measles-like symptoms, but then offered stronger immunity to the disease. It had already been administered to millions around the world.

Far from causing the epidemic, said Prof Ward, the expedition's plans had been thrown into disarray when, a week before they left Caracas, they heard the measles epidemic had already begun, in the Indian settlement of Ocamo.

The team then spent two to three weeks in about eight villages, vaccinating Indians in the hope of stemming the epidemic. Although none of those who were vaccinated appeared to have caught measles, and no one died of the disease, they were unable to prevent it spreading into more remote communities, and there were many deaths.

Prof Ward said it turned out the Yanomami had no more or less resistance to measles than British or American people. So many died because everyone in a village would fall ill at the same time, people - especially the old and very young - would not get enough food and water, and this in turn left them prey to other infections, such as pneumonia.

Prof Ward accepted that part of the funding for the expedition came from the US atomic energy commission, which was interested in natural genetic mutations. But he said it was false to connect Dr Neel with other experiments where people were injected with plutonium without their permission.

He said Dr Neel was often arrogant and impatient, but it was wrong to characterise him as having a supremacist attitude towards "primitive" people such as the Yanomami, who he believed had much to teach the developed world in terms of diet and fitness.

A showdown over the book is expected in San Francisco next month, when the American anthropological association holds its annual meeting.

webTitle: Hague invites Major in from cold to back 'one nation' policy switch

fields.headline: Hague invites Major in from cold to back 'one nation' policy switch
fields.standfirst: Special report: Conservative party conference 2000
fields.trailText: John Major has been drafted in by William Hague to lend credibility to a series of "one nation" policies unveiled by the Tory leadership in Bournemouth this week.
fields.body:
John Major has been drafted in by William Hague to lend credibility to a series of "one nation" policies unveiled by the Tory leadership in Bournemouth this week.

Senior members of the shadow cabinet have been instructed to brief the former prime minister on their announcements to ensure they win support from the man who has cast himself as the champion of the party's one nation wing.

The top billing enjoyed by Mr Major contrasts with a low key performance by Margaret Thatcher who hijacked last year's conference when she appeared at a pro-Pinochet rally.

During a one day visit to Bournemouth yesterday, Lady Thatcher appeared on the platform - where she received a standing ovation - but made no formal speech.

Her only intervention of the day was to round on the government for perpetrating a "fraud" on pensioners. The for mer prime minister said: "This government has put a means test of old age pensions so that thousands and thousands of people who paid contributions all their lives are not getting their pensions. That to me is outright fraud."

Mr Major had underlined his anger with Mr Hague's lurch to the right when he told a fringe meeting at the Tory conference on Monday that the party had failed to reach out to voters "outside the circle of rising prosperity".

However, the former prime minister believes that Mr Hague is now making a genuine bid to reach out to voters on the centre ground. The Tory leader launched this week's conference with a pledge to revitalise Britain's inner cities and the leadership promised yesterday to outspend Labour on health, though this will involve a greater role for the private sector.

Mr Major has been briefed on all the new policies announced this week, which have met with his approval. "The shadow cabinet have been consulting me, they have been meticulous and call me regularly," Mr Major said. "I have suggested some policies, but I take no credit for any of it. I repeat I take no credit."

Some Tories on the left of the party, who were exasperated by Mr Hague's provocative interventions on asylum seekers and law and order, believe that the leadership's conversion to one nation policies is too little too late. Sir Edward Heath spoke up for the critics yesterday when he accused Mr Hague of making up policies "on the spur of the moment". Asked whether he agreed with this view, Mr Major indicated some sympathy with the "wets" when he said: "Maybe."

The new warmth between Mr Major and the Tory leadership marks an important rapprochement after the shadow cabinet attempted at last year's conference to airbrush the former prime minister out of Conservative history.

Mr Major, who pointedly went on holiday to Venice during last year's gathering, was deeply hurt. Tory activists demonstrated their affection for Mr Major at his fringe meeting on Monday night, which was packed out.

fields.headline: At this price?  HSBC
fields.trailText: That HSBC is being courted heavily by US banking group Merrill Lynch is becoming part of City folklore.
fields.body:
That HSBC is being courted heavily by US banking group Merrill Lynch is becoming part of City folklore.

Scared by the might of the Citigroup conglomerate, which includes Salomon Smith Barney, many believe the "thundering herd" that is Merrill Lynch would feel much more comfortable if it could team up with HSBC. The speculation started as a result of the joint venture established by the two groups at a cost of £300m a year to provide banking and investment services over the internet to the "mass affluent".

But, there appears little reason for HSBC's management team to bow to Merrill Lynch's rumoured advances. At three times the size of Merrill, it is HSBC which would have to take the lead.

At their annual board meeting today in Kuala Lumpur John Bond and his HSBC team are unlikely to be considering ways to woo the staff of Merrill, who own as much as 40% of their bank. He will be able to remind his board that HSBC is one of the banks which can truly claim to be global. In the US, HSBC's hexagon is a familiar sight on the streets of New York after its acquisition of the Safra banking empire. The hexagon is now accepted on the streets in Britain after replacing the tired Griffin of the renamed Midland Bank. It will gain credibility in France after the acquisition of CCF.

The City seems content with HSBC's progress. Its shares have galloped upwards in recent months and their power yesterday was much of the reason for the FTSE's gains.

The biggest problem for investors is deciding whether it is too late to join in the ride at £9.80. Perhaps so, says Richard Coleman, banking analyst at ABN Amro. But HSBC is also one of the few British banks on his recommended buy list.

Hated during the Asian crisis three years ago, HSBC has convinced investors it has diversified from emerging markets. The shares look as if they should be held and bought gently on dips.

fields.headline: Hollick pulls off a coup
fields.trailText: How things change: only a couple of months ago Lord Hollick, boss of United News & Media, was being cast as the loser in the battle for ITV.
fields.body:
How things change: only a couple of months ago Lord Hollick, boss of United News & Media, was being cast as the loser in the battle for ITV.

The grand merger with Carlton Communications , up 8p at 538p, was dead and Granada Media , 13p higher at 456p, had emerged triumphant by snapping up United's TV assets for £1.75bn.

City professionals, however, are now telling their clients that former investment banker Lord Hollick may have pulled off a rather good deal.

Last week Granada Media shares plummeted after the company warned advertising revenues in the first half of next year would fall below this year's levels. With the ITV network also under pressure from the onslaught of digital TV, United seems to have timed its exit from broadcasting to perfection, say analysts.

This, however, is only part of the story.

When Lord Hollick agreed to sell United's ITV assets, a clause was negotiated whereby payment could be taken in cash instead of shares if the Granada Media share price is below 585p in mid-December.

With Granada Media shares showing no signs of recovery - last week's warning shattered City confidence in the company - the prospect of a significant cash windfall for United shareholders now appears to be real possibility.

Yesterday, analysts at investment back CSFB were telling anyone who would listen that £1.25bn of cash could to be returned to United shareholders via a share buyback as early as December.

Assuming a purchase price of 850p, United could afford to buy in around 30% of its outstanding shares, CSFB says. A buyback of this size would provide significant support for United shares, which CSFB sees as having a fair value of between £10 and £12 per share. Buoyed by the story, United shares ended the day 26.5p higher at 773p.

Leading British shares, meanwhile, enjoyed a good session, finishing with their biggest points gain in 13 sessions. The main FTSE 100 index finished the session 60.5 points higher at 6,345, with many traders attributing the strong showing to technical factors.

On Monday the FTSE 100 had closed nine points lower after spending most of the day in positive territory. According to dealers this was because a big investment bank had been selling large tranches of shares in after hours trading at the end of the session.

That said, a positive opening on Wall Street and strength in market heavyweights HSBC , up 25p to 985p, and Shell , 7p better at 564p, also helped.

However, technology stocks were the best performers. Misys rose 61p to 693.5p after the business software group said it was confident about the year ahead. The news filtered through to the rest of the sec tor, helping CMG to gain 70p to £14.85 and Sage to rise 38p to 543p.

The Techmark 100 index closed the day 64.11 points higher at 3,846.11.

On the down side, Sainsbury - 14.75p lower at 358p - was the biggest faller, unsettled by price cuts at Tesco , down 5.25p at 238.75p.

Lower down the corporate scale, Innogy Holdings , the newly demerged domestic arm of National Power, surged 27p, or 16.34%, to 192.25p, helped by directors' share buying and a bullish note from Schroder Salomon Smith Barney, which initiated coverage with a 225p target price.

IT company ITNET dropped 115p to 350p on news that London's Hackney council has terminating its contract with the company.

Reflective inks maker Reflec was attracting some interest. Although its shares closed unchanged at 12p, on a volume of 1.6m shares.

Reflec is due to make a presentation at the ninth Company Investor Show on Thursday and according to the gossips, the company will preview several new products including a reflective tape for workwear and a fire-resistant ink.

fields.headline: No: 1733
fields.standfirst: Sir Henry Norris
fields.trailText: Sir Henry Norris
fields.body:
A knight of the realm!
And some. A scion of one of England's most distinguished families, Norris was one of King Henry VIII's closest confidantes.

How close?
The King made Norris first Senior Esquire of the Body, and later Groom of the Stole, Master of the Hart Hounds and of the Hawks, and...

Lord of the Flies?
Nope, Weigher of Goods in the port of Southampton.

I'd be wary of getting too close to that Henry VIII.
Rightly so. The tubby tyrant presently accused Norris of plucking his Tudor rose.

On what evidence?
At a tournament in Greenwich, the Queen, Anne Boleyn, dropped her hankie in Norris's path.

What, other than a runny nose and butter fingers, does that demonstrate?
"That, following daily her foul and carnal lust, Anne did falsely and traitorously procure by base kisses, touchings, gifts, and other infamous incitations, divers of the King's servants to be her adulterers and concubines," according to the official charges.

It's a fair cop.
Anne, Henry's second wife, was beheaded while Norris and three more of her alleged lovers were hanged.

A good thing too - nip the treachery in the bud.
Well, not quite. Norris had descendants, you see, who married into a family called Jephson.

You don't mean...
That Patrick Jephson, Diana's ex-private secretary and tell-all "royal rat" de nos jours , is following in illustrious footsteps.

Most likely to say:
"I would rather die a thousand deaths than accuse the Queen of that which I believe her, in my conscience, innocent."

Least likely to say:
"I take full responsibility for my decision to write about my personal experience of Anne Boleyn between 1533 and 1536."

Titles Jephson may now have denied himself:
OBE, MBE, Weigher of Goods in the port of Southampton.

Not to be confused with:
Sir Henry Norris, one-time chairman of Arsenal football club.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: The Hitchhiker's Guide To The Future With Douglas Adams | 34th Annual Country Music Association Awards
fields.body:
Those baffled by the Internet are offered a few simple explanations over the next four weeks in The Hitchhiker's Guide To The Future With Douglas Adams (11.0am, Radio 4). Without a preview tape it's hard to gauge how useful it will be. The first topic is the web's impact on the pop music business. However, battalions of expensive lawyers currently fighting over alleged infringements of copyright show that technical explanations are not always the point.

The red-eyed zombies missing their small-hours Olympic fix can get some temporary relief with the three-hour overnight coverage of the 34th Annual Country Music Association Awards (12.55am, Radio 2). The tension may not be quite up to Sydney levels. Faith Hill (pictured), whose platinum discs are scattered about like confetti, has been nominated for eight of the major awards. The one thing that might persuade a stunned Grand Old Opry crowd to yell foul would be her failure to win anything.

fields.headline: Silent sandwich maker
fields.trailText: Since receiving an unsolicited takeover approach at the start of September there has not been a murmur from Hazlewood Foods, the UK's biggest sandwich maker.
fields.body:
Since receiving an unsolicited takeover approach at the start of September there has not been a murmur from Hazlewood Foods, the UK's biggest sandwich maker.

But, according to City gossips, things have been moving behind the scenes. One tale circulating the dealing rooms yesterday said former Hillsdown chief executive Michael Teacher, with the backing of Legal & General Ventures, has tabled an offer of 120p to 130p a share.

The gossips claim Hazlewood's four biggest shareholders - including Merrill Lynch Asset Management and Schroders, which control about 40% of the firm's shares - are prepared to back the deal. They are said to have been pressing Hazlewood's board to accept the offer.

Hazlewood refused to comment on the market speculation. The stock ended the day 4p higher at 112.5p after 1m shares changed hands.

fields.headline: Tale with a twist
fields.standfirst: With a string of raw crime dramas she became one of Britain's top TV writers. But after a cool reaction to Lynda La Plante's recent work,  Sally Weale  asks whether the serial storyteller has lost her edge
fields.trailText: With a string of raw crime dramas she became one of Britain's top TV writers. But after a cool reaction to Lynda La Plante's recent work, Sally Weale asks whether the serial storyteller has lost her edge
fields.body:
When Lynda La Plante was Lynda Titchmarsh - Tittie or Loopy to her friends - and she lived with her family in the Crosby district of Liverpool, she used to enjoy terrifying her younger sister with horror stories late at night. The lights in the Titchmarsh household would go out and Lynda would pipe up: "Right, story time! There's a man in the wardrobe with no head."

She was bossy and exhibitionist. She would scalp her sister's dolls and dunk them down the toilet. She was the star of the household - the little girl who had to take the place of her five-year-old sister who was killed in an accident; a Scouse Shirley Temple, forever putting on shows, singing, dancing and telling stories.

Today, La Plante is still telling amazing stories at a ferocious rate. She has just published her eighth novel; the fourth series of her crime show Trial and Retribution starts on ITV tonight; a fifth series has just gone into production and another pilot drama called Mind Games is to be broadcast this autumn. Before all this there was a string of tele-vision hits - Widows (1983), Civvies (1992), The Governor (1995), to name but three.

La Plante, once a jobbing actress, is now one of the most prolific and successful television writers ever. Her name on a script can bring in millions of viewers. She has her own production company with swish offices in London's Soho. She is feted by Hollywood; she gets personal calls from Barbra Streisand and has more projects in development than Steven Spielberg.

We meet in her office in Wardour Street - all pale wood and cream carpet. She looks like a million dollars, petite, with good skin and teeth - like a member of the First Wives Club (her 18-year marriage to writer and rock musician Richard La Plante ended in divorce in 1996.)

She wears a long, grey, fitted dress coat and trousers, with a tight cream bustier which encases a large, brown, crumpled bosom. She has lots of heavy, shiny jewellery, and toys with a sparkly cigarette case and lighter as she talks in a gravelly posh voice. Entertaining, telling stories, mimicking, acting out scenes - she is very good company. Shirley Temple grown up.

La Plante, now 52, has just returned from the US, where her work increasingly takes her. A display board in the boardroom of La Plante Productions lists projects in development. On the left there is a list of UK projects - five in total. On the right are the US projects - Widows, Prime Suspect and Cold Shoulder, plus a number of less likely ventures such as Wuthering Heights and Helen of Troy (a six-hour mini-series for US television). Eight in total. Little Tittie from Crosby is doing well.

But La Plante is disillusioned. Her star may be in the ascendant in the US, but here the critics have not been kind about a couple of her recent productions. Her 1998 show Killer Net, about the dangers lurking within the burgeoning internet culture, was dismissed as a "ridiculous, middle-aged fantasy"; the Channel 5 mini-series Bella Mafia was, according to the Guardian, "so bad it made you yearn for the magic of that master storyteller Jeffrey Archer". The consensus seems to be that she has not recently matched the raw brilliance of her ear lier work, especially Prime Suspect, featuring the vividly drawn character of DCI Jane Tennison, played by Helen Mirren.

It is little wonder La Plante feels persecuted. She is tired of the critics' snide remarks; she is sick of being accused of using gratuitous violence (the Daily Mail once posed the question: "Is this the most dangerous woman on television?"), and she is fed up because her work is shown no respect in this country, unlike in the US. "I'm shown respect there for my work. I don't think there's the respect here. Truthfully I don't.

"When I did Killer Net I was six months too early. People here hadn't heard of www.com The journalists looked at me as if I had two heads."

The inspiration for the story came from a dinner party where La Plante met a woman whose 12-year-old daughter had made a friend on the internet and arranged to meet him in a cafe in downtown Los Angeles. Her mother found out, contacted the police and discovered the man her daughter had arranged to meet was a known killer. "She would probably never have seen her little girl again," says La Plante. "Now everyone knows. Now everyone is warning, warning, warning. But when Killer Net went out the response to it was like [she puts on a scornful, boozie drawl], 'Well, this couldn't happen'. " Then she spits out angrily: "Why the fuck don't they just look at it and listen?

"This is the one area in my work I can never ever understand. I very rarely work off the truth. I don't put something on the screen that either hasn't happened or can't happen. So therefore when I'm given these snide remarks by the critics" - she puts on the boozie drawl again - " 'I notice Lynda La Plante's killers are always very handsome', I just want to say, [her voice drops to one of quiet suspense - I'm gripped], 'Do you want to see the real guy? Do you want to see what he really looked like? He was a movie star. He did look like Tom Cruise. That's how he could kill'. "

Her new book, Sleeping Cruelty, sees La Plante on unfamiliar territory. Her central character is an entrepreneur called Sir William Benedict who gets caught up in a political scandal which leaves his reputation in tatters. Among the themes swirling around, though not very satisfactorily explored, are paedophilia and the effect on abused children; children as killers; the hounding of public figures by the press; the rehabilitation of disgraced figures and sexual deviancy (some of the sex scenes had to be toned down on the advice of her agent). La Plante says she thought the plot was doing well up until about three-quarters of the way through. I found it a bit far-fetched.

La Plante prides herself on her exhaustive research. For this book she talked to people who had been injured by the press (she won't divulge any names) and to people who grew up being abused by a paedophile. Previously she has trawled prisons, police stations and brothels, digging out real-life stories on which to hang nailbiting drama. Once she even stripped down to her sports bra and a rather large pair of tennis knickers to interview prostitutes in downtown Los Angeles, all in the name of research.

Nowadays it is hard to picture this rather grand, glitzy multi- millionairess grubbing around among the miserable, the criminal and the dispossessed. She has got two full-time researchers to do a lot of the legwork.

She still sits through trials to pick up the tiniest details - the way a barrister slips his pen in and out of his pocket, the way he gazes over the witness's shoulder to unnerve and unsettle. It all adds to the authenticity of a scene. She has a team of barristers, judges, detectives who go through every script, checking for inaccuracies - down to the way a hair is removed for forensics.

So what has La Plante learned after all these years of rooting around the underworld? She has learned that we live in a very sick world. She has also learned that victims of crime get a very raw deal. She used to be concerned about the prisoner, and the need for rehabilitation. Now the focus of her concern has shifted from criminal to victim.

"Myra Hindley can stand up and say: 'I'm completely rehabilitated. I have studied therapy, I am a qualified psychiatrist and Christ knows what else.' The victim's mother stands up and says: 'Release her and I'll kill her.'

"Who rehabilitated the victim's mother? Who helped her overcome the grief, the fury? Nobody. She has remained in the same position as she was when her child was murdered 30 years ago. It has to be victim first, criminal second."

It is hard to imagine La Plante moving from this sort of territory to the likes of Helen of Troy and Wuthering Heights and she admits she has found the research difficult. But she is happy to have a go. It is only telling a story after all, just like she did as a child in Crosby after the lights went out. Now, back to that man in the wardrobe with no head.

 Sleeping Cruelty is published by Macmillan at £16.99. Trial and Retribution IV can be seen tonight and tomorrow at 9pm on ITV.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Sainsbury is switching to wind power at one of its Scottish distribution sites in a move that could be duplicated elsewhere in Britain.
fields.body:
Sainsbury turns to wind

Sainsbury is switching to wind power at one of its Scottish distribution sites in a move that could be duplicated elsewhere in Britain.

The high turbine will be built at the East Kilbride distribution centre. Ian Coull, company director, said: "It makes good business and environmental sense to try a technology that reduces our carbon dioxide emissions and will be exempt from payments under the climate change levy."

The Enercon E40 500 kW turbine is being build by Next Generation, part of the Gloucester-based NexGen group. It should be completed before the end of 2000 and will generate about a third of the energy required at the depot saving 1,645 tonnes of carbon dioxide every year.

MG Rover goes on defensive

MG Rover yesterday denied as "wholly unsubstantiated" reports that it planned to extend its repayments schedule to suppliers from 60 to 90 days.

Malaysia's Proton, tipped as a possible joint venture partner in a new medium-sized car, also denied reports it was in talks to take an equity stake in the British group or even take it over.

UK gas could run out by 2020

Britain's natural gas reserves could be exhausted within 20 years if demand continues to rise at the present rate and is not matched by new gas field developments, gas transport firm Transco said.

Its 10-year statement, which forecasts gas supply and demand, said imports could start sooner than previously forecast - with the possibility of imports this winter during high demand. In the longer term, imports are likely to come from Norway, via North Sea pipelines, or from Russia through the gas interconnector to Belgium, usually used for export to Europe.

Asda to open a dozen stores

Wal-Mart, the US retailer which owns Asda, is planning to open about 12 stores in Britain over the next year. The plans are part of a worldwide expansion which will see 300 new stores.

Lee Scott, Wal-Mart president and chief executive, announced the plans to American investors at a briefing in Arkansas.

Asda has 240 UK stores. A spokesman said that the new stores would include locations in Cornwall, Hull, Cambridge, Dunstable, Greater Manchester, Scotland and east London.

Axa may face legal action

The Consumers' Association yesterday threatened to seek court intervention in the move by insurance group Axa to free up its £1.7bn so-called orphan estate. The consumers group said it was setting a Friday deadline for Axa to agree to pay the legal costs of a challenge to its controversial plan.

Axa said it had already cooperated with the Consumers Association, which only yesterday had rejected the opportunity of a meeting with Mark Wood, chief executive of Axa.
