fields.headline: Sir Fred Pontin
fields.standfirst: Shrewd businessman who caught the mood of Britain's postwar holidaymakers
fields.trailText: Shrewd businessman who caught the mood of Britain's postwar holidaymakers
fields.body:
Less flamboyant than his holidays tycoon rival Sir Billy Butlin, Sir Fred Pontin, who has died aged 93, was the more significant judge of social trends. He sensed that the blue-collar holiday camp concept pioneered by Butlin would be overtaken in the postwar years by the more middle-class holiday village; in short, that self-catering would erode the "Wakey, wakey!" ambience.

The two pioneers were temperamentally at opposite poles. The bluffly moustached showman Butlin was fond of the limelight and any form of celebrity. The clean-shaven and seldom-smiling Pontin, a man of few words, valued his contacts with royalty, and coolly tailored himself to the demands of a more classy type of clientele. He merged a blunt, even pugnacious, management style with work for theatrical and sporting charities, which won him a knighthood in 1976.

Perhaps Pontin was only superficially the less pushy of the pair. Butlin once paid a sneaky visit to a Pontins camp to get ideas from his rival, something Pontin would never have done. But he responded with a publicity brochure that included a photograph of Butlin at a Pontins bar, and the caption: "All the best people come to Pontins."

Like many self-made multi-millionaires, Sir Fred was fond of emphasising his lack of academic qualifications. His family had been East End cabinet makers for generations, and, after the local council school in Dalston, he attended the Sir George Monoux grammar school, Walthamstow, leaving at 15 without having passed any examinations.

His father wanted him to seek security in the local bank, but Fred's fortune-hunting eyes alighted on the stock exchange, and he joined stockbrokers Gordon Askew and Biddough as a jobber for £1 a week, plus commission. A week later, the firm went into voluntary liquidation. However, in addition to two weeks' pay, he also got £100 in commission, a large sum in those days. A week later, he got a job with a another stockbroker, Gow and Parsons, at 15 shillings (75p) a week.

This time, he was sacked for allowing errors in the postal system, but he pleaded his case with such vigour that he was reinstated at 25 shillings a week - and the assurance that his work would not involve such details. He left after three years for the jobbers Bristow Brothers, and, after a year, moved on to the Rock Investments Company, where for 10 years he gained experience of company investment, market dealings and group shares. In 1937, he set up on his own, running a football pool in London.

Called up at the beginning of the war, he found himself labelled medical grade 4 (the lowest) because of mastoid trouble, and was sent to Orkney to help 5,000 Irish labourers build a naval base. He soon found himself appointed catering manager, a task he relished.

Directed to Kidderminster to manage a hostel for steel and sugar beet workers, he discovered that his predecessor was in hospital, having had his ribs kicked in by workers protesting over food grievances. With a typical blend of blunt ruthlessness and delight in being of service, Pontin got himself a large alsatian guard dog and a bodyguard even bulkier than himself, then set to work improving the conditions. He appears to have succeeded; at any rate, his ribs remained intact.

After the war, Pontin decided to use all his painful experience in a more upbeat fashion. Abruptly demobbed servicemen and women found themselves with money - their demob gratuities - perhaps for the first time in their lives. What would they most want? A holiday, surely? Pontin backed his intuition, and set his eyes on a former military camp at Bream Sands, near Burnham-on-Sea, Somerset. It cost £23,000, which Pontin didn't have. But he did have ingenuity: he formed a syndicate for £25,000, ensuring he held 50% control by buying half the equity with a bank loan.

This was to be the beginning of a strategy that would make him millions. He bought more camps, personally ran each for a year to lick it into shape, then sold it to the syndicate - in which he still had 50%. The Pontins company was formed in July, 1946, with 400,000 shares, all placed in one day - a feat never accomplished, or even attempted, before.

By the 1960s, his British holiday camps and villages were thriving, and he cast his eyes abroad. Though he had managed to enlarge the domestic holiday season from April to October, the British weather prevented him from stretching it further. So, in 1963, he formed Pontinental and built a chain of holiday villages in Spain, Majorca, Sardinia, Ibiza, Greece, Morocco and Yugoslavia.

The first was in Sardinia, a double-winged building of three storeys, which became the template for future developments. Each apartment had its own bathroom and tea-making machine and, because British holidaymakers still believed that all foreign food would upset their stomachs, the restaurants served plain English food, augmented by a single Mediterranean dish for bolder spirits. There was a nightclub, relegated to the basement. Foreign governments were at first eager to lend Pontin up to 50% of his building costs, at modest interest rates over 15 to 20 years. Then they realised they might be wasting their charity on lucrative foreign enterprises unpopular with their own electorates, and cut back the financial aid. Pontin lost £200,000 in two years on his overseas complexes.

By then, however, he had seen the potential of the self-catering holiday in smaller housing units in a holiday village. He tried out the first at Wick Ferry village, near Christchurch, with entertainment and restaurants for the occasions when no one wanted to cook for themselves. His first year profit was only £16,000, but by 1975 it had leapt to £3.6m - from 25 villages, 18 with catering, and seven with self-catering, the largest with 5,000 beds. The self-catering idea had proved its worth against those who argued that, when people went on holiday, they wanted to be sociable and abandon cooking for themselves.

By now, Pontin's wealth had helped him to acquire a string of racehorses, but, even here, his interest was less exhibitionism than calculated business. His first horse was named Go Pontin, followed by Pontingo and Go Pontinental. His instruction to his trainers and jockeys was that they must always finish in the first three or four - so that the sports commentators would keep on mentioning them - and give their owner free advertising worth millions. One of his horses, Specify, won the Grand National in 1971.

Such flirting with the world of the turf might have irritated those who worked for him. But Pontin shrewdly kept on the right side of his employees, especially in the recessions of the 1970s, by voluntarily taking a salary cut of £928 a week and foregoing substantial sums in commission. This, he said, was because his workers were only getting small wage increases, although later he acknowledged that the money would have gone in tax anyway.

Pontin's work for charities also kept him in favour. He had been chief barker of the Variety Club of Great Britain, for which he raised more than £1m, and was a member of the Grand Order of Water Rats, two of the biggest theatrical charities. He was also a member of the Lord's Taverners.

In 1978, he sold out his main leisure interests to the Coral group. He remained a director, but was not suited to running in harness with the Coral family - or anyone else for that matter - and, after two years, resigned from the board with a £200,000 pay-off. His personal business was centred on his ownership of flagship hotels, including the Farringford, on the Isle of Wight, once the home of the poet Tennyson.

At 80, he joined Ponti's restaurant chain, run by his friend Peter Ispani, and, in 1988, celebrated his 82nd birthday in the Covent Garden Ponti's, which specialised in serving fish and chips with champagne, a supposed levelling taste which was slower to gain ground than his previous ventures.

By the 1990s, he was amazing his wife and daughter by his reluctance to ease back on work, taking an active interest in plans for a Euro Pontin company that would eventually take 3,000 trippers a week to Euro-Disney, where he had a 3,000-unit resort. He did not believe in retirement. "When I take up golf or buy myself a yacht," he said, "see that I am certified."

After the death of his first wife, Dorothy, he married Joyce Hey last year. She survives him, as does a daughter from his first marriage.

Frederick William Pontin, holiday camp founder, born October 24 1906, died September 30 2000

webTitle: Dead miners hidden from Chinese public

fields.headline: Dead miners hidden from Chinese public
fields.trailText: Rescue teams at a mine in south-western China admitted yesterday that they had all but given up hope of saving any more miners trapped in caves full of poisonous gases.
fields.body:
Rescue teams at a mine in south-western China admitted yesterday that they had all but given up hope of saving any more miners trapped in caves full of poisonous gases.

At least 107 miners have died and a further 52 remain entombed after an underground explosion last Wednesday at the Muchonggou coal mine in Guizhou province. Eighty-five people have been rescued.

The state-run media have published moving accounts of the desperate attempts to save the trapped miners. Air, along with water, soup, porridge and milk, have been sent into the mine through a pipe in an effort to keep them alive during the long rescue attempt.

The men, reported to include many sets of brothers, tapped on the pipe to communicate with people on the surface.

But the official China Daily reported yesterday that those still stranded are believed to have suffocated in the poisonous gases released by the blast. More than 200 people involved in the rescue attempt have had to rely on picks, shovels and their bare hands, for fear of igniting the gases.

"We're using human power only, no machines," said one mine official. "It's too dangerous to use machines or explosives."

Efforts have also been hampered by the collapse of structures supporting the mine shafts, although rescuers did succeed in clearing some rubble and pumping in enough air to reduce the risk of further explosions.

Those killed have been brought out under cover of darkness, apparently for fear of the public anger that might be ignited, and then turned on officials.

"Rescuers have found plenty of bodies but they're keeping them in the mine until night-time because there are a lot of people gathered around and mine officials don't want people to see all the bodies," said a doctor at the local mining bureau hospital.

The accident at Muchonggou has highlighted the appalling casualty rate in China's coal mines. At least 2,730 people died in mining accidents in the first six months of this year, according to official statistics.

In January, 22 miners died, trapped underground by a torrent of water in Dahuangshan mine in the eastern province of Jiangsu.

Most of the deaths have been in small unlicensed mines, which the government says it is trying to close. Many have no emergency exits or vents, let alone safety certificates.

Muchonggou, which employs 4,000 people, is properly licensed and mine officials insist it had been considered relatively safe. But it was the scene of another gas explosion in 1983, which killed more than 80 miners. And an official has admitted that the government company that runs it has - like many state-owned enterprises in China - run into financial difficulties.

"Salaries for miners have not been paid on time," he said. When they are paid, those who work underground get 1,000 yuan (£82) a month.

fields.headline: Shipman's family strips surgery
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Shipman trial
fields.trailText: A new doctor has taken over as a replacement for the serial killer Harold Shipman, but not before Shipman's family stripped his former surgery of computers, telephones, desks and chairs.
fields.body:
A new doctor has taken over as a replacement for the serial killer Harold Shipman, but not before Shipman's family stripped his former surgery of computers, telephones, desks and chairs.

Amy Cumming has been appointed as a permanent replacement for Shipman at the surgery in Market Street, Hyde, Cheshire, where he killed at least three patients with injections of diamorphine.

She is working along with Amir Hannan to treat the 3,000 patients on Shipman's list. The practice has been run by locum doctors since Shipman was arrested in 1998.

Dr Cumming said they faced problems after Shipman's children stripped the building of furniture at the weekend.

"The family had left the furnishings while the locums were at the surgery, but decided to come and get the stuff at the weekend," she said. "They did take everything and we only had a day to replace everything, which was a headache."

She said she regarded her job as a major challenge - but one she was looking forward to.

"It is going to be a good practice, a smoothly run practice, and we are going to regain the trust and confidence of the patients as far as we can," she said.

A public inquiry into Shipman's crimes will be held later this year.

webTitle: US bid for RJB to come this month

fields.headline: US bid for RJB to come this month
fields.trailText: Renco, the private US conglomerate owned by billionaire Ira Rennert, is to launch an agreed bid of about £130m this month for Britain's biggest coal producer, RJB Mining.
fields.body:
Renco, the private US conglomerate owned by billionaire Ira Rennert, is to launch an agreed bid of about £130m this month for Britain's biggest coal producer, RJB Mining.

The news of the estimated 80p a share bid sent RJB's stock up 7.5p to close at 62p. The shares have fallen from a peak of more than £6 to a low of about 30p this year.

Renco, which has been carrying out due diligence for four months, is understood to be waiting for clearance from the European commission for the government's £100m in aid to the coal industry.

RJB, which declared a £10m pre-tax loss for the first six months in August, is due to gain £70m under the package designed to avert a further round of pit closures and preserve the indigenous coal industry through a period of unstable global energy demand.

RJB owns 13 deep-mined pits, including two - Ellington, near Morpeth, and Clipstone, Notts, rescued when ministers announced the aid.

RJB employs 8,000 miners and produces 23m tonnes a year but has slipped into financial difficulties because of geological problems, cheap imports and low global prices.

fields.headline: Open Gate
fields.standfirst:
Kohl stays away as Germany celebrates 10th anniversary of reunification he masterminded

Special report: the fall of the Berlin wall, 10 years on
fields.trailText: If ever there were a case of Hamlet without the prince, then yesterday's 10th anniversary celebrations of German reunification was it. Helmut Kohl, who as chancellor rammed the merger through with the power of his personality and conviction, was nowhere to be seen.
fields.body:
If ever there were a case of Hamlet without the prince, then yesterday's 10th anniversary celebrations of German reunification was it. Helmut Kohl, who as chancellor rammed the merger through with the power of his personality and conviction, was nowhere to be seen.

After learning he had not been invited to speak, Mr Kohl said in August that he would be staying away from the main official event in the eastern city of Dresden, where President Jacques Chirac of France was guest of honour.

Last night, a big concert was planned for Berlin where, earlier in the day, thousands had flocked to the Brandenburg Gate, some unfurling flags from Germany's 16 states.

In less than a year, the "reunification chancellor" has become an embarrassment, due mainly to revelations of his role in his party's fundraising scandal.

But he still has a powerful influence on German politics. And, in the run-up to yesterday's festivities, he sparked an ill-tempered debate between the governing Social Democrats and his own Christian Democrats over who should get the credit for unification.

As the former chancellor recalled, the left was very uneasy about the whole project. President Johannes Rau, a Social Democrat and one of those attacked by Mr Kohl, tried yesterday to inject a note of magnanimity.

"He is not taking part in our festivities today," Mr Rau said. "But beyond all the current arguments I would like to stress that nothing can diminish Helmut Kohl's contribution to German unification."

Polls suggest a big majority still favours unification, but disillusionment is widespread. Westerners complain of the cost in subsidies to the east, and easterners have seen their job prospects and security eroded.

Fears that reunification might conjure up a more aggressive Germany have so far proved wholly unfounded. But leaders in Gerhard Schröder's Social Democrat coalition with the Greens have expressed growing concern about rightwing extremism at home.

"But beyond all the current arguments I would like to stress that nothing can diminish Helmut Kohl's contribution to German unification." Polls suggest a big majority still favours unification, but disillusionment is widespread. Westerners complain of the cost in subsidies to the east, and easterners have seen their job prospects and security eroded. Fears that reunification might conjure up a more aggressive Germany have so far proved wholly unfounded. But leaders in Gerhard Schröder's Social Democrat coalition with the Greens have expressed growing concern about rightwing extremism at home.

fields.headline: Firebombers hit synagogue
fields.standfirst: Special report: the fall of the Berlin wall, 10 years on
fields.trailText: A synagogue in the western town of Düsseldorf was slightly damaged overnight when three firebombs were thrown at the building, German police said.
fields.body:
A synagogue in the western town of Düsseldorf was slightly damaged overnight when three firebombs were thrown at the building, German police said.

A skinhead attack on a Russian immigrant couple in the eastern town of Schwerin and the defacing of a memorial to those who died in the Buchenwald concentration camp also stained a day of festivities marking 10 years of German reunification.

Witnesses said they had seen two to four people near the Düsseldorf synagogue and police said they had detained two young men for questioning.

A group of Jewish immigrants was injured in a bomb attack in Düsseldorf in July, sparking a wave of soul searching about far-right violence in modern Germany. The country has seen an upsurge in racist extremism since reunification, particularly in the former communist east where unemployment has soared.

Paul Spiegel, head of the Central Council of Jews in Germany, called the latest bombing "horrible".

"It really makes us think about whether it was right to build up a Jewish community in Germany again," Mr Spiegel said.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: As editor of the Daily Mail, Paul Dacre is a good friend of the motorist, as seen by the Mail's staunch support for the aims of the fuel blockades last month. But while he's happy to support motorists on his front page, Dacre's not so happy to have them outside his front yard.
fields.body:
As editor of the Daily Mail, Paul Dacre is a good friend of the motorist, as seen by the Mail's staunch support for the aims of the fuel blockades last month. But while he's happy to support motorists on his front page, Dacre's not so happy to have them outside his front yard. Paul and the 11 other home owners of Malvern Terrace, N1 (including Baroness Dean, the former Sogat union leader), have chipped in to raise £121,000 to buy the cul-de-sac from Islington council and end the road's status as a public highway. That would allow Paul and his neighbours to run their own mini traffic department - and stop the Mondeos of middle England from parking there. All was going to plan when the council approved the road's privatisation, but sadly for Dacre there has been a hitch. The buy-out was due to go before a final magistrates hearing, but objections from local residents have forced a delay. Fortunately Paul doesn't live in Malvern Terrace at the moment, and is renting his house out, so he doesn't have to endure the horror of the public parking outside his property.

The BBC is, as we now know, going to move its late evening news bulletin to 10pm, head to head with ITV. Despite that discovery, we should not read anything into the news that Greg Dyke was seen wining and dining Sir Trevor Macdonald two weeks ago. "There is no significance in the fact that Sir Trevor had lunch with Greg Dyke," says the ITN press office. Of course not. It was probably just a coincidence.

The Japanese have given us so many of the products that make modern life such a delight - including the Walkman, the fax, and Pokémon. Now scientists there have come up with something just as revolutionary: a pair of knickers with three leg-holes called "six-day underwear". The wearer is supposed to save money as well as time on washing. They come with instructions on how to put them on: "Rotate 120 degrees each day for three days, then turn inside out for another three days." If this product is to take off anywhere in the world, my money is on the UK.

Game as ever, Peter Hitchens rings to deny that he's changed his views between an article in the Express this week describing Nelson Mandela as a great man, and one on February 4 1998 where he called Mandela the incompetent leader of a "greedily corrupt" party. Peter sat impassively through Mandela's address to the Labour conference last week, unfazed by delegates flicking pellets of paper at his head. "I must have a pretty thick skin," he said. One delegate sitting behind Peter reported that he sat stony-faced and didn't even clap when Mandela appeared or finished his speech. "I never applaud at party conferences," the old dear retorted.

Short memories of South Africa also abound at the Tory party conference in Bournemouth. On Monday evening the Commission for Racial Equality hosted a reception for delegates -sponsored by Barclays, the bank that insisted on working from the inside to bring down the apartheid regime for so many years. How times change. Meanwhile, the green shoots of Conservative party revival are not appearing in that most important of forums, the marketplace. The eBay auction website recorded no bids at all yesterday for signed photographs of Margaret Thatcher, Peter Lilley or John Redwood, even at £2 for a colour 6x8 of the Vulcan ex-frontbencher.

Those of you who can't wait for the start of National Toast Week on October 30 may be interested in an away-day to what the Polish Tourist Office newsletter describes as "the first bread museum in Poland". The museum is located in Radzionkow in the Reszow region, "and contains many unique exhibits".

webTitle: Judges could face Europe court over rights act

fields.headline: Judges could face Europe court over rights act
fields.standfirst: Special report: human rights in the UK
fields.trailText: British judges could be taken to the European court of human rights in Strasbourg for denying litigants a fair hearing if they throw out human rights claims too readily, one of Britain's most senior judges warned last night.
fields.body:
British judges could be taken to the European court of human rights in Strasbourg for denying litigants a fair hearing if they throw out human rights claims too readily, one of Britain's most senior judges warned last night.

Lord Hope, one of the 12 law lords who sit in the House of Lords, said judges had been told they should be "robust" in rejecting unmerited claims under the Human Rights Act, which came into force on Monday.

The act incorporates the European convention on human rights into UK law, making it directly enforceable in UK courts. But the law lord said he favoured caution over robustness "lest, in a fit of enthusiasm for throwing cases out, the judges find themselves on the wrong end of a challenge under article 6 of the convention" - the right to a fair hearing.

Lord Hope, who was Scotland's senior judge before his appointment as a law lord, said it was wrong to assume that because few challenges had succeeded north of the border, few would be successful in England.

Human rights cases have been possible in Scotland since May 1999, when Scottish devolution took effect. Of some 600 human rights challenges, only around 16 have been successful. But until this week only the Scottish executive and parliament were subject to human rights challenges in the Scottish courts, said Lord Hope.

Because the lord advocate, a member of the executive, is responsible for prosecutions, prosecutors' decisions have been open to human rights challenges but not the acts of public bodies generally. Therefore the Scottish experience was no guide to what would happen in England now that all public authorities and bodies performing public functions were open to challenge.

"Now that the way is open for challenges across the entire field of action by public authorities the likely success rate is much less predictable," said Lord Hope. "My guess is that it is likely to increase." Giving a lecture sponsored by the law reform group Justice in central London, he said the fact that people no longer had to take their cases to Strasbourg, but could take the simpler and quicker route of applying to courts in the UK, was bound to lead to a great increase in the number of cases brought.

"But I do not see this as a reason for treating applications for relief against breaches of convention rights any more robustly than any other kind of application, or for asking lawyers to exercise greater restraint in the bringing of these applications.

"The tradition in this country is that the courts are open to any person who feels that his rights have been infringed."

Lord Hope said lawyers owed a duty to their clients, and in July the law lords had removed their immunity from negligence claims over court work. "So the judges are in no position to complain if counsel err on the side of caution in their own interests in the making of these applications."

fields.headline: Captive role idea for teenagers
fields.trailText: Sixth-formers should become "peer role models" to young offenders, the chief inspector of prisons said yesterday.
fields.body:
Sixth-formers should become "peer role models" to young offenders, the chief inspector of prisons said yesterday.

Addressing the Headmasters' and Headmistresses Conference in Harrogate, David Ramsbotham said: "Of course, there are difficulties and risks in all that, but that's what growing up is all about.

"Imprisonment must be seen as a positive opportunity for personal development, while staff are encouraged and motivated to identify, challenge and develop the good rather than merely contain the bad of those in their charge and care."

Also at the conference of independent school heads, David Calvert-Smith, the director of public prosecutions, said crime and punishment should be on the curriculum as part of basic classroom teaching.

He said the public was "startlingly" ignorant about the workings of the criminal justice system at the highest level.

"I have a daily postbag of letters from MPs complaining about this or that, and I would say that upwards of 50% of these letters betray a complete ignorance of what the Crown Prosecution Service is and what it does, what the role of the police is, where the courts come in and so on." he said.

He added: "Nobody actually learns about [criminal justice] when they are young. Prejudice and misconceptions abound.

"I suggest schools can begin the process and put basic criminal justice on to the hard disk of children by basic classroom teaching. I believe a topic like this can hardly be unhelpful to personal development."

fields.headline: The curse of light verse
fields.trailText: It is National Poetry Day tomorrow: an example, along with a proliferation of prizes and the continuation of some poetry lists despite economic unviability, of a new phenomenon: the marketing of poetry.
fields.body:
It is National Poetry Day tomorrow: an example, along with a proliferation of prizes and the continuation of some poetry lists despite economic unviability, of a new phenomenon: the marketing of poetry. New Generation Poets! The New Poetry! The New Plain Style! The "New Epic" (© John Walsh, this year's chairman)! It takes a peculiar form of cultural amnesia to see everything as constantly "new", whether New Labour (which looks so much like the old SDP) or BritArt (with its debts to Duchamp and a host of European artists of previous decades). But "new" is the selling point par excellence in a consumer culture obsessed by novelty and low on concentration.

It seems churlish to complain that poetry is receiving publicity, however dishonestly generated. Sales and readerships are very low; I read recently that 3% of all book sales are of poetry, and even that figure seems surprisingly high. But might we not be in danger of an inflationary rhetoric with regard to contemporary poetry, where so many superlative epithets - "best poet of their generation", "best American poet currently writing", and so on - are scattered like confetti over the whole crowd? Poetry, said Cressida Connolly, "can transform into gold that most everyday and overworked of materials, our common language". But these days - especially this week - our poetry is turned into gold by its adoption of the everyday and overworked vocabulary of marketing; and compromises are made.

In the past decade or so there has been an increase in people writing poems in ordinary language about ordinary life. Some have been excellent; but many, many more are at best competent. The structure and rhythms, where present, are unambitious; the conclusions clear (I grieve; I love; poverty and war are bad; capitalism makes me uneasy).

Some of these poems are very like chats in the pub. Poetry, if it is to be regarded as a distinct art, should be distinguishable from prose or anecdote or epigram. It has generally achieved this in its language, with regard to the sound of the words, or the dramatic properties of phrases and clauses, as well as their context, their etymologies, their politics.

In several ages, poetry has also and simultaneously examined language itself; it is a concentrated and serious art, which worries over the failures of language even as it demonstrates the suc cesses. It is not that simpler lyrics do not have force and value; it is that sticking to "accessible and approachable" poetry severely restricts what one can say, suggest, explore or evoke in terms of a more complex engagement with politics, history and humanity.

I also wonder whether, in our delighted promotion of this "new" poetry, we are being fair and honest with regard to an art which, like any, does not throw up a remarkable talent very often. In the history of the Forward Prize, Paul Muldoon has been nominated for best collection twice. Muldoon's work, in terms of reach and ambition and technique, is far ahead of what many practitioners do (or want to do), and he is one of the only contemporary poets who will still be read in 50 years' time. On neither occasion did Muldoon win. Last year he was beaten by Jo Shapcott; I mean no offence to Shapcott when I say that Muldoon's book was a quantum leap ahead of hers. Comments by one judge, Simon Armitage, suggest the decision was aimed at Oxford University Press, which had closed its poetry list - from which Shapcott's was one of the last publications: "It's irresistible not to think [sic] of this as a two-fingered cheerio to a publisher that recently chose to discontinue its contemporary poetry list for no reason whatsoever," he wrote.

Previously, I had thought that the decision was based on offering accessible work to a larger public, who might find Muldoon beyond their capabilities; but even that would be, frankly, patronising. We should not be ashamed to say: "This is excellent, but it will not please everyone." When we please everyone, we are offering them Wilbur Smith, Jackie Collins, Jeffrey Archer.

I do not think there has been an explosion of interest in contemporary poetry on the scale described by its promoters; poetry groups, readings, prizes, magazines and presses have been widespread for years. The attention of the media is welcome, but it is potentially corrupting, too; it might well usher in a world of Poetry Lite, with only minimally higher sales to compensate for the loss. Poetry will never be as popular as television and film; but it can do things they cannot, and would rarely even attempt. That is its unrewarded virtue. That is why it matters at least as much as television and film.

Robert Potts is the Guardian's poetry critic.

webTitle: It took 12 minutes to list Omagh victims' names

fields.headline: It took 12 minutes to list Omagh victims' names
fields.standfirst:
As grim inquest ends, coroner urges capture of bombers

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: The coroner halted for a moment, a catch in his voice. John Leckey took refuge in his glass of water, emotion overwhelming him as he read the pathetic, prosaic details, recording in the barest terms how 28 victims of the Omagh massacre two years ago had died.
fields.body:
The coroner halted for a moment, a catch in his voice. John Leckey took refuge in his glass of water, emotion overwhelming him as he read the pathetic, prosaic details, recording in the barest terms how 28 victims of the Omagh massacre two years ago had died.

It took him precisely 12 minutes to record the name of each of the dead, his or her occupation - toddler, he gave for one - and the cause of death. Those ranged from decapitation, in the case of Olive Hawkes, 60, married with two children, through laceration of the brain, as with two-year-old Maura Monghan, to the most common of all, multiple injuries. All were due to a bomb explosion.

Everybody was aware of what had killed the victims even before Mr Leckey, coroner for Greater Belfast, was drafted for the 19 days of harrowing evidence. They may only have learned the most gory of details over the past four weeks, but they knew the Real IRA had murdered 29 people in the biggest atrocity of what in Northern Ireland are euphemistically dubbed the Troubles.

Mr Leckey, a veteran of scores of inquests into terrible slayings, was unable even to say that those who died had been unlawfully killed. His hands were tied, he said, for, unlike in England and Wales, the rules in Northern Ireland permit only the most basic findings of who, when, where and how.

So there was an anti-climax as the families drifted away, bent in huddled groups, from the Omagh leisure centre yesterday. They were wondering whether sitting through the shocking video evidence, the horrifying witness testimonies, and the sickening pathology reports, had all been worth it.

For some, it was a pointless, painful and even cruel exercise, the outplaying of callous bureaucracy. Others found it cathartic, bringing them tiny solace, another hurdle negotiated in a lonely road they know can never lead to the recovery they crave.

Michael Gallagher, whose son and colleague Adrian, 21, was killed, admitted: "In one way, it was just the carrying out of the duties of the state. Our dead weren't officially recognised as dead until today.

"It was important for us to have the details. We are never going to hear anything worse than we have heard during the inquests. We don't have to wonder any more.

"But the families have been forced to go back for two years. Many see it as a setback."

Marion Radford, whose son, Alan, 16, died while they were out shopping, said: "I am glad I came. I had a lot of unanswered questions, but I know now he died rapidly and I was able to meet the policeman who was with Alan's body. That was a great comfort to me, but it has been very painful, like a horror film."

After delivering his findings, Mr Leckey, who yesterday laid a tribute of lilies in the Co Tyrone town's memorial gardens, told the families: "The last four weeks have been a difficult time for us all. I personally found it an emotional experience the like of which I have never encountered previously, and which I will never forget. I have no doubt many others found it that way too.

"The investigation of the facts was often unpleasant and distressing, I always knew it was going to be. My strong view is that it would have been quite wrong for me to have engaged in an exercise whose purpose was to sanitise or dilute the horror perpetrated on behalf of the Real IRA. I believe that would not have served the interests of justice and it would have been unfair to the memory of those who did so tragically."

Mr Leckey, close to tears, defended the work of the police, criticised by some lawyers, including Michael Mansfield QC, who questioned evacuation procedures. He said: "The age of Robocop has not dawned. It is a film. The police officers who confronted the horror were real men and women, not robots without feelings and emotions. I am sure all who assisted in any way as a consequence of what happened - police officers, traffic wardens, civilians and members of the emergency services - are grateful for the way the bereaved families acknowledged their efforts."

Mr Leckey continued: "The Real IRA claimed responsibility for the car bomb, though they sought to pass responsibility to the police for the casualties. As far as I am concerned, they were responsible for all that happened.

"The bomb warnings they gave were inadequate and misleading and the self-serving statement they issued subsequently had been shown to be untrue. If you park a car containing up to 200kg of explosive in a busy shopping street, set a timer, and walk away, you do not walk away from the responsibility for any resultant carnage.

"I share the hope, expressed forcibly by many of the families, that those responsible for the explosion are brought before a court of law. The conclusion of these inquests may close a chapter in the story of the dreadful events that happened in Omagh on August 15 1998, but a criminal trial and convictions will be necessary to close the book."

The families hope so too. They had a briefing on Monday with Eric Anderson, RUC acting assistant chief constable, leading the investigation into the atrocity, and believe criminal charges will follow.

The inquest into the 29th victim, James Barker, 12, the boy whose remains were disinterred from a cemetery in Buncrana, Co Donegal, six months ago, and reburied at home in England, will be held tomorrow. It was delayed because of procedural problems.

John Leckey took refuge in his glass of water, emotion overwhelming him as he read the pathetic, prosaic details, recording in the barest terms how 28 victims of the Omagh massacre two years ago had died. It took him precisely 12 minutes to record the name of each of the dead, his or her occupation - toddler, he gave for one - and the cause of death. Those ranged from decapitation, in the case of Olive Hawkes, 60, married with two children, through laceration of the brain, as with two-year-old Maura Monghan, to the most common of all, multiple injuries. All were due to a bomb explosion. Everybody was aware of what had killed the victims even before Mr Leckey, coroner for Greater Belfast, was drafted for the 19 days of harrowing evidence. They may only have learned the most gory of details over the past four weeks, but they knew the Real IRA had murdered 29 people in the biggest atrocity of what in Northern Ireland are euphemistically dubbed the Troubles. Mr Leckey, a veteran of scores of inquests into terrible slayings, was unable even to say that those who died had been unlawfully killed. His hands were tied, he said, for, unlike in England and Wales, the rules in Northern Ireland permit only the most basic findings of who, when, where and how. So there was an anti-climax as the families drifted away, bent in huddled groups, from the Omagh leisure centre yesterday. They were wondering whether sitting through the shocking video evidence, the horrifying witness testimonies, and the sickening pathology reports, had all been worth it. For some, it was a pointless, painful and even cruel exercise, the outplaying of callous bureaucracy. Others found it cathartic, bringing them tiny solace, another hurdle negotiated in a lonely road they know can never lead to the recovery they crave. Michael Gallagher, whose son and colleague Adrian, 21, was killed, admitted: "In one way, it was just the carrying out of the duties of the state. Our dead weren't officially recognised as dead until today. "It was important for us to have the details. We are never going to hear anything worse than we have heard during the inquests. We don't have to wonder any more. "But the families have been forced to go back for two years. Many see it as a setback." Marion Radford, whose son, Alan, 16, died while they were out shopping, said: "I am glad I came. I had a lot of unanswered questions, but I know now he died rapidly and I was able to meet the policeman who was with Alan's body. That was a great comfort to me, but it has been very painful, like a horror film." After delivering his findings, Mr Leckey, who yesterday laid a tribute of lilies in the Co Tyrone town's memorial gardens, told the families: "The last four weeks have been a difficult time for us all. I personally found it an emotional experience the like of which I have never encountered previously, and which I will never forget. I have no doubt many others found it that way too. "The investigation of the facts was often unpleasant and distressing, I always knew it was going to be. My strong view is that it would have been quite wrong for me to have engaged in an exercise whose purpose was to sanitise or dilute the horror perpetrated on behalf of the Real IRA. I believe that would not have served the interests of justice and it would have been unfair to the memory of those who did so tragically." Mr Leckey, close to tears, defended the work of the police, criticised by some lawyers, including Michael Mansfield QC, who questioned evacuation procedures. He said: "The age of Robocop has not dawned. It is a film. The police officers who confronted the horror were real men and women, not robots without feelings and emotions. I am sure all who assisted in any way as a consequence of what happened - police officers, traffic wardens, civilians and members of the emergency services - are grateful for the way the bereaved families acknowledged their efforts." Mr Leckey continued: "The Real IRA claimed responsibility for the car bomb, though they sought to pass responsibility to the police for the casualties. As far as I am concerned, they were responsible for all that happened. "The bomb warnings they gave were inadequate and misleading and the self-serving statement they issued subsequently had been shown to be untrue. If you park a car containing up to 200kg of explosive in a busy shopping street, set a timer, and walk away, you do not walk away from the responsibility for any resultant carnage. fields.headline: Parents 'did playground drug deal'
fields.trailText: Strathclyde police are investigating allegations that two parents carried out a drug deal in the playground of a primary school.
fields.body:
Strathclyde police are investigating allegations that two parents carried out a drug deal in the playground of a primary school.

The headteacher of St James primary school in Renfrew called in police after other parents reported seeing the deal take place within the school grounds two weeks ago.

Security measures at the school have been stepped up and the two people at the centre of the allegations have been banned from the school grounds while inquiries continue.

Renfrewshire council has praised the school for acting promptly once the concerns came to light, and stressed that no children were involved. "We have informed the parents of the ongoing inquiry and those adults allegedly involved have been denied access to the school grounds until the result of the police investigation is known," said the director of education, Shelagh Rae.

Strathclyde police said that inquiries were continuing into the alleged incident, which took place on September 18.

webTitle: More fish than flesh in future diet

fields.headline: More fish than flesh in future diet
fields.trailText: Fish farming will soon be feeding more people than cattle ranching, according to the think tank the Worldwatch Institute.
fields.body:
Fish farming will soon be feeding more people than cattle ranching, according to the think tank the Worldwatch Institute.

Aquaculture is the fastest growing sector of the world food economy, climbing from 13m tonnes of fish produced in 1990 to 31m in 1998 and increasing at 11% a year.

Cattle ranching, which produces four-fifths of the world's beef, tripled production in the 40 years to 1990 but has run out of productive land, and the figure remains static.

The report says the real test for future production comes because cattle need seven pounds of grain to produce one pound of beef while fish need only two pounds to gain a pound in weight. It also requires more water to keep cattle alive than fish - even taking into account the need for fish tanks and ponds.

With overfishing of ocean stocks now commonplace, developing countries are turning to fish farming to satisfy their growing appetite for seafood.

Fish farming is expected to double in size over the next 10 years.

The report says that a world that is reaching the limits with both oceanic fisheries and rangelands while adding 80m people each year needs efficient new sources of animal protein. Furthermore, herbivorous species of fish such as carp, grown in China in paddies, offer an efficient way of expanding animal protein supplies.

The report adds that while fish farming is not a solution to the world food problem, it does offer a potential source of low-cost animal protein for lower income populations.

fields.headline: No time to talk
fields.standfirst: The government has reformed pension policy more quickly and with far less consultation than in other European countries
fields.trailText: The government has reformed pension policy more quickly and with far less consultation than in other European countries
fields.body:
The United Kingdom is exceptional in the swiftness and decisiveness of policy-making. Prime ministers, provided they have an adequate majority, are able to make substantial shifts in policy much more rapidly than leaders in any other country in Europe.

Here, single-member constituencies and first-past-the-post voting delivers parliamentary majorities; two-party politics is adversarial, with little opportunity for coalition or cross-party negotiation. Unlike in other European countries, trade unions have been unable to influence the policies of either Tory or Labour governments. No constitutional court limits the power of the executive and the powers of the second chamber are being curtailed. Prime ministerial authority has recently been extended - the Cabinet Office now employs more than 200 staff. The Treasury is ascendant.

Reform of pensions (the highest spending programme across the European Union) is a good example of how these differences in the capacity of government to shift policy has played out. All face the same problem - ageing populations, leading to rising costs. Other countries spend more on state pensions (most have "Bismarckian" social insurance schemes and a much weaker tradition of private pensions than the UK). In most, the proportion of older people will increase more rapidly than in the UK (the chart shows changes in the balance of the pensioner pop ulation). The cost of ageing is thus lower in the UK than elsewhere, yet this is the country that has carried through the most rapid and thoroughgoing reform.

Two decades ago, the majority of the British workforce expected to receive the bulk of their pensions from the state through the basic national insurance pension, the state earnings-related pension and means-tested supplementary pension. Reforms by both Tory and Labour governments have relied chiefly on private provision - personal pensions, the new stakeholder pensions or occupational provision. Elsewhere in Europe, policy change has been pursued more gradually. Consensus has been built between political parties and other interests; new policies are essentially adjustments to bring future pension spending within acceptable limits.

In Germany, reforms in 1992 and 1999 altered the pension formula to reduce entitlement, removed incentives for early retirement, tapped VAT as an extra source of funding and introduced a "demographic moderator", so that pension rates take into account increases in life expectancy. The 1992 reform was supported by all parliamentary parties (except the Greens) and by both business and unions. The 1999 reform evolved through extended discussions between government and opposition parties (the Rentenkonsensgespräche).

Sweden, stronghold of social democratic universalist welfare, has also altered the formula and introduced a demographic moderator. An innovative scheme diverts a small proportion of contributions (2% of income) into a private funded scheme to supplement the state earnings-related pension. The basic pension has effectively become means-tested. The package was negotiated through a commission which involved the five main parties and representatives of pensioners' organisations in a broad investigation from 1984 to 1990. All five parties supported consensus legislation in 1994, which then gained a 90% majority.

In France, the Balladur government introduced reforms which required longer contribution periods, eliminated incentives for early retirement and weakened the formula linking contributions to benefits for private-sector workers in the early 1990s. These changes were achieved through concessions to the unions which reinforced their role in the management of the schemes. When Alain Juppé attempted to extend this to the large French public sector in 1995, he ne glected to smooth the path with unions and a national transport strike forced abandonment of the scheme.

In Italy, the Amato reforms of 1992 introduced some restrictions after extended debate. When Silvio Berlusconi sought more severe cuts (reminiscent of UK experience) in 1994, union resistance was one of the major factors leading to the fall of his government. The technocratic Dini administration negotiated a further reform package with unions and a coalition of leftwing parties and introduced it in 1995. More recently, Romano Prodi's attempt to introduce further cuts (at the recommendation of the 1997 Onofri commission) was confounded by opposition from his leftwing coalition partners. In all these countries, tax reforms are under way to encourage the growth of private funded pensions alongside the state sector, but have as yet had little impact.

UK governments are precipitate because, once in power, they encounter fewer restraints. It is simply not possible for other leaders to put their policy ideas into practice without extensive negotiations, because they have to deal with coalition partners, stronger trade unions and political cultures where negotiation with the main interests on the major issues confronting the government is normal. Our policy-makers are swift and decisive - but the fact that we do not need to generate consensus for major policy upheavals leaves UK policy shifts vulnerable to fresh reforms from the next government. Proposals made in Bournemouth this week could in theory become public policy within a matter of months.

Peter Taylor-Gooby is professor of social policy at the University of Kent

webTitle: Treading in the steps of Shackleton

fields.headline: Treading in the steps of Shackleton
fields.trailText: Three Britons are to follow in the footsteps of Sir Ernest Shackleton's 1916 crossing of the Antarctic island of South Georgia.
fields.body:
Three Britons are to follow in the footsteps of Sir Ernest Shackleton's 1916 crossing of the Antarctic island of South Georgia.

Next month Jock Wishart, Duncan Nicoll and Jonathan Chastney will cross the island's ice-bound peaks and glaciers, exposed to the same harsh weather conditions in replica Burberry clothing.

Shackleton crossed the island in 36 hours at the end of his 18-month attempt to cross Antarctica. His ship, Endurance, became trapped in sea ice and was crushed. For six months Shackleton and his 27-strong crew camped on ice floes.

Shackleton and five of the fittest men fought their way in an open boat across 800 miles of ocean to reach South Georgia and get help.

After a treacherous journey across the island, he and two of the men reached the Norwegian whaling station at Stromness, where they organised the rescue of the marooned men.

All 28 returned home safely, and Shackleton was hailed a national hero.

Wishart, 48, who has already rowed the Atlantic and circumnavigated the globe, said: "This expedition provides me with the opportunity of a lifetime, the chance not only to retrace the great man's steps but to do so enduring similar conditions."

The three, who have no back-up team, leave the UK on November 20 and are due to return on December 13.

webTitle: England v Germany: Keegan puts faith in twin powers

fields.headline: Keegan puts faith in twin powers
fields.standfirst:
Coach to field two strikers for Wembley finale with Germany
More about England v Germany
fields.trailText: David Lacey reports as Kevin Keegan looks set to field two strikers against a German team attempting rise above domestic scandal.
fields.body:
Kevin Keegan thought aloud yesterday about taking home a Wembley seat as a souvenir after Saturday's World Cup qualifier against Germany, preferably one from the royal box. But while the queen's sit-upon has a certain curiosity value the three points to be gained from beating Germany would be priceless by comparison.

For Keegan and England this is a unique week. True, they met the Germans only four months ago, beating them 1-0 in Charleroi during Euro 2000, but this will be the last match at Wembley before it is demolished and the game will be played against a background of poignancy and nostalgia which, from an English point of view, must not be allowed to trespass on the practical needs of the job in hand.

Keegan is well aware of the need not to be distracted by historical echoes. "I think it's a fitting match for the last game at the old Wembley," he said yesterday. "The players are aware of that but I think they are very focused. A lot of this stuff is going to go on around them but it will not affect their performance."

When it comes to demolition jobs Uli Hoeness, a regular member of West Germany's outstanding team of the 70s, appears to have done his utmost to take a steel ball to the present side's newly repaired confidence.

Hoeness, the Bayern Munich general manager, was quoted in the German sports magazine Kicker as saying that Bayer Leverkusen's coach Christoph Daum, due to take over the national squad from Rudi Völler next summer, has effectively disqualified himself as a fit person for the post after sex and drugs allegations about him appeared in a German newspaper.

The legal wheels in Germany are already rolling while an unhappy Völler has appealed to his country's media not to question any of his players about the controversy.

The row is unlikely to affect Germany's approach to Saturday, unless it further stiffens their resolve. Keegan refused to comment on Hoeness's allegations yesterday and the matter will probably be no more relevant to the result than was the defection of Rudolf Hess to the course of the second world war.

Not that a second England win against Germany this year can ever be a matter for comfortable assumption. Not only has Völler restored life to the enfeebled team who slunk disconsolately out of the European championship; he has also made adjustments to Erich Ribbeck's team - Ribbeck resigned after Germany's embarrassing first-round exit - calculated to make them stronger in areas where England may still be relatively weak.

Völler's five-man midfield may permutate the Bayer Leverkusen pair of Carsten Ramelow and Michael Ballack, along with Dietmar Hamann and Marco Bode, to establish an early ascendancy while Sebastian Deisler and Christian Ziege pose a threat on the wings. Unless Keegan switches to a similar 3-5-2 formation England will be outnumbered in the central positions from the start.

Either way Keegan will spend part of the next 48 hours debating whether or not to start the game with Steven Gerrard, so impressive when he came on in the final half-hour against Germany in Charleroi, in midfield along side Paul Scholes. The alternative is to go with the greater experience of Paul Ince, along with his limitations.

Joe Cole, the 18-year-old West Ham United prodigy whose inclusion in the squad for the first time is a healthy sign of things to come, will almost certainly start on the bench. "Joe's aim has to be trying to get involved in this game as one of the 22," Keegan explained yesterday. "I think that's the best he can hope for on Saturday."

Up front Michael Owen, whose goal as a late substitute in France last month enabled England to force a 1-1 draw with the world and European champions, looks certain to start alongside Andy Cole. "Michael's had a tremendous start to the season and I did say after the France game that I would change things for Germany."

Cole was used as a lone striker in Paris, with Scholes playing off him, but Keegan will not repeat the experiment on Saturday. "I would be very unlikely to play one striker at home," he said. "I think you would have to go back to the Domesday Book to see the last time I did that."

As it is, England have to go back 25 years to the last time they beat a German team at Wembley. Germany, moreover, have won on their last four visits if their "golden goal" triumph over the Czech Republic in the final of Euro 96 and the victory on penalties over Terry Venables's side in the semi-finals are included.

Kieron Dyer, who has a twisted knee, is England's only serious fitness doubt at present and Keegan is optimistic that his squad will have a clean bill of health by tomorrow morning.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

Hoeness, the Bayern Munich general manager, was quoted in the German sports magazine Kicker as saying that Bayer Leverkusen's coach Christoph Daum, due to take over the national squad from Rudi Völler next summer, has effectively disqualified himself as a fit person for the post after sex and drugs allegations about him appeared in a German newspaper. The legal wheels in Germany are already rolling while an unhappy Völler has appealed to his country's media not to question any of his players about the controversy. The row is unlikely to affect Germany's approach to Saturday, unless it further stiffens their resolve. Keegan refused to comment on Hoeness's allegations yesterday and the matter will probably be no more relevant to the result than was the defection of Rudolf Hess to the course of the second world war. Not that a second England win against Germany this year can ever be a matter for comfortable assumption. Not only has Völler restored life to the enfeebled team who slunk disconsolately out of the European championship; he has also made adjustments to Erich Ribbeck's team - Ribbeck resigned after Germany's embarrassing first-round exit - calculated to make them stronger in areas where England may still be relatively weak. Völler's five-man midfield may permutate the Bayer Leverkusen pair of Carsten Ramelow and Michael Ballack, along with Dietmar Hamann and Marco Bode, to establish an early ascendancy while Sebastian Deisler and Christian Ziege pose a threat on the wings. Unless Keegan switches to a similar 3-5-2 formation England will be outnumbered in the central positions from the start. Either way Keegan will spend part of the next 48 hours debating whether or not to start the game with Steven Gerrard, so impressive when he came on in the final half-hour against Germany in Charleroi, in midfield along side Paul Scholes. The alternative is to go with the greater experience of Paul Ince, along with his limitations. Joe Cole, the 18-year-old West Ham United prodigy whose inclusion in the squad for the first time is a healthy sign of things to come, will almost certainly start on the bench. "Joe's aim has to be trying to get involved in this game as one of the 22," Keegan explained yesterday. "I think that's the best he can hope for on Saturday." Up front Michael Owen, whose goal as a late substitute in France last month enabled England to force a 1-1 draw with the world and European champions, looks certain to start alongside Andy Cole. "Michael's had a tremendous start to the season and I did say after the France game that I would change things for Germany." Cole was used as a lone striker in Paris, with Scholes playing off him, but Keegan will not repeat the experiment on Saturday. "I would be very unlikely to play one striker at home," he said. "I think you would have to go back to the Domesday Book to see the last time I did that." As it is, England have to go back 25 years to the last time they beat a German team at Wembley. Germany, moreover, have won on their last four visits if their "golden goal" triumph over the Czech Republic in the final of Euro 96 and the victory on penalties over Terry Venables's side in the semi-finals are included. Kieron Dyer, who has a twisted knee, is England's only serious fitness doubt at present and Keegan is optimistic that his squad will have a clean bill of health by tomorrow morning.  You've read the piece, now have your say. webTitle: England v Germany: Scandal rocks German preparation

fields.headline: Don't mention the civil war to Germany
fields.standfirst:
Big build-up marred by lurid allegations against coach in waiting
More about England v Germany
fields.trailText: Germany's build-up to the crucial Wembley clash has been marred by lurid allegations against their coach in waiting.
fields.body:
As the German players left the Hamburg pitch after a 2-0 win over Greece in their opening World Cup qualifying match, the loudspeakers incongruously blasted out England's Euro 96 anthem, Football's Coming Home.

This was either an indication of a previously uncharted German sense of irony or their national football team are as easily deluded as our own.

The Germans did not play particularly well and their only other match since the disasters of Euro 2000, a 4-0 win over Spain, would have been as impressive as it sounded only if the Spanish had shown any signs of taking it seriously.

There is, however, no doubt that Rudi Völler, a World Cup winner in 1990 and scorer of 47 goals in 90 internationals, had begun to engender a renewed spirit in the German camp after taking over as coach from the unpopular Erich Ribbeck. Until, that is, the internecine warfare that has broken out following the sensational sex and drugs allegations against Christoph Daum, who is due to take over from Völler next June.

State prosecutors in Cologne confirmed last week that they had launched a preliminary investigation into Daum for fraud and embezzlement after a former business associate accused the coach of owing him money from a property deal in Mallorca. That triggered an investigation into Daum's personal life and a Munich newspaper then weighed in with talk of cocaine and prostitutes.

Daum's lawyer dismissed the allegations as absurd and said the accuser, the ex-husband of Daum's girlfriend, had made the allegations only to exonerate himself in a separate fraud investigation.

Whatever the truth of the affair, it has already led Uli Hoeness, the Bayern Munich general manager and a member of the national selection committee that voted for Daum, to suggest that he is no longer the man for the job. And it brought a stinging rebuke from Reiner Calmund, general manager of Bayern's hated rivals Bayer Leverkusen, whom Daum manages. Calmund said: "Hoeness must have Alzheimer's as he voted for Daum. The allegations are infamous, insidious and malicious."

Among the others entering the fray yesterday were Paul Breitner, who called it "the biggest scandal in the history of German football", and Franz Beckenbauer, who demanded an end to the infighting. Even Völler issued a plea for the matter to be dropped until after Saturday's Wembley set-to.

The German Federation is unable to apply damage limitation by cancelling the contract yet to be signed by Daum and appointing Völler since the latter has made it clear that he cannot face the aggravation that would go with it. After the last few days one can understand why.

Even the players appear to have become unsettled, with Germany's Bayern contingent adopting a uniform "no comment" at yesterday's press conference while their Leverkusen counterparts expressed concern for their coach.

The 46-year-old Daum, has long been touted as the messiah of German football, though a reluctant one since he has previously turned down the role of national coach. He also shows signs of being barking mad, once forcing his players to walk over broken glass and, when at VfB Stuttgart, papering the dressing-room wall with banknotes to motivate the players.

Völler is much more in the Kevin Keegan style, a man respected by the players for his own achievements on the field and who believes in inspiring players not by making them walk on glass but by attempting to convince them that they can walk on water.

As with Keegan, the tactical side is not his strength; he had no previous coaching experience. Then again, nor had Beckenbauer before guiding Germany to World Cup success; Völler, like Beckenbauer, is just the sort of inspirational figure Germany needed to lift the players and steady the nation's nerves after the traumas of Euro 2000.

That caused such a collective national angst that Ribbeck had no choice but to resign. While they looked for a new coach, the Germans also set up a task force (thankfully, no relation to the one led by David Mellor) to pick over the bones, appointing Karl-Heinz Rummenigge, another of the national team's favourite sons, as its head.

Despite the two victories since, the debate is still raging across the country, though even Beckenbauer, who has become the arch critic of the German team, laces his criticism with some praise for Völler and his deputy Michael Skibbe, former coach of Dortmund.

Beckenbauer says: "The wins over Spain and Greece didn't fall out of the sky. Völler, Skibbe and Rummenigge have worked hard and in unison. Rudi speaks the players' language, which is important, and they believe what he tells them.

"For decades we believed we were the best and would say 'come on, Brazil, let's play'. Today it is more like 'not yet please, maybe in a few years' time'. The best in the world are 10 years ahead of us and we have been overtaken by France, who started to copy us 20 years ago.

"But, if there is some good to come out of Euro 2000, it is that everyone involved with the national team has woken up to our problems. We had been dozing for years."

Völler, as popular in the dressing room as he is with the fans, has done much to help the healing process of a nation that demands football success. The rebuilding process will take a lot longer, though he has laid one or two impressive foundation stones.

One of them comes in the form of Bayer Leverkusen's Jens Nowotny, whose sweeping skills have apparently brought a bid from Arsenal. He has finally ascended to the role retained for so long by Lothar Matthäus, who at Euro 2000 became the symbol of an ageing, decaying German team.

Völler has also backed his intimate knowledge of Leverkusen players by giving midfield places to Carsten Ramelow and Michael Ballack, who has long been seen as a coming star. Völler has turned to them after failing, seemingly prompted by Daum, to persuade Steffen Effenberg to reverse his international retirement.

Alexander Zickler, the Bayern Munich striker, has also been brought in to replace the retired Ulf Kirsten and freshen up a strike force that still seems to get around the pitch by use of invisible zimmer frames. Though Oliver Bierhoff seems more asthmatic than talismatic these days, he is still regarded as the No1 choice and, after his goal for Milan against Vicenza at the weekend, seems certain to start at Wembley.

Völler's greatest achievement, though, is in charming the best out of Mehmet Scholl, a player who many fans insist can be the saviour of the new Germany and who just as many insist is a waste of space. Think Matt le Tissier.

Scholl was impressive in the hole against the Greeks, linking with midfield and the two strikers and providing a tantalising low cross that a panicking Marinos Ouzounidis turned into his own net by way of a Greek gift.

The second was scored by 20-year-old Sebastien Deisler from Hertha Berlin, the wunderkind of German football who is beginning to come of age. "He is exceptional," says Völler, though it will be interesting to see whether he again starts him on the right side of midfield against England, as he did in Charleroi. Given our frailties at left-back, maybe he will.

Through Völler's success in restoring faith in the side, or perhaps through an abiding German footballing arrogance, they now believe they can win at Wembley. But as the arguments continue to rage between the conflicting power barons of German football, the message behind the dressing-room door will doubtless be: "Don't mention the civil war".

webTitle: England v Germany: Cole takes the hype in his stride

fields.headline: Cole takes the hype in his stride
fields.standfirst:
West Ham's 18-year-old playmaker is ready for the big stage
More about England v Germany
fields.trailText: Confidence and maturity, but not arrogance. Jon Brodkin reports on whether these qualities will see Joe Cole become England's missing link.
fields.body:
Joe Cole looked so relaxed yesterday, strolling around with a stud in his ear and flip-flops on his feet, that it was hard to tell whether he was preparing for beach volleyball or for a possible England debut in a World Cup qualifier.

But then the country's great teenage hope is not short of self-belief. He might talk, as if starstruck, of wanting the shirts of new colleagues such as Paul Scholes and Michael Owen. But he also behaves as if training with his heroes comes as naturally as making a cup of tea.

"I thought I have been ready," the West Ham midfielder said of a call-up which comes after 25 Premiership starts and one England Under-21 appearance. "You could have asked me when I was 13, I would have said I was good enough to play for England, but that's just kids."

Thankfully, the 18-year-old's engaging mix of confidence and innocence stops short of arrogance. He may have described this as "just another step" and admitted he was bitterly disappointed not to have been called up sooner, but he knows he has much to learn from his team-mates here. "I'm looking at why they're such great players," he said. "I want to take bits from their game."

All the same Kevin Keegan's remark that Cole "doesn't seem too fazed by anything" seemed as great an understatement as suggesting Saturday's match against Germany was mildly important.

Cole, though, has grown up with expectation. When he signed a professional contract on the pitch at Upton Park the Tannoy man announced: "You can tell your grandchildren you were there when Joe Cole signed for West Ham."

Impressively, Cole has lived up to the hype, overcome a broken leg sustained last April and returned stronger. A year ago he was training with England's under-18s. Now he is being spoken of as the missing link: a player who can change a match with a spark of brilliance, as his idol Paul Gascoigne used to.

"Quite honestly we haven't got 10 players in that hotel behind us who can do that," Keegan said. "That's why he finds himself in this postition so quickly. He does bring something different to the table.

"When you've got a talent like his you've got to find a way of accommodating that. I don't think he's a liability. Some players of his ilk can turn a game for you but also cost you a game. The Joe Cole I've seen this season has worked very hard for the team. Maybe it's a little bit quick to be putting him at this level but I think he will take it in his stride."

Cole is unlikely to start against Germany but his uninhibited skill is sure to be given a chance before long. Now a regular with his club, he turned the negative of his broken leg into a positive by spending more time in the gym.

"The main reason I am playing a bit better this year," Cole said, "is because I've been in the gym working on my strength, which is just as important as technique."

Not that he is short of the latter. His darting runs and astute passes were critical in hauling West Ham back from 2-0 down to draw with Manchester United this season. The backheel he produced within minutes of his league debut in 1998-99 at Old Trafford suggests he is not easily inhibited. "But it's never to show off," he insisted. "It's always with scoring a goal in mind."

Moreover, on those young shoulders is an old head. Despite paying homage to Gascoigne and his club-mate Paolo di Canio, Cole has not picked up their disciplinary traits. "You're only going to get booked if you shout at referees and throw your arms about," he said. "You might not see it but I am aggressive and I do have a will to win." As England should soon find out.
